HEADLINE: A U.S. Agency, Once Powerful, Is Dead at 108

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 29

 BODY:
There was a time, long forgotten in this city, when few arms of Government instilled more fear, hatred or anger than the Interstate Commerce Commission.
The robber barons of the railroad industry, James P. Morgan and James J. Hill, fumed against its interference in their affairs. Teddy Roosevelt spent much of his first term fighting to expand its once-vast authority, and Oliver Wendell Holmes Jr. and his brethren argued endlessly over the scope of the I.C.C.'s power to dictate to the states. When the lawyers who argued in front of the I.C.C. held a convention in Washington in 1930, Herbert Hoover invited them over to the White House for a picnic on the South Lawn. 
 For years those glory days have been just echoes in the empty hallways of the commission's ornate headquarters. And with the arrival of the new year, something happens to the country's oldest regulatory agency that almost never happens in Washington. It dies at the age of 108.
It was a slow and painful death. Deregulation a decade and a half ago stripped the I.C.C. of most of its powers to set transportation rates, except in the rare case when a single railroad or trucking firm monopolizes a route. But until just days ago, clerks were still wheeling tons of paper past the I.C.C.'s towering columns on Constitution Avenue and into its moldy Tariff Examination Room -- endless, computer-generated lists of the charges for taking sugar or wool or auto parts between, say, Seattle and Boston. Almost every page was stuffed, unread, into filing cabinets.
Nonetheless, the commission survived innumerable assassination attempts. Richard Nixon tried to merge the I.C.C. out of existence in 1970. A decade ago, after the deregulation of American transportation was well under way, Ronald Reagan tried to eliminate its budget. Eventually he gave up. Sheer inertia, bureaucratic guile and lobbying by companies that thought twice about what life would be like in a completely competitive marketplace resulted in reprieve after reprieve. The commission shrank without disappearing: When the last wave of layoffs hit a few weeks ago it was reduced to 300 job-seeking souls, from a peak of 2,400 employees in the early 1960's.
President Clinton signed the commission's death warrant on Friday night, the White House said.
Now, there is only one ghostlike remnant of the I.C.C. About 190 employees, including three remaining commissioners, will be transferred to the Transportation Department, which is taking over a few functions that Congress still views as essential. Chief among them is protecting workers whose jobs are being wiped out by the merger fever sweeping the railroad industry. The Transportation Department also acquires the power to approve or disapprove rail mergers. But the organization that pioneered Government regulation -- busting trusts, issuing safety regulations and reluctantly desegregating trains and buses that moved across state lines -- will be reduced to a small office within a vast Cabinet department.
"It makes you realize Washington isn't a very sentimental place," said Gail C. McDonald, the last chairwoman of the commission, who had the foresight to find another job earlier this year -- as head of the St. Lawrence Seaway Development Corporation -- when it became clear that the Clinton Administration had finally bought the I.C.C. a one-way ticket to nowhere. Mrs. McDonald briefly put up a fight to "save this grand old place, to make it contemporary." But she gave up when she discovered "there was just a hunger in Washington to just get rid of something."
In fact, the Republican majority in Congress had its eye on much bigger game this year. It had hoped to kill off the Commerce Department, the Energy Department and the Education Department, but failed. And while both the Clinton Administration and the Republicans are claiming credit for the I.C.C.'s demise, the savings are chiefly symbolic: The commission's budget was a mere $40 million last year, a rounding error by the standards of the current battle to balance the budget.
Even before the I.C.C. issued its last order a few days before Christmas -- a wry permit for Santa Claus to operate "as a common carrier by two-runner sleigh" as long as he "renders reasonably continuous and adequate service to the public" -- other bureaucrats were moving into the commission's offices, mostly from the Internal Revenue Service across the street.
No one seems to know what the I.R.S. plans to do with the bronze busts that sit under the building's rotunda, commemorating once-famed regulators like Judge Thomas McIntyre Cooley, the first I.C.C. chairman, who was hailed by The New York Times a century ago as "the father of the Interstate Commerce Bill" of 1887. The other day Judge Cooley's regulatory descendants looked like lost souls, dumping yellowed binders of shipping tariffs and long-forgotten administrative-law decisions into huge bins.
"It's been sad because people here were trying to get a big job done," Lillian A. Bateman, a 22-year employee, said the other afternoon as she emptied her office on the third floor. "I don't know why we were such a target, because we were small even when we were large."
The I.C.C.'s critics suggest it is responsible for its own demise. The commission once heard testimony that took up 53,000 pages to transcribe before deciding the proper rates to set for shipping grain. It took 11 years to come to a decision on a railroad merger. That example was cited time and again by those who wanted to kill off the commission, even though the process has been radically streamlined in recent years.
When the I.C.C. began, its real purpose was to break up huge concentrations of wealth in the hands of the country's railroad magnates. Protecting consumers or workers was almost an afterthought. But starting at the turn of the century its powers expanded dramatically: It regulated the burgeoning telephone industry until the creation of the Federal Communications Commission, and it gained authority over trucks, buses, and virtually anything else that moved across state lines. Until the commission's dissolution, consumer complaints about moving companies, for example, had to go through the I.C.C.
But by the 1960's critics began to charge that the commission was actually anti-consumer, keeping prices artificially high and becoming far too close to the industry it was supposed to regulate. There were corruption charges, and in the end it was the pro-consumer movement that pressed for deregulation and doomed the agency.
But for all their complaints about intrusive Government regulation, many railroad and trucking companies wanted to keep the commission alive. Submitting all those rate notifications was burdensome, but it assured that competitors would get early warning of price changes, which stabilized prices. Railroads and trucking companies learned how to manipulate the commission to slow deregulation, and the price-cutting that resulted from free competition. The American Trucking Association once maintained a cozy office inside the commission's headquarters, from which it coordinated a campaign to make sure the I.C.C. did not carry out its deregulatory mandate too quickly.
The arguments over the pace of deregulation became so bitter that in the 1980's the commissioners made no secret of the fact that they detested one another. They refused to meet in the same room, and issued decisions by memo.
One commissioner got himself on front pages around the country in 1982 by declaring that bribes in the trucking business were just "discounts" or "rebates," and declaring that there was no reason a convicted felon could not operate a trucking firm from prison.
In the end, even the defenders of the I.C.C. -- who included Vice President Al Gore when he was a Senator -- finally abandoned it. That left it vulnerable to Republicans who viewed it as a symbol of everything that is bloated in the Federal Government. "This is the dinosaur that wouldn't die," Representative John Kasich, the Ohio Republican who has led the balanced-budget charge, said not long ago.
But the dinosaurs went extinct with more style. In the 20's and 30's the I.C.C. celebrated its anniversaries in Washington's most lavish banquet halls, selling tickets to lawyers and others among its supplicants.
This weekend there will be no banquet. Instead, a "Government closure team" will dispose of miles of container reports, rate filings and safety rulings, some dating to Grover Cleveland's Administration.
One official in the I.C.C.'s Office of Economic and Environmental Analysis left a suggestion about what to do with it all: He pasted a photograph of nuclear devastation on the door of his abandoned office, under the caption: "The I.C.C. -- 1/1/96."

HEADLINE: 2 SIDES IN SENATE DISAGREE ON PLAN TO END FURLOUGHS

BYLINE: By JERRY GRAY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 31

 BODY:
A last-ditch effort to bring 260,000 furloughed Federal employees back to work just after New Year's Day failed today when Republicans and Democrats in the Senate rejected back-and-forth proposals from each other.
Senator Bob Dole, the Republican majority leader, and Senator Tom Daschle, leader of the Democratic minority, could not agree on a temporary plan passed by the House on Saturday that would have allowed Federal employees to work without pay until a budget agreement was reached. They said they would resume negotiations when the Senate reconvened on Tuesday. 
"We need to end the impasse," Mr. Dole said from the Senate floor. "It's gotten to the point where it's a little ridiculous, as far as this Senator is concerned, so we are going to keep trying."
The Democrats continued to reject the limits the House had voted to impose on Senate debate as a condition for sending Federal employees back to work, and the Republicans rejected attempts to replace their plan with a temporary spending resolution that would allow all Government functions to resume -- without conditions -- until a budget accord was reached.
"On Tuesday, if we can't do anything else," Mr. Dole said, "we may pass whatever it takes on the Senate side."
Mr. Dole and Mr. Daschle came to the Senate floor about an hour after they left budget talks at the White House. Republicans and Democrats, including President Clinton, have spent the last three days negotiating the terms of a plan to balance the Federal budget by 2002.
Each side left today's meeting at the White House saying progress had been made, although neither would provide any details. Senior aides have said that the last three days of talks have been taken up with the two sides laying out their positions on issues like welfare, Social Security and Medicare but that no decisions have been made.
The White House spokesman, Michael D. McCurry, said that when negotiations resumed on Tuesday the political leaders would open discussions on "the trade-offs" on those issues. "The President is ready to discuss the issues in good faith," Mr. McCurry said.
Mr. Clinton, Mr. Dole and Speaker Newt Gingrich spent three hours today in talks at the White House, the shortest negotiating session of the three days. Afterward, each of them left Washington, despite the growing public frustration over the budget impasse, which has left thousands of Federal employees in limbo. This is the second partial Government shutdown in as many months.
President Clinton is spending New Year's Eve in Hilton Head, S.C., where he will attend the annual Renaissance Weekend, a private gathering at the resort. Participants discuss public policy, socialize and play golf.
Mr. Dole was off to New Hampshire for a series of political events. And Mr. Gingrich was bound for his home in Georgia and a private family gathering for the New Year.
The last act of 1995 in the budget drama was left to Mr. Dole and Mr. Daschle, as each tried and failed in midafternoon to leave Washington with at least an agreement that the House could consider on Wednesday to bring back the Federal employees. During today's Senate debate, both leaders said they wanted an agreement, and both directly or indirectly blamed the House for the impasse.
"I believe the White House -- and I certainly believe the Democratic leader, Senator Daschle -- would like to see this thing ended and Government employees go back to work and get paid," Mr. Dole said, without mentioning his Republican colleagues in the House. "That's not going to happen, unfortunately, today. So it's not going to be a happy New Year."
Mr. Daschle has blamed Mr. Gingrich and other Republican conservatives in the House for the stalemate over putting furloughed workers back on the job. He said on Saturday that "the House wants confrontation, not solutions." Today, he pointedly avoided blaming Mr. Dole.
"I know that the distinguished majority leader wants an agreement as much as I do," Mr. Daschle said. "And I don't hold him personally responsible for the fact that we're not able to overcome this impasse."
Mr. Dole, a candidate for the Republican Presidential nomination, has taken the lead in the past week in trying to find a political solution to put Federal workers back to work. That effort has put him between the political pincers of Mr. Gingrich and other Republican conservatives in the House, who want to continue to use the crisis as political leverage against Mr. Clinton, and Senator Phil Gramm, the Texas Republican who is also a candidate for the Republican Presidential nomination.
Mr. Gramm said today on the ABC News program "This Week" that the partial shutdown demonstrated that the Government could get along with far fewer workers.
"Have you missed the Government?" he asked.
But Mr. Dole, standing on the floor of the Senate this afternoon, said, "I don't share the view of some of my colleagues that we ought to have a partial shutdown of the Government and that people shouldn't be paid."
The shutdown has clouded any bit of cheery news that might have come from the White House talks in the last few days. Not only has it affected 760,000 Federal employees who are contending with delayed paychecks -- and about a third of them are furloughed -- but it has also disrupted public services, from issuing passports to providing new or replacement Social Security cards or processing mortgage applications.
The current shutdown of parts of the Federal Government began on Dec. 15, when a temporary spending bill expired. President Clinton and Congressional Democrats asked for another temporary spending bill, or continuing resolution, but the Republican majority in Congress refused. The Republicans have been trying to use the Government shutdown as political leverage to force Mr. Clinton to agree to a balanced budget in seven years on their terms.
In the last two weeks, there have been about a dozen attempts by Democrats and Republicans to fashion a temporary plan that would bring workers back to their jobs, but each has gone down in the crossfire of partisan politics.
Most of the debate over the issue in recent days has come over Republican attempts to put Federal employees back to work without pay until a budget deal is struck with the White House. Although the proposal included a legal guarantee that the furloughed Federal workers would receive back pay, it would not reopen the parts of the Government that are shut down and it would not allow the departments without 1996 budgets to spend money.
Mr. Dole offered that proposal on Dec. 22 in the Senate, and it was approved on a unanimous voice vote. But in the House, where the measure was approved on a voice vote on Dec. 30, Republicans added a provision to limit the debate over the budget deal that is finally reached to 10 hours. That idea immediately became a sticking point for Senate Democrats.
Today's attempt to break the impasse reflected how narrow the focus of the debate had become in the last hours of this year. It began with Mr. Dole offering a modified version of the Republican plan that would allow 12 hours of debate on the eventual budget. In a bid to woo support from the Democrats, Mr. Dole included two provisions requested by the White House counsel: that returning Federal workers be allowed to receive unemployment benefits, which would be repaid when their salaries were reinstated, and that the furlough would not affect workers' vacations.
Mr. Dole sought unanimous support from the Senate, but Mr. Daschle called the proposal "a sham" and "a facade," and he refused to give his consent.
"The effect of this unanimous-consent agreement is that Federal workers will be asked to show up in their offices and not be given the authority to do virtually anything," Mr. Daschle said. "What this allows them to do is to go to their offices and sit on their hands and do nothing. They can't get into their truck because that uses gas. They can't make a long distance phone call because that incurs expense.
"This does not work," he said.
Mr. Daschle then proposed another continuing resolution, an idea that Mr. Dole quickly squashed.
The Democratic leader then tried to win passage of Mr. Dole's original proposal of Dec. 22 -- this time, Mr. Dole objected.
Mr. Daschle's third and final attempt of the day was to offer a substitute amendment to the bill passed by the House. His amendment would call for the debate on the budget to be truncated only if the agreement met a shopping list of conditions: if it protected spending for Medicare and Medicaid, did not raise taxes on working Americans and did not cut money for education or the enforcement of environmental laws and if any tax deduction in the budget agreement went only to Americans making less than $100,000.
That proposal was also rejected.

HEADLINE: Forbes's Silver Bullet for the Nation's Malaise

SERIES: THE CONTENDERS -- Seventh article of a series.

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH KOLBERT 

DATELINE: COUNCIL BLUFFS, Iowa

 BODY:
In the back room of the restaurant 1892, a few dozen Iowa Republicans have gathered over identical entrees to listen to Steve Forbes. The invitation to the noontime event had suggested a $10 donation, presumably to cover the cost of the broiled chicken sandwich served with potato chips and iced tea. But the campaign staff has not pressed for a contribution, and almost no one in the audience, it seems, has paid.
Who says there's no free lunch? 
 Mr. Forbes, an heir to the famous publishing fortune, is running for President on a platform that promises virtually every American a tax cut without increasing the Federal deficit or reducing services. He proposes a flat tax on income which, he says, will spur so much economic growth that the drop in tax revenues will actually turn into a gain.
In the three months since he announced his candidacy, Mr. Forbes has already spent more than $7 million of his own money pushing his version of the flat tax and the effortless wealth he says it will generate. In that time he has confounded political odds makers and exasperated his opponents.
In polls, he has passed several candidates who have been campaigning for the Presidency for years, and recent surveys in Iowa and New Hampshire show him in second place.
It is, to be sure, a distant second to Senator Bob Dole; still, he is the only other candidate whose support registers in double digits.
Mr. Forbes, who has never before run for office, attributes his popularity to a message he calls "pro-growth, pro-hope, pro-opportunity."
"I think what it shows is the power of the message," he said during a trip on a chartered jet from Des Moines to Council Bluffs. "It also shows that people realize the other candidates don't have the message."
But others, and particularly his competitors, trace Mr. Forbes's rise directly to the personal fortune he is lavishing on his campaign.
Most of the millions Mr. Forbes has spent so far have gone to television advertising, and much of that to attack ads. And unlike the other candidates, who are taking Federal matching funds, Mr. Forbes is subject to no state-by-state limits on his spending. This gives him a special advantage in crucial states like Iowa and New Hampshire, with small populations that keep spending limits low.
A few weeks ago candidates like Lamar Alexander and Phil Gramm, desperately trying to get a clear shot at Mr. Dole, were ignoring Mr. Forbes. Now, they are openly challenging him and, in the process, revealing their frustration.
"Nobody wants to get chased down the street by a mad billionaire with a squash racquet," said Mr. Gramm's media adviser, Alex Castellanos.
Mr. Forbes, 48, is president of Forbes Inc. and is on leave from his job as editor of Forbes magazine, which was founded by his grandfather. He is the eldest son of the late Malcolm Forbes, the flamboyant publishing magnate perhaps most widely remembered for riding a motorcycle and playing escort to Elizabeth Taylor.
Yet, the younger Forbes offers hardly a glimmer of his father's elan. He is somber to the point of being soporific and must struggle his way to the occasional joke.
 
No Burning Ambition To Become President
Mr. Forbes insists that he has no burning ambition to be President and says he would not be in the race if another Republican candidate had come forward preaching confidence in the future and in Reaganomics. "I had no intention of doing it until it became apparent that there was a void in the Republican field this year," he said.
His candidacy is built around his economic vision. The country, he says, is poised for growth of historic proportions, if only the Federal tax code would get out of its way. "No one outside of Washington could have devised something more complex, more incomprehensible, more monstrous, more anti-growth, more anti-family than the tax code we have today," he told a crowd of about 150 supporters recently in Sioux City.
The flat tax, Mr. Forbes says, is the key to liberating the nation's economic potential. His version of the tax, similar to that proposed by Representative Dick Armey of Texas, the House majority leader, would, in essence, eliminate taxes on investment income. There would be no tax on interest, no tax on capital gains, no tax on inheritances and no tax on pensions -- just a 17 percent flat tax on income that would replace the graduated tax schedule, which now has a maximum rate of 39.6 percent. Exemptions would also be expanded to help those with lower incomes. A family of four whose income was $36,000 or less, for example, would pay no taxes at all. At the same time, there would be no deductions for home mortgage interest or for state and local taxes, and no earned income tax credit.
If enacted, the flat tax would represent a huge tax cut for the wealthiest Americans and, Mr. Forbes asserts, a sizable tax cut for almost everyone else. Mr. Forbes does not propose raising other sorts of fees or taxes to make up for the loss in revenue. Instead he invokes the logic of supply-side economics: cuts in the tax rate would lead to stunning growth in the economy that would, in turn, lead to increased tax collections.
"Every time in America that we've reduced tax rates, Government revenues have gone up," he said.
But many economists, including many conservative economists, are skeptical of this Alice-in-Wonderland optimism, and they note that when supply-side thinking was put into practice during the Reagan Presidency, revenues declined and staggering deficits were produced. Mr. Forbes pushes such objections aside by maintaining that the deficits of the Reagan years were the result not of tax cuts but a Congressional spending spree.
"The problem with the 1980's was that Washington spent the money, and then some," he said.
Along with the flat tax, Mr. Forbes calls for a return to something like the gold standard, which would tie the value of the dollar to a fixed measure. Aides say he does not actually advocate bringing back the gold standard -- something almost no economist would support -- but is simply advocating a policy similar to the anti-inflationary program the Federal Reserve has in recent years pursued. Nevertheless, Mr. Forbes maintains that his policy, unlike the Federal Reserve's, would bring mortgage rates down to 4.5 percent.
Mr. Forbes devotes much less attention to other issues, touching on them only briefly in his speeches. He favors privatizing part of the Social Security system, establishing term limits for members of Congress and providing school vouchers. He opposes affirmative action.
On abortion, an issue he only mentions when pressed, Mr. Forbes says that he wants "to help create an environment where abortions disappear in America." He does not advocate laws that would make abortion illegal, saying that what is needed is for the country to experience "a change of heart."
But Mr. Forbes fends off criticism that he is essentially a one-issue candidate, insisting that his detractors have missed the point of his flat-tax campaign. "Contrary to what some people would have you believe," he told the crowd in Sioux City, "there really is no difference between values and economics. They're one and the same."
 
First on the Offense In Negative Ads
Though it may seem incongruous for someone whose childhood home has a name -- Timberfield -- Mr. Forbes is running as an insurgent. He is, he often insists, an outsider.
But not too much of one. In his standard stump speech, Mr. Forbes talks about his many meetings with world leaders, including Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany. He often invokes his political experience as chairman of the Board for International Broadcasting, which oversees Radio Free Europe, and likes to say that from his travels he has amassed "more foreign experience than all of my opponents put together." More specifically, he has criticized President Clinton's stand on Bosnia.
In his public remarks, Mr. Forbes mentions his opponents only in passing. But in his commercials, he takes aim at them directly. He was the first candidate in the race to run negative commercials, and his media campaign has been devoted at least as much to attacking Mr. Dole and Mr. Gramm as it has been to touting his own ideas.
For example, one recent Forbes commercial broadcast in New Hampshire accuses Mr. Gramm of engineering a $100 billion tax increase as part of the 1990 budget. That ad prompted Mr. Gramm to broadcast a reply saying "Forbes's money talks, but it's not telling the truth." The Forbes campaign then responded with another ad insisting that the original commercial was accurate.
"In typical Washington fashion, they don't want people to know their record," Mr. Forbes said when asked about the exchange. (Senator Gramm was part of the team that negotiated the 1990 budget package; he later voted against the deal, however, and says he did not support it in its final form.)
 
A Clear Strategy With Obscure Goals
Mr. Forbes's advertising strategy is unusual for someone so little known. Generally, candidates try to establish their own credentials before starting to attack their opponents, and even some of Mr. Forbes's allies worry privately that the approach is flawed. But at least for now, it appears to be having the desired impact.
Here in Iowa, Mr. Forbes has already spent more than $1 million on radio and television advertising -- the legal limit for the other candidates -- and appears to be well on his way to doubling that. Because Iowa is a caucus state, where residents have to devote an entire evening to register a vote, conventional wisdom holds that advertising is not enough and that organization is crucial. But in a recent Des Moines Register poll of likely caucus goers, Mr. Forbes, who has almost no organization in the state, came out ahead of every other candidate except Mr. Dole.
"He's rewriting the Presidential rules," said Sal Russo, a Republican political consultant who has conducted focus groups for Mr. Forbes but is not working on his campaign. Mr. Forbes, Mr. Russo added, is demonstrating that a candidate can do "credibly" in Iowa without spending an inordinate amount of time there.
Mr. Forbes insists, though, that he is not in the race to do credibly, or to advance the supply-side cause, but to get the nomination. He does not, however, sound convincing when he says this.
Perhaps the most surprising thing about Mr. Forbes, after his popularity, is that he still cannot, or at least will not, explain how his strategy will lead to the nomination. "Expectations haven't really started yet," was all he would say when pressed to talk about what kind of showing he hoped to make in Iowa and New Hampshire.
His campaign manager, William Dal Col, predicted Mr. Forbes would do "exceptionally well" in Delaware, which holds its primary on Feb. 24, four days after New Hampshire, and where most of the candidates have not filed. He also forecast a strong showing in Arizona, which holds its primary on Feb. 27 and where the Forbes campaign appears to be breaking spending records. But he, too, demurred when asked where and how Mr. Forbes planned to win. "The other campaigns can predict their victories," he said. "I'll simply predict that we expect to do well."
Aides to his rivals say the reason the Forbes camp is not offering an explanation of how his strategy will work is because there is none. In the end, they maintain, Republican primary voters simply will not nominate for President a man who has never held public office.
"Money can buy you love," said Mr. Castellanos, Mr. Gramm's adviser. "But it can't buy you the Presidency."
 
The Contenders
 
TUESDAY -- Senator Bob Dole of Kansas.
 
WEDNESDAY -- Senator Phil Gramm of Texas.
 
THURSDAY -- Senator Richard G. Lugar of Indiana.
 
FRIDAY -- Former Governor Lamar Alexander of Tennessee.
 
SATURDAY -- Representative Robert K. Dornan, Alan L. Keyes and Morry Taylor.
 
YESTERDAY -- Patrick J. Buchanan.
 
TODAY -- Steve Forbes.

HEADLINE: A Dial Tone All the Same

BYLINE: By MARK LANDLER 

 BODY:
Lawmakers and journalists like to describe the impending deregulation of the nation's telecommunications industry as revolutionary, sweeping, even historic. That may be true for telecommunications companies. But for most Americans, life immediately after deregulation will not seem much different than life before it.
At the outset, before the din of telemarketing starts, it may actually be a bit quieter. The titans of the telephone business -- the local and long-distance carriers -- will call off their lobbyists and cease the chorus of advertisements that have championed one position and denigrated others. 
 "A hush is going to come over the industry for about a year and a half," said Daniel Reingold, a telecommunications analyst at Merrill Lynch & Company.
Before anything can happen, of course, the legislation has to become law. That is still generally expected to happen early this year, although Senator Bob Dole, the Republican majority leader, criticized some of the provisions in the bill last week, which could delay passage.
If and when the legislation does take effect, Mr. Reingold and other experts said, state regulators and the Federal Communications Commission will spend most of this next year just setting new ground rules for the game.
"Ironically, at least in the short term, deregulation probably means more regulation," said David Roddy, chief telecommunications economist at the accounting and consulting firm Deloitte & Touche.
To say that the regulators face some knotty issues is an understatement. The changes envisioned in the bill would affect virtually every corner of the industry. Among other things, it would throw open the local and long-distance telephone markets to competition from many directions: regional Bell operating companies, long-distance carriers, even cable-television companies.
But in doing so, it would raise important questions: How much competition should a Bell company face in its monopoly local market before it is allowed to compete in long distance? How much should a local phone company charge a long-distance carrier to connect its local calls? And how should new local competitors, like the long-distance carriers or cable companies, share in the burden of providing residential phone service to poor customers?
It will fall to the F.C.C. and the state public service commissions to adjudicate most of these issues. And given the billions of dollars riding on their decisions, local and long-distance companies are almost certain to file a flurry of grievances and lawsuits.
"The bill is a significant step," said Peter Huber, a legal scholar who studied the state of competition in the telecommunications industry for the Justice Department in 1986. "But does it clear away all the underbrush? No, it doesn't."
Once the underbrush is finally cleared, analysts and communications executives said, the industry was likely to embark on a substantial transformation. Reports abound that Nynex and Bell Atlantic are exploring a merger, which would create the nation's second-largest telephone company. Or, the companies may create a joint venture to get into the long-distance phone business.
Analysts foresee a range of other possible combinations, including mergers of other Baby Bells, a merger of a Bell company with a long-distance provider like MCI Communications, an alliance between a local phone company and an overseas carrier, or a merger of a Bell company and a cable TV concern.
In all these cases, the goal for companies is to bulk up for a world of freewheeling competition. "Economies of scale make a lot of sense for phone companies," said William Bane, a telecommunications consultant at Mercer Management Consulting in Washington.
But Mr. Bane said that many phone companies could achieve their goal of offering customers a package of services without buying up or merging with the nearest competitor. Bell companies can offer long-distance service quite easily once the regulatory obstacles are removed by the states in their regions. Outside their regions, they can lease capacity on the networks owned by long-distance carriers like AT&T, MCI or Sprint.
For the long-distance carriers, the outlook is a bit cloudier. Lacking the Bell companies' direct physical connections to local customers, long-distance companies intending to compete with the Bells would need to forge ties with cable companies or invest in wireless communications to leap the critical gap between their networks and the customer's home phone.
For that reason, Wall Street analysts like Mr. Reingold are now far more chary about the stock performance of long-distance companies, while they are warming up to the prospects of the Baby Bells.
Adding to their enthusiasm for the Bells, many analysts also believe that the seven regional companies will throttle back on their ambitious and costly expansion into television to concentrate on the long-distance market.
Bell Atlantic recently began testing a telephone system that delivers video programming to 200 customers in Toms River, N.J. But the company's deployment of the system elsewhere in its six-state region has been delayed by regulatory and technological hurdles.
Bell Atlantic is continuing to pour money into Tele-TV, the television joint venture it started with Nynex and the Pacific Telesis Group. But with "switched digital video," Bell Atlantic's network technology of choice, developing more slowly than the company expected, Tele-TV has opted for wireless cable as an interim technology to transmit its programs.
Whoever ends up delivering the services to consumers, analysts and executives are convinced that open competition will lead to lower prices and more choice. In particular, analysts said, local companies will be in a position to offer cut-rate prices for long-distance service because they will be able to lease capacity from long-distance carriers at very favorable rates.
Consumers will probably have to pay for these savings by withstanding a blitz of advertising as the big players all vie to provide their local and long-distance service. "A great business in 1996 will be an advertising agency that specializes in telecommunications ads," Mr. Roddy said.
Some consumer advocates worry that the supposed savings may never materialize for many consumers.
For one thing, the most robust competition is likely to be confined to large metropolitan areas where the concentrations of people and money make it potentially lucrative enough to fight a price war.
Moreover, some consumer groups and long-distance executives contend that the pending legislation will allow the regional Bell companies into long-distance without breaking their monopolistic grip on local service.
"The way Congress wants to deregulate the industry would give the Bells a huge head start," said Bradley Stillman, the director of telecommunications policy at the Consumer Federation of America.

HEADLINE: When Pointing and Clicking Fails to Click;
More and More Questions, and Employees, at Computer Help Services

SERIES: @ Work -- Guides to Techology's Maze

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR 

DATELINE: NOVATO, Calif.

 BODY:
Their pay is modest, their labors are unheralded, and even their bosses admit that the job is grueling. Each second of their work is electronically monitored; the corporate Big Brother is always watching. So are these people seething with working-class resentment? Hardly. "This is the entry-level job of the 90's," explained Colleen Dolan, a 43-year-old former kindergarten teacher, who joined Broderbund Software Inc. last year. "This is where the jobs are."
Unlikely as it seems, the computer help-desk job is one of the fastest-growing occupations in America's high-technology economy. These workers are voices at the end of phone lines at hardware and software companies and at specialist technical-support firms. They try to walk frazzled users of personal computers through the confusing labyrinth of "drivers," "extensions" and "win.ini" and "config.sys" commands often required to stir a frozen children's game or a desktop publishing program back to life. 
 This is the busiest time of the year on computer help desks around the country. The new computers and software people received as Christmas presents are unwrappped, turned on, loaded up and . . . oops.
The ads rapturously proclaim how easy computer technology is to use these days: Simply point and click, and off you go, effortlessly, through a wondrous new world of information, entertainment and empowerment. The reality, though, is that using a PC still bears a certain similarity to driving a car in the early days of the automobile -- it helps to be a self-taught mechanic, able to fix the machine, when it inevitably breaks down.
Most people do not have those computer skills. With PC sales to households growing at twice the rate of the business market, more and more customers are first-time computer users, who need the most help. Americans will make an estimated 200 million calls to help desks in 1996, up from 120 million four years ago. The average length of a call has increased to 13 minutes from 8, according to Dataquest Inc., a research firm. At an estimated cost of $1.50 a minute to the company, calls to help desks amount to a $3.9 billion annual expense for the personal computer business. Companies often charge for some support services, but those revenues are a fraction of the help-desk costs.
Desktop software companies, like Microsoft and Broderbund, receive the most customer calls for help. So they have spent the most on technical support -- the industry's term -- and have added the most to their help staffs. In 1989, 1 of every 12 employees in PC software companies was in technical support. Today, that ratio is 1 in 6, according to Dataquest.
At the Microsoft Corporation, for example, 3,400 people -- 1 in 5 workers -- are now in technical support. The 1995 price tag for the work: $600 million.
"Every software company is struggling with this growing cost," said Deborah Willingham, vice president of support for Microsoft. "It's an essential service for customers, but we've got to stop it from becoming a runaway spending machine."
To cope with the flood of calls and rising costs, software companies are trying just about everything, from installing sophisticated data base and diagnostic software to lift the productivity of help-desk workers to setting up sites on the Internet's World Wide Web so PC users can help themselves. In doing so, they are elevating the corporate status of long-neglected customer-support operations.
"The support people used to be the grunts of software companies," said Kurt Johnson, an analyst for the International Data Corporation, a research firm. "But now, the companies recognize these people are crucial. Support can make or break a company."
Yet for all the new technology and changed priorities, life on the computer help desk remains largely a one-to-one affair, a conversation between a worker and an anguished consumer seeking help. In that sense, the help-desk worker is like the radio talk-show host or the newspaper advice columnist, inviting familiarity between strangers who share problems and personal asides.
Here at Broderbund's offices in Marin County, about 30 miles north of San Francisco, the job finds its purest expression: helping the public rather than more sophisticated business customers. Broderbund's titles -- Myst, Where in the World is Carmen Sandiego?, Print Shop Deluxe, Kid Pix Studio, Math Workshop and others -- are marketed to home computer users.
Last Wednesday at 9 A.M., three hours after the help desk's starting time, Mason Woodbury, a Broderbund vice president, looked at a computer screen and found the results encouraging. Seventy-one people on the phones, 56 calls waiting, and callers waiting 8 minutes or so to talk to someone. Eight minutes is nearly three times the wait in normal periods, but, Mr. Woodbury said, "it's not bad for this time of year."
Broderbund, Mr. Woodbury said, has all the state-of-the-art help-desk tools. It uses sophisticated diagnostic software. It has sites for on-line help on America Online, Compuserve and the Microsoft Network. It has its own electronic bulletin board, and in October it opened its own site on the World Wide Web.
But the on-line alternatives to phone calls are useful mainly as supplementary tools, Mr. Woodbury said. "Our focus is still on dealing with people over the phone one-to-one and improving the quality of that communication," he said.
Toward that end, Mr. Woodbury has tried to change the culture of Broderbund's help desk since he joined the company four years ago. He has done that mainly by changing the people, which was easy for two reasons: He added staff members quickly, and an employee's average stay on a help desk is just a couple of years.
Traditionally, he explained, help desks were called "technical support" because they were staffed by technical people. Too often, he said, the technicians did not like talking to people and believed that because they understood computers, everyone else should, too. Calling a help desk was regarded as a sign of failure, if not inferiority.
Mr. Woodbury mocked the old-style help-desk culture, saying to an imagined caller: "What? You don't know what a clean-boot disk is?"
To an imagined colleague, he added: "Hey Frank, we've got another moron on the line over here."
These days, Mr. Woodbury explained, his ideal help-desk candidate is a former teacher, someone who likes people and wants to get into the computer business, who is enthusiastic about PC's but not really a computer person.
Someone like Colleen Dolan, the former kindergarten teacher. Ms. Dolan said that for 10 years she was "a stay-at-home mom," raising her two daughters, Chelsea, who is now 12, and Sabrina, 8. But a few years ago, Ms. Dolan, a divorced mother, refreshed her teaching credentials and looked for teaching jobs, but found work in Marin County only as a substitute teacher. Needing steady work, she showed up at Broderbund's doorstep in August 1994. She was familiar with its children's and educational software, and she had an Apple Macintosh computer at home in nearby Fairfax, Calif.
"But I had no computer experience whatsoever," she said. "I was surprised that they hired me."
Broderbund help-desk representatives, like Ms. Dolan, handle 40 to 70 calls a day, depending on the length of the calls. They labor at standard-issue work stations with beige partitions, tethered to telephone headsets and their personal computers.
They make $20,000 to $29,000 a year and generally see the job as a steppingstone rather than a dead end. They view the help desk as a one- to three-year commitment on the way to jobs in marketing, product development or other areas, with higher salaries, stock options and flexible working hours. And it happens; last week, three Broderbund help-desk workers moved on to other departments.
Ms. Dolan wants to work in the Broderbund department that sells educational software to schools. But that is the future, and at 11:20 A.M. last Wednesday, Howard from Gainesville, Fla., was on the line with a problem. He was unable to run his Print Shop program, which is used to design greeting cards, newsletters, posters and other home printing projects.
After Ms. Dolan asked Howard a few questions about his PC's horsepower and what he had on his screen, it seemed evident that he was running too many programs at once, hogging the temporary memory, or RAM, needed to get the Print Shop program going. So Ms. Dolan guided him through shutting down some of his other programs.
Eventually, Howard shut them down and double-clicked with his mouse on Print Shop. Was it running? "Oh yes, yes, thank you."
Broderbund gives its help-desk employees guidelines: Speak English instead of computer jargon, empathize with the customers, offer solutions and never say, "I don't know." But the style of help-desk patter varies from individual to individual. Ms. Dolan disarms ruffled callers with extra helpings of courtesy, and fills gaps in the conversation with banter.
"It's teaching," Ms. Dolan explained later. "I'm teaching all day long. It's a lot like teaching kindergarten. It's basic information and you have to be kind."
There are new college graduates on the Broderbund help desk, but a surprising number of the workers are people seeking new starts in life, who gravitate to the high-technology economy, like Ms. Dolan or Drew Coughlin.
After graduating from Penn State University, Mr. Coughlin, who grew up in a small town (Tidioute, Pa.) and rarely traveled, decided that he wanted to see the world. But at 31, he decided it was time to settle down for a while.
He joined Broderbund in July, and he and his wife, Pamela, a registered nurse, now live on a sailboat in nearby Sausalito. "It's about the only place you can live in Marin County on my salary," Mr. Coughlin said.
Mr. Coughlin hopes to be off the help desk in another six months. He would like to work for the Broderbund department that assesses proposed programs, much as a movie-studio reader judges the screenplays of Hollywood hopefuls.
Like other help-desk workers, Mr. Coughlin is familiar with the field's classic anecdotes -- the woman who puts the mouse on the floor and tries to pump it as if it was a sewing-machine pedal, or the man who holds the mouse up and points it at the screen as if it was a television remote control.
In the 4,827 calls fielded last Wednesday by Broderbund's help desk, the diversity of the callers was striking. They called from Vancouver and Staten Island, they ranged from grandparents to children, and they were at every imaginable level of computer skill.
One boy, Shane from Tesuque, N.M., called Mr. Coughlin in the afternoon, having trouble with the latest version of Prince of Persia, a computer game. "Basically, it randomly freezes up on me," he said.
Eventually, Mr. Coughlin discerned that Shane's problem was an "extension" -- or bit of software code -- on a virus-checking program on his computer that was preventing his game from running smoothly. "Yeah," Shane replied with aplomb, "I thought it was an extensions conflict."
After a marathon day on the help desk that began at 6 A.M. and ended nearly 12 hours later, Mr. Coughlin was weary, but he said he found the work satisfying. "I don't have any signs of burnout yet," he said. "But in another six months, I may."

 The computer industry is expected to be a chief engine of job creation in America and abroad over the next decade. Unlike other growth fields -- health care and residential care -- this one is creating a unique class of jobs, some new and some transformed. This series of articles profiles the people who fill these jobs and the world in which they work.

HEADLINE: Where the High-Tech Jobs Are

 BODY:
While jumping on the Internet bandwagon seems to be the latest rage, the second-largest fad for the computer industry is coming up with ever-sillier nicknames for the areas that house their home offices. Silicon Valley was one of the first, but that has spawned Multimedia Gulch (the area in San Francisco known for web site and CD-ROM development), Siliwood (the meeting place of technology and Hollywood somewhere slightly north of Silicon Valley) and Silicon Alley (New York City's attempt to claim a piece of the multimedia pie.)
 Boston is known for its Route 128, a rough aggregation of companies like Digital Equipment and the Lotus division of I.B.M., Texas has Texas Instruments and the software companies in Austin, and Washington state has Bill Gates and his friends. Minnesota is a surprising blip on the map, but further inspection reveals that Control Data, Honeywell, 3M and other hardware and software companies make their home in that state. 
 The maps are a broad indicator of computer employment. The computer industry is projected to be one of the three top job-creating fields in the next decade.

HEADLINE: Taking In the Sites;
A Virtually Balanced Budget

BYLINE: By LAURENCE ZUCKERMAN 

 BODY:
Anyone who has taken the time to follow the budget impasse between Democrats and Republicans in the nation's capital may secretly believe that he or she could resolve matters in minutes, if only given the chance.
On the Internet's World Wide Web, such armchair critics can indulge their Capraesque fantasies without having to follow Mr. Smith to Washington or wading through the arcana of foot-thick budget proposals. A computer model called the National Budget Simulation allows browsers to emulate the budget negotiators; all they have to do is point and click with their computer mouse. 
 The simulation, created by the Center for Community Economic Research at the University of California at Berkeley, divides the Federal budget into more than two dozen categories, ranging from agriculture to veterans' benefits. Moving down the list, one can cut or increase spending in each category. A section on tax breaks allows players to close loopholes or raise corporate taxes.
After the users make their choices, a computer at Berkeley calculates the results, revealing the size of the resulting deficit or surplus.
The simulation is a great way to procure ammunition for political arguments with friends and family, or to simply test long-held assumptions. For those who want to delve deeper, the National Budget Simulation home page is a good jumping-off point for a look at a copy of the President's proposed 1996 budget, a "citizen's guide" produced by the White House and some critiques of the budget bill recently passed by the Republican-controlled House of Representatives.
The Republican view is well represented at a site created by the party's Congressional delegation from Washington State. And no tour of the nation's budget woes would be complete without a stop at the National Debt Clock, the real-time record of the country's red ink. The clock is now available on line, thanks to an outfit called Fusebox.

HEADLINE: TECHNOLOGY: DIGITAL COMMERCE;
A few resolutions for high-tech movers and shakers.

BYLINE: By Denise Caruso 

 BODY:
DESPITE the mood swings of high-tech stocks throughout last year, at the dawn of 1996 more people in the world are computerized, World Wide Webbed or dripping rich from Internet-related public stock offerings than anyone would have dreamed of at the dawn of 1995.
Yet there is always room for improvement. So as a public service, this column offers a few New Year's resolutions for those in the business who might otherwise be tempted to overlook their shortcomings. 
 For the the Netscape Communications Corporation, the high-flying Internet software company, and for America Online, the premier commercial on-line service provider: Kindly resolve to stop vacuuming up new companies and adding technologies to your software offerings, and fix what you're selling today.
While using either Netscape's World Wide Web browser or logging onto America Online's overloaded system, it is routine for active users to have their computers crash at least once a day. Is this why everyone is so hot on the idea of a $500 "network computer"? So there is only a network connection and no hard drive to crash? As they say in the software world: Is that a bug or a feature?
For any commercial enterprise getting ready to start a site on the World Wide Web: Resolve to scotch your plans immediately unless you can honestly answer the question, "Why?" with one of the following responses:
1. "I know my customers have computers and Internet connections, and I have products they can buy using the Web for transactions."
2. "My customers say they're ready and willing to pay cash money to get their information and/or entertainment from the Web."
3. "I have figured out a killer business plan that will be profitable in three years without 100 percent advertising support and without siphoning profit from other divisions of my giant media conglomerate."
(Please note that "Everyone is doing it" is not one of the listed responses.)
For President Clinton, Vice President Al Gore, members of the United States Congress and all the various Federal regulatory bodies: Resolve that within the first 30 days of the new year, you'll paste a copy of the Bill of Rights alongside your computers, get an Internet account, and -- most important -- log on and use the Net.
It's only by doing this that our public servants can clearly see the damage they risk to a surging new information marketplace with censorship legislation. Free speech is vital to the practice of democracy and the growth of commerce. It is the only environment in which the information economy of the next century can thrive.
For Microsoft's chairman, Bill Gates: As if you didn't have enough on your mind, you have even more reason now to watch your back -- not for the Justice Department, Oracle or Netscape, but for Steven Johnson. Mr. Johnson, editor in chief of Feed, a Webzine (http://www.feed mag.com) resolves that in the new year he will jack into the network of the Gates mansion and replace all his digital art with wall-sized reproductions of dogs playing poker.
For journalists and social activists: On the heels of last week's announcement that Compuserve is being censored by the German Government, you should resolve this year to start using encryption technology for your electronic communication.
Jim Warren, an on-line activist, believes that the PGP (Pretty Good Privacy) public-key encryption program, available free via the Internet and legal to use and distribute in the United States, will become a de facto requirement for journalists and others who want to protect their information and messages from prying eyes -- Government or otherwise.
Mr. Warren says that those trying to gather or divulge sensitive information won't dare communicate any other way, and encourages people to look into PGPfone software for voice communications as well.
For Apple Computer's executive staff: Based on your long-standing inability to keep Apple's superior products competitive in a hot and fast-growing market, resolve to reflect on the tradition among Japanese managers at faltering companies. They've been known to resign their posts amid a flurry of suitable apologies to shareholders.
Apple executives have consistently under-forecast demand for the company's computers and squandered the organization's formidable technical and creative energy on dead-end projects like Kaleida and Taligent, joint ventures with I.B.M. that both died in 1995. When they finally do something right, like license the Macintosh operating system to clone makers, they get all picky about whom they'll allow to manufacture them.
So here's one last tip: If Steve Jobs is asking, sell him a license. A cheap, black Next box running Mac software won't save Apple, but it would neatly close the loop on Apple's unfocused, chaotic decade since his 1985 ouster from the company he founded.
Finally, one for the Wall Street analysts and the members of the news media who cover technology: Resolve to stop letting visionaries set your agenda.
Technology can be addictive, especially when it is attached to vast sums of investment money with the promise of exponential returns. But Wall Street's naivete about what technology can deliver (and the mass media's parroting of this so-called expertise) have consistently fed nasty boom-and-bust cycles that make only a few people very rich, very quickly. One need only look to the interactive television and CD-ROM start-up companies of the last few years for too many examples of what happens when the bottom falls out and oversold promises cannot meet expectations.
In fact, the best resolution that anyone who works in the converging worlds of technology, media and the Internet can make for 1996, after last year's giddy public offerings and chaotic growth, is to look beyond the big money and hype to focus on the hard work it takes to build a real industry from the promises of vision.

HEADLINE: Howard Petersen, 85, Banker and Trade Adviser

BYLINE: By ERIC PACE 

 BODY:
Howard C. Petersen, a former president and chairman of the Fidelity Bank of Philadelphia who had earlier held posts in the Truman and Kennedy Administrations, died on Thursday at his home in Radnor, Pa., a suburb of Philadelphia. He was 85.
The cause was cardiac arrest, and he had been in declining health, said his wife, the former Elizabeth Watts. 
 Mr. Petersen was the chief executive of Fidelity Bank from 1966 to 1975. He again ran the bank for a brief period in 1978.
At that time, Fidelity, which had $2.6 billion in deposits in 1977, was one of the larger regional banks.
Mr. Petersen was also Fidelity's president from 1950 to 1966 and its chairman from 1966 to 1978. The bank is now part of First Fidelity Bank and is soon to be merged into First Union National Bank.
He originally joined Fidelity as executive vice president in 1947, when it was known as the Fidelity-Philadelphia Trust Company.
Although Mr. Petersen was a Republican, he was special assistant to President John F. Kennedy for international trade policy in 1961 and 1962 and Assistant Secretary of War from 1945 to 1947 under President Harry S. Truman. He was also prominent early in the campaign for the nomination of Dwight D. Eisenhower as the Republican Presidential candidate in 1952.
When President Kennedy named Mr. Petersen, an expert in international economics, in 1961 as a special assistant, the White House announcement of his appointment said his job was "to advise and assist in the development of a new international trade program."
Mr. Petersen acquired his expertise in international economics as Assistant Secretary of War under Mr. Truman after World War II. In that post, Mr. Petersen's tasks included working on the economics of occupied Germany and of other war-ravaged nations.
At the time that he stepped down as Assistant Secretary, he was supervising the United States' military government activities in Germany, Japan, Korea, Austria and Italy and was the War Department's chief representative at the State Department on all matters involving political policy.
As Assistant Secretary of War, Mr. Petersen was sometimes outspoken. In 1947, he warned at a Washington news conference that the United States must give priority to food shipments to the American-occupied zone of western Germany. Otherwise, he declared, Communism might gain a foothold in the zone.
Earlier that year, he announced War Department action to alleviate the threat of famine and of resulting food riots in Italy: the diverting in midocean of six Germany-bound, wheat-laden ships to Italian ports.
Earlier in the 1940's, he held lesser War Department posts, helped to write the Selective Service Act and wrote implementing rules and regulations after it became law.
He was also a director of the Panama Canal Corporation under Presidents Eisenhower and Kennedy.
Mr. Petersen was born in East Chicago, Ind., graduated from high school there and went on to receive a bachelor's degree in 1930 from DePauw University in Greencastle, Ind., and a law degree in 1933 from the University of Michigan. From 1933 to 1941, he was an associate in the New York law firm that was then called Cravath, deGersdorff, Swaine & Wood.
Over the years, he was variously a trustee of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace and the Committee for Economic Development and chairman of the boards of the Institute for Advanced Study in Princeton, N.J., the University of Pennsylvania Museum and the Marshall Foundation.
In addition to his wife of 59 years, he is survived by a daughter, Elizabeth Spiro Clark of Washington; two grandsons; and a sister, Ruth Sfura of Munster, Ill.

HEADLINE: For More and More Job Seekers, An Aging Parent Is a Big Factor

BYLINE: By JUDITH H. DOBRZYNSKI 

 BODY:
Just over a year ago, after much soul-searching, Robert W. Crispin turned down a plum job as one of the top three executives of a prestigious company on the West Coast. He decided instead to stay in Hartford, within easy visiting distance of his ailing 90-year-old father-in-law in northwest Pennsylvania.
"We tried to figure out ways to deal with this," Mr. Crispin said. "We talked about opportunities to travel back to the East. But traveling transcontinental every couple of weeks is not easy, and I was very concerned about how my wife would agonize, and how much she would have to be away from me and my 14-year-old daughter." 
 The company even offered to move Mr. Crispin's in-laws, but he thought that would be too disruptive.
Just when corporations were getting used to the "trailing spouse" -- the wife or husband whose career puts obstacles in the way of business moves -- a new problem is cropping up. The graying of America is starting to create "trailing parents," who pose even bigger relocation hurdles.
Nobody knows the exact extent of the problem. But already an estimated 10 to 12 percent of the work force is responsible for caring for an aging relative, said Andrew Scharlach, a professor at the University of California at Berkeley. By 2020, Mr. Scharlach projects, one in three people will have to provide care for an elderly parent. The Conference Board, a business research group, estimates even more people will be affected -- as many as 40 percent before 2000.
With many more elderly parents to care for, more employees will face tough choices in deciding whether to move. "This is a new factor in the job equation," said Durant A. Hunter, president of Pendleton James & Associates, a search firm.
It is also a new wrinkle for the American economy, which has always depended on a high degree of mobility.
Like that first laugh line or gray hair, the problem is barely attracting notice -- yet. But as baby boomers start turning 50 in 1996, their parents, who are expected to live longer than any previous generation, will ascend into their 70's and beyond. Soon, more and more Americans will find themselves in the same position as Mr. Crispin, who is 48.
Companies are only beginning to deal with the implications of trailing parents. A few, like Apple Computer Inc., have sometimes agreed to foot the bill for moving elderly relatives rather than settle for a second choice in important personnel appointments. But many, fearing high costs, do not want to acknowledge the problem.
Besides, no matter who pays, moving elderly people to unfamiliar surroundings often causes problems. Whether they live with a child, in a nursing home, or on their own, they risk social isolation and increased dependence on their children.
"This was not on our radar screen a few years ago," said Cris Collie, executive vice president of the Employee Relocation Council, a business-supported organization in Washington. "But the growth in concern is astronomical."
Meanwhile, corporations are ever-eager for a mobile work force. In a study released in May, 80.9 percent of the 147 companies surveyed by Atlas Van Lines said they expected to transfer more employees in 1995 than in 1994. Sixty-two percent said they expected to move more people in 1999 than in 1994.
And those numbers do not include the outside talent that companies increasingly seek to fill crucial slots. But with a larger number of people looking after elderly relatives, corporations are likely to see some of their choices stymied -- even at top levels.
"I have had two or three cases in a row where it was definitely a factor," said Mr. Hunter, the corporate headhunter.
Frederick W. Wackerle, a recruiter at McFeely Wackerle Shulman in Chicago, echoed the concern. In each recent search by his firm for a chief executive, "there's been one candidate who has needed to stay close to an elderly parent in their 80's or 90's."
Usually, recruiters said, such candidates temporarily drop out of the job-changing market, restrict how far they will move, or both. Mr. Crispin, for example, did move to a new job after his father-in-law died last spring. But the post -- as executive vice president and chief financial officer of the UNUM Corporation -- is in Portland, Me., still a relatively short flight from Pennsylvania, where his mother-in-law and his own parents, all in their 80's, live.
Not everyone is fortunate enough to stay in the running for a job. John F. Johnson, a recruiter at Lamalie Amrop International in Cleveland, said his firm recently considered candidates for a $500,000-a-year job. "One executive told us that he'd look at the opportunity, but might not pursue it because of elder-care responsibilities," Mr. Johnson recalled. "We decided not to pursue him."
Mr. Johnson said the issue currently affects "a very small minority of individuals in our work." But he added, "I don't always know if they will tell me about this."
Relocation specialists agreed that people often do not volunteer the information, lest they be left out of the running for promotions. Even so, in a survey of employees at eight large companies conducted by Rodgers & Associates, a research firm in Boston, 37 percent of those who identified themselves as providing care for an elderly relative said they were not interested in relocating. By comparison, 26 percent of all employees said they would not be interested in such jobs.
And in the 1995 Atlas Van Lines survey, "family ties" edged out "spousal employment" for the second consecutive year as the primary reason employees turned down a relocation. It was cited by 64 percent of respondents. Concern for elderly relatives was undoubtedly a large part of that, relocation experts said.
Recent Census Bureau statistics show that Americans over all are moving less frequently in the 1990's than they have in decades past, though they still relocate more often than people in Western Europe and Japan. In a one-year period ending in March 1994, 16.7 percent of the population changed residences, down from the 20 percent that was typical in the 1950's and '60's.
Many companies have not yet decided how to respond to the elder-care problem. "People are starting to voice it, but it has not become an outcry yet," said T. J. Chiles Jr., director of work force diversity at the International Business Machines Corporation. Like many companies, I.B.M. -- whose initials, it was often said, stood for "I've Been Moved" -- has no policy on moving elderly parents, unless they live with the employee. Then, they move with the household.
Sometimes, though, the rules are bending to circumstances. "We do not move multiple households," said Kathleen Curtis, relocation manager at Apple Computer. "But we don't grill employees either. If they say parents are living with them, we do it."
Other trend-setting companies are winking at the rules, too. "We will move the new hire or the transferee and their dependents living at home," said Burke Stinson, a spokesman for the AT&T Corporation. He said if he were a transferee with a parent in a nursing home, "I'd just make arrangements to move him or her into my home for a month before the move."
In the Atlas survey, only 3 percent of the companies said they would move an elderly person who would not share the employee's home at the new location. In reality, though, these decisions are often made on an individual basis.
"Most companies are at the point where if someone's supervisor says, 'I want this to happen for this person,' they make an exception and pay for it," said Steve Mumma of Atlas Van Lines.
But there are few hard-and-fast rules in this sensitive area. Before setting a policy, "we'd have to see that people who are critical to us in managing our business are unable to accept assignments because of this," said Mr. Chiles of I.B.M.
The trouble is, employers may not know how an employee's personal responsibilities affect his or her professional life. "Transferees are not requesting help because there are so many other things that they are asking for," said Donna J. Malinek, president of Forward Mobility, a relocation consulting firm in Bernardsville, N.J. "They either turn down the transfer or they cope with moving the elderly parent themselves."
That, in turn, can create family tensions, Ms. Malinek said. "The spouse tends to do all the legwork to reconnect the elderly parent with the community, and that's an awful lot of work," she said.
Help with those tasks -- already provided for employees who need to find schools for their children and job opportunities for their spouses -- may be as important to transferees with responsibilities for parental care as paying for the moving van.
When one man was transferred from Cupertino, Calif., to Modesto, Calif., last year, his ailing mother-in-law, a stroke victim in her mid-70's who was living in a convalescent home, moved with the family. The employer, a large consumer products company, paid for the move and also for Forward Mobility to identify appropriate nursing homes in Modesto. As part of its package, Forward Mobility also researched doctors, hospital contacts and home health aides.
But "this is not standard policy among corporations," said Bonnie E. Graziano, a manager at Forward Mobility. "It's usually done on a case-by-case basis." Companies that pay for help with child-care and other family issues are the most likely to approve it, she added.
There is no question that demand for such services will grow. "It's when people reach the 70's," said Dana Friedman, co-president of the Families and Work Institute, "where problems start arising."

HEADLINE: Abusing the Nation's Children

 BODY:
The death in New York City of 6-year-old Elisa Izquierdo, allegedly at the hands of her mother, has focused national attention on an issue that, too often, is pushed to the sidelines. Congress, in particular, should be mindful of Elisa's fate as it moves to weaken programs that are designed to protect the nation's most vulnerable children -- victims of abuse and neglect.
Child abuse is hardly a new phenomenon. It burst onto the national consciousness in the late 1960's and early 1970's when a number of books and studies about battered children appeared. These were not tales of occasional maltreatment, but prolonged patterns of physical and sexual abuse. Studies also made it clear that child abuse and other forms of family violence were linked to alcohol, drug abuse and economic devastation. 
 Doctors, teachers and neighbors have been enlisted in the effort to look for and report abuse cases. But it falls mainly to the child welfare system, a patchwork of programs usually run by states and counties, to protect abused and neglected children and offer services to troubled families where children are at risk. The system also helps families who take responsibility for neglected and abandoned children through foster care or adoption.
In 1994, there were 3.1 million reports of child abuse and neglect, of which 1 million were substantiated. That year, 1,300 child abuse victims died.
As early as 1961, the Federal Government helped pay for foster care and adoption services for abused and neglected children who had to be removed from their homes. Particularly since 1980, Washington has also tried to impose minimal standards on states receiving Federal funds for child welfare programs. The standards require states to provide written plans for each child, with recommended services and timetables to move children into or out of foster care, help them return to their families or make them eligible for adoption.
For an array of child welfare programs, from child protection to family preservation, the Federal Government spent $4.8 billion in 1995. The states, collectively, spent about the same amount.
There is, generally, some correlation between spending resources and quality of child welfare services. While it is impossible to prevent all child abuse fatalities, states can offer children more protection when they have sufficient numbers of well-trained caseworkers.
In addition, many states are trying to put more resources into family support and family preservation programs and are beefing up community-based services, like drug treatment programs. Some improvements have resulted from legal challenges. Currently, 21 states are under court order or operating under consent decrees after failing to protect children adequately or provide services to families.
That situation is likely to get worse as Congress seeks to collapse a number of child welfare programs into a block grant for each state, eliminating Federal standards and reducing overall funding by perhaps $4.5 billion over seven years.
The reductions Washington wants to impose are likely to ripple through the social welfare system, hampering child abuse prevention efforts. That hardly seems the right response to the tragedy of Elisa and other young victims.

HEADLINE: The Progress of Peace

 BODY:
Granted, the structure of peace is rickety and various cease-fires could burst apart at any moment. It must be agreed as well that wars could explode overnight in countries ostensibly at peace. Nevertheless, something wonderful happened in 1995: the year ended with fewer guns being fired and fewer people being killed as conflicts long deemed intractable yielded to diplomacy. From the Caribbean to the Balkans, from southern Africa and the Middle East to the Irish Sea, the dream of Peace on Earth has circled the globe.
For the first time in five years, Sarajevans can cross the street without fear of sniper bullets. Belfast marked a second peaceful Christmas after three decades of strife. For the first time since its birth in 1948, Israel is formally at peace with the Palestinian people, Jordan and Egypt, and talks are under way with Syria. 
 Weariness with unremitting tension and periodic blood baths among civilians have nudged peacemakers to the table. Also important was a yearning for material betterment, which proved a potent ally for peacemakers, especially among Arab peoples who seemed to be falling increasingly behind. In the former Yugoslavia, the need to rebuild shattered economies helped drive warring parties to the negotiating table.
Initially, the end of the cold war gave fresh life to dormant separatist movements. But once America emerged as sole superpower and Moscow ceased to be its global rival, dictators and guerrillas alike lost their old leverage and had to deal with each other, as in southern Africa.
Still, the triggering catalyst in 1995 was American leadership. The Bosnian accord was forged in Ohio, the peace talks in Northern Ireland were kept alive with help from President Clinton, and the Middle East breakthrough was in major part the result of determined American diplomatic efforts.
Mr. Clinton was initially reluctant to assume the risks of foreign policy leadership. A Somalia peacekeeping mission, launched by George Bush, blew apart. Americans were deeply divided about how to promote democracy in Haiti and peace in the former Yugoslavia. The reckoning is not yet final, but the worst fears about Washington's intervention in Haiti did not materialize.
Elsewhere in the Caribbean, El Salvador and Nicaragua remain at peace as left and right manage to compete within a still-shaky democratic framework. In Guatemala, scene of some of the worst massacres, peace talks are under way between Marxist guerrillas and the Government. Remarkably, for the first time since the early 1950's, there are no civil wars or insurgencies around the Caribbean, with the cruel exception of Colombia.
Asia is less fortunate. Against all reason, fighting continues in Afghanistan, and its capital, Kabul, is reduced to rubble. Not even a hint of compromise is evident in rebellious Kashmir, India's most unwilling state, and Tamil extremists have rebuffed overtures from a new Sri Lankan Government. Cambodia is nominally at peace, but a United Nations settlement has yet to sink roots. Turkey continues its scorched-earth drive against Kurdish rebels, and truces rather than real settlements mute conflicts in Georgia and Chechnya.
In Africa, a new President in Algeria has opened the way to peace talks with Islamic militants, and civil wars in Mozambique and Angola are yielding to pragmatic diplomacy. But in the Sudan, Africa's longest war resists mediation, and ethnic strife continues to menace Rwanda and Burundi.
The progress of peace in 1995 confirms that even the oldest, angriest conflicts are amenable to energetic diplomacy. May 1996 be as encouraging.
