HEADLINE: Ballet in the Big Apple

 BODY:
At Lincoln Center during the holidays children and their families crowded the New York State Theater for a look at "The Nutcracker," and an art form that was born over 500 years ago at the court festivals of the Italian Renaissance. For them and for people ranging from Henry VIII to Louis XIV to members of Congress who in 1842 forced a recess because they were all off seeing ballerina Fanny Ellsler, everything is beautiful at the ballet.
For centuries ballet has flourished in some of the world's great cities, and nowhere more than in the New York of the last 50 years. This, after all, was where George Balanchine began his school and his company, shaped several generations of dancers and inspired a cadre of choreographers. New York, too, is what spawned the new ballet companies that are thriving all over the United States. 
 New York's three major ballet companies, however, are in varying degrees of health today. The glory days of the Iron Curtain mystique and defectors like Nureyev, Baryshnikov and Godunov, dancers as famous for their glamour as their artistry, are past. Balanchine, a colossus, is gone. Still, it is his New York City Ballet that is the healthiest. It has its own home, a long list of subscribers, major foundation money and a cash cow in "Nutcracker." Even so, public funding is down, the interest in repertory in steadily declining and the Sunday night performances have been cut.
"We're in a much more competitive marketplace, and the performing arts will have to do more than serve cappuccino at intermission," the company's director of marketing, Chris Ramsay, said.
To Mr. Ramsay, marketing is the key, much of it aimed at Baby Boomers, whom Mr. Ramsay described as not notably philanthropic and not much attuned to classical dance. Also, because anyone who sees ballet in childhood tends to be stuck on it for life, the company is spending $500,000 to perform for youngsters and their parents in the outer boroughs and subsidize some performances.
American Ballet Theater has lost about 70 percent of its public funding. At the same time costs keep rising. "Those cultural groups that are going to thrive," said Michael M. Kaiser, its new executive director, "are those that are going to get people excited about them. All year round you've got to keep trying to be a presence."
Dance Theater of Harlem is truly ailing. It has lost more than half its public funding, has had to downsize the number of dancers and administrative staff and cannot afford a New York season this year. "We took some very drastic steps," said Arthur Mitchell, its co-founder and artistic director, "but we finished the fiscal year in the black and I'm very proud of that."
Life might be simpler if the company had its own theater. But it already has the young, racially and economically mixed audience that the two other ballet companies are hoping for, Mr. Mitchell said.
Money is important for these companies, not only for sustenance but for risk taking. But so is high visibility, powerful institutional identities and an influx of new talent, choreographers in particular. Buy a ticket to the ballet in some cities and you are buying into the only game in town. But there are hundreds of games in New York on any given night. If New York's ballet companies are to remain the dazzling part of New York's cultural life they are, they have to turn a floodlight on themselves.

HEADLINE: Abroad at Home;
Marx And Gingrich

BYLINE: By ANTHONY LEWIS 

 BODY:
Among the memorable documents of the year just ended was a letter from Vaclav Havel, the Czech President. He sent it in October to an international environmental conference.
"I come from a country where forests are dying," Havel wrote, "where rivers look like sewers and where in some places the citizens are sometimes recommended not to open their windows. . . . 
 "When I think about what has caused these frightening conditions and when each day I encounter the barriers that make any quick improvement impossible, again and again I have to conclude that the root causes of these conditions are neither technical nor economic but are philosophical in nature.
"In my view, Marxist ideology and the Communist style of rule reflect an extreme and threatening culmination of arrogance of new age human beings who enthroned themselves as lords of all nature and of all the world. . . ."
After the year 1995, Americans know that it is not only ideologues of the left who in their arrogance destroy nature. As Communist rulers poisoned the land and air and water of the Soviet Union and its satellites, so our new class of right-wing zealots would ravage America.
The Republican radicals in Congress have made it a priority to undo the environmental safeguards built up in legislation and regulations over the years beginning with the Nixon Presidency. An unannounced priority: Newt Gingrich said nothing about ending the protection of clean air and water until he had won power in November 1994.
Right now, as the Republican leaders and President Clinton negotiate about the budget, severe restrictions on environmental programs are taking effect. It is not clear how much of the slashing, if any, a budget compromise may undo.
The Environmental Protection Agency has cut way back, for example, on inspections of possible discharges of sewage and pollutants into rivers used for drinking water. The deterrent effect of enforcement is in danger.
The E.P.A. appropriation voted by Congress would cut its funds by nearly a quarter from this year's budget. President Clinton vetoed that bill, but officials fear the final figure will still be a drastic cut -- forcing large-scale dismissals of E.P.A. employees and reductions in aid to states for sewage treatment and clean water installations.
It is not only a question of money. Congressional Republicans have written into legislation orders to stop listing further endangered species, to allow more logging in the Tongass National Forest in Alaska and to remove or restrict many other protective measures.
The assault on environmental protection has aroused a significant public backlash as Americans have grasped what Speaker Gingrich and his colleagues are doing. In response to the unease, G.O.P. leaders have tried to disguise the character of their environmental bills. A small but illuminating example is the work of Senator Christopher Bond of Missouri, who steered through Congress the bill slashing E.P.A. funds.
Two sentences in that bill would forbid the E.P.A. to veto, as destructive of wetlands, any project approved by the Army Corps of Engineers. The E.P.A. has that power now and has used it to stop such things as a huge highway around Nashua, N.H.
When the new provision was criticized, Senator Bond protested in a letter to The New York Times that he was only trying to prevent duplication of Government effort. The President, he said, governed the Army Engineers and could tell them what to do.
Could Senator Bond really expect anyone to believe that disingenuous argument? To believe that a President can tell the Army Engineers what to do, case by case? To forget that the real reason the Republicans want to reduce protection of wetlands and air and water is to increase the profits of campaign contributors?
The hypocrisy of those who would destroy is brazen, and the danger great. President Havel said it:
"The environmental desolation created by the Communist regimes is a warning for the whole of civilization today. . . . [We face] a challenge to defend ourselves against all those who despise the secrets of being, might they either be cynical business people pursuing nothing but the profits of their business or left-wing saviors who have succumbed to the drug of cheap ideological Utopias."

HEADLINE: Essay;
Ours Not to Reason Wye

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
For two days last week, at the secluded Wye plantation in Maryland, Israeli negotiators told representatives of Syria's dictator, Hafez al-Assad, of the economic wonders that peace would bring to the Middle East. The Syrians listened, offering nothing.
They do well that way. Six months ago, when Israel under the cautious Yitzak Rabin dared suggest a modest Israeli presence with electronic monitoring on the Golan Heights, the Syrians refused to talk further. 
 Now, under the eager Shimon Peres, Israeli negotiators are finessing the subject of security. The most the Israelis say at Wye about the Golan is that nothing unacceptable to the Israeli army's high command can be offered.
But through osmosis diplomacy, the impression is left that total withdrawal is exchangeable for neighborliness. Not, as with Egypt, a "cold peace" that perpetuates hostility, but an arrangement with cultural exchanges, tourism, joint business ventures, regional water sharing.
By focusing more on the quality of peace than the requirements of security, Mr. Peres hopes to create an irresistible momentum within Israeli public opinion toward giving Assad what he has long sought.
The Syrian dictator responded to these inducements by sending his team back to the table. But when told that the level of representation will determine the pace of negotiations, Assad balked: although Israel's team is now led by Uri Savir, chief of the Peres peace process, Syria pointedly kept its delegation at the level of ambassador.
Peres ardently desires a personal meeting of the two men at the top. Assad is likely to make Peres pay for that summit with an assurance of a total Golan giveaway in return for a minimum of gestures of public diplomacy.
But there's a contradiction in Syria's strategy. Peres cannot deliver the Golan to Syrian control without the expression of Israeli support in a referendum, perhaps wrapped in the coming election. To help Peres gain that support, Assad must offer concessions that will win over the skeptical majority in Israel.
Up to now, the Syrian may have deluded himself that American mediators will do most of that job of reassuring Israelis for him. The notion that U.S. troops can be permanently stationed on the Syrian-occupied Golan as a tripwire is a recurring diplomatic pipedream.
That won't happen. No American President could place soldiers in a potential crossfire without a guarantee from Israel never to launch a pre-emptive strike without American permission. And Israel could never give up that degree of sovereignty on a matter of survival.
How can Assad take advantage of the window of opportunity that Peres is offering to regain all the heights? The answer, which would be met with hosannas in the U.S. and Israel, is to close the Damascus headquarters of terrorists and global drug dealers, while curtailing the power of Iran's Hezbollah in the part of Lebanon patrolled by 30,000 Syrian troops.
Even an Assad feint in that non-pro-terrorist direction to Warren Christopher on Jan. 15 would be cause for Peres to offer to abandon the Golan, triggering a trilateral summit with President Clinton in Damascus in late spring and an election referendum amidst euphoria in the fall.
My sources say there's a 50-50 chance Assad will make that feint; in a couple of years, once in control of the high ground, he could manipulate the quality of the peace. My gut feeling is that Peres, in his haste to make history, is trading tangible strategic position for hard-to-verify hopes.
But that's for Israelis to judge. Two members of David Levy's splinter party have rejoined Likud; the General who had the northern command, Yitzak Mordechay, will lead the charge against any Golan goodbye; opinion polls are moving back toward pre-assassination levels, and Peres has twice demonstrated his talent for losing elections.
Dictator Assad -- destroyer of Hama, ally of Iran, conqueror of Lebanon, protector of terrorism -- has earned the world's distrust. Let the pressure be on him to slowly, steadily earn its trust.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;
Final Round of Tax Cut

BYLINE: By SUSAN JO KELLER 

DATELINE: TRENTON

 BODY:
It is time to ring in the third and final phase of the tax cut that Gov. Christine Todd Whitman promised when she ran for office.
Starting today, the state income tax rate will be 30 percent lower than it was in 1993 for families with up to $80,000 in taxable income and individuals with up to $40,000. For those who earn more, the cuts are smaller; for example, the reduction totals 9 percent for families whose income is over $150,000. 
 "These tax cuts will put $1.2 billion back into the economy in 1996," the Governor said in a prepared statement. Of course, the cuts also mean the state government will have to make do with less; when the Governor gets back from vacation, she will face the task of figuring out how to make ends meet in her next budget.

HEADLINE: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;
More Jobs in Mercer County

BYLINE: By SUSAN JO KELLER 

DATELINE: EAST WINDSOR

 BODY:
Again and again last year, Mercer County was rocked by announcements of job cuts by big employers. But at year's end, the county had actually gained jobs, according to the County Executive, Robert D. Prunetti. 
 That is because several small high-tech firms moved to the county, providing new jobs; meanwhile, the announced cuts -- more than 6,000 of the county's 199,000 jobs -- are still being phased in. The county has won an $800,000 Federal grant to retrain workers being let go by the Lockheed Martin Corporation and the Mobil Corporation, as well as three big Trenton employers: a Carter-Wallace condom factory, Hill Refrigeration and state government.

LENGTH: 1207 words

HEADLINE: OUTLOOK '96: MARKETS AND INVESTING;
With U.S. Flat, Where Will the Money Go?

BYLINE: By EDWARD WYATT 

 BODY:
AMERICAN investors, pack your moneybags.
After a year in which United States stock and bond markets outperformed nearly every market around the globe, many market strategists and investment managers are predicting that 1996 will bring better opportunities abroad. 
 Forget those 40 percent gains in Nasdaq stocks. Turn your back on 30 percent returns in long-term Government bonds. And disconnect from the Internet. Over the next 12 months, the gains racked up in this country's raging bull markets are unlikely to be repeated, experts say.
To be sure, some sectors of the American markets hold promise in 1996. Wall Street still expects further interest rate cuts by the Federal Reserve, and if they come, makers of heavy machinery and other capital goods are likely to benefit. The Magellan fund, the country's largest mutual fund, recently added to its stakes in two concerns that make floor coverings: Armstrong World Industries and Shaw Industries.
Whether individual investors can similarly lower their sights is uncertain because some markets they are being told to look at -- most notably Japan -- have been among the worst performers the last three years.
But the tremendous gains most investors have experienced over the last year make this an appropriate time to revamp portfolios with an eye on the road ahead.
"One of the classic traps that investors fall into is thinking, 'Because this is doing so well for me, I'm going to keep buying more of it,' " said Jon S. Fossel, chairman of Oppenheimer Management.
Investors who continue to pour fresh cash into last year's big winners -- technology stocks or big American companies -- are making that mistake, Mr. Fossel said. He predicts that in the first six months of 1996, the Dow Jones industrial average is likely to undergo a downward move of 10 percent or more.
AS head of a company that manages $35 billion of mostly domestic mutual funds, Mr. Fossel is not predicting that the American economy is about to go into a free fall. But, he said, a slowdown is more likely than many people believe, and disappointing growth in the economy generally and in corporate profits in particular could upset American equity markets.
Robert Haddick, manager of the $488 million Fremont Global fund, a mutual fund that currently has about two-thirds of its assets spread outside the United States, agrees. "For the first half of the year, we're not going to be adding to our U.S. equity position because I think we'll see better results outside," he said.
And while both men expect short-term interest rates in the United States to fall, they are not too optimistic about the potential of such a cut to fuel either the economy or further rallies in United States equity markets. "Look at Japan," Mr. Fossel said. "They have cut interest rates so far that they are negative in real terms, but that hasn't turned their economy around."
Which is why Japan is at the top of many forecasters' lists of the most attractive global markets the next few years. "The Bank of Japan has engineered the same formula to get out of a crisis and increase liquidity that we were using in this country four to five years ago," said Charles E. Cain, president of Cain Asset Management in New York.
Japanese banks have been able to borrow money from the central bank at extremely low interest rates and invest it in long-term securities, earning a spread of 3 percent or more, Mr. Cain explained. That has earned the banks some criticism for not helping to rebuild the economy. "But what they are really doing is improving their balance sheets," he said.
"Japan Inc. is the banks," said Henry A. Frantzen, executive vice president of Federated Global Research, part of the Federated Investors family of mutual funds. Improvements in the banks' financial situation led Mr. Frantzen to increase the weighting of Japan in Federated's global mutual funds to nearly 40 percent from 18 percent.
Jeffrey Russell, international markets specialist at Smith Barney, is somewhat cool toward Japan but likes the emerging market economies of the Pacific Rim. Some of those markets, he acknowledges, have burned American investors in recent years. But now, he said, "virtually every market there presents the opportunity of double-digit earnings growth."
Mr. Fossel of Oppenheimer Management particularly likes the debt markets of the emerging economy nations. If interest rates in the United States fall, as he expects, rates will similarly come down around the world. Emerging markets, he said, with high consumer demand and young populations, "stand to benefit most from cheaper capital and improved terms of trade."
While some Asian countries probably have a better outlook than others, predicting which markets will perform best is more difficult. Therefore, investors might be better off owning a mutual fund that specializes in the region rather than individual country funds.
IN Europe, on the other hand, certain countries' prospects are easier to identify, and investors can invest in them either through mutual funds or through stocks that are traded both in that country and in the United States. For instance, the American depository receipts of the Nokia Corporation, Finland's largest publicly held company, which are traded on the New York Stock Exchange, are sometimes as affected by broad moves in the Helsinki market as by the company's own prospects.
Mr. Russell of Smith Barney is most optimistic about the prospects for Europe, where the economic cycle is one to two years behind that of the United States, he said.
Big, high-cost European companies like Philips, Fiat and Olivetti are now undergoing the kinds of cutbacks and overhauls that American companies have already achieved, which should lead to greater profit improvements, Mr. Russell said. And he finds the greatest overall prospects in Sweden and Ireland, countries that are attracting foreign investment with low wages.
There is a general lack of enthusiasm for Latin America, where troubled economies continue to haunt investment markets. But this lack of enthusiasm might make regions like Latin America a good place to shop for bargains.
At the least, said R. Stephen Doyle, chairman of Montgomery Asset Management, emerging markets are attracting some smart investors -- particularly pension funds. He said that more than 200 American pension funds have started searches in recent months for specialists in emerging markets. For the smart money, the point is to get there before the crowd.
But trying to guess where the crowd will go can be a dangerous game for individual investors. Even after a spectacular year like the one just ended in American markets, individuals who are long-term investors should not be too quick to try and find the next hot spot, said John C. Bogle, chairman of the Vanguard Group.
"If you feel a really compelling need to reduce your risk exposure" to United States stocks, Mr. Bogle said, "don't do it by more than 15 percent." That is, if 65 percent of your assets are in the stocks, do not lower the allocation below 50 percent.
"Even if stocks are going to go down, and you get out at the right time," he said. "You still have to get back in at the right time."

HEADLINE: OUTLOOK '96: THE ECONOMY;
The Welfare State Is Alive and Welcome in Western Europe

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH 

DATELINE: PARIS

 BODY:
FOR years, a favorite pastime of economists has been prophesying the demise of Europe's comfortable welfare state.
Social payments, wages and subsidies are all too high in Europe. Labor laws are inflexible, and Europeans take too much vacation and pay too much in taxes. Technology is behind that of the United States and Japan. Everything is too expensive. And unemployment rates here are twice that of the United States. 
 Europe, according to the doomsayers, has become less and less competitive, can no longer afford such spreading of the wealth and is heading for a slow collapse.
If there is hope, it is because Europeans are beginning to realize that they have to lower taxes, cut spending, privatize everything and withdraw much of the safety net.
But if anything has served to underscore that Europe is not about to change its cradle-to-grave welfare state in fundamental ways, it was the three weeks of labor protests that paralyzed parts of France late last year and forced Prime Minister Alain Juppe to back down on a series of policies aimed at reining in France's exploding budget deficit.
While the public groused at the traffic jams in Paris caused by the shutdown of the nation's rail system, there was little real widespread opposition to the strikers. Logic demanded that if Mr. Juppe could take away the transit workers' acquired rights, he could take away those of others as well.
"There is always this messianic thinking that once you reach the promised land of free markets, everything will be all right," said David McWilliams, senior European economist for UBS Global Research in London.
He added, "Well, that is just not happening here. There is no broad consensus to change the system. The voters are simply against it."
But the system is creaking, and there are attempts besides those of Mr. Juppe to impose change. Prime Minister Lamberto Dini of Italy pushed through welfare changes last year aimed at saving $60 billion through 2005. Germany sharply cut its $7 billion in coal subsidies, and Sweden made the first major cuts in its social safety net in decades.
What is happening in Europe is a modest belt-tightening by politicians who want their countries to be part of a single European currency, which is scheduled to come into being at the beginning of the next century. Major overhauls -- passing through real economic pain to generate a renewed private sector that will create jobs -- are not on the horizon.
One reason is that many of Europe's leaders are weak and govern only by slim parliamentary majorities.
Another reason the overhaul of the welfare state will not become a major issue soon is that Europe's economy is markedly slowing. After predictions in early 1995 that export-led growth would turn into growth led by consumer spending, the Continent's economy appears to be softening, with the possibility that some countries, like France, could see negative growth less than 12 months from now.
"Weakness is more entrenched than expected," said Paul Horne, senior international economist at Smith Barney in Paris. "Our forecast is for soggy growth at best till mid 1996."
This will put European governments in a big bind, particularly if they are trying to cut their budget deficits to 3 percent of gross domestic product by the end of 1997 to qualify for membership in the Euro, the new single European currency.
Slow growth will mean lower tax revenues and bigger deficits. And cutting government spending in a sizable way will be nearly impossible since unemployment is already growing.
One solution is to abandon serious budget cutting. But economists doubt that would be acceptable since the markets would punish the country with higher interest rates and a weaker currency, making already anemic growth even slower. That leaves few policy initiatives besides raising taxes. Mr. Juppe has already raised France's value-added tax by two points, to 20.6 percent. A similar move is being considered in Germany.
All the West European economies have been helped by last month's interest-rate cuts by the Bundesbank. The discount rate at the German central bank, which effectively dictates monetary policy for all of Europe, is at 3 percent, its lowest in more than seven years. D. Sykes Wilford, managing director of Bankers Trust Private Advisory Services, predicts the Bundesbank will cut rates even further in 1996.
So Europe might be able to muddle along, cautiously preserving what it has, not risking significant change.
And for many here, that is fine. After two world wars, hyperinflation and a cold war, Europe tends to fight any attempt to abandon the systems it has put in place to insure social, political and economic stability.
"The approach in Europe is totally different than in the United States," said Alfons Verplaetsa, governor of the National Bank of Belgium. "Europeans want to be sure that there is no adventure in the future. They have had too much of that. They want stability and orthodoxy. They will compromise and compromise to get it."

HEADLINE: OUTLOOK '96: THE ECONOMY;
Modest Forecasts for U.S. Shift Focus Overseas

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

 BODY:
A YEAR ago, almost no one expected 1995 would turn into one of the biggest boom years for the American economy since the end of World War II.
It took the country by surprise: a huge surge in productivity, an even larger run-up in the stock and bond markets, a tidal wave of exports. American manufacturers, who only a few years ago were symbols of industrial decline from Germany to Japan, suddenly regained an aura of success unseen for 30 years. 
 Not surprisingly, many investors, corporate strategists and executives, have come to the same conclusion: it cannot last.
That conviction has propelled one of the odd paradoxes of the mid-90's boom. When the nation's capital seems to be growing more isolationist -- contributing less to the United Nations and the World Bank, cutting back on the government agencies pressing foreign nations to buy more American goods -- corporate America is finally investing abroad with a vengeance.
In the 1980's and early 1990's, companies talked about globalization but often had to be dragged abroad. A General Motors executive in Asia once spent an hour explaining to a reporter why it made no sense for G.M. to invest in Thailand, even though its auto market was growing at an annual rate of 130 percent.
Now American investment abroad is surging. By some estimates, American companies invested roughly $150 billion abroad between 1993 and 1995, triple what they invested outside the United States in the late 1980's.
Estimates of modest growth are behind the change. The American economy is expected to expand no faster than 2.5 percent a year through 2002, assuming no big recession intervenes. That is not the kind of number that makes a corporate strategist think about spending too much time at home.
The problem is where to go. Japan's recession seems endless; 1995 was supposed to be the year of recovery.
"It's not going to be a pretty year," said Kenneth S. Courtis, chief economist for Deutschbank Group (Asia). "And you can see it in the speed with which the Japanese themselves are headed out: more money into China and Southeast Asia."
Europe is not much better. The European Union seems mired over monetary union. Britain, traditionally the favorite foreign investment for American companies, has seen the inflow of direct investment fall by half, to lows it has not seen since 1987.
And then there is Latin America, still shaking off the Mexican shock of a year ago. In many countries throughout the region, starting with Chile, the markets look promising, and American business is starting to stir again. But Mexico made everyone a bit gun shy, and Brazil and Argentina are still feeling the effects.
That leaves the obvious: East Asia, especially China. Its growth is still phenomenal, upward of 7 or 8 percent a year, and some weeks it is hard to book hotel rooms in Shanghai with all the American, Japanese, Taiwanese and European executives muscling each other aside to strike deals.
But in the last year a good deal of the gloss has come off investing in China. Corruption has run rampant, and China's relationship with Washington was on a slide all last year. Many more arguments are expected this year over the treatment of dissidents and the piracy of American software, music and movies.
A recent survey of top executives by the Control Risks Group, a London-based consulting firm, concluded that bribery was skyrocketing in China's provinces and that for many companies "competitive pressures may leave them with no choice but to conform." No surprise there; the other big economic powers in China, including Japan and Germany, have no equivalent of the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act, the law that makes it illegal for American businesses to bribe officials abroad.
And then there is China's increasing skill at dangling the prospect of huge aircraft purchases from Boeing or a big deal for General Motors just as Washington is considering how to respond to the latest imprisonment of a dissident.
Such problems have left Washington in disarray, lurching from crisis to crisis, constantly weighing commercial costs against diplomatic interests. It is an ad hoc equation, rarely explained in terms of consistent principles. Often, Washington is alone. No country has joined the Administration's ban on direct investment in Iran's oil industry, for example, and a French company, Total S.A., won a huge deal that Conoco Inc., a Du Pont company, was forced to give up.
This leaves executives angry that their deals are entangled in foreign policy disputes over which they have no control.
Officials in other nations charge that even when it comes to business disputes, America is abandoning international trading rules. In their view, a mercantilist American administration would prefer to "manage trade" with Japan and other big trading partners one on one, reserving for itself a guaranteed share of their markets, rather than leave disputes over cars or semiconductors to international bodies like the new World Trade Organization.
Many Americans agree. In a recent article in Foreign Affairs, the former Under Secretary of Commerce for International Affairs, Jeffrey E. Garten, who left the Administration a few months ago, delivered a stinging critique of America's go-it-alone approach.
But the tide in Washington is not with Mr. Garten. While American business is saying it needs Government support abroad more than ever before -- akin to what Germany and Japan regularly provide for their businesses -- the Republican majority in Congress is going in the other direction.
And conservative Republican candidates for President, most notably Patrick J. Buchanan, see involvement in international groups like the W.T.O. as a surrender of national sovereignty.
If Mr. Buchanan does well in the primaries, it could make the question of America's business role abroad a much more potent one in the political world. But no matter how the election year turns out, the broad movement of the 1990's seems clear: there is no turning back for American business on its new focus on emerging markets abroad. Whatever the risks, whatever the political complications, there are few other places to grow. Just ask the American car companies: over the last few months, they have suddenly become interested in Thailand.

HEADLINE: OUTLOOK '96: TECHNOLOGY AND MEDIA;
Telecommuting Options Are Gaining Sophistication

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA 

 BODY:
TWICE a week, Ralph Silvestro skips the two-and-a-half-hour train ride from his home in Martinsburg, W. Va., to his office at the General Services Administration in downtown Washington.
Instead, he drives for about half an hour over rural roads to a building in Hagerstown, Md., about 50 miles northwest of the capital, where he and other Government workers do their jobs without the burden of a long trip fighting traffic. "With the office in Hagerstown, I can be home by 5 P.M.," Mr. Silvestro said. "It's nice to be able to go out to an early dinner now and then." 
 The Hagerstown office is one of a network of satellite offices the G.S.A. has established in the Washington suburbs for its employees and those of other Federal agencies. The use of such offices is one of the newer approaches to telecommuting; the typical telecommuter is an individual who works one or more days a week from home.
But not all home offices are equipped with high-capacity telephone lines, laser printers, copiers and desktop video cameras that can be used economically on a shared basis in a satellite office.
"These centers offer an alternative to working at home," said Faith Wohl, director of G.S.A.'s office of workplace initiatives. "For example, they are a good place to meet customers. You would not want to meet customers at home."
For the agency, which is the Federal Government's landlord, the offices are intended to improve the productivity of employees by shortening long, tiring commutes and reducing automotive traffic and the air pollution they cause. The agency is also looking to provide some guidance for the private sector. "Too often we think of work as a location rather than a process," Ms. Wohl said. "Today technology allows us to divorce the location from the process."
Ms. Wohl's enthusiasm notwithstanding, telecommuting programs appear to be at a crossroads for many workers. A survey of 1,200 households by the New York polling firm of FIND/SVP found that the number of telecommuters declined to 8.1 million in September 1995, compared with 9.1 million the previous year.
The company said the data suggested that many workers were voluntarily giving up the telecommuting arrangement out of concern for the stability of their jobs. "We believe corporate downsizing and outsourcing has made it less attractive for full-time employees to request home telecommuting arrangements out of fear of losing in-office visibility," the company said.
At the same time, the strongest Government incentive to reduce driving -- promoting telecommuting as a result -- has been weakened. Congress has voted to modify a provision of the 1990 Clean Air amendments that required employers with more than 100 employees to reduce commuting trips by 25 percent. The provision is now voluntary for the states, and California has already repealed it.
But even as Government pressure eases, some companies are encouraging telecommuting because they have found it improves productivity as well as morale.
Not surprisingly, high technology companies are quicker to adopt new ways than more traditional ones. It also helps that information-processing work is more easily dispersed than hands-on factory jobs.
"We view telecommuting as part of a strategy to enhance employee productivity," said David Abrahamson, a spokesman for the 3Com Corp. in Santa Clara, Calif. He said many Silicon Valley companies were developing programs to cope with the congested roads in the area.
One worker who appreciates the company's policy is Tess Santos, whose 65-mile commute from her home in Vallejo, Calif., kept her on the road for up to two hours each way. Now she does her job as a property accountant at home two days a week using a computer, modem and digital telephone line provided by the company. "In the past, I worked 10 A.M. to 7 P.M. to avoid the traffic, but I got home too late for parent conferences at school and P.T.A. meetings." Now, she said, she is much more involved in the lives of her 9- and 11-year-old daughters.
There are many approaches to telecommuting. But the practice seems to be spreading increasingly to jobs that were formerly fixed in place.
At the moment, the schedule of Mr. Silvestro of the General Services Administration is fixed: Monday and Wednesday in Hagerstown, Tuesday, Thursday and Friday in Washington. He is hoping to increase that to three days in the regional office.
The problem, he said, is that having workers at remote locations is new to most executives and many fear their control of organizations will be eroded by the practice. "They feel better if they can see you," he said.
Alex Dickinson is a two-day-a-week telecommuter, as well, working from his loft in the TriBeCa section of lower Manhattan. His office at AT&T Bell Laboratories in Holmdel, N.J., is almost 60 miles away. With a digital telephone line and a small video camera atop his computer display, Mr. Dickinson can have face to face meetings with his colleagues in New Jersey or at the Jet Propulsion Laboratory in Pasadena, Calif.
Mr. Dickinson, who does research on computer chips and video compression technology, said the chief advantage of working from home, aside from the time saved by not commuting, was that there were fewer distractions. "I believe I'm more effective at home and, with call forwarding, people are unaware of where I am," he said.
But there are limits. "If I was to telecommute more than three days a week, I'd feel disconnected," he said. "I have a supervisory job, and it would become a complex job supervising people if I'm out all the time."

HEADLINE: OUTLOOK '96: THE ECONOMY
The Economic Consensus on 1996: The Year of the Big Yawn;
Outlooks at the Edge: From Bust . . .

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

 BODY:
Not only is John Mueller one of the few economists predicting recession in 1996, he has been arguing for a long time that the new year will be a downturn, a Presidential election notwithstanding. No worse than 1990-1991, but a recession this year will still be the real, painful thing.
Causing this recession, the signs of which he sees emerging in various reports of deceleration, is the delayed effects of Federal Reserve policy that doubled short-term interest rates between February 1994 and February 1995. 
 "Every big rise in the funds rate is followed about two years later by recession," says Mr. Mueller, an economist with Lehrman Bell Mueller Cannon, a consulting and money management firm based in Arlington, Va. He says most analysts err in assuming Fed action is felt much sooner, within several months, and is then dissipated.
He contends that the immediate effect of interest-rate increases is to speed the economy, not to slow it, as people rush to borrow before rates climb further. This, he says, helped produced the 1994 boom.
Now, with the economy cooling and rates on the way down, the situation is reversed. "The only question is when, and to what rate, the Fed's going to cut," Mr. Mueller says. And this is causing people to put off action to try to catch the lowest rate.
"In 1996, we'll get this deferral effect," he says. "That's going to deepen the recession, which was really baked in the cake by the rate hikes two years earlier."
But just as mortgage rates tend to reverse course suddenly as dilatory home buyers panic at the first uptick in rates, the economy will snap back starting probably in late 1997 with "the real recovery beginning in 1998," Mr. Mueller predicts.
Mr. Mueller worked 10 years for Jack Kemp, a former Republican Congressman from New York and Housing and Urban Development Secretary as well as a prominent advocate of supply-side economics.
But while his forecast rests heavily on monetary policy, Mr. Mueller describes himself as a supply sider who happens to favor a balanced budget. Indeed, his monetary analysis itself is nontraditional in that he focuses not just on the dollars the Fed creates but on those created by foreign central banks when they intervene on world currency markets, as they did substantially last year.
"We found there was a wonderful relationship between the growth of the world dollar base and the inflation rate in the United States two years later," he says. From there, of course, he forecasts how the Fed -- and eventually the economy -- will respond.

HEADLINE: OUTLOOK '96: THE ECONOMY;
Sideshows Aside, Economy Is Still Key to Election

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL 

 BODY:
WHAT will turn on -- or turn off -- the voters in 1996? Bob Dole's back-and-forth position on abortion? Bill Clinton's taste for the fast lane and fast food? The Gingrich who stole Medicare?
Answer: None of the above. Again, it is the economy that matters most. The choice Americans make in Presidential elections, according to two statistical models produced by Ivy League researchers, are more directly tied to their perceived financial security than to any other factor. And strikingly, both models predict an exceptionally close contest in 1996. 
 Start with the latest from Ray Fair, an econometrician at Yale who has been using statistics to explain Presidential votes since 1978. His current model, based on election results from 1916 through 1992, is disarmingly simple. A handful of noneconomic factors do seem to matter. Incumbents have an edge and incumbent Republicans have an even greater edge. Mr. Fair also includes a "time-for-a-change" factor that costs votes for the candidate from a party in power for more than two terms.
But election results in times of peace, he suggests, usually turn on three significant economic variables:
*One is the rate of inflation during the first 15 quarters of the Presidential term. Statistically, each percentage point increase reduces the incumbent's votes by 0.83 of a percentage point.
*The second is the rate of economic growth during the previous three quarters. Each percentage point of growth averaged over the first three quarters of the election year increases the incumbent's vote by 0.65 of a percentage point.
*The third is what Mr. Fair calls the "good news" variable, which is gauged by how many times the rate of growth -- measured each quarter -- exceeds 4 percent. Indeed, every quarter that is above the threshold adds a full percentage point to the incumbent party's vote.
The equation explains past results exceptionally well, typically missing the victor's share of the two-party vote by less than 2 percentage points. Unfortunately, it missed by 3.4 percentage points in 1992 -- a result that Mr. Fair argues is linked to his necessarily crude assumption that Ross Perot took equal numbers of votes from George Bush and Mr. Clinton.
So where does that leave Mr. Clinton in 1996? Inflation will almost certainly average less than 3 percent and economic growth for the first three quarters of 1996 is forecast at 2 to 2.5 percent. But Mr. Clinton is short on "good news" -- quarters with growth exceeding 4 percent. Indeed, with just two such quarters thus far, Mr. Fair predicts that the President will receive just 49 percent of the two-party split. It would thus take at least one more strong quarter to push him over the top.
The prediction makes this election too close to call. After all, the analysis is reliable only within two percentage points, plus or minus. Still, if Mr. Fair is correct, the Democrats face an uphill fight to maintain control of the White House -- a fight that will probably be won or lost on the success of the economy next year.
Alberto Alesina of Harvard and John Londregan and Howard Rosenthal at Princeton show there is more than one way to play this statistical game. They argue that just two variables capture the noneconomic factors influencing the Presidential vote: the division of popular vote in the previous mid-term House elections, and the share of House seats won by the incumbent President's party in this same mid-term election.
The first, they suggest, captures the general popularity of the incumbent President. But the more House seats the President's party actually wins in the mid-term election, the greater the inclination of the voters to balance the impact by electing the opposition candidate.
The two effects tend to cancel each other except in times like these, when a relatively modest gain in the percentage of the House vote for the Republicans produced a switch in control of the Congress.
So what will determine the outcome of the 1996 election? Economics, of course.
In the Alesina-Londregan-Rosenthal model, the rate of economic growth in the Presidential election year has substantial sway. A 1 percentage point increase in the growth rate leads to a 1.45 percentage point increase in the two-party vote split for the incumbent.
Plugging in the same 2.5 percent growth rate for 1996 assumed by Mr. Fair, Mr. Clinton would end up with 49.97 percent of the vote.
Skeptics may take these results with a generous dollop of salt. Like the Fair model, the Alesina-Londregan-Rosenthal equation missed by a wide margin in 1992.
Still, all this suggests that the results of the 1996 election might be shaped in the marble-clad meeting rooms of the Federal Reserve. If the Fed plays its usual game of "better safe than sorry" on inflation, Mr. Clinton is in trouble. But if the Fed, which cut interest rates a modest quarter of a percentage point just before Christmas, gives a nod to growth over price stability, the Democrats may yet hold the White House.
It is often said that Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, is the most powerful man in America. This year, it may be true.

 Ray Fair, an econometrician at Yale University, argues that the winners of Presidential elections are generally decided by a handful of economic factors -- inflation, average growth and the "good news" of rapid growth usually associated with brisk economic recoveries. If he's right, Bill Clinton is in trouble. With the Fair model, an election is to close to call if the predicted margin of victory is less than 2 percentage points.

HEADLINE: OUTLOOK '96: MARKETS AND INVESTING;
Reaping Profits From Wall Street Run-Up

BYLINE: By PETER TRUELL 

 BODY:
WALL STREET had its crop of winners this year as the stock market set new highs through the year, merger activity surged and interest rates declined.
"The people that are heavy in investment banking and mergers and acquisitions did very well in 1995," said Perrin H. Long Jr., an analyst at Brown Brothers Harriman & Company, a New York investment bank. 
 And in a year when companies rose remarkably in value -- the stock market alone is up by more than 30 percent from a year ago -- many of those who themselves sold companies, public or private, did particularly well.
In one such deal, Theodore J. Forstmann, co-founder and senior partner of Forstmann Little & Company, bought and sold Ziff-Davis Publishing, a private company, to net a profit of several hundred million dollars in less than a year.
On Nov. 9, Forstmann Little sold Ziff-Davis, a publisher of computer magazines, to the Softbank Corporation of Japan, a software distributor and computer magazine publisher, for $2.1 billion. This, less than a year after Forstmann Little had bought the company from the Ziff family for $1.4 billion. Mr. Forstmann, 55 years old, said that he had wanted to own Ziff-Davis for a long time to come, but that when Masayoshi Son, Softbank's president and chief executive, approached him with such a strong offer "we felt we had a fiduciary obligation to our investors to accept it."
Acquiring a fast-growing company like Ziff Davis, helped Forstmann reap such a profit. Forstmann also tinkered with the company's management, introducing new incentives for top managers and strengthening the company's financial management. The last 12 months, Ziff Davis also has done well from the surge of interest in the Internet, selling its magazines -- it started Internet Life in the summer -- and information products to a public that is eager to learn about this new medium.
Such rapid financial activity spelled a good year for Wall Street, where most brokerage firms reported rising profits. But it was Morgan Stanley & Company and Goldman, Sachs & Company -- with their big investment banking and mergers and acquisitions departments -- led the pack, analysts said.
The two firms advised on almost 50 percent of the $600 billion of American mergers and takeovers in the year, according to Securities Data Company of Newark. As the year closed, Morgan Stanley, however, was just maintaining a narrow lead over Goldman. Goldman, meanwhile, topped the rankings for managing initial public offerings, raising as much as $6 billion.
Analysts particularly credited Jon S. Corzine and his management team for pulling Goldman back together again after a rocky 1994, when a slew of partners left the firm. Just over a year ago, some observers even thought that Goldman might be going into decline after the sudden departure of Steven Friedman, the partnership's chairman.
Most firms did well last year, Mr. Long of Brown Brothers Harriman noted. But he cited Paine Webber Inc. and Merrill Lynch & Company as two that might have done better.

HEADLINE: OUTLOOK '96: MARKETS AND INVESTING;
Wall St. Takes a Shine to Fee-Based Businesses

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM 

 BODY:
ONCE considered too tame for Wall Street's gunslingers, businesses like asset management, global custody and clearing are being wooed by investment bankers with Romeo-like ardor.
And no wonder. These businesses are the industry equivalent of Valium. They are impervious to sudden drops in the Dow, increases in interest rates, rising unemployment, sinking consumer confidence and the various other uncontrollable factors that buffet the fortunes of securities firms. And they can, if properly managed, produce fees year in and year out. 
 "There's no question that tending that garden of fees makes a difference in downside performance," said Guy Moszkowski, a securities industry analyst with Sanford C. Bernstein & Company.
Raymond A. Mason, chairman and president of Legg Mason Inc., noted, "The theory is that if you can't stop the ups and downs, you can certainly moderate them."
In 1994, when the securities industry suffered one of the worst drubbings in memory as interest rates skyrocketed and stock markets limped along, those firms that had been building their fee-based businesses fared better than those that had not. Merrill Lynch's earnings dropped 25 percent last year, while Salomon Brothers, a subsidiary of Salomon Inc., one of the most volatile firms on Wall Street, lost $399 million, compared with a profit of $864 million a year earlier.
Such fee-based businesses not only help smooth the ups and downs of the market, they also have fat profit margins at a time when margins in the industry are under pressure. And they require very little capital, a precious asset in an era when firms increasingly have to put their own capital at risk to reap a profit.
About 30 percent of Legg Mason's revenues come from asset management, which will account for a larger share of the firm's top line after it completes its acquisition of Bartlett & Company early this year, and its purchase in December of Lehman Brothers Holdings Inc.'s London-based asset management unit will bolster the importance of that business. "It's much more than a cushion against bad times for us," Mr. Mason said. "It accounts for close to half of our profits."
Since 1990, fees earned by Wall Street firms for managing client assets have nearly doubled, to an estimated $4.3 billion in 1995, according to the Securities Industry Association. They account for a gradually increasing share of revenues after interest expense, or net revenues, while income sources like commissions and underwriting have leveled off.
Merrill Lynch & Company, Goldman, Sachs & Company and Morgan Stanley & Company are some of the major securities firms singing the praises of such businesses, which are far afield from their traditional roles as raisers of capital for corporate America and brokers for institutional and individual investors. Just last month, Smith Barney Inc., the brokerage unit of the Travelers Group Inc., which had $92.2 billion in assets under management through Sept. 30, exhorted its brokers to raise their efforts to attract customer assets by an average of 33 percent -- or forgo a portion of their bonuses.
Analysts estimate that asset management, the most lucrative of the fee-based businesses, generates a pretax profit margin upward of 25 percent. At Dean Witter, Discover, for instance, fee-based businesses account for roughly 18 percent of revenue but almost one-third of profit, Mr. Moszkowski estimated.
Some analysts wonder, however, how deeply Wall Street's commitment runs to these new businesses. Perrin H. Long Jr., a veteran securities industry analyst at Brown Brothers, Harriman & Company, noted that most firms continued to grow more capital-intensive businesses like underwriting and trading at a faster clip than their fee-based businesses. "The brokerage business is becoming more and more cyclical, so if they really wanted to reduce volatility, they would increase assets under their management by a factor of two," he said.
Perversely, the stock market, which would be expected to reward firms for their efforts to even out volatility, often punishes securities firms. Legg Mason's stock has lagged its peer group this year, even though investors who owned its shares in 1994 fared far better than those that owned its competitors.
"Building fee revenue is a great thing for shareholders," Mr. Long said, "but the market doesn't seem to give you much credit for all your hard work."
Yet one good measure of the industry's passion is price. Firms have been paying top dollar to buy money managers, a much quicker way of expanding their asset management business than gathering assets through their brokers.
Morgan Stanley raised eyebrows last summer when it paid $350 million for Miller Anderson & Sherrerd L.L.P., a money management firm with $33 billion under its control, and in October Legg Mason paid an equally hefty $36.7 million for Bartlett, which had assets of $2.2 billion. Last month, RCM Capital Management, with about $26 million under management, was sold to Dresdner Bank for $300 million.
The rewards of fee-based businesses justify such prices, buyers say. Morgan Stanley, for instance, figures its collection of noncapital intensive businesses -- asset management, custody, clearing and mergers and acquisitions advising -- will add five to seven percentage points to its return on equity above its cost of capital, analysts said.
"If we can earn our cost of capital or slightly better in our capital-intensive businesses, that's good because it's hard to do better than that in a competitive market," said Philip N. Duff, chief financial officer of Morgan Stanley. "Then things like asset management and custody can add to that."
Going global can also help even and pad the earnings stream, and the same big firms that have demonstrated a commitment to reducing volatility through their mix of businesses are also busy establishing far-flung outposts. Last summer, Merrill stunned Wall Street with its high-priced purchase of Smith New Court, a London-based brokerage with a highly regarded European market making capability and enticing toeholds in emerging markets.
Morgan Stanley, which was criticized during most of 1994 for sticking to its plans for global expansion when other firms were bailing out of offices in Asia and curtailing activity in Eastern Europe, opened an office in Bombay and formed a joint venture with Chinese partners to put down roots in Beijing. And Goldman, Sachs has begun managing money for Nenpuku, a large Japanese public pension fund.
"If you believe that not all markets move in the same direction at the same time," said Joseph T. Willett, senior vice president and chief financial officer of Merrill. "Having business around the globe gives you a little bit of a hedge against downturns in one country."

HEADLINE: OUTLOOK '96: MARKETS AND INVESTING;
Dollar's Star Tied to Budget

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS 

 BODY:
The central question about the dollar in 1996 is: If President Clinton and the Republican Congress agree on a credible plan to balance the Federal budget in seven years, will this push the dollar higher or lower?
Naturally, economists are divided over this question. 
 Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, has lost no opportunity in recent months to indicate that cutting the budget deficit means a stronger dollar.
But at a symposium organized in September in Jackson Hole, Wyo., by the Federal Reserve Bank of Kansas City, Laurence Ball of John Hopkins University and Gregory Mankiw of Harvard presented a paper arguing that closing the budget gap is more likely to depress the dollar.
And a number of prominent American economists, including Paul Krugman of Stanford University and Martin Feldstein of Harvard, agree.
At first sight there does not appear to be any necessary connection between a country's budgetary discipline, or lack of it, and the exchange rate of its currency.
After all, the dollar went through the roof in the 1980's just as the Federal budget deficit was exploding. And the German mark remained strong despite the big fiscal stimulus provided by unification with East Germany.
On the other hand, contagion from Mexico's financial disaster early in 1995 quickly spread to other countries judged to have unsustainable budget deficits, including Italy, Sweden and Canada, putting downward pressure on their currencies.
Chris Turner, an economist at the British securities firm of Barclays de Zoete Wedd, has analyzed 11 examples of fiscal tightening in such countries as Germany, Italy, Japan, Ireland and Norway. In five of these cases, cutting the budget deficit sent the exchange rate higher. In the other six, the exchange rate fell.
Those who believe a lower budget deficit translates into a weaker currency argue that less government red ink leads to less domestic spending which in turn means lower interest rates, reduced capital inflow and a lower exchange rate.
C. Fred Bergsten, head of Washington's Institute for International Economics, said that while he did not exclude a brief "upward tick" in the dollar's value if a credible budget-balancing agreement is reached, in the longer run the outcome would be lower interest rates and a weaker currency.
This in turn would give American industry the competitiveness it needs abroad to increase exports.
The opposite view holds that tackling the Federal budget deficit would convince the international community the United States is finally curing its wasteful ways. That in turn would prompt a great new surge of international confidence in the dollar that will propel its value higher.
Robert D. Hormats, vice chairman of Goldman, Sachs International, said, "A good budget agreement would bring lower interest rates, a rising stock market and a big surge of investment in America from Asia and Japan that would lift the dollar."

HEADLINE: OUTLOOK '96: THE ECONOMY
The Economic Consensus on 1996: The Year of the Big Yawn;
. . . to Optimism on Everything

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

 BODY:
Gail D. Fosler, a former chief economist for the Senate Budget Committee, is not known as a particularly venturesome forecaster. This year, however, she is much more optimistic than her colleagues: her prediction of 1996 growth was more than three-quarters of a percentage point higher than any other forecaster polled by the newsletter Blue Chip Economic Indicators.
Ms. Fosler, now at the Conference Board, a corporate-sponsored research group, finds economic strength nearly everywhere and does not assume any election-year gunning. 
 She points to nine consecutive quarters in which domestic demand has climbed at least 4 percent, a rise in current wage and salary of about 3 percent after inflation, a rise in hourly earnings, continued high rates of business investment and the "substantial stimulus" the economy is getting from the drop in long-term interest rates.
"Eventually output is going to rise to meet demand," she says. The first half of the new year will get a lift from a cut in the capital gains tax, she adds, which she expects to survive the final round of budget talks.
And Ms. Fosler says that not only has the impact of proposed tax cuts been underestimated, the impact of proposed cuts in spending has been overestimated. Spending on health care, for example, does not have the multiplier effect of, say, closing a military base or scrapping a missile system.
Ms. Fosler worries little about the buildup of consumer debt, which she says is no higher than at previous peaks and is a dubious predictor. "I've never seen debt represent a barrier to consumer spending in the absence of other shocks," like the Persian Gulf war, she says. She believes that the consumer sector is neither weak nor strong -- it is just not where the economic action is.
Ms. Fosler says the Federal Reserve will not make further cuts in short-term interest rates and is baffled by the consensus that it must.
The economy is not in danger of stalling, she says, and she also points to inflation pressures like the 7 to 8 percent increase in the price of industrial materials the last year.
She is a bit concerned, however, about her forecast's being so much higher than those of other economists.
"I can't figure out," Ms. Fosler says, "why everybody doesn't think like I do."

HEADLINE: OUTLOOK '96: THE ECONOMY;
In Japan, Pessimism Is Pervasive

BYLINE: By SHERYL WuDUNN 

DATELINE: TOKYO

 BODY:
FOR Japan, 1995 was annus horribilis: an earthquake in the central city of Kobe, a nerve gas attack on the Tokyo subway, a gyrating yen, a banking crisis and a sagging economy.
Many Japanese remain anxious, cynical and uncertain about the economy in the year ahead, and this is reflected in the number of rakes they are buying. 
 Rakes?
In Japan, rakes are a traditional symbol of good luck in commerce, and so every November Japanese go to Shinto shrines to pray and to buy rakes, or kumade, in hope of raking in profits during the coming year. But rake purchases (175-pound rakes sell for $3,000, while hand-size ones cost about $7) tend to increase when times are good and drop when they are bad, as they have been doing the last several years.
So far, the rake sales seem to be trailing those of a year ago, suggesting that even hope may be evaporating.
"It's the worst we've seen in recent years," an official in charge of rakes at Hanazono shrine in Tokyo said. "Such poor sales are really depressing."
The Government is hoping a huge stimulus package it planned for the next few months will bolster the economy for a good chunk of next year. Partly because of that, many economists have raised their forecasts for 1996, putting growth at about 2 percent or more, compared with an estimated growth rate of less than 1 percent that was forecast for 1995.
But improved growth prospects do not appear to have raised the confidence of consumers or business executives. Consumers continue to curb their spending.
Moreover, some analysts say the depressed property market and the nation's troubled financial institutions, which are saddled with at least $400 billion in bad real estate loans, are a potential drag on the economy. In December, the Finance Ministry announced sweeping measures to change the way it manages the nation's banks, but there may still be bankruptcies.
Even the failures of small institutions can cause significant ripples throughout the region. When Nishiki Finance, a consumer finance company in Osaka, declared bankruptcy last summer, its failure provoked the subsequent bankruptcies of 445 small companies that did business with it.
Toshifumi Suzuki, president of Ito-Yokado Company Ltd., a retailer, is an outspoken cynic about prospects for growth next year. Mr. Suzuki will be adding 500 stores in Japan to his chain of about 6,000 7-Eleven Stores across Japan and 5,630 in the United States, but real economic recovery, he said, will emerge only if the Government loosens rules and regulations.
"All the signs are pointing to gloomy prospects," he said. If things remain as they are, he added, the prospects are as bad as they were for 1995.
Others were less pessimistic, although many economists and industry executives are aware of the potential obstacles to growth. High unemployment has crimped household sales, and recognition that the years of economic boom are unlikely to return soon are dampening expectations.
But one of the main reasons Mr. Suzuki and other Japanese executives remain cautious is that sustained, broad-based vitality strongly depends on economic deregulation and revamping, which have not had a widespread impact in Japan.
There are, however, a few bright spots. The technology sector is growing quickly, and business profits in general are expected to rise.
Moreover, some analysts are bullish about the stock market. The market's chief barometer, the Nikkei index of 225 issues, is trading close to 20,000 after trading below 15,000 in July. A rising market could help raise confidence in the economy over all.

HEADLINE: OUTLOOK '96: MARKETS AND INVESTING;
1995 HIGHLIGHTS

 BODY:

So Many Deals, So Little Time
 It wasn't "another day, another billion-dollar merger" last year -- it was far more than that. According to the Securities Data Corporation, 1995 (through Dec. 26 anyway) saw American companies announce some $465 billion in mergers and acquisitions, surpassing the old record of $347 billion set just the previous year. And while hostile takeovers are happening with greatest frequency since 1988, a popular offshoot is the "bear hug" -- an offer too good for the target company's board to refuse. (Did someone say I.B.M.-Lotus?) 
 Because most deals these days involve stock rather than debt, whih was the 1980's instrument of choice, the merger trend has a spiraling effect on Wall Street: a rising stock market lifts the value of company shares, which make deals easier to do, which stimulates speculation about other takeover candidates, which helps lift stock prices, which make more deals easier to do.
 
The New Billionaires
 Millionaire. What a quaint term. They're a dollar a dozen these days. If you're talking real money, you're talking billionaires.
There's Bill Gates, of course, who could buy and sell a few billionaires before breakfast. But others vaulted into these rarefied ranks last year, notably James H. Clark, founder of Netscape Communications, whose holdings crossed that threshold in November as Netscape's stock kept soaring toward Internet heaven.
And Steve Jobs -- yes, the Apple co-founder is back -- joined this elite briefly. When Pixar Animation Studios, his latest venture, went public, the stock nearly doubled in a day, sending Mr. Jobs's 80 percent stake past $1 billion. But the stock soon slid back again, leaving Mr. Jobs's holdings at a mere $866 million.
 
Commute? Moi?
Sometimes it seems the boss can get away with anything. As in: "I made the rules; I don't have to obey them." Sometimes, but not always.
At Morrison Knudsen, William Agee took the work-at-home concept to new heights -- or depths. Problems were mounting, along with complaints about his management, and morale was dismal at the Boise, Idaho, headquarters. Mr. Agee's solution: stay home in Pebble Beach, Calif., and run things from there. Did the directors mind all this? Apparently not -- though many of them had strong ties to a charity run by Mr. Agee's wife, Mary, so they might have been reluctant to challenge the boss. In February, though, it all got to be too much, and Mr. Agee departed.
 
A Fairer Shake From Nasdaq
To small investors, it's all too familiar. If you want to buy a Nasdaq stock, you see two prices miles apart: a "bid" price (what you can sell it for) of, say, $20 and an "asked" price (what you must pay to buy it) of $25. An exaggeration, perhaps, but not by that much. The little guy, of course, rarely gets the best price on any stock trade, but Nasdaq is notorious for nibbling the most extra pennies. But last year the S.E.C. -- and, grudgingly, Nasdaq itself -- moved to make things a little fairer, making various proposals to give everyone access to the best prices at all times.
 
Don't Look Back, Kerkorian May Be Gaining
If takeover battles typically resemble samurai warfare, Kirk Kerkorian's pursuit of Chrysler is more in keeping with the stratagems of chess masters. And though Chrysler is far from being captured, it can't seem to bring the game quite to a close. In April, Mr. Kerkorian made a $22.8 billion offer -- one that shareholders found hard to take too seriously because he didn't have financing in place and couldn't line up a Wall Street firm to lead the charge. But Mr. Kerkorian brought in Jerome B. York, a former chief financial officer for Chrysler, to figure a way to keep pressure on the company.

HEADLINE: OUTLOOK '96: THE ECONOMY;
1995 HIGHLIGHTS

 BODY:

New Tack on Interest Rates
After raising interest rates for more than a year, the Federal Reserve reversed course in 1995 and cut short-term interest rates twice, in July and in December, bringing the Fed's rate for overnight loans, to 5.5 percent. Signs of soft economic growth and moderate inflation prompted the rate cuts and some economists say that -- and an agreement in Washington to balance the budget -- will be the recipe for several more cuts this year. 
 A little bipartisan harmony could also help the prospects of Alan Greenspan, the Republican-appointed Fed chairman, and Alan S. Blinder, the Democratic-appointed vice chairman, both of whose terms expire in the very political year of 1996.
 
BANKING LOOKS TO CLOSE RANKS
There simply had never been a year like it in banking, an industry that had resisted the merger and acquisition fixation of other sectors. But times have apparently changed: more banks were sold in the first nine months of the year than in any full year before, with the biggest deal the $10 billion acquisition of Chase Manhattan by Chemical Banking. The new bank, which will keep the Chase name, will become the largest American commercial bank.
What do these mergers mean for consumers? Well, as banks consolidate their operations, there should be fewer branches and fewer jobs: one study forecast that half the nation's 59,000 bank branches will close and 450,000 of the industry's 2.8 million jobs will be eliminated in the next 10 years. Translation: there's an A.T.M. in your future.
 
FIRST COMBINE, THEN DIVIDE
Corporate America was indeed restless last year, with lots of big companies craving to become much bigger, while other giants felt bloated and had the urge to slim down. But had AT&T tried to get any bigger, it would have burst, so it splintered itself in three. In part, of course, this represented the failure of a previous round of gobbling -- AT&T's 1991 purchase of NCR. That computer business is one of the three new splinters, along with communications service and equipment.
 
LABOR LOSES MORE OF ITS PUNCH
Even for the grim slide organized labor's been on, last year was surprisingly bleak. While many companies posted record profits, earnings for union workers rose at the smallest annual rate on record. Companies like Caterpillar that stood their ground against strikers could claim victory.
Meanwhile, three of the nation's biggest unions -- the steel workers, automobile workers and machinists -- made plans to form a two-million-member giant. And Lane Kirkland was effectively ousted after 16 years as president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. John J. Sweeney, head of the service employees union, won the subsequent election, though in time he may wonder just what he has won.
 
RESOLUTION TRUST, 1989 - 1995
In the partial shutdown that characterized Washington's holiday season, there were no doubt few cups of cheer raised to the Resolution Trust Corporation. But the agency that had been set up in 1989 to save the country's savings and loans from their investment excesses of the 1980's officially went out of business on Dec. 31. Reviews on its performance -- taking over hundreds of savings and loans, selling their assets, investigating the conduct of bank officers and pressing for recovery of misused funds -- were mixed. But the agency's legacy will still be visible in the coming months. Japan is using the R.T.C. as a model for an agency set up to dispose of failed banks there -- which should see plenty of work.

NEW YORK CITY
 
Arrest in Fatal Queens Fire
Fire marshals arrested a paroled drug offender who the authorities say accidentally caused a fire in an abandoned house in Jamaica, Queens, that claimed the life of a firefighter, Lieut. John M. Clancy, inset. Prosecutors charged the man with second-degree murder, saying he fled the scene and made a "conscious decision" not to help arriving firefighters determine whether people remained inside. [Page B1.]
 
Crew Reveals His Savvy
Six weeks after taking over as New York City's Schools Chancellor, Dr. Rudy Crew is turning out to be far more street-smart than was widely believed, a man determined to take charge not only of the city's vast school system but of the furious politics that surround it. Significantly, he meets at least once a week with Mayor Giuliani, whose ceaseless criticism had hounded Ramon C. Cortines from office. [B1.]
 
For Some, Famine After Feast
Most of the San Gennaro festival's contractors and employees have not been paid because of a continuing dispute over whether the festival is run by organized crime. The monitor appointed by the city said he hopes to concentrate on paying all debts he deems legitimate later this month. But the Society of San Gennaro, which runs the festival, said that the delays in payment have caused hardship. [B1.]
 
Federal Fight, Local Victims
Anyone compelled to tote up the biggest victims of 1995 might want to consider the thousands of New Yorkers whose lives are still being turned upside down by the budgetary gamesmanship in Washington that has shut down much of the Government for weeks. A special nomination goes to the many small businesses whose livelihoods trickle down the drain because of their dependence on a practically nonexistent Federal apparatus. NYC by Clyde Haberman. [B1.]
 
Weighing a Judge's Past
One of Mayor Giuliani's recent choices for judge flunked out of Brooklyn Law School twice and never earned a law degree but became a lawyer by studying on his own and passing the bar exam. The judge, Robert E. Torres, acknowledged that he had had "academic problems" that brought an end to his two brief stints in law school in the 1970's. But he and his supporters said his ability to overcome those hurdles and forge a legal career for himself spoke well of his abilities and intelligence. [B3.]
 
New Year Starts With Sushi
For many Japanese-Americans, Jan. 1 is a particularly special holiday, one in which they not only welcome the new year but call attention to their heritage with elaborate parties featuring delicacies from Japan. The day is celebrated with a traditional Japanese meal of steaming ozoni (traditional Japanese rice cake soup), makizushi (hand-rolled vegetable sushi), chicken teriyaki and a rainbow-colored gelatin dish called kanten. But for many, it is really about tradition. [B3.]
 
Train Riders Are Stranded
About 1,000 people leaving New York City after ringing in the New Year were stranded for three hours on the Hackensack River Bridge after the New Jersey Transit train they were riding in broke down. [B3.]
 
City Unions Push for Higher Pay
New York City's labor unions are on a collision course with Mayor Giuliani over the issue they have made their No. 1 legislative priority: enacting a law that would require companies with city contracts to pay more than the $4.25-an-hour minimum wage. A coalition of 97 labor unions wants city contractors to pay workers at least $9 an hour and give them health insurance. [B4.]
 
REGION
 
Pataki Plans Austerity Budget
Reducing spending from state taxes for the second consecutive year, Governor Pataki's budget for 1996-97 promises an austerity not seen in Albany since World War II. The budget provides perhaps the clearest view yet of Mr. Pataki's three core political beliefs: that shrinking government and reducing taxes spur economic growth; that lengthening prison sentences deters crime, and that sharply limiting welfare benefits encourages work. [A1.]
 
Race an Issue in Shooting
On a quiet, dark street in Elmont, L.I., a white police officer confronted a black man he thought was acting suspiciously. Minutes later, the black man was dead with nine bullet wounds. That fatal encounter is now at the center of a disagreement between the Nassau County police and friends of the dead man, who said he was killed because of the color of his skin. [B6.]
 
Drive-By Shooting Wounds 4
Just four hours into the New Year, a drive-by shooting in Elizabeth, N.J., left four people wounded. [B6.]
