HEADLINE: A Toll Road in California Offers A High-Tech Answer to Traffic

BYLINE: By B. DRUMMOND AYRES Jr. 

DATELINE: YORBA LINDA, Calif., Jan. 1

 BODY:
The section of the Riverside Freeway that runs past this Orange County community is one of the busiest stretches of highway in the Los Angeles region, which means it is among the busiest stretches of highway anywhere in the world.
Other freeways dump extra traffic onto both ends of the stretch, and the result is an old Southern California tale of road woe: traffic can clog the 10-mile-long bottleneck at any time, and during rush-hour gridlock is a sure thing that can routinely cost commuters an additional 25 to 35 minutes of stop-and-start travel time. 
 But as of last week, the-bumper-to-bumper gridlock on the freeway, also known as State Route 91, began to improve -- for those willing and able to pay for it.
In what transportation specialists say is a bold experiment in traffic management in the state that made traffic management both an art form and an oxymoron, a private company has opened a brand new toll road, the most technologically sophisticated highway ever built anywhere, smack in the median of the old jammed road.
And the company, California Private Transportation, guarantees that any commuter willing to pay the price will have a delay-free, 65-mile-an-hour ride through the bottleneck.
Or your money back.
The price?
An insignificant 25 cents for a one-way trip in the middle of the night, but a hefty, think-twice $2.50 for a trip during the middle of the rush hour, which in the Los Angeles basin actually lasts a good three hours.
The fare is collected electronically, this being the ultimate space-age highway, with no delaying toll lanes or toll booths.
All vehicles using the road must carry a prepurchased windshield transponder that sends a coded signal to a computer whenever the vehicle rolls onto the road. The computer records the identity of the car and the fare in effect at the time of travel. Then, periodically, bills are sent to the driver's home, credit card company or bank.
The small print?
Though the new four-lane road will rely mainly on computerized traffic-monitoring devices and the we'll-bill-you-later toll system to make good on its money-back guarantee to keep traffic moving without delay, its ultimate quality control device will be its toll schedule, posted prominently for all to see on overhead entrance signs.
If at any point over several months, traffic on the road becomes so heavy that delays occur, fares will be raised for that travel hour until some of the overload shifts to the old road, however jammed its eight free lanes might already be.
"Once again California is leading the way for the whole nation in ground transportation," James W. van Loben Sels, director of the California Department of Transportation, said at Wednesday's ribbon-cutting ceremony that opened the new $126 million road, built at the company's expense with state approval.
Gerald S. Pfeffer, the managing director of California Private Transportation, takes a similar, though more business-oriented, view of the road, which stretches through a series of sunny bedroom communities from the Riverside County line on the east to State Route 55 on the west.
"We're another example of private enterprise filling a gap in government services -- the Federal Express of roads," he said on one of his daily inspection tours. "Some drivers need and are willing to pay for guaranteed overnight delivery. Others don't have to get there overnight and are willing to take their chances with a postage stamp. You get what you pay for, the great American way."
But some questions have been raised by environmentalists and growth control advocates about whether adding still more highway capacity is the right approach to the commuting problems of California or the nation. And here and there, some defenders of the needy have raised questions about whether the new road might "price the poor out of the fast lane."
Mr. Pfeffer counters that highways cannot be ignored as part of the transportation mix, and that his privately built and operated road, while not free, lightens not only the tax load on poor citizens but also the traffic load on the jammed parallel road that their economic status might force them to use.
"What could be fairer or more American?" he argued. "Anyway, most toll roads in this country don't offer drivers a genuine alternative, just yards away."
He noted that like many major American highways, especially California highways, the Riverside Freeway, already clogged with 270,000 vehicles daily, anticipates a 50 percent increase in traffic over the next 15 years. At the same time, he pointed out, taxpayers are demanding better roads but increasingly are resisting paying for them, just as the Federal Government is beginning to cut back on construction aid.
"We see the private toll road making a comeback in this country," Mr. Pfeffer said.
"Transportation departments in Virginia, Minnesota, Texas and Washington State already are talking about adopting our concept and other variations."
In fact, some private toll roads have recently been completed in other areas of the county, including one in Northern Virginia. But they are mainly the traditional type of toll road, designed to stretch an old road to a new point; they do not use parallel lanes to compete for the old road's jammed-up traffic.
Besides being the first private toll road to compete with an adjacent free public road, the new road here is also the world's first fully automated toll road, relying not just on transponders to collect fares but on other space-age devices to guarantee users a smooth, safe ride.
Midway along the road, engineers and safety officials sit in a darkened situation room, 24 hours a day, monitoring movement on every inch of the road with remote television cameras, as well as various combinations of lasers and computers, to alert the authorities to problems.
The vehicle windshield transponders required of all travelers are about the size of a deck of cards and can be obtained by mail or at toll road offices by putting down a $40 deposit that will be credited toward the bill. Whenever $30 in tolls has been rung up, bills go out.
And what if a vehicle without a transponder enters the road?
The sensors note that and, depending on availability, a highway patrol car may give chase -- and then a ticket or a warning. But if no patrol car is immediately available, an overhead television camera, which constantly records an image of all cars entering the highway, separates out a special shot of the violator, including an enhanced close-up of the rear license plate.
A warning or a ticket is then mailed to the vehicle's owner, with fines starting at $100 for the first intentional violation and rising to $300 or more for multiple violations.
Standing in line here at a newly opened tollway office that was taking orders for transponders, Bonnie Lutz was almost joyful about the prospect of driving the new road.
"For years," she said, "I've spent the better part of every Friday and Sunday afternoon fighting that old highway, losing precious time that I could spend with my family at our mountain place. And all during the week, Chris, my husband, fights it, losing time, and money, because he's a salesman. Thirty dollars in tolls a week? Chris can more than make that up after this with the extra sales he'll have time to fit in."

HEADLINE: OUTLOOK '96: MARKETS AND INVESTING;
Overseas Markets Expected to Improve

BYLINE: By PETER TRUELL 

 BODY:
OVERSEAS markets are beginning to perk up and may offer better opportunities in 1996 than they did last year, several market analysts say. They argue that the favorable trends in American markets are spreading overseas.
"The factors which have made U.S. markets do well will gradually apply to foreign investments that are in good growth areas," said David R. Malpass, director for international economics at Bear, Stearns & Company. Mr. Malpass said he believed that Southeast Asia -- especially Singapore and Hong Kong -- would particularly benefit. 
 Expected declines in interest rates overseas, particularly in Europe and Japan, should bolster overseas markets, as they have over the last year in the United States. Stock markets love the prospect of cheaper money, which tends to persuade investors to favor stocks over bonds and which also reduces costs for investors who buy stocks with borrowed funds.
"Deflationary pressures roam throughout most of the developed world and downward pressures on money rates and bond yields should persist," said Charles I. Clough Jr., chief investment strategist at Merrill Lynch & Company, whose firm recently forecast that emerging markets in Latin America, the Asia-Pacific region and Europe would continue to recover in 1996 from their recently depressed positions.
Economic growth is expected to remain particularly strong in Southeast Asia, helping equity markets there.
Nicholas Kwan, senior economist in Merrill Lynch's Asian Research Group, forecasts average economic growth in 1996 of 7.4 percent for the 10 major Asian economies, excluding Japan, compared with 7.9 percent in 1995.
Even Japan, which has been in the doldrums for more than three years, looks set to pick up. The Bank of Japan "has stepped on the gas" as Grant's Interest Rate Observer, a market newsletter, wrote recently, drawing attention to the 16.4 percent growth in the assets of the central bank in November.
This reflationary push has already helped to revive Japanese bank stocks and is likely to help push the economy to grow faster. The Nikkei 225 stock index recovered in recent months, closing at 19,868.15 at year-end. This turnaround, from a low of 14,484.41 in July, brings the index roughly back to its level of 19,723.06 at the end of 1994.
But some are cautious on the outlook for Japanese stocks. "It's hard to read," Mr. Malpass said, "Each year for the last four years, people have been positive at this time of year," and their expectations have not been met. "This year might be different," he added, "because of the new central bank policy."
And in Europe, there are some big risks and uncertainties to make investors hesitate. The countries of the European Union have yet to organize, and agree on, their program for proposed monetary union. And the size of fiscal deficits are likely to inhibit economic growth, although prospective interest rate cuts should buoy equity markets. The London stock market has already experienced some strong growth in 1995. In terms of dollars, the Financial Times index of 100 leading shares rose 19.2 percent for the year, to 3,689.30, its high for the year.
Now it may be the turn of markets on the Continent. Gary A. Dugan, European strategist for J. P. Morgan Securities Ltd., said he liked the interest rate environment on the Continent. "We are talking about interest rates coming down quite aggressively," he said, "by as much as two percentage points to three percentage points, in Spain, Italy and Sweden, led by the Germans cutting their rates." He added that a widening spread between short- and long-term interest rates in several European countries should help bank profits, making banks good investments in the next few months.
The DAX stock market index in Germany has already risen in response to recent cuts in interest rates. That index closed at 2,253.88 at the end of the year, up substantially from levels close to 1,900 in March. The CAC 40 share index in France, depressed by recent nationwide strikes, did not provide significant gains in 1995. At year-end, the index was at 1,871.97, about 150 points above the year low of 1,721.14, and down from its high for the year of 2,017.27 on May 12.
LATIN America has already begun to rebound from the Mexican crisis of a year ago. Argentina and Brazil are expected to emerge from recession in the first few months of 1996. Argentina and Mexico, where output declined in 1995, will recover in 1996 and 1997, according to J. P. Morgan's emerging markets economic outlook.
Stock market indexes in Latin America often rise rapidly as stock prices keep pace with local inflation. The chief stock market index in Mexico reached a high for the year of 2,747.46 on Dec. 20 and closed at 2,778.47 at year-end, nearly doubling in value from its 1995 low of 1,447.52 on Feb. 27. Indeed, one caveat for Mexico may be that the index is now just short of the record high reached in the fall of 1994. Argentina and Brazil also saw their stock markets rise late in the year in anticipation of the benefits of a resumption of economic growth. Argentina's General index finished the year at 16,237.81, up substantially from a March 9 low for the year of 9,831.09, but still down from its level in early January when the index touched 16,531.1. TheBovespa index in Brazil rallied late in the year to levels over 42,000, ending the year at 42,990.02, almost twice its level in March.
But many analysts, while seeing the opportunities abroad, said that it would still be difficult to move American investors to look overseas.
Why should American investors want to exchange their dollars for overseas equities priced in foreign currencies when the dollar is expected to strengthen, thus cutting into their gains in dollar terms?
"The U.S. will provide the hurdle," Mr. Malpass said. "It will be the toughest benchmark for international investors."

HEADLINE: Unions Push for Higher Minimum Wage on New York City Contracts

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

 BODY:
New York City's labor unions are on a collision course with Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani over the issue they have made their No. 1 legislative priority: enacting a law that would require companies with city contracts to pay more than the $4.25-an-hour minimum wage.
A coalition of 97 labor unions is pushing the City Council to approve one of two similar bills that would obligate city contractors to pay workers at least $9 an hour and provide health insurance. 
 Supporters of the idea assert that the city has a moral obligation to insure that all people working under city contracts receive what they call a living wage -- one that lifts them above the poverty line and provides enough money so they do not need welfare, food stamps and housing subsidies to get by.
"This living-wage legislation is at the top of our agenda," said Brian McLaughlin, the new president of the New York City Central Labor Council, the union coalition that he is seeking to re-establish as a major force in city politics. "We're seeing city workers being replaced with private-sector people who make the minimum wage or just a little more and receive no protection for health care."
The Giuliani administration is vigorously fighting the legislation, saying it will raise city labor costs $500 million to $750 million a year, forcing it to make further budget cuts.
"We're in very difficult fiscal times, and it's critical that the city make the most of every tax dollar that it spends," said Richard Schwartz, a senior adviser to the Mayor. "This would make the least of every tax dollar and translate into massive service reductions that hurt precisely the kinds of people the bill's proponents claim they are trying to help."
The City Council Speaker, Peter F. Vallone, who holds great sway over every piece of legislation the Council considers, said he supported the idea but had reservations about the ultimate cost of the proposal and was trying to negotiate a compromise bill. One of the bills under consideration has the support of a majority of the Council.
In lobbying for the bill, New York's unions have embraced a strategy that labor is pursuing around the nation as John J. Sweeney, the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s new president, has hammered home the theme of giving America a raise.
Convinced that the Republican-led Congress will not raise the Federal minimum wage unions are pushing state legislatures to enact higher state minimum wages and pressing city councils like New York's to approve "living wage" laws. Last summer, Baltimore's City Council enacted a law requiring that city contractors pay workers at least $6.60 an hour, while the City Council in Jersey City is debating a bill that would force city contractors to pay $12.10 an hour.
According to the Giuliani administration, the city will spend $5.6 billion this year on contracts for goods and services. (The figure does not include construction contracts; state law requires that the city pay construction workers union scale.)
City officials say they do not know exactly how many people work under those contracts, although some supporters of the wage proposal estimate that it would cover at least 50,000 people. About a quarter of them, labor leaders say, make less than $6 an hour as custodians, security guards and clerical workers, among other jobs.
Labor leaders are confident that some version of the living-wage legislation will be approved because 29 of the City Council's 51 members co-sponsored the original version of the bill. That bill, introduced by Sal F. Albanese of Brooklyn, calls for paying $12.10 an hour to private-sector workers employed under city contracts. A newer version, sponsored by Kathryn E. Freed of Manhattan, would set the wage at about $9 an hour and require contractors to provide health insurance.
Mr. Albanese and Ms. Freed said that the city paid contractors an average of $11 an employee an hour, while the contractors often paid their workers $5 or less per hour.
"Some city contractors pay so little that their workers need food stamps or housing subsidies," Ms. Freed said. "Why should we, the taxpayers, subsidize employers who pay less than subsistence wages?"
The Albanese and Freed bills have ground slowly forward since the summer. Hearings have been held, but Mr. Vallone has not put either bill on a fast track. But in recent weeks, the city's labor unions and a coalition of community groups led by the Rev. Johnny Ray Youngblood, pastor of St. Paul's Community Baptist Church in East New York, Brooklyn, have mounted a major campaign to push the bill forward.
"People who work full time should not remain mired in poverty," said Michael Gecan, the chief lobbyist for the community coalition. "If you pay workers a living wage, they'll be able to buy food, get off public assistance, invest in their families' education, buy homes. That will help reknit the fabric of the city."
A major snag is that Mr. Vallone said he was uncomfortable with the Albanese and Freed bills because they might cost too much. He is negotiating a scaled-down version that might, for instance, require the city to give preference to contractors that offer health insurance. Mr. Vallone is also considering requiring contractors to a pay a minimum percentage of the contract amount as wages -- perhaps 50 to 60 percent.
"I have to think that a living-wage bill is a fascinating idea," Mr. Vallone said. "I wish we could do it and keep it balanced. A living-wage bill would be very helpful to get people off of welfare. But there are also legitimate concerns that you might be pushing people out of work. I'll support anything that works and that's balanced."
Labor leaders and Council members predict that the Mayor will veto any version the Council passes.
Criticizing the bill, Mr. Schwartz, the Mayor's adviser, said, "It would send out a very negative message about New York City, which is that we want to still try to administer a centralized, government-regulated economy even though the Berlin Wall fell years ago."
Mr. Schwartz said that the proposals before the City Council could push up wages around the city, negating the millions of dollars in savings that he said Mr. Giuliani had achieved by hiring private contractors to deliver city services.
Mr. Schwartz also said that the bill's supporters had exaggerated how many people working under city contracts received government aid.
But Mr. McLaughlin, the labor leader, said the savings the administration pointed to in its privatization efforts were illusory.
"Taxpayers save very little when the city contracts out services," he said. "And the economy suffers very much because you replace middle-income consumers with poor workers who need public subsidies."

HEADLINE: Remote Border Crossing Turning to Remote Control

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE 

DATELINE: SCOBEY, Mont., Dec. 27

 BODY:
From the air, the United States' "silent" border is also invisible. In a vast prairie landscape, Canadian and American wheat fields stretch smoothly to each nation's edge.
But, in contradiction of a popular image of the world's longest open frontier, the Canadian-American border invisibly deforms the rural communities it courses through. 
 Like a cuckoo-clock Berlin wall, the steel border gates just outside of Scobey drop at 6 P.M., forcing cross-border visitors who tarry over dinner to pay the penalty: a 120-mile drive to and from Raymond, Mont., the nearest 24-hour border crossing. For generations it has been thus: a Christmas dinner invitation declined, a wedding reception left awkwardly early, a Canadian cousin's curling match missed.
"Our kids and grandkids are growing up without socializing," Jim Crandell, a hotel owner here, said of the lack of contact between the American and Canadian branches of his family. "It's really difficult if there is a wedding or a death in the family. We have a business back here we can't leave overnight."
In addition to the social connections, forged through marriage, the United States and Canada have the world's largest trading relationship. Trade between the countries is estimated at $300 billion for 1995.
"One hundred percent of the net new trade between the U.S. and Canada is occurring between the Western provinces and Western states," said Philip M. Burgess, co-author with Michael Kelly of a new statistical book, "Profile of Western North America."
"What you have along the length of the western border is a cross-border community developing," said Mr. Burgess, who is president of the Center for the New West, a study group based in Denver.
In recognition of the strong and growing economic ties between the countries, President Clinton and Prime Minister Jean Chretien of Canada signed an accord last February in an effort to ease border crossings and increase air travel between the two countries. And so on Jan. 17 glasnost will come to the prairies in the form of video cameras, personal identification numbers and a computerized voice-recognition system.
Billed as the world's first voice-activated border crossing, this border post will test an electronic system that will allow registered local residents to cross back and forth 24 hours a day. If successful, the system could be expanded later this decade to the roughly one-third of the 113 United States-Canada crossings that are not 24-hour posts. Dotting the nearly 3,000-mile border, these isolated posts stretch from Washington State to eastern New York State to rural Maine.
Here in this northern town, where cars are driven on snow-covered streets four months out of the year, vehicles pass through two checkpoints -- an American one and a Canadian one -- every time they cross the boundary. In a measure of Scobey's remoteness, the village is 340 miles by road from Billings, Montana's largest city -- the equivalent of driving from New York City to Richmond.
"It's like a prayer that's been answered," said Edgar Richardson, a wheat farmer here who has been fighting the social deformities caused by the border for most of his 68 years. "This is like a dream come true for our two communities. We have been trying to get a 24-hour post for over 30 years."
To hear people around here tell it, human activity does not coincide with the hours set by Ottawa and Washington: 8 A.M. to 9 P.M. during the summer, and 9 A.M. to 6 P.M. during the rest of the year. Both Governments have long maintained that the low level of international traffic through here does not warrant staffing the crossing around the clock.
"On Saturday, a lady from here is marrying a fellow from Canada," said Gary Leibrand, who owns a plumbing and electrical supply store on Main Street. "A lot of the guests are going to have to stay overnight, whether they like it or not."
Concerts in the summer, rodeos in the fall and hockey games in the winter can involve overnight stays for visitors from Scobey or its Canadian neighbor, Coronach. In Scobey, a railhead town of 1,100, the struggling movie theater is cut off from a potential Canadian audience.
"Our daughter came here with some friends for a country-western show last August -- and they had to drive all the way around to get home," Chris Gold, a visiting Canadian elementary school teacher, said of the 120-mile detour the concertgoers took at 3 A.M.
On spring mornings, the best time for American farmers to spray herbicide on their Canadian wheat fields is well before the gates open. On summer evenings, when it stays light here until 10 P.M., the best time to catch walleyes in a Canadian reservoir is around the time the gate is closing. On a warm fall day, the best time to run a wheat harvesting combine can be in the late evening.
Over the years, several men who raced to the border at gate-closing time have been killed in car crashes.
"There shouldn't be a border anyhow," said Chris Gold's husband, David. "It's a stupid thing."
With last February's accord, life should change for the Golds and others in the cross-border community. Less than a year after that accord, there are already an additional 100 flights between Canada and the United States. And on the ground, both countries are experimenting with ways to ease the crossings.
"We want to increase air service, we want to increase rail service," Gov. Marc Racicot of Montana said in an interview.
To catch people who try to cross the border illegally, the United States Border Patrol maintains a network of movement sensors and surveys the border regularly with four-wheel-drive vehicles and airplanes.
"Our goal is a hassle-free border for honest travelers and businesses, and a brick wall for those who try to smuggle or break other laws at this border," Canada's Minister of National Revenue, David Anderson, said last summer of Canada's participation in the joint effort.
On the American side, the effort comes down to a sophisticated remote-controlled camera that can sweep, tilt and zoom in temperatures ranging from last week's 58 degrees below zero to last summer's 100 degrees.
"We were joking that if we use hand geometry, the hands would stick to the metal plate -- and that would not be very friendly," said Robert A. Mocny, the Immigration and Naturalization Service official in charge of developing alternative inspection technology. Used on some immigration lanes at Newark and John F. Kennedy International Airports, hand geometry computers measure the size of the right hand of a frequent international traveler as a means of rapid identification.
Today, as fresh snow sparkled in fields of yellow wheat stubble, David F. Kueber, the immigration service inspector stationed here, explained the newly installed system. During off hours in Scobey, an inspector at Raymond will monitor traffic through the remote-controlled camera. Scobey was chosen as a test site because of the virtual absence of border crime here.
To participate in the program, residents must apply for a wallet-sized pass card. After approval, cardholders record on a border post computer a secret phrase and a four-digit number. On approaching the crossing, the cardholder picks up a gate telephone, punches in the secret number, and then utters the secret phrase, a high-tech version of "open sesame."
If the computer does not recognize the voice, the driver can talk to the immigration inspector in Raymond by telephone. Using the camera, the inspector can also scan the car to verify that all passengers have cards. Drivers who take undocumented aliens across the border run the risk of losing their cards and their vehicles.
From both sides of the border, only praise is heard of the program.
"All the feedback I get is positive," said Rod Tande, manager of KCGM, a local radio station that bills itself as "the voice of the prairie."
Referring to Scobey's pioneering role in the electronic border experiment, Mr. Tande said, "We are tickled pink."

GRAPHIC: Photo: At the border crossing in Scobey, Mont., an electronic system will permit some people to cross when the station is closed. David F. Kueber, an Immigration and Naturalization inspector, showed the system. (Larry Mayer for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Clinton the Conciliator Finds His Line in Sand

SERIES: THE CONTENDERS -- Eighth article of a series.

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL and TODD S. PURDUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 30

 BODY:
Bill Clinton had been ceding ground and seeking compromise for months, by temperament always the conciliator. But one day in early November, the President spelled out the limits of accommodation.
Closeted in the Oval Office with the leaders of Congress, Mr. Clinton told the Republicans that he would give them much of their budget, aides said. To win everything, the President said, pointing at the dark oak antique that Queen Victoria gave to Rutherford B. Hayes, they would have to elect someone else to sit at that desk. 
 It was a moment that crystalized the political philosophy that Mr. Clinton has embraced in the year of the Republican ascendancy.
Hoping to erode the rationale of any Republican challenger in 1996, he has steadily retreated to embrace his rivals' goal of balancing the Federal budget in seven years. This has meant accepting a level of cuts in domestic spending that Mr. Clinton's own advisers had repeatedly denounced as unthinkable.
But he has added Democratic grace notes and defended the role of Government by standing firm against certain Republican proposals for savings in programs for education, environmental protection and the Great Society health insurance plans, Medicare and Medicaid.
This balancing act has emerged across months in which Mr. Clinton has once again tried to reinvent himself -- refining, explaining, defending and amending his record of the past three years. By showing resolve this autumn on his handful of chosen issues, and by repeatedly characterizing the budget debate as a struggle over American values, the President, Democratic strategists say, has finally begun to change the impression that he stands for little.
"With the public, the great strength right now is that he is seen as fighting for things they believe in," said Mark Mellman, a Democratic political consultant.
In foreign policy as well, after months of embarrassing missteps, Mr. Clinton has staked out his own ground, coupling diplomacy with the threat of force to return Jean-Bertrand Aristide to Haiti and to push the Balkan leaders to reach a peace accord in their four-year-old war.
Indeed, after a tumultuous year that brought him from the low point of the Republican sweep of Congress to some of the highest popularity ratings of his Presidency, Mr. Clinton now enters the election year on the rebound, gearing up for what will most likely be the last and one of the most difficult campaigns of his life.
And yet he will run on the record of a very different Presidency than he and his supporters seemed to imagine when the man from Hope, the youngest President since John F. Kennedy, came into office speaking of generational and social change.
At first, Mr. Clinton embraced an activism that culminated in 1994 in his failed effort to enact the most ambitious social engineering in decades: the extension of health insurance coverage to all Americans.
Now, he has settled into a more rhetorical Presidency, trying to exploit his bully pulpit to keep an activist Republican Congress from dismantling Democratic social programs that have been embedded in the political landscape for decades.
The Vietnam-era protester who once seemed nonplused by foreign policy now takes obvious solace in his role as commander in chief and peacemaker in hot spots from Haiti to Northern Ireland to the Balkans.
But in reasserting United States leadership, he has dispatched 20,000 American troops to Bosnia in a peacekeeping mission that conventional political wisdom holds could well haunt him in an election year.
Mr. Clinton's political ratings are among the highest of his Presidency, as the public judges the President against a Republican Congress that it now thinks may be going too far in its quest to scale back the Federal Government. Mr. Clinton's Republican rivals have so far failed to capture the public imagination. And a President and White House team that have always thrived on campaigning seem newly energized and ready for the fight.
And yet, Mr. Clinton remains a figure of galvanizing public controversy, intensely unpopular with segments of the electorate.
Questions linger among voters about what he stands for. And the Republicans, through months of hearings into the Whitewater real estate deal, have worked to keep up doubts about the probity of Mr. Clinton and his wife, Hillary.
All this uncertainty hangs over the President's quest for a second term.
Who would Mr. Clinton, the consummate campaigner, be if freed from the burden and the adrenaline rush of another election? And would he change his agenda again if Democrats were to regain control of either or both chambers of Congress?
The Republicans paint him as a man without convictions, and even some of his disillusioned liberal supporters say Mr. Clinton is a creature of whatever political milieu he swims in. "Because he's a master of empathy, he's defined by his environment," one longtime supporter said. "He can't escape it. He doesn't soar above it."
Mr. Clinton declined to be interviewed for this article. His spokesman, Michael D. McCurry, said: "This is not a moment for discussion about his political candidacy. It's a moment for working on budget issues."
But his advisers say Mr. Clinton has never been as malleable as he has been portrayed. "Who's the pollster on Nafta, the Mexican loan guarantee, on Bosnia?" asked James Carville, one of Mr. Clinton's campaign strategists in 1992. "Let's find this man and get our money back. You can't follow the polls and also do the unpopular thing."
Mr. Clinton's aides say the President has gone through a searing education in office, that he has come to curb his intellectual tendency to roam. Shocked by the repudiation of the 1994 election, they say, he became determined to hew to the centrist course he once promised.
 
Nontraditional Democrat
Many Contradictions Instead of a Theme
From the moment he began his quest for the Presidency, Mr. Clinton struggled to forge an identity as a nontraditional New Democrat.
But his search for what moderate Democrats like to call a third way has often led in contradictory directions instead of building into an overarching theme. This lack of coherence combined with the early abandonment of nominees like Zoe Baird and Lani Guinier in the face of opposition quickly earned Mr. Clinton a reputation for vacillation.
During the Democratic primaries of 1992, Mr. Clinton promised a middle-class tax cut. But in his first year in office he abandoned that pledge to seek instead an economic stimulus package of investments, and to emphasize deficit reduction.
The stimulus package quickly died in Congress, but months later Mr. Clinton passed his deficit reduction plan, including increases in taxes primarily for the rich, with no Republican votes. Then he took on organized labor, Congressional Democrats and some of his own top advisers by pushing the North American Free Trade Agreement through a reluctant Congress.
These initiatives were hardly examples of liberal orthodoxy, and, in fact, Mr. Clinton achieved them by bucking prevailing tides.
But their success was overshadowed when Mr. Clinton and his wife, Hillary, gave an different cast to his Presidency with the unsuccessful bid for universal health care.
From the start, some inside the Administration argued that welfare policy should come before health care, that Mr. Clinton's 1992 pledge to "end welfare as we know it" was the signature issue that had drawn back the Reagan Democrats to the party. But Mr. Clinton not only moved forward with health care, he also put Mrs. Clinton in charge in an unprecedented and risky expansion of the role of the First Lady.
For months, a task force led by Mrs. Clinton drafted the plan in secret, producing a 240,000-word bill and alienating crucial Democrats and interest groups. Even so, there was a moment when Republican Congressional leaders like Senator Bob Dole of Kansas endorsed the Administration's broad goal, and seemed willing to compromise.
But the White House held out for a whole loaf while opposition built, and Republicans and interest groups from insurance to small business pilloried the measure as the very symbol of big government run amok. By September 1994, it was dead.
Mr. Clinton had already styled his Presidency as an exercise in domestic policy-making, and health care became the issue that most defined that effort and consumed his energy and public attention. He spoke constantly of the need to extend coverage to the tens of millions of Americans without it.
So when the effort failed, it became an emblem of the potential failure of his entire Presidency before his term was even half over. Republicans leaped at the chance to cast public unease about the policy as far broader distaste about the whole notion of Federal activism, and rode the issue into control of Congress. Now, for all his defense of Medicare, Mr. Clinton seems prepared to eventually endorse a budget plan that makes virtually no stab at all at extending coverage.
When Mr. Clinton belatedly unveiled a welfare plan to make good on his campaign pledge, it envisioned Government jobs for welfare recipients willing but unable to find work. This gave a liberal tinge to his campaign vow to limit welfare recipients to two years of benefits.
After the repudiation of the 1994 midterm elections, Mr. Clinton pivoted once again.
 
A Series of Apologies
Second-Guessing Puzzles Supporters
In months of soul-searching, consultations with historians and most important, late-night conversations with Dick Morris, the political strategist with whom he has had a relationship across his career, Mr. Clinton grew certain that he had allowed himself to become the captive of the Democratic barons of Congress.
So he returned to the middle-class tax cut and in June, causing confusion in the White House ranks, decided to embrace the Republican goal of a balanced budget. Mr. Clinton also repudiated elements of his own record. At a Texas fund-raising dinner in October, he appeared to have second thoughts about the deficit reduction package that was one if his achievements of 1993.
"There's probably people in this room still mad at me about that budget because you think I raised your taxes too much," he said. "Well, it might surprise you to know that I think I raised them too much, too." He blamed the Congress for forcing his hand, prompting an enraged response from Democrats who had, in fact, fought for fewer taxes and backed him reluctantly.
Weeks later, the President told the neo-conservative author Ben Wattenberg that his welfare plan of 1994 was too lenient. And while Mr. Clinton now plans to veto a Republican welfare bill because of cuts in assistance to disabled children and in welfare recipients' entitlement to Medicaid, his aides say he may yet sign off on a compromise plan that ends the 60-year-old guarantee of Federal aid for poor women and children.
Mr. Clinton's second-guessing of himself has been puzzling to supporters. "If you ask me, he doesn't have a damn thing to apologize for," said Paul Begala, one of Mr. Clinton's 1992 campaign strategists.
Some of the apologizing was tactical. Under Mr. Morris's tutelage in 1982, Mr. Clinton apologized for much of his record as governor when he came back from defeat in 1980 to win a new term.
It is also true that Mr. Clinton has always been quick to parse his own problems in public, whether in sharing his childhood family traumas, or musing aloud on whether the nation might be in a "funk."
But it is clear that voters find this tendency unsettling, as the President himself acknowledged in an interview with People magazine on the perils of public introspection, even as he indulged in yet another burst of it.
"Al Gore gave me some great advice," Mr. Clinton said. "He may kill me for this -- but he said, 'You can analyze a problem and calculate all of its aspects, but you also can feel what is right about a course of action. The American people pay you to think, but they want to know how you feel. And you make a big mistake if you spend too much time letting them see how you think rather than letting them know how you feel on what's right or wrong.' "
And so Mr. Clinton deliberately set out this year to take stands on moral and social issues. He discovered the power of Presidential oratory and delivered a series of speeches, with topics ranging across the field of social and cultural issues that the Republicans have sought to make their own, from school prayer to violence in the media, to affirmative action. In each case, he sought to reach across sharp political dividing lines by telling Americans they could find "common ground."
Mr. Clinton has also used a string of foreign policy successes to portray himself as a peacemaker.
This pose is intended to send a subliminal message to Mr. Clinton's doubters that the very character traits that worry them -- Mr. Clinton's desire to conciliate, his constant compromising -- can be the core components of an effective leadership style when combined with a willingness to use force.
His aides say Mr. Clinton has become more comfortable with his role as commander in chief since the early days when he backed away from talk about employing air strikes in the war in Bosnia and brought the U.S.S. Harlan County, which had been sent on a mission to pave the way for the return of Mr. Aristide, back from Haiti when armed thugs appeared on the docks.
But even Mr. Clinton's recent tentative success in the Balkans came after months of fitful temporizing and avoidance. Only after limited air strikes prompted hostage-taking and the prospect of a NATO withdrawal that would have forced Washington to send troops, did the President push for strikes in reprisal.
 
Crucial Challenges
Bosnia, Whitewater And Economy Loom
For now Mr. Clinton's strategy of co-opting Republican issues like the balanced budget while fighting to preserve his own priorities on shrinking turf, has borne enough fruit that Republican strategists worry openly about the difficulty of finding a compelling rationale for a campaign against him.
"There's some uncertainty among Republicans about how to go after Clinton," said Bill Kristol, the Republican theoretician who was chief of staff to Vice President Dan Quayle. "It's not like 1994, when he had proposed this horrifying health care plan and ludicrous crime bill and tax increase and one could pose to the country a clear choice against big government liberalism."
At the same time, important nods to liberals -- from proposing an increase in the minimum wage, to making a stand on Medicare, to insisting on maintaining affirmative action programs in the face of calls to scale them back -- have staved off a challenge from the left.
Mr. Clinton has succeeded so well at this task that he now appears certain not to face a fight for the nomination -- an unusual occurrence in the fractious Democratic Party.
But crucial challenges persist. Mr. Clinton is at last creeping up to a 50 percent job approval rating in public opinion polls, but throughout his term he has been hard pressed to expand his electoral base beyond the 43 percent that was enough to let him win in a three-way race in 1992, yet smaller than the vote that Michael S. Dukakis lost with in 1988.
Many of the President's own aides are frank about the difficulty of piecing together an electoral college majority and holding on to the big industrial states he needs -- like Michigan, Ohio, Pennsylvania, New Jersey -- especially in a two-way race.
"If you just look at the map, we can't win," one aide said on the condition of anonymity, overstating the case just a bit for effect.
A year is a lifetime in politics, and pitfalls loom, whether they be Bosnia, Whitewater or the state of the economy. Will there or won't there be a budget agreement and who will the public consider the victor?
As it has been from the beginning of his political career, Mr. Clinton's biggest vulnerability may yet be the public's lingering unease about who he is and what he stands for.
In recent polls, his overall unfavorable ratings among the public have declined a bit from their peak at the time of the Republican Congressional victories a year ago. But they still remain in precarious balance with his favorable ratings, with 44 percent in the most recent New York Times/ CBS News Poll this month expressing a favorable view to 37 percent with an unfavorable view.
"This is the central paradox of Clinton," said Michael Beschloss, a historian of modern politics. "One side is this enormously supple, malleable, versatile, mercurial political figure who is able to make and remake and remake himself in order to benefit from changing political situations and environments."
He continued, "The other side of it is that this very suppleness, and his willingness to change his rhetoric and his tactics -- as helpful as they are in restoring his political fortunes -- they undercut his ability to establish a following for himself among the American people and claim a mandate for a second term."
The President's own aides confess they are unsure what shape a second term would take, whether Mr. Clinton would be buoyed by the election of more Democrats to Congress and feel free to expand his priorities again, or whether he would remain an accommodator. So far, he has fallen short of the promise of 1992, which was that he could expand his plurality, with backing from Ross Perot's supporters and Republicans, into a moderate, centrist coalition that could govern for years to come.
Should he win, Mr. Clinton would become the first Democrat since Franklin D. Roosevelt to win two full terms in the White House, breaking the quarter-century pattern of Republican dominance in Presidential politics. Even if he wins a second term, Mr. Clinton will still become the youngest former President since Theodore Roosevelt, and doubtless some kind of restless presence on the political scene for years to come.
"Most Presidents, when they complete their second term, retire and write books," mused Skip Rutherford, a friend of Mr. Clinton's. "Bill Clinton may write books but I don't think he'll retire. I can't see him sitting on a front porch somewhere."

". . . And a Chronology of His Term"
 
1993
 Jan. 29 -- Mr. Clinton temporarily suspends the discharge of homosexuals from the military.
 Feb. 11 -- Mr. Clinton nominates Janet Reno as Attorney General, after Zoe Baird and Judge Kimba M. Wood withdraw.
 April 3 -- Mr. Clinton and Russian President Boris Yeltsin have their first meeting.
 April 19 -- After a 51-day standoff, about 80 members of the Branch Davidian cult die in a fire that started as Federal agents assaulted their compound in Waco, Texas.
 May 19 -- The White House fires the seven-person staff of the travel office alleging shoddy accounting practices, mismanagement and possible overbilling.
 July 19 -- Mr. Clinton announces that homosexuals can serve in the military, but only if they do not engage in homosexual behavior and remain quiet about their sexual identity.
 July 20 -- Vincent Foster, Jr., Mr. Clinton's deputy legal counsel, commits suicide.
 Aug.5-6 -- Congress passes Mr. Clinton's budget plan. The plan cuts spending, increases taxes and reduces Federal budget deficits through 1998 by a total of $496 billion.
 Sept. 13 -- Israel and the Palestine Liberation Organization sign a peace accord on the White House lawn.
 Sept. 22 -- Mr. Clinton unveils his health-care reform proposals to Congress.
 Oct. 3 -- Mr. Clinton orders additional troops to Somalia following a battle in which 18 Americans die.
 Nov. 17 and 20 -- Congress passes legislation to implement the North American Free Trade Agreement.
 
1994
 Jan. 20 -- A independent counsel is named to investigate the Clintons' personal and political finances and their businessess dealings in the 1980's, including their role in the Whitewater Development Corporation.
 Jan. 25 -- Mr. Clinton delivers his first State of the Union address, promising a forceful effort to enact health care reform.
 June 27 -- Mr. Clinton announces an extensive White House staff shake-up. He removes Thomas F. McLarty as chief of staff and replaces him with Leon E. Panetta, the budget director.
 Aug. 26 -- Congressional leaders and the White House all but concede that health care reform is dead for the year.
 Sept. 19 -- After a last-minute agreement averts an invasion, United States troops peacefully enter Haiti to enforce the return of the exiled President, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide.
 Oct. 7 -- Mr. Clinton announces that Navy and Marine forces will be deployed to the Persian Gulf area in response to a buildup of Iraqi troops along its border with Kuwait.
 Oct. 21 -- The United States and North Korea sign an agreement requiring that North Korea dismantle its nuclear-development program.
 Nov. 8 -- Congressional elections. Republicans take over the House and Senate for the first time in 40 years.
 Dec. 6 -- Webster L. Hubbell, the former Associate Attorney General and the man President Clinton had described as his closest friend, pleads guilty to stealing hundreds of thousands of dollars from his former law firm.
Dec. 8 -- Mr. Clinton signs a sweeping global tariff-cutting trade pact approved by Congress.
 
1995
 Jan. 31 -- Mr. Clinton sidesteps Congress and uses his own emergency authority to lend up to $20 billion to Mexico to keep it from defaulting on Government-issued bonds.
 Feb. 2 -- Mr. Clinton chooses Dr. Henry W. Foster Jr. as Surgeon General to replace Dr. Joycelyn Elders, who was forced to resign in December.
 Feb. 6 -- Mr. Clinton sends to Congress his $1.6 trillion budget plan for fiscal year 1996. It calls for modest spending cuts, some tax relief and $200 million deficits through the end of the decade.
 March 23 -- Mr. Clinton defends the concept of affirmative action and outlines plans to review existing Federal programs.
 April 19 -- A Federal building in Oklahoma City is bombed, killing XX.
 June 13 Mr. Clinton presents a new budget proposal, that calls balancing the budget in 10 years.
 June 22 -- Dr. Foster's nomination as Surgeon General dies when Senate Democrats fail for a second time to end a Republican filibuster.
 June 29 -- Congress passes a budget resolution that promises to balance the budget in seven years by cuts in social programs, Medicare and Medicaid while cutting taxes by $245 billion.
 July 19 -- Mr. Clinton offers a vigorous reaffirmation of the goals and results of affirmative action saying it has been good for America.
 Oct. 19 -- Mr. Clinton says that the Republican plan to balance the budget by 2002 is an attainable goal, but adds that cuts in education, health and environmental programs must be scaled back to ensure his cooperation.
 Nov. 14 -- The Federal Government suspends "non-essential services". An estimated 800,000 Federal workers are furloughed after Mr. Clinton and Congress cannot agree on an interim spending measure.
 Nov. 19 -- Congress and the White House agree on a stopgap spending measure that re-opens government operations through Dec. 15.
 Nov. 21 -- The presidents of three rival Balkan states initial an agreement a peace agreement that ends nearly four years of war in Bosnia.
 Dec. 16 -- After weeks of fruitless negoations on a balanced budget, portions of the Government shut down for the second time. (pg. C34)

HEADLINE: Saudi Crown Prince to Take Over While King Rests

BYLINE: By YOUSSEF M. IBRAHIM 

DATELINE: PARIS, Jan. 1

 BODY:
King Fahd of Saudi Arabia handed over authority today to his half-brother, Crown Prince Abdullah, saying he needed time to rest.
A royal decree directed the Crown Prince "to take over management of government affairs while we enjoy rest and recuperation." The King's order did not specify how long he expected to be absent. 
 Saudi officials stressed that the King was not abdicating, but was taking a medical leave to recover from exhaustion. King Fahd, 74, was taken to a hospital emergency room a little more than a month ago, and the Saudi Government has maintained that he was suffering the effects of his heavy workload, persistently denying Western officials' accounts that the King had suffered a stroke.
The King was released from the hospital on Dec. 7, with assurances to the public that his health had improved. While he was shown on television receiving members of the royal family and senior officials, King Fahd has left all business of government to the Crown Prince for weeks, officials have said.
The Crown Prince has been leading Cabinet meetings, and he represented Saudi Arabia at the recent meeting in Oman of leaders of Gulf Cooperation Council countries.
Saudi Arabian businessmen said the transition was smooth and elicited no outward signs of dissent within the royal family. Crown Prince Abdullah, 72, was long ago designated to succeed King Fahd. Third in line for the throne is Prince Sultan, the Defense Minister and a full brother of the King from the Sudeiri clan.
Crown Prince Abdullah, while not a member of the powerful Sudeiri clan of King Fahd, has his own power base among the large Bedouin tribes of Saudi Arabia and in the 57,000-member National Guard that he commands. In addition he is first deputy to the Prime Minister, who is the King.
In Arab circles, the Crown Prince is known to be an Arab nationalist who strongly favors unity among Arab countries. He maintains close personal ties with President Hafez al-Assad of Syria and has spoken a number of times of the need to rebuild the cohesion among Arab countries that was shattered by Iraq's invasion of Kuwait five years ago.
Western diplomats suggest that the Crown Prince may be less enthusiastic than King Fahd to endorse any and all American policies in the region.
However, Crown Prince Abdullah is likely to follow the broad outlines of established Saudi policy, which rest on maintaining a strategic alliance with the United States and friendly Arab countries to contain both Iraq and Iran.
In the last few years King Fahd has initiated a number of changes in government, intended to introduce new figures in some 250 top positions of administration and education.
In 1992, political and economic reforms reached the royal family circle when the King said future rulers should be chosen from among the ranks of the grandsons as well as the sons of King Abdelaziz ibn Saud, the founder of the Kingdom. That opened opportunities for the younger princes.
But even then, Saudi officials said the succession in the immediate future would be by seniority.
Crown Prince Abdullah's stewardship will be challenged by a persistent deficit in the Saudi budget that has resulted from a large drop in oil prices during the last decade. Government austerity measures have not succeeded in closing the gap.
Government spending increased dramatically during the Persian Gulf war, when some 500,000 troops made their base on Saudi territory at a cost to the Saudi economy of approximately $100 billion. The result has forced the country to borrow domestically as well as internationally. The country's financial reserves, once ranked at $100 billion, are all but spent.
The Gulf war also ushered in a form of domestic dissent, mostly from Islamic fundamentalists, challenging the authority of the royal family. Hundreds have been jailed, then released, but leading dissident figures remain imprisoned, leading many of their adherents to acts of increasing violence.
Last year a car bombing near the headquarters of the National Guard, commanded by the Crown Prince and trained by the United States military, killed six people and wounded scores of others. No suspects have been uncovered in the resulting investigation.

HEADLINE: OUTLOOK '96: THE ECONOMY;
Middle Age Catches Up With the Me Generation

BYLINE: By STUART ELLIOTT 

 BODY:
THOSE who argue with the assertion that demography is destiny, ponder this: the generation that once refused to trust anyone over 30 is turning 50.
Yesterday began a fateful countdown: a member of the baby-boom generation is marking a 50th birthday every seven to eight seconds every day for the next 18 years. That's more than 10,000 people who were born from 1946 through 1964 crossing over daily into the mature market. 
 "The primary consumers in America are about to become the middle-aged," said Ken Dychtwald, president and chief executive of Age Wave Inc., a research and publishing company in Emeryville, Calif., that specializes in the demographics of aging.
The 76 million baby boomers transformed the nation as marketers raced to cater to their every want, need or whim. Disposable diapers, Barbie dolls, sugary cereals, mini-vans, bottled water, designer jeans -- it's an exhaustive (and exhausting) list.
"From the moment the first squalling boomer was born, they have been changing markets by the sheer force of their numbers," said Stephani Cook, executive vice president and strategic planning director at Lowe & Partners/SMS in New York, an ad agency owned by the Interpublic Group of Companies.
The graying of America will be such that by 2005, boomers will represent a majority of the population between 50 and 74. There is a widespread belief that the distinctive characteristics setting boomers apart from preceding generations will lead them to act differently from people now 50 or older.
Those among the elderly now "are more conscious of their duties and obligations to others and are more willing to sacrifice self-interest for the good of you name it -- children, family, country," said Cheryl Russell, editor in chief of New Strategist Publications in Ithaca, N.Y., which publishes demographic reference books for business.
By comparison, she added, "the dominant trait of boomers is a heightened sense of individualism, that at any moment they're thinking of, about and for themselves."
Yet boomers have confounded demographic forecasts that they would veer from the behavior patterns of previous generations. Remember all those predictions the boomers would not marry, would not have children, would not move to the suburbs? For the most part, they have; the difference is they made those life-style changes later than their parents did. So there is some validity to the notion that aging boomers might not be all that different in their older years from their progenitors.
"Whether you like Mick Jagger or Count Basie," Mr. Dychtwald said, "when you roll into your 50's you're worrying about arthritis, osteoporosis and enlarged prostate."
And there is the danger that boomers, for the first time in their lives, might not find themselves front and center when it comes to the forces effecting change.
"There's a good chance we're going to become old and irrelevant," said Watts Wacker, the resident futurist at SRI International, a strategic research and consulting company in Westport, Conn.
The rise of what Mr. Wacker described as "the information economy," fueled by forces like PC's and interactive media, threatens to consign boomers to the backwaters because "we're so complacent."
"We will become marginalized if we don't keep up," he warned.
Still, the chameleon-like powers of the boomers to bend society to their will by adapting to new circumstances -- switching, for instance, from marathon running to race-walking to low-impact aerobics -- suggest the generation will remake the so-called golden years in its own image.

HEADLINE: OUTLOOK '96: THE ECONOMY;
Recovery in California Wears a New Costume

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
CALL it the tinsel recovery.
After a vicious recession that left California reeling long after the rest of the country was growing again, the state is back on its feet and appears likely to surpass national growth rates in 1996. 
 It is not, however, a traditional California recovery: this time one of the principal engines of growth is not the aerospace business or housing construction. It is Tinseltown, the booming entertainment industries clustered around this city.
The University of California at Los Angeles has estimated that personal income and job growth in California will run at nearly twice the national levels in 1996, and that a major contributor will be the array of businesses involved in the media and entertainment industries. Other major contributors will be international trade and tourism. The Bank of America has forecast gross domestic product expansion in the state of 2.5 percent in 1996, up from 1.1 percent in 1995.
"The economy here is gaining momentum now, even as the rest of the country decelerates a little bit," said Lynn Reaser, chief economist at the First Interstate Bank.
Take a look at Burbank, the center of what is sometimes called the media triangle. With the Walt Disney and Warner Brothers studios expanding there, along with scores of smaller production companies and suppliers, office vacancy rates are a mere 5 percent, according to the CB Commercial Real Estate Group, a large broker. Rents average about $28 a square foot.
Compare that with downtown Los Angeles, where the vacancy rate is about 17 percent and rents are a little less than $20 a square foot.
For the first time, employment in the entertainment industries surpassed aerospace in 1995, and economists predict the gap is likely to widen. According to state data, there were 151,000 jobs in the motion picture industry as of November 1995, compared with 130,000 in aerospace.
But Jack Kyser, the chief economist for the Economic Development Corporation here, said he estimated real employment in the entertainment industries at double the official figures because of the large number of independent workers and small suppliers in related businesses.
Entertainment, Mr. Kyser estimates, now accounts for about $36 billion of economic activity in this area, a substantial portion of Los Angeles County's annual economic output of $275 billion; aerospace accounts for $30 billion of activity here.
The U.C.L.A. forecast anticipates that employment in the entertainment industries throughout California will grow 16.3 percent in 1996. Aerospace and manufacturing, on the other hand, will be flat.
"This is a much different mix than we're used to in recoveries in California," Tom K. Lieser, an economist at the university, said. "It's services-led, mostly entertainment. Those are high-paying jobs, but they are a little riskier. This is not lifetime employment by any means."
And while many other traditionally strong sectors, like housing, remain weak, they are no longer affecting the recovery. "This started out as a very modest recovery, and then it accelerated a bit in 1995 and will accelerate a little more in 1996," Howard Roth, a senior economist at the Bank of America, said. "It's gotten past the stage where you call it a modest recovery now."

HEADLINE: OUTLOOK '96: THE ECONOMY;
In New York Region, Stirrings of a Revival

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK 

 BODY:
FOR a region that has long been treading a line between recession and anemic growth, 1995 was hardly a turnaround year in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut. With layoffs cutting deeply into banks, insurance companies, military bases and government agencies, total employment rose less than 1 percent.
But after three years as an also-ran, left far behind in a swift national expansion, economists point to stirrings of renewed strength -- especially in New York City -- that might become more pronounced in 1996. 
 Indeed, the bright spots are centered in the city. The bull market is promising rich year-end bonuses for many executives on Wall Street, with some predicting increases of 30 percent or more. Employment in the securities industry in the city, reduced by layoffs early in the year, began growing in the summer and increased by 1 percent, to 150,400, by October.
Manhattan hotels and restaurants benefited from a weak dollar that attracted visitors from abroad and from a burst of tourism over all. The New York Convention and Visitors Bureau estimated that 24.8 million people visited the city in 1995, a 1 percent increase from 1994.
And analysts say a spurt of new developments -- like the Chelsea Piers sports complex and several new megastores, including Barnes & Noble bookstores -- reflect a renewed confidence that may not yet be fully reflected in employment or spending.
"This was the best year in recent memory for New York City -- certainly since 1987 -- and what is good for the city is good for the surrounding economies," Irwin L. Kellner, chief economist at the Chemical Bank, said.
The upturn transcends most routine economic yardsticks, he said, and is being helped by factors like the city's reduced crime rate, which has lifted the confidence of many, and a surge in demand for small rental apartments, suggesting an influx of young professionals.
In New York City, for example, employment and retail sales gains outpaced the rest of the region last year, particularly in recent months. Federal data also show that employment in the city was up by 21,600 jobs, to 3.3 million, at the end of October, compared with a year earlier, and that the biggest increase -- 13,000 jobs -- came in a two-month surge that began in September. Retail sales in the city also rose briskly, increasing 5.4 percent in the first nine months of the year, according to an analysis by Alan G. Hevesi, the city Comptroller. In the corresponding period a year earlier, sales rose only 1.5 percent.
Some experts, however, contend that the signs of improvement are too scattered to overcome the financial worries of many in the region for whom the distinction between recession and slow growth remains hard to discern.
According to a study by Nicholas Perna, chief economist for the Fleet Financial Group in Hartford, the region's steep downturn from 1989 to 1992 lowered employment by 580,000 jobs in New York State, 262,000 in New Jersey and 165,000 in Connecticut. Since then, he said, New Jersey has managed to regain 67 percent of its 1989 total; New York 32 percent and Connecticut only 19 percent.
The region's steep recession was attributed to many factors -- a real estate boom gone bust, the exodus of some corporate headquarters to the South and the loss of some jobs to Mexico because of the North American Free Trade Agreement. But most analysts say these broad-based losses were overcome by other engines of growth.
Although Connecticut's $29,044 in per capita income is the highest of any state -- far higher than the national per capita income of $21,699 -- the state stands out as the region's laggard. For the year ended in October, it lost 1,500 jobs, a drop of a tenth of 1 percent in total employment, making it the only state in the region to have a loss.
In Hartford, the home of several large insurance companies, a wave of merger announcements involving concerns like the Connecticut Mutual Life Insurance Company, the Massachusetts Mutual Life Insurance Company, Travelers and Aetna Life, were accompanied by more than 2,000 layoffs. And the closing of the Naval Undersea Warfare Center in New London, Conn., also cut deeply into employment.
In New York City and its suburbs, bank employment was cut sharply because of several mergers. More jobs are expected to be lost with the pending merger of the Chemical Bank and Chase Manhattan. New Jersey's huge chemical industry shed plants and workers, as did other manufacturers in the region.
Despite signs that New York City's economy is now the region's strongest, real estate executives say home and apartment sales in the city have dropped. Demand for offices rose slightly in most of the region. According to Cushman & Wakefield, a commercial brokerage firm, office vacancies dropped in midtown Manhattan to 12.3 percent in October from 12.8 percent a year earlier.
Vacancies also declined in lower Manhattan, Westchester County, Fairfield County and northern New Jersey, the company said, but demand fell on Long Island, with vacancies rising to 16.4 percent from 14.2 percent.


GRAPHIC: Since January 1992, regional job growth has triled national growth. In New Jersey, where the recovery has been strongest, two-thirds of the jobs lost during the state's recession were recovered by October. In New York, the figure was closer to one-third while in Connecticut, it was less than one-fifth.

HEADLINE: OUTLOOK '96: THE ECONOMY;
The South: Prosperity With an Asterisk

BYLINE: By ALLEN R. MYERSON 

 BODY:
FROM the perspective of the bricklayers working on the Olympic Stadium and other projects in Atlanta, things could not be better.
A tight labor market has driven up the bricklayers' wages 20 percent the last year, to $20 an hour, with abundant overtime. For them, the Games have become the fullest flowering of the new South. 
 From the perspective of apparel workers in Cedartown, Ga., less than an hour-and-a-half drive away, it is the same old South, or worse. Hundreds of sewers at the Arrow Shirt Company, who were making $5 to $7.50 an hour, were dismissed when the plant closed in October and the jobs moved to Latin America.
Although Atlanta, as host of the 1996 Olympic Games, might be a special case, it is only the leader of a region favored by many companies. A number of Atlanta wannabes, including Charlotte, N.C., and Nashville, are having their own booms.
Nashville has such a labor shortage, with its unemployment rate near 3 percent, that the owners of the Opryland Hotel bought another hotel nearby just to house its staff. Charlotte has become the nation's third-largest banking center, and in South Carolina, the arrival of European companies, including BMW, has produced Oktoberfest celebrations patterned on those in Germany. But the same mobile economy that favors Atlanta and its smaller sisters is destroying the low-paid jobs that sustain many small towns.
On average, economists say, the South's economic growth was greater than that of the nation last year and will continue to be this year, especially in Florida, Georgia and North Carolina, some of the region's largest, most urbanized states.
Although some fear that as the South becomes wealthier its cost advantages will erode, economists at the Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta say that the region's attractions -- low heating costs, low taxes, few unions and a minimum of local and state regulations -- are enduring. The South's real wages may have caught up with the nation's, but a lower cost of living means that nominal wages, what employers actually pay, have remained lower, said Thomas J. Cunningham, the senior economist at the Atlanta Fed. "That suggests the South is going to keep growing for a long period of time," he said. From 1983 to 1993, the 12 states of the Southeast had the nation's most rapid growth in total personal income -- 3 percent annually, compared with the national average of 2.4 percent, a recent Commerce Department report said. That growth is projected to slow only to 2.5 percent through 2005.
In Atlanta, construction executives say the Olympic Games' payoff is hardly limited to the $600 million Olympic Stadium, athlete housing and other buildings. A number of other projects that might have been completed years later, if at all, have been finished ahead of the Olympic sites, including a renovation of the airport, expansions by many hotels and an overhaul of the arts center.
Although business people at one time feared a post-Olympics letdown, economists now expect only minor slowing for perhaps half a year. The cost of labor and materials has risen so much that those who can postpone their projects have done so, said Larry Gellerstedt 3d, the chief executive of the Beers Construction Company, Atlanta's largest contractor and a subsidiary of Beers Inc.
Atlanta's greatest payoff from the Olympic Games might come in the longer term. With the same zeal that won Atlanta the Games, the city and state's business recruiters are using the Olympics to attract yet more attention to the state.
While other recent Olympic sites -- Los Angeles, Seoul and Barcelona -- tried to increase tourism, Lynn Pitts, a Georgia Power executive, is working with state and local agencies and other companies on pulling in more plants, warehouses and offices through what they call Operation Legacy.
They are inviting 226 business executives from other states and nations for four-day tours before the Games, to view sites, mingle with athletes, dine with the Governor at his mansion and hear that Georgia is the world's best place to put a business. During the Games, 175 top executives and their spouses will receive even better treatment.
Mr. Pitts's goal is 20 new factories or other businesses, with 6,000 new jobs. Operation Legacy has already captured more than 1,000 jobs with four new plants or offices, he said.
At the same time, the South's loss of apparel jobs appears to be accelerating. Labor leaders say the free trade pact with Mexico and the peso's devaluation have pushed more garment makers to open Mexican plants, although some economists say these plants would otherwise have gone to Asia.
That may be cold comfort for Belle McFall and 350 other workers who in October lost their jobs at the Cedartown plant owned by Arrow Shirt, a unit of Bidermann International.
Her options? "Jobs are few and far between here," she said. "I've thought about going back to school, but I've been out of school for 37 years."

SECTION: Section C; Page 13; Column 1; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 940 words

HEADLINE: OUTLOOK '96: THE ECONOMY;
Little Pessimism From the Executive Suite

BYLINE: By JUDITH H. DOBRZYNSKI 

 BODY:
AS everyone knows, you can never satisfy the boss. Business was strong at many of America's big companies in 1995, and it is looking as good or better for 1996. Profits were bountiful, and this year they are again expected to outpace the consensus forecast for economic growth of 2 to 2.5 percent.
But America's chief executives want more. 
 They want lower interest rates. "If they come down 100 to 200 basis points, this economy will really take off," J. Willard Marriott Jr., chairman and chief executive of the Marriott Corporation, said several days before the Federal Reserve cut rates 25 basis points -- or hundredths of a percentage point -- last month.
"The economy could grow 4 percent to 5 percent without reigniting inflation," he added. "This old myth of the minute you have growth of over 3 percent you get inflation doesn't make sense."
Few executives, however, seem to be counting on the Fed chairman, Alan Greenspan, to bring down rates sharply. For now, they are basing their optimism on payroll numbers, income statistics, the low inflation rate and what is in their order books.
"We assume no decreases, but we are confident that 1996 is an election year," noted David R. Goode, chief executive of the Norfolk Southern Corporation, the big railroad. As a rule, the White House does everything in its power to produce a favorable economic climate in the months before the Presidential showdown.
The election will bolster some businesses directly. Media companies and advertising agencies are bound to benefit. In Chicago, Richard Notabaert, the chief executive of the Ameritech Corporation, is reveling in the prospect of putting in telephone, fax and computer modem lines for politicians, delegates, media people and others attending the Democratic National Convention there this summer.
Ameritech -- like other communications companies -- was already doing just fine. "People are making more calls, buying second phone lines, and 12-year-olds today want to get on the Web and communicate," Mr. Notabaert said. "People now see communications as just a given, not an expense, so if the regional economy stays strong, we'll see an upward trajectory in revenue growth."
Older industries cannot expect to be so buoyant, but they will probably rack up healthy growth.
From his office in Norfolk, Va., Mr. Goode gauges the industrial economy by watching rail-car loads. "We've seen some softening in the auto business, a little bit of softening in chemicals -- although that has come back lately -- and building and construction materials are a little weak," he said. "But that's all in comparison to a pretty strong last year and earlier this year."
"And when we talk to our customers, it looks like we'll get a recovery in 1996," he added. "This is a temporary slowdown in what has been a very robust economic climate."
"On a scale of 1 to 10, I'd give this economy a 9," said Thomas J. Usher, chief executive of the USX Corporation. "We were running at capacity in 1995, and we will in 1996, too."
The appetite for steel seems to cut across the industrial spectrum. "It's not concentrated -- the auto business is not as good as it was a year ago, but it's still good, construction looks pretty good, appliances are still strong and rail cars and barge cars are strong," Mr. Usher said.
Others offer similar reports. The entertainment economy keeps expanding, securities firms and other financial institutions are faring well and the outlook for health care and pharmaceuticals is healthy.
In retailing, "1996 will be a rerun of 1995," said David D. Glass, the chief executive of Wal-Mart Stores. "There's not a lot of real strength, but business is not bad."
Mr. Glass faults the merchandise, not the customers, however. "It's not so much that the customer isn't willing to buy or can't buy," he said. "But there's nothing new to buy to drive the business."
Meanwhile, shopping as recreation has lost its allure.
The new year "will see modest growth, low-single-digit growth in retail sales," Mr. Glass predicted.
If Mr. Glass is gloomy, however, Mr. Marriott is not. Many of the dollars going unspent in the malls are funneling into hotels, restaurants and other areas of the tourism business. "We just had our best fall since the early 1980's," Mr. Marriott said. "I think 1996 looks real good. I see no reason why there shouldn't be double-digit earnings growth."
In lodging, where Marriott manages hotels in all price categories, demand has finally caught up with supply. Companies, which cut back travel when the economy soured in the early 1990's, are sending people on the road again. Individuals are traveling more now, too.
Mr. Marriott believes that after raising prices 6 to 7 percent in 1995, the market can bear another, though lower, price increase in 1996.
That in itself is remarkable. Many chief executives envy the ability to raise prices once, let alone twice. Cars, industrial materials, consumer goods and food all encountered resistance from consumers when their prices were marked up.
If the view from these corner offices is correct, the current softness in the economy is temporary, as many companies finish working off inventories that grew too plentiful. Once inventories are back to normal, the economy is expected to resume its climb. The main worry of these captains of industry lies overseas, in the potential problems facing Japan, Europe and other American trading partners.
Their bottom line: if you liked 1995, you will like 1996. That's not bad, considering America's economic expansion turns five years old -- middle-aged, at best -- in April.
