HEADLINE: OUTLOOK '96: TECHNOLOGY AND MEDIA;
Rough-and-Ready Time in the Internet Business

BYLINE: By PETER H. LEWIS 

 BODY:
IF brilliant realizations really did appear as light bulbs flashing above people's heads, 1995 would have been an especially bright year for the information and telecommunications industry. Company after company came to understand that their futures were at least partly linked to the Internet.
Microsoft announced that it was redefining itself an Internet company. AT&T declared that it, too, wanted to be an Internet company. I.B.M. announced an ambitious Internet strategy. America Online set a new course for the Internet. 
 The awakening of the information and telecommunications giants means that even the most nimble of the Internet companies will have to be careful to avoid being trampled as the rush to cyberspace intensifies this year.
While companies like Netcom and PSINet, which recognized the potential of Internet access before most others, have earned the right to compete with AT&T and MCI, hundreds of smaller Internet service providers are looking for new partners, new markets, or new jobs, in part because of the expected competition from telephone and cable TV companies.
Even Netscape Communications, the poster child of the Internet industry, now faces direct competition from one of the most feared competitors of the information jungle: Microsoft, whose chairman, William H. Gates, pledged last month that the company would focus on making its software synonymous with the Internet.
Indeed, an Internet shakeout has started, several analysts said, and it is cutting across many industries.
"We see a lot of these guys dying or being acquired," said Stephen Auditore, president of Zona Research Inc. of Redwood City, Calif. Particularly vulnerable, he said, are "smaller companies focusing on one or two Internet-related widgets."
"The people who are going to prosper are the ones who sell technologies and products that help businesses integrate the Internet into all their operations, the so-called intranet," Mr. Auditore said.
Internet or intranet, "there's going to be a huge expansion in the size of the marketplace, and within that, a lot of dynamism," said Mark R. Anderson, president of Technology Alliance Partners, a software and telecommunications trends prediction company in Friday Harbor, Wash.
In other words, the expanding Internet market presents a lush environment in which new companies can emerge, but it will also attract some of the most carnivorous competitors in today's PC and telecommunications industries.
The competition in the Internet service provider business will be particularly nasty as the telephone companies enter the market, Mr. Anderson said.
But there will also be a shakeout among companies that make the Internet software known as Web browsers and Web servers, he said, "and once the telecommunications reform bill is signed, we'll see an acceleration of mergers among telcom and cable companies."
The proposed Nynex and Bell Atlantic partnership is just the first sign of things to come, several analysts agreed. The next phase will be increasing mergers of phone companies with cable TV companies, said Jerry Michalski, editor of Release 1.0, an information industry newsletter.
Traditional publishers and media businesses, meanwhile, have "over-invested in the Internet and put themselves in a new- media arms race," Mr. Michalski said.
And the Internet stampede could hit a bottleneck in 1996, said Allen Weiner of the market research company Dataquest Inc. Many companies that are building fancy World Wide Web applications, may find that consumers are unable to use them.
The most exciting new Internet applications, ones that deliver high-quality audio, video and two-way communications, require more network capacity, or bandwidth, than most consumers can get over phone lines with standard PC modems.
So while NBC, CNN, Sony and other so-called content providers are racing to develop dazzling new Internet services with promising multimedia tools like Sun Microsystems's Java, Microsoft's Internet Studio, and Macromedia's Shockwave, all but the most technically advanced consumers may be stuck on the sidelines.
A lack of bandwidth is hampering adoption of business-to-business Internet development, internal or intranet development and business-to-consumer development.
It is unclear whether the lack of cheap, reliable bandwidth is retarding consumer acceptance of electronic commerce, or whether it is the lack of compelling applications, or mistrust of computer security, or some combination of many factors.
It is clear, though, that while companies are stampeding to the Internet, consumers are watching.
"Electronic commerce really hasn't happened at home yet," said Nicholas Donatiello, president and chief executive of Odyssey L.P., a market research firm based in San Francisco that specializes in home entertainment.
In October, the most recent month in which a survey was taken, only 7 percent of American households with on-line service or Internet connections reported buying something electronically.
"That translates to roughly 600,000 U.S. households out of a universe of 96 million households," Mr. Donatiello said. "So, while electronic commerce at home is growing, it is still very, very small."
BUSINESSES seem to have a more optimistic outlook about the World Wide Web. At a recent conference held by Forrester Research Inc. in Boston, nearly half of the 216 corporate executives said their companies would use the Internet for business transactions in 1996, and 70 percent said they would do so by 1997.
Though prospects for new revenues from electronic commerce are small, the idea of saving money by streamlining operations through the Internet are promising.
Such optimism encouraged investors to pour billions of dollars into Internet stocks in the last half of 1995. Netscape, for example, amassed a market valuation of several billion dollars based on third-quarter 1995 revenues of about $20 million.
And it looks like the Internet hysteria will continue in 1996, even though the prospects of a shakeout are relatively high. Cybercash, a company that hopes to facilitate electronic payments on the Internet, recently filed for an initial public offering of two million shares, at an average of $16 a share, even though the company has no real expectation of generating any significant revenue until 1997.
"In effect, individuals are becoming venture capitalists for these new Internet companies, at a very steep price," said Andrew B. Whinston, a business professor at the University of Texas and co-author of a new book, "Frontiers of Electronic Commerce." "The thinking is that you can buy a dozen of these companies, and in the year 2002 most will be bankrupt -- but two or three will be tremendous winners."

HEADLINE: NYC;
In Washington, A Fight Hurts New Yorkers

BYLINE: By CLYDE HABERMAN 

 BODY:
AS usual, lots of lists have been drawn up looking back at the old year: top news stories, best books, worst films. The last thing we need is another list.
But anyone compelled to tote up the biggest victims of 1995 might want to consider the thousands of New Yorkers whose lives are still being turned upside down by the budgetary gamesmanship in Washington that has shut down much of the Government for weeks. A special nomination goes to the many small businesses, and their work staffs, that have received almost no attention while their livelihoods trickle down the drain because of their dependence on a practically nonexistent Federal apparatus. 
 We're talking about Francine Krieger, who owns Acme Passport Photographers, two floors below the United States Passport Agency, on 630 Fifth Avenue, just off Rockefeller Center. With the agency closed to all but supposedly life-and-death cases, Acme's film is severely underexposed these days.
At a nearby newsstand, Mahfuzul Karim says his income has been cut in half by the lack of passport traffic. A similar lament was heard yesterday from Mohammed Nadim Rahim, selling hot dogs and pretzels to a few foreign tourists who turned up at the ferry landing in Battery Park. It seems they had not read -- or their tour guides didn't bother to warn them -- that no boats have sailed from there to the Statue of Liberty and Ellis Island since mid-December.
"It's dead," Mr. Rahim said. "Today's a little better because it's New Year's, but most of the time there is no business."
It has been the same for Eddie Medina, who manages a store on lower Broadway across the street from 26 Federal Plaza. He specializes in fingerprinting and photography, catering to the thousands of people who usually flow through the Immigration and Naturalization Service offices. But with Immigration closed, "we're hurting bad," he said. "It's horrid. Lately, we've been letting employees take days off without pay."
ONE flight up, it's no better for George Fletcher, part owner of a translation service that depends on visa seekers streaming into Federal Plaza. Ditto for the fast-food restaurants along the same stretch of Broadway. And for Robert and Jodi Kaplan, who own a card and gift shop on the block and who stood by helplessly while their peak season, Christmas, was stolen from them, Grinch-like, by Congress and the White House.
If nothing else, the budgetary paralysis underlines how umbilically tied the local economy is to government at every level. All it takes to hurt thousands of New Yorkers in the pocket, instantly and seriously, is for a few Federal departments to stop working. And unlike furloughed Federal workers, who are being promised that forfeited income will eventually be restored, the Kaplans and Rahims of this city have no chance of recovering their losses.
Are they disgusted about it?
Do you really need to be told the answer?
"What they do in Washington, Democrat or Republican, is look out for No. 1," said Richard Witt, an Acme photographer with time on his hands. "No. 1 is not me or you. We're not even No. 2. The guy who said that first was Frank Zappa."
Eddie Medina has no doubt that cosmic issues are at stake in Washington. But he can't get over stories like the one about Newt Gingrich being peeved because President Clinton had forced him to use the rear exit on Air Force One after the return flight from Yitzhak Rabin's funeral. "If it's a personal vendetta, why should we suffer?" Mr. Medina said. "Let them hammer out their differences on their own time."
WHAT gets to him and others is the absence of any gesture in their direction from Washington that in effect says, Sorry for your troubles. The cavalier treatment fuels resentment among some New Yorkers who have been heard asking of late why they must pay full taxes for this period when the Government is not providing full services.
Good question. You don't need to be a gun-toting, Commie-hunting survivalist to have the thought cross your mind. You'll get no comfort, though, from Stephen Cerow, a tax lawyer in Manhattan who prefers pinstripes to camouflage.
"In the final analysis, this ain't a social contract," he said. "The tax law says that 'you, the citizen, will pony up a certain amount of your income to us.' Nowhere is it written that 'we, the Government, will give services in return.' Their obligation is minimal. Ours is complete."
In short, forget it -- this is a message that Mohammed Nadim Rahim absorbs while waiting gamely for the Statue of Liberty to reopen. "Every day, I wait," he said. "I hope and hope and hope. But there's no hope."

HEADLINE: OUTLOOK '96: THE ECONOMY;
Giving Business A Chance to Test The Wings of Deregulation

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
LAST year presented the vision. Is this one about to produce the reality?
As Congressional Republicans move into their second year in power, their campaign to hack away at mounds of Government regulations is likely to have its first tangible impact on business -- from Wall Street to Hollywood, from silicon to steel. 
 It is still unclear just how much of the Republican business agenda will become law, given President Clinton's threat to veto many measures and the added difficulties of grappling with election-year politics.
But it is hard to overstate the extent of the changes that Speaker Newt Gingrich and his band of fire-breathing Republicans have already pushed through the House of Representatives. One major deregulatory bill, which will make it harder for shareholders to sue corporations for securities fraud or misrepresentation, became law just before Christmas. And lawmakers, having devoted most of 1995 to fighting about the budget, may well spend much of 1996 in a struggle over limiting Government's role in monitoring business.
"Regulatory agencies have run amok and need to be reformed," said Representative Tom DeLay of Texas, the House majority whip and a leader of the deregulatory forces in Congress. "We have made great progress, but completing that agenda needs to be one of the top legislative priorities of the second session."
Not since the 1946 election, when Republicans last won control of both Houses, has business had a Congress more zealously determined to roll back Government regulation and let corporate America fly free. The House has already passed a bill that would eviscerate the authority of the Environmental Protection Agency and other regulatory agencies. Congressional proposals to open millions of acres of Federal wilderness land to logging and mining are at the center of the budget stalemate between Congress and the White House. Both chambers have voted to sweep away decades of restrictions on media and communications companies.
Now comes the crucial test: navigating roadblocks in the Senate, where the minority Democrats have more ability to block legislation than in the House, and muscling past veto threats from President Clinton.
"It's going to be difficult," said Jeffrey H. Joseph, vice president for domestic policy at the United States Chamber of Commerce, one of the country's biggest lobbying groups for business. "Because of the political nature of the year, with all the elections going on, there are a lot of games that get played."
And not all efforts to rein in Government regulation are equally popular within the Republican majority. Many pro-business lawmakers, stung by criticism that they were bent on destroying the environment to help industry, voted against bills that proposed to chip away at certain environmental restrictions.
For all the uncertainty over the ultimate fate of the new agenda, however, the reversal of decades of accumulated regulation of industry promises to go far enough to have a major impact on many segments of business and society.
Just before Christmas, Congress overrode a veto by President Clinton of the securities-fraud bill, enacting a law to reshape the rules under which publicly held companies are accountable to shareholders. The new law will give companies more freedom to make predictions about their financial performance without being sued if the predictions turn out to be wrong. It will also make it harder for investors to recover losses, by limiting their ability to seek damages from lawyers, accountants and others charged with "aiding and abetting" a company's misrepresentations. And it will require judges to decide whether a lawsuit was "frivolous"; if the judge determined that it was, that could expose aggrieved investors to potentially severe financial penalties for unsubstantiated claims.
Meanwhile, despite some unexpected intramural dissent among House Republicans, most experts say that Congress will at some point this year pass a sweeping telecommunications bill that would free telephone, cable television and media companies from scores of restrictions on the businesses they could enter.
That is only the beginning. A "regulatory reform" bill that would block new environmental, health and public safety regulations unless they ran the gantlet of a cost-benefit analysis has passed the House. A similar measure has stalled in the Senate, although Republicans will almost certainly push it again.
A "property rights" bill, passed by the House and pending in the Senate, would make it vastly more expensive for the Government to enforce existing environmental laws, like those that protect wetlands or endangered species. Washington would be required to compensate landowners for declines in property values that resulted from new regulations.
The scope of this activity goes beyond any particular law or regulation. The changes coursing through Congress would alter the basic calculus by which the Government has conducted most of its efforts to protect the environment, to improve health and to promote safety. Gone would be absolute mandates to achieve particular goals, whether reducing the level of pollutants in the air and water or setting a specific standard for coal dust in mines. Instead, Government regulators would be required to document in painstaking detail how the benefits of a new rule would be greater than the costs and to show that business had been allowed to meet any target by the least burdensome method.
There is no commonly accepted estimate of the real costs -- and benefits -- to business and society of Government regulation. Thomas Hopkins, a professor at the Rochester Institute of Technology, has estimated that the combined cost of regulation in America is about $581 billion a year. Others say the number is much lower -- though almost certainly in the tens of billions of dollars -- and that many regulations have positive effects that outweigh the extra burden.
The goal of deregulation, business groups say, is to bring greater rationality, establish clearer priorities and allow more flexibility in the way that companies satisfy Government requirements. "A great deal of this has to do with the waste of resources," said Jerry Jasinowski, president of the National Association of Manufacturers. Regulators, he said, mistakenly seek a "nirvana" of zero risk at work and home and unattainable purity for the environment, food and health care.
Critics of the Republicans' deregulatory agenda say it would produce many more problems than it would solve. "It would create massive bureaucracy, massive expense and would give companies opportunities to stall things in court," said Gary Bass, head of OMB Watch, a nonprofit group that has organized a rough alliance of environmental groups, labor unions and consumer organizations to oppose the mostly pro-business efforts.
In some cases, however, it is business itself that has been most instrumental in defending what some call government red tape. Insurance companies essentially blocked the most serious effort in years to let banks, insurers and other financial institutions compete in each others' markets. Long-distance telephone companies mounted an intense lobbying campaign to keep the regional Bell companies out of their business, and may yet try to stop the telecommunications bill if it remains in its current form.
But for the most part business groups have been instrumental in pushing the new agenda. Lobbyists representing basic manufacturing and the chemical industry were recruited to help rewrite parts of the Clean Water Act and the Endangered Species Act. Telecommunications and media companies were invited to special closed-door forums with lawmakers, who explicitly asked for suggestions about how Washington could make life better for them.
The outcome of all this, assuming much of it eventually becomes law, will not in all cases necessarily advance the professed goals of free markets and states' rights. One House proposal would strip states of their authority to regulate the sale of securities within their borders, while another would block local zoning ordinances on cellular telephone towers.
While business groups continue to fight among themselves for specific advantages over their competitors, they are united behind a new approach that in bill after bill stands at the core of Congress's pro-business agenda. This approach is most clearly distilled in the "regulatory reform" bill approved by the House. Put simply, it would block Washington from approving any regulation that would impose more than $100 million in additional costs on an industry unless the Government could demonstrate that the benefits exceeded the costs. Because every new proposal is likely to generate conflicting economic claims that would take years to resolve, any Federal agency would be hamstrung in writing new regulations.
Moreover, while differing on particulars, both the House and Senate versions would offer business new legal opportunities for challenging rules that have been on the books for years. President Clinton has threatened to veto either measure if it passes the full Congress.
Supporters of the new agenda acknowledge that much Government regulation is hard to stamp out. Mr. Joseph of the United States Chamber of Commerce, who has fought what he sees as Government interference in business since the 1970's, said Presidents Ronald Reagan and George Bush both established requirements for "cost-benefit analysis" and "regulatory flexibility" through executive orders. But the Federal Register, which publishes new regulations, grew fatter anyway.
So why should the new laws make a difference? Advocates contend that there is a big difference between laws established by Congress, which a business can enforce by going to court, and executive orders, which simply provide instructions to Federal agencies. Beyond that, the zeal to rewrite the laws is being accompanied by budget cuts on regulatory agencies and by a general willingness in Congress to knock out particular regulations opposed by industry.

SECTION: Section C; Page 17; Column 4; Business/Financial Desk; Second Front

LENGTH: 955 words

HEADLINE: OUTLOOK '96: MARKETS AND INVESTING
What Now?;
Even if '74 Rings a Bell, Avoiding The Market Remains a Risk, Too

BYLINE: By EDWARD WYATT 

 BODY:
THE reason so few professionals on Wall Street remember the last real bear market -- 1973, when stock values fell 15 percent, and 1974, when they fell 26 percent -- is that most of the unlucky ones who suffered through it have made so much money in the last 20 years that they could retire.
About the only people still around to rekindle the memories of those dark days, and to warn that the good times will not last, are financial journalists. And many of them have been wrong about stocks for nearly a decade. 
 Simply put, the biggest risk to individual investors in recent times has come from not being invested in the market.
An investor in a mutual fund that matched the performance of the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, among the most watched market indicators, would not have suffered an annual loss of more than 5 percent in any year since 1977. Seven times in those 18 years, the annual return on the S.& P. 500 exceeded 20 percent, assuming all dividends were reinvested.
Four times, there were back-to-back gains exceeding 15 percent, and in three of those four, the second year was better than the first.
In all but two of the 18 years -- 1981 and 1990 -- investments gauged by the S.& P. 500 made money. Even in 1987, when stocks took a frantic tumble, falling 22 percent in one day, the S.& P. index finished the year with a gain of 5 percent.
None of which means that investors are assured of double-digit returns in 1996, or even single-digit returns. But the outlook for stocks for the rest of the decade -- a decade in which inflation has all but died, interest rates have been tame and the economy has continued to chug along -- appears sound at this point.
So it should be of little surprise that more money than ever poured into mutual funds that invest in American stocks in 1995. So good was the year that the previous record, set in '93, was broken in November, with a full month to be reported.
Over the next five years, the chances are that those investors will make money. In the shorter term, however, "investors could be disappointed if they jumped in for the first time in the last quarter of 1995," said John C. Bogle, chairman of the Vanguard Group, the country's second-largest mutual fund company after the Fidelity group. "Investors certainly have been informed about the rewards of investing," he said. "I wonder if they have been well enough informed about the risks."
One of the greatest risks the market faces this year is likely to be that all those individuals who plunged into the market recently will flee if results in the first half do not measure up to their expectations.
"I'm concerned about the growing illiquidity in the marketplace," said A. Michael Lipper, president of Lipper Analytical Services, which tracks mutual fund performance. "The capital of the big Wall Street firms is not growing at the same rate as the capital invested by institutional investors," including mutual funds.
That means that Wall Street, which often has been able to absorb selling pressure when investors might be inclined to panic, might not be as much of a cushion during sharp declines, Mr. Lipper said.
Wall Street is not the only place where liquidity has been drying up. "Household liquidity is down considerably over the last several years," said Byron R. Wien, portfolio strategist for Morgan Stanley & Company. "Individuals do not have the money to keep up the pace of mutual fund investments they have over the last few years."
In addition, Mr. Wien warned, "debt burdens have hampered consumers' willingness to spend," which could prove to be a bigger drag on the economy than some people anticipate. "That was one of the reasons that Christmas retail sales were so disappointing," he said.
BUT far from Wall Street, where the horizons are broader and individuals pay less attention to wrangling in Washington and the nuances of economic pronouncements, many investors remain positive about prospects for growth from the big engines of the economy -- capital goods and machinery makers.
"I think the environment of low interest rates and inflation that propelled the market over the last year should continue in the first half of '96," said Alan B. Lancz, an investment adviser in Toledo, Ohio, who also writes a stock-picking and economic newsletter.
Mr. Lancz, who last year included the media giants CBS, Time Warner and Times Mirror among his favorite stocks, this year sees the greatest potential in several companies engaged in more basic industries, which should benefit from lower interest rates around the globe.
Among them, Mr. Lancz said, are Imperial Chemical Industries and Hanson P.L.C., two British conglomerates; the Lubrizol Corporation, a producer of engine oils and fluids, and two Canadian energy concerns, TransCanada Pipelines and Westcoast Energy.
In the second half of the year, the Presidential and Congressional elections are likely to drive economic and financial concerns and to have unpredictable effects on certain stock sectors. In January 1992, few on Wall Street would have predicted that Bill Clinton would be elected President, much less anticipated the wringer that stocks of health care companies would be put through in concern over the President-to-be's proposals for medical care.
So while the outlook is positive for people who truly are long-term investors, with expectations of staying around for five years or so, the only certainty in the short term is that past performance is no guarantee of future results. Investors hoping for another year of better-than-30-percent gains in stock prices are likely to be disappointed. But fearful investors who stay on the sidelines will probably be worse off.


GRAPHIC: Low interest rates, strong corporate profits and a surging tide of fresh cash have helped propel the Dow Jones industrial average to record heights. In 1995, the Dow climbed 33.5 percent, closing the year at 5,117.12.

 Graph tracks the Dow during 1995. (Source: Datastream)
 
"A Tough Act to Follow"
 While Wall Street still expects further interest rate cuts by the Federal Reserve, the raging bull market is unlikely to repeat its stellar 1995 performance. Some experts advise investors to look elsewhere this year, particularly to overseas markets. Page C19.

HEADLINE: Wyllis Bandler, 79, Who Sought Application of Abstract Algebra

BYLINE: By WOLFGANG SAXON 

 BODY:
Wyllis Bandler, a mathematician who worked in the rarefied sphere of abstract algebra and sought to give it practical application, died on Dec. 22 at Tallahassee Memorial Regional Medical Center in Florida. He was 79 and lived in Tallahassee.
The cause was emphysema, said a friend and associate, Vasco Mancini. 
 At his death Dr. Bandler was professor of computer science at Florida State University and about to retire.
Dr. Bandler's early research dealt with abstractions and purely theoretical constructs. But over the years he became known for his work in applying algebraic structures to real-life situations.
Together with Mr. Mancini, an architect, he produced several scholarly papers exploring how people interpret their urban surroundings. Another subject he investigated was how people feel about their medical needs. His research found growing use in such fields as medical diagnosis, information retrieval, environmental studies and industrial engineering.
In 1994, the International Institute for Advanced Studies in Systems Research and Cybernetics gave Dr. Bandler a special lifetime achievement award in recognition of his decadeslong efforts to use mathematics, science and technology to improve the quality of human life.
He was born in White Plains and graduated from Columbia University, where he also earned a master's degree in economics. He also earned a master's in meteorology at New York University and put that knowledge to work with an Army Air Forces weather unit in China in World War II, rising to the rank of captain.
After the war, he lived in Florence and received a doctorate in mathematics at the University of Zurich. He then taught mathematics in England at the University of Essex and established its Cognitive Studies Center.
He joined the department of computer science in Tallahassee in 1983 and founded the Institute for Cognitive Sciences. An interdisciplinary unit, it seeks to meld contributions from philosophers, mathematicians and logicians.
He left no immediate survivors.

HEADLINE: OUTLOOK '96: MARKETS AND INVESTING;
Workers Are Expected to Push for More of the Economic Pie

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
A FAIRLY basic tenet of economics holds that as worker productivity increases, so does labor's share of national income.
To some analysts, however, the experience of the recent past has stretched that rule to the limit. So far this decade, workers are not reaping the benefits of greater productivity, they argue, even as profits have posted sharp gains and the stock market has soared to record levels. 
 "The bottom line is that this has been a very powerful competitive revival for corporate America," said Steven S. Roach, chief economist at Morgan Stanley, "and an extraordinary environment for investors. But the worker has not nearly enjoyed as prosperous an opportunity."
Given that disparity, Mr. Roach says that at some point labor will intensify its demands for a bigger piece of the national economic pie.
Searching for signs of inflation, economists like Mr. Roach have for some time been on the lookout for a rise in wage rates. Indeed, while the Federal Reserve noted that wage pressures were intensifying in some parts of the country, one of the big surprises of the current economic expansion has been how modest wage gains have been.
Given the size of the productivity gains, wage rates might have been expected to climb. Although a gap between productivity and real wages began to appear in the 1980's, in this decade it has grown to unprecedented proportions: output per man hour has increased at a little more than 2 percent a year in the first half of the 1990's, according to Mr. Roach. By contrast, real compensation per hour increased at an average annual rate of just six-tenths of a percent.
"The contribution of the worker has risen more than three times the reward," he said.
Those gains have resulted in rising corporate profits, which as a share of national income have risen two percentage points over the last three years, to 10 percent. About half of that gain has come at the expense of employees. In the same period, employee compensation as a percentage of national income has fallen by about a percentage point, to just under 74 percent.
Sweeping corporate layoffs, which between 1991 and 1995 came to nearly 2.5 million jobs, help account for the rise in productivity, and also why labor has not been pushing for more.
"Never in our history have American workers been asked to do so much for so little," said Allen Sinai, chief economist at Lehman Brothers. Cost-cutting employers have all the power in this equation," he said. "Workers have none."
Rather, workers are more apt to pressure Washington for relief.
Mr. Sinai and others find that forecast implausible, in large measure, they argue, because labor is getting more than Government statistics -- or Mr. Roach -- suggest. If true, that might explain why the worker backlash Mr. Roach says could materialize has not already arrived.
Indeed, respondents to a recent NBC News/Wall Street Journal poll said by nearly 2 to 1 that they were better off now than they were four years ago.
In a recent paper, Robert J. Gordon, an economist at Northwestern University, presented findings suggesting why that may be so. After looking at wage, productivity and inflation data from 1963 through the second quarter of last year, Mr. Gordon asserts that contrary to published statistics, real wages have not been flat, but have, in fact, gone up.
The reasons, he writes, are "that productivity growth has been overstated, inflation has been overstated and growth in compensation understated." Correcting for what he sees as an upward bias in the consumer price index, Mr. Gordon estimated that real consumption wages were 61 percent higher at the end of the second quarter of 1995 than they were in 1972.
But in the paper and in a subsequent interview, Mr. Gordon cautioned that his conclusions refer to "widely varying experiences of more than 100 million households.
"My story is that everybody is better off than what almost anybody else thought," he said.
Rising corporate profits have helped to bolster stock prices, and workers, through investment vehicles like 401(k) retirement plans and company pension plans, have much more of a stake in the performance of financial markets than before.
Still, Mr. Gordon acknowledged that while everybody may be doing a bit better than previously thought, gains at the top far exceed those in the middle.
"None of these estimates include capital gains," he said, "which is much of the way the rich have gotten richer. The average person is doing better, but the gains at the top are better still."
Mr. Roach is unmoved by many of these arguments. "The gap between productivity and real compensation may be a little bit smaller," he said, "but I don't buy the notion that it is a statistical mirage. If you tell American workers that, I don't think they will believe you."

HEADLINE: OUTLOOK '96: MARKETS AND INVESTING;
Many See Sparkle Dimming In I.P.O.'s

BYLINE: By REED ABELSON 

 BODY:
WATCHING the initial public offering market last year was enough to give anyone goose bumps.
While no records were set for the volume or the dollar amount of deals done in 1995, despite a torrent of offerings over the last few months, the performances of many new issues were nothing short of spectacular. The average deal gained 31 percent, according to the Securities Data Company, a research firm in Newark. 
 This spellbinding show is not expected to stop as long as the overall market continues its dazzling display, fueled by low interest rates and investors' boundless enthusiasm for equities. But few, if any, market participants think 1996 will be a repeat of last year's bonanza.
Among the year's star performers were I.P.O.'s like Premisys Communications, a telecommunications company, and two Internet outfits, Spyglass and Netscape Communications. The stocks are now up fivefold and sevenfold from their initial offering prices, and the average technology issue gained 45 percent.
"All of the fireworks was in the technology I.P.O.'s," said Robert Natale, the director of equity research for Standard & Poor's and editor of Emerging & Special Situations.
Technology issues also crowded the stage with 217 deals that raised $8.6 billion in capital, twice the amount raised in 1994 and more than 1992's previous high of $7 billion, according to Securities Data. "This has been a market of a fair number of newer industries and newer companies," said Linda Killian, an analyst with Renaissance Capital, a Greenwich, Conn., firm that specializes in new issues.
Investors can expect even more technology issues where those came from, although fewer are expected to soar. "Once we start to pick up, we see high tech as the buzz word of the beginning of 1996," said David Menlow, the president of I.P.O. Financial Network, a Springfield, N.J., firm that estimates the opening prices of new issues. "There will be a scramble on the part of the underwriters to get the next tier of issues."
And underwriters are anticipating a busy first three months of the year as the market gets off to a quick start. "Our backlog is pretty big and building rapidly," said David DiPietro, a managing director for Alex. Brown & Sons, who expects the pace to slow later in the year. "I think it would be kidding ourselves to think that 1996 is going to be as good as 1995 was."
While market observers say the quality of the deals has remained strong, there are some signs of weakening. Because many of the companies seeded by venture capitalists have already been harvested, some of the deals being done are younger and have less a history of making money, Ms. Killian noted. "It would be healthy to have a slowing down," she said.
The result would likely be an increasingly mixed performance among the year's new offerings. "I think it will be a good I.P.O. year, but I think the market will be more selective," said Sanford R. Robertson, the chairman of the San Francisco firm of Robertson, Stephens & Company. "The good ones will breeze right through."
But that means investors are taking more risks on new issues than they were, say, five years ago when the market had not been boisterous for as long. "The overall market is getting more speculative and so is the I.P.O. market," Mr. Natale said.

HEADLINE: Boat Industry Back in Good Health

BYLINE: By BARBARA LLOYD 

 BODY:
The Viking Yacht Company reacted in 1991 to a shrinking powerboat market by closing one of its two manufacturing plants. But the company, now reinvigorated, plans to show off a new line of sport cruising yachts this week at the New York National Boat Show.
Manufacturers generally are riding the same wave of prosperity. The cyclical downturn that sent marine sales plummeting in 1989 began its climb back in 1993. The newest statistics from the National Marine Manufacturers Association, an industry trade group, indicate that the boating market has chalked up a third consecutive year with double-digit increases in overall sales. For 1995, the upswing is at 22 percent. 
 There is apt to be a competitive climate at the New York show, which is scheduled for its 86th edition from Jan. 6-14 at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center, 11th Avenue at 35th Street in midtown Manhattan.
"For this year, compared to 1990 -- the best year we've ever had -- we're ahead by 12 to 15 percent," said Tom Carroll, president of Viking Sport Cruisers, a new Viking Yacht collaboration with a British boat-builder. The firm's Sport Cruiser 45 will be on display at the Javits center, and retails for about $560,000.
But it's not just the big yachts that are selling. Greg Proteau, a trade group spokesman, said that of the 650,000 boats sold in 1995, nearly 100,000 were canoes. Another 200,000 were personal watercraft -- small jet boats with names such as Sea-Doo, Jet Ski and Waverunner.
The $1.1 billion in jet boat sales reflects a 41 percent growth since 1994. While controversial in the boating industry because of driver competency issues, personal watercraft represent a third of all new boats sold in 1995. Numerous models will be on display in New York, at an average price of $5,722.
On a broader level, boat show organizers are offering plenty of incentives to boost attendance. "In the past, New York seemed to lag behind some of the other shows, such as Miami," said Michael Duffy, the New York show's manager. "I attribute that to the Northeast lagging economically behind the rest of the country. But I think we're catching up."
One show-stopper is likely to be the Aquastrada Delta, a prototype of a new amphibious vehicle that reaches speeds of 100 miles per hour on land, and 50 m.p.h. on water. The first retail version of the car/boat is expected to be available in 18 months for about $150,000.
Among the show's special events are Gone Fishin' Day, Jan. 11; and Marine Cuisine Day, Jan. 13. At Family Day on Jan. 7, customers who carry a discount card from the A&P/Food Emporium Bonus Savings Club can bring their family into the show for free with the price of one adult admission ticket. On Jan. 6 and 7, the Olympic sailing contenders Danielle Brennan, a national dinghy champion, and Alfred Imperato, a champion windsurfer, will be at the show.
Women in particular are being targeted as consumers this year. "People are trying to get the industry to recognize the buying power of women," said Wanda Kenton Smith, a marine executive and founder of International Women in Boating, a Chicago-based advocacy group. "Some sales people don't give a woman the time of day because they don't recognize her as a buyer. We are trying to bring these people out of the ice age."
More than 1,000 boats are expected to be on display, about 85 percent of them powerboat models and 15 percent sailboats. Marine accessories, outboard engines and new electronic equipment also will be on exhibit. Watercraft will include cruising boats from Regal Marine, Silverton, Mainship, Cruisers and Maxum; and high-performance boats from Sunseeker, Baja, Wellcraft, Formula and Donzi.
Fishing boats include models from Pro-Line, Albermarle, Regulator, Aquasport and Seaswirl. Small powerboats are from Cobalt, Eclipse, Powerquest and Larson; and inflatables from Avon Marine, Zeppelin and Yamaha. Sailboats include models from Beneteau and General Boat, which will show a new Rhodes 22 that comes with a self-tending mainsail.
Daily admission to the boat show costs $8 for an adult ticket, $3 for children ages 6-12, and is free for children under age 6. For further information, telephone (212) 984-7070.
For people interested in sailboats, Sail EXPO in Atlantic City offers a wider range of sailing craft and accessories. The show is scheduled for Feb. 3-11 at the Atlantic City Convention Center. It is sponsored by Sail America, the sailing industry trade association. For information, telephone (401) 842-0620.

HEADLINE: New Family Tree Is Constructed For Indo-European

BYLINE: By GEORGE JOHNSON 

 BODY:
LINGUISTS have long agreed that languages as diverse as English, French, German and even Iranian, Albanian and Armenian all descended from a long-dead tongue, Proto-Indo-European, spoken some 5,000 years ago. But the exact nature of the relationship has been a matter of dispute. How should the family tree of the Indo-European languages be drawn?
Recently, in what some linguists are welcoming as an important development in historical linguistics, researchers at the University of Pennsylvania have proposed an answer. Drawing on ideas in biology, computer science and historical linguistics, they have developed what they say is the most accurate picture yet of how the Proto-Indo-European language fractured into the major branches that exist today. 
 The research by two linguists, Dr. Don Ringe and Dr. Ann Taylor, and a computer scientist, Dr. Tandy Warnow, was described at the National Academy of Sciences Symposium on the Frontiers of Science in Irvine, Calif., in November.
For simplicity's sake, linguists often depict the principal Indo-European language groups as 10 equal branches radiating like spokes from a wheel. But they do not seriously suppose that all these splits could have occurred simultaneously, as if 10 bands of adventurers had struck off in different directions from the Indo-European homeland.
More likely, one group parted ways, then another, which might have fractured into two more. When linguists sit down and calculate the possibilities, they are overwhelmed by a dizzying case of combinatorial explosion. By one reckoning, there are more than 34 million ways the genealogical chart for all the Indo-European languages could be drawn.
Using a new computer program, or algorithm, the scientists at the University of Pennsylvania have sifted through the myriad possibilities and come up with what they believe is the general shape of the tree. According to their picture, the first to split off from Proto-Indo-European was Anatolian, an extinct group of languages, including ancient Hittite, which were once spoken in Turkey.
Next to split off were Celtic, which gave rise to Irish, Gaelic, Welsh and Breton, and Italic, the precursor to Latin and the Romance languages. These were followed by Armenian and Greek. Among the last to split off were the Indic and Iranian languages.
The exciting implication is that the tree shows, in schematic form, how the descendants of the original Indo-Europeans might have spread across Europe and Asia.
Consider, for example, the puzzling case of the ancient Germanics. Their language, which gave rise to English, Dutch and German, has stubbornly resisted efforts to fit it into the Indo-European tree. The new genealogy offers a possible reason: an early ancestor of the Germanic language was closely related to Balto-Slavic, whose modern descendants include Lithuanian, Latvian, Russian, Czech and Polish. Then its speakers migrated westward, coming into contact with speakers of Italic and Celtic.
"What really surprised us was that we were able to come up with a clear and consistent explanation for Germanic," Dr. Ringe said.
Dr. Craig Melchert, a linguist at the University of North Carolina, called the new technique "a promising innovation."
"Based on what I've seen so far," he said, "one undeniable merit of their model is that it allows for the testing of different hypotheses in a very explicit and efficient way not previously available."
But Dr. Melchert cautioned that the data fed into such a model were always open to interpretation and dispute. He, for one, strongly disagrees that the scientists have verified that Anatolian was the first to split away from Proto-Indo-European. This theory, the Indo-Hittite hypothesis, has been debated for years.
Not everyone is convinced that computational studies have much to offer a science like linguistics, in which the data are so incomplete and indecisive. "What this emphasizes to me is that there are places for exact methods, and also places where it's silly to pretend to have them," said Dr. Jay Jasanoff, a Cornell University linguist. He said that in constructing such charts, there was always a danger that linguists would unconsciously pick data that confirmed their prejudices. "It's like 'scientific' poll taking," he said. "You put the questions in a way that gets the answer you're looking for."
But Dr. Ringe noted that before this study, he believed, contrary to his findings, that the Indo-Hittite hypothesis was wrong. "It might even be fair to say that I was biased against it," he said. "So you can imagine how startled I was when the algorithm kept turning up Anatolian as one first-order branch of the family, and everything else as the other first-order branch -- exactly what the hypothesis says."
In tracing the pedigree of languages, linguists face the same problems biologists confront in drawing taxonomic charts of the species. Similar traits do not necessarily imply common descent; they might be coincidences. All birds are related because they have wings. But insects also have wings, as do bats. Try to connect all winged creatures into one big family and you would end up with a tangle instead of a tree. The similarity is an artifact of what biologists call convergent evolution.
"Suppose two languages inherit the same word meaning 'winter,' and both of them independently shift its meaning so that it means 'snow' instead," Dr. Ringe said. "Greek, Armenian and Sanskrit actually did that. If we used our method blindly, we'd group those languages together because they all innovated in the same way, and we'd be wrong."
Even when linguists have good reason to believe that innovations are related, coming up with the right diagram can be a daunting task.
To constrain the explosion of possibilities, linguists need some way to sift out the best candidates. The most obvious criterion is Occam's razor: the simplest tree is most likely to be correct. But weeding out the most economical tree from the deluge of possibilities results in one of those problems that mathematicians call intractable. As the size of the variables slowly increases, the computer time it takes to find the best tree soars. The problem would hopelessly overwhelm even the fastest conceivable computer.
By making artful assumptions, scientists can devise algorithms that will run in reasonable times. Dr. Ringe, Dr. Taylor and Dr. Warnow assumed that the best tree for the Indo-European language was what linguists and biologists call a perfect phylogeny, with branches, limbs and twigs radiating neatly from the trunk without the tangles caused by accidents like convergent evolution.
Using an algorithm devised by Dr. Warnow and Dr. Sampath Kannan, they analyzed 12 languages representing the 10 major Indo-European branches. The computer grouped the languages according to whether they shared certain similarities.
In addition to cognates -- related words with the same meaning, like English "mother," German "Mutter" and Spanish "madre" -- the algorithm searched for similar innovations in pronunciation. For example, "k" sounds at the beginning of Indo-European words become "h" sounds in the Germanic languages. While the initial consonant in the Latin word "cornu" (meaning horn) is preserved in French ("corne") and Spanish ("cuerno"), it shifted in ancient Gothic to "haurn" and is reflected in German as "Horn," in Dutch as "hoorn" and in Norwegian and English as "horn." Latin "centum" became the English "hundred" and German "hundert." Latin "cor" and Greek "kardia" appear as the English "heart," German "Herz," Dutch "hart" and Norwegian "hjerte."
The scientists also looked for similar grammatical innovations. Germanic languages, for example, share the same kind of past-tense marker (the "-ed" ending on regular English verbs). Nothing like this exists in other Indo-European languages.
When all the number crunching was done, the scientists were left with two diagrams showing possible relationships between the languages. But there were a number of points that could not be fit into a neat tree structure: 12 for one chart, 13 for the other. These anomalies were probably the result of chance similarities, like convergent evolution and undetected borrowings between languages. Since Germanic occupied very different places on the two trees, the linguists suspected that it was the culprit causing most of the problems.
Sure enough, when they removed Germanic from the pool, they came up with four much sturdier tree structures. This time each tree had only four or five anomalies, and the scientists were able to explain away all but two.
The first surprise was that in all four trees, the Anatolian language group immediately split away from Proto-Indo-European, just as the Indo-Hittite hypothesis has held.
The second surprise was the evidence that Germanic had shifted allegiances, from Balto-Slavic to Italic and Celtic, like a country pulled between the orbits of neighboring powers. In the past, some linguists have used Germanic's ambiguous position in the Indo-European family to argue that, in their early stages, these languages were more like a network than a tree; instead of neatly cleaving one from the other and developing in isolation, they hovered nearby, trading innovations back and forth. But Dr. Ringe and his colleagues showed that Germanic might simply be a special case.
This conclusion has raised at least one pair of eyebrows. "It's a gratuitous interpretation," Dr. Jasanoff said. "The shifting position of Germanic could simply be interpreted as saying the method didn't work."
But Dr. Ringe argued: "We've shown what we principally set out to show, that this new computational method for evolutionary tree construction is more powerful and more reliable than any in existence, and that it is especially apt for the precise testing of hypotheses about the subgroupings of languages. We're hoping this will help lead to new directions of research in historical linguistics."

HEADLINE: Wildlife Finds Odd Sanctuary on Military Bases

BYLINE: By WILLIAM K. STEVENS 

DATELINE: NICEVILLE, Fla.

 BODY:
FEW places outside the tropical rain forests contain such a wealth of biological riches as a certain plot of Florida Panhandle not far from here. In this snippet of a mostly vanished landscape, the wind sighs in the flat tops of centuries-old longleaf pines spaced as invitingly as if in a park, soaring above a thick carpet of wildflowers, grasses and haphazardly arranged shrubs.
The diversity of life "is unbeatable," Dr. Louis Provencher, an ecologist with the Nature Conservancy, said in wonder at this precious remnant of natural landscape, possibly the best example of an endangered ecosystem that once stretched from Virginia to Texas. 
 As he spoke, a red-cockaded woodpecker, its species also endangered, flitted though the sunbathed canopy -- an "R.C.W.," as the bird has become known in military parlance, for this woodland flourishes not in a national park or wilderness area but on Eglin Air Force base, half a mile from an active bombing range.
Over the last half century, as the United States kept itself girded for the cold war while converting its private domestic lands pell-mell to economic use, hundreds of military bases became islands of rich, green nature in a sea of development. The Pentagon owns more than 25 million acres on more than 400 bases in the United States, the third largest acreage of any Federal department, after Interior and Agriculture.
Some of these lands offer "the last, best hope for protecting certain kinds of ecosystems," said Sherri W. Goodman, the Deputy Undersecretary of Defense for Environmental Security, who has aggressively promoted an active conservation role for the military.
Typically, only part of a base is actually used for military purposes, with much land set aside as a buffer zone. The military has long managed these lands to protect fish, game and, under Federal law, endangered species. But in some ways the military contribution to conservation until recently has been one of benign neglect. Not least among the accidental benefits has been the inadvertent restoration of fire to many landscapes that depend on it for regeneration.
Fire insures biological diversity, for instance, by keeping a handful of aggressive plant species from crowding out scores of less aggressive ones. This sort of cleansing fire has generally been suppressed in America. But at Eglin and many other bases, fires started by exploding munitions have restored the natural process. The rich scene marveled at by Dr. Provencher has been one such beneficiary.
Now, to the cheers of conservationists, the military is going a step further by trying to turn its lands into models of conservation practice. The goal is to manage whole ecosystems for maximum biodiversity while still allowing for human use of the land -- in this case, military training and weapons testing.
According to this way of thinking, only an ecosystem approach allows the necessary flexibility. Advocates also argue that it is vital to preserve vanishing ecosystems, with whole assemblages of potentially threatened species, rather than simply to manage the landscape for limited objectives like hunting and fishing or for a few endangered species.
It is an approach widely espoused by leading conservationists and the Clinton Administration, but difficult to pursue on private lands because it requires the hard-to-get cooperation of many owners. Ecosystem management is likewise frustrated on many Federal lands because of grazing and logging interests. In the military, there is only one owner and user, and once the word comes down and the base commander gets on board, things tend to happen. "We don't have our shoestrings tied together," said Eglin's wildlife manager, Carl J. Petrick.
Ecosystem management is now official Pentagon policy everywhere, reinforced by detailed guidelines. At Eglin, for instance, managers are systematically taking inventory of the 460,000-acre base's multitude of species large and small, protecting the coherent assemblages in which they exist, restoring areas formerly damaged by logging and purposely setting fires of rejuvenation. They are doing it while Eglin pursues its mission of training air crews and testing weapons.
The conservation effort requires detailed and hard-to-obtain knowledge of the ecosystem, so Eglin has formed working alliances with experts at a number of universities and with the Nature Conservancy, the nation's largest private, science-based landscape manager and collector of ecosystem data. As a result of similar undertakings at other bases, the military is acquiring a new green reputation to offset the bad odor surrounding its continuing struggle to clean up decades' worth of toxic wastes on its land.
Conservation organizations have showered Eglin with awards and generally praised the military's new effort, though some experts say the quality of that effort varies from place to place. Interior Secretary Bruce Babbitt, a dedicated conservationist, has become an evangelical cheerleader on the military's behalf. His department has signed a number of partnership agreements with military bases to protect valuable species habitats.
The Nature Conservancy, for its part, is "pretty impressed," said Michele Leslie, who works for the organization and heads a cooperative program with the Department of Defense to help manage landscapes at more than 170 bases in 41 states. "We think, in general, they're doing a pretty good job," Ms. Leslie said of the bases, "and in fact they're setting new standards."
On another front, the wave of base closings in recent years has presented instant opportunities to convert large tracts of habitat to nature preserves and to create harmonious blends of open space and private development. This is particularly true in the East and the North, where there are relatively few large tracts of public land.
A case in point is Fort Devens, Mass., New England's largest Army post and its military center in four wars. The post's 9,300 acres contain the biggest plot of open land in southern New England. Much of it is classic Northeastern forest in an undulating setting sculpted milleniums ago by the last Ice Age glacier and punctuated by a number of "kettle ponds" created when great blocks of ice depressed the land and then melted. Extensive wetlands dot the landscape. The big, ungainly nests of great blue herons are dotted about the wetland treetops. Beaver lodges grace the water's edge. Twenty-three species of plants and animals rare in Massachusetts live on the post.
Devens is being closed as an active post, with about half its land retained for training reservists. The rest, including the post's extensive "town" area and more than 2,000 acres of open land, is to be given up by the Army. Roughly a thousand acres of critical habitat flanking the Nashua River are being transferred to the United States Fish and Wildlife Service, more than doubling the size of the adjacent Oxbow National Wildlife Refuge.
"When you can set aside those kind of acres in a heavily developed area like the Northeast, it's a major accomplishment for the wildlife," said Ed Moses of the Fish and Wildlife Service, who manages the Oxbow refuge and eight others.
About 1,000 other acres on the base are to be managed for conservation values, with varying degrees of human use allowed. The urban area of the post is to be converted by the state into a new economic center focusing mainly on technology-based companies and education. The intended result is an environmentally friendly new civilian community decorated by what its boosters call an "emerald necklace" of ecologically valuable natural areas.
Similar things are happening at other bases being closed or partly closed. At Fort Ord, Calif., some 17,000 acres of prime beach, dune, chaparral and oak forest habitat containing imperiled species like the snowy plover and Smith's blue butterfly are to become permanent nature reserves under nonmilitary Federal land agencies.
At Fort Meade, Md., the home of the National Security Agency, more than 8,000 acres of forest and wetland have been transferred to the neighboring Patuxent Research Refuge of the Fish and Wildlife Service, tripling the size of the refuge. At Joliet Arsenal in Illinois, plans call for transforming part of the post into a 19,000-acre National Tallgrass Prairie, the largest such preserve east of the Mississippi.
Base closings present risk as well as opportunity. Much unexploded ordnance lies around. A worse risk, some conservationists say, is that the military's withdrawal may touch off land grabs by developers. Fort Devens was eyed by Massachusetts as a promising site for a new regional airport. It took an explosion of outrage from towns around the post to make the state back off.
The Marine Corps' 126,000-acre Camp Pendleton stands out as the last relatively undisturbed natural area between Los Angeles and San Diego. Outside the base, conservationists and developers are struggling to put together a network of nature preserves designed to save the coastal scrub sage ecosystem while allowing some habitat to be developed. But inside the base, the Marines are already actively managing an extensive preserve of coastal scrub sage, grasslands, chaparral, beaches and estuaries, all home to nearly 600 wild species, 13 of them endangered.
The challenge is to "work out ways in which the military mission and nature can coexist," said Maj. Jeff Caspers, Pendleton's deputy commander for natural resources. One illustration: in a successful effort to rebuild the base population of the endangered least Bell's vireo, the Marines avoid the bird's habitat during the summer mating season.
At Eglin, the main object of ecosystem management is a 320,000-acre remnant of the longleaf pine ecosystem. The woodland, which once covered 60 million to 90 million acres in the Southeast, occupies about three-quarters of the base. Under the pines live more than 150 species of plants and thousands of species of invertebrates, making the woodland's flora and fauna among the most diverse in the world.
The ecosystem as a whole is adapted to fire; the pines themselves are fire-resistant, but thay have highly flammable needles that together with equally combustible wiregrass provide the fuel for the rejuvenating blazes.
Most of the longleaf system throughout the South has been logged and replanted with other tree species, and fire has long been suppressed in most of the rest. As a result, the longleaf landscape covers only about 3 percent of its former area. At Eglin, where managers set controlled fires in addition to those caused by munitions, the patches of longleaf are beginning to regain their original character and richness. On many tracts where logging was allowed, longleafs are being replanted.
The Eglin managers hope that as the base's woodlands, wetlands, rivers and beaches recover, so will populations of the red-cockaded woodpecker and some 90 other rare or imperiled species on the base. Among them are animals like the Okaloosa darter, the bog frog, the alligator snapping turtle, the Florida pine snake, Bachman's warbler and the bald eagle, and plants like bogbuttons, Chapman's aster, the ebony spleenwort, the toothed savory, the perforate reindeer lichen, the pond spicebush, naked-stemmed panic grass and the pineland hoary pea.
If the Pentagon's managers at Eglin and other bases achieve their new goals, they will have demonstrated that those who bomb, strafe and sew mines can be among nature's best stewards.

HEADLINE: OUTLOOK '96: THE ECONOMY: Middle Age Catches Up With the Me Generation;
Increasing the Demand For Health Care Services

BYLINE: By MILT FREUDENHEIM 

 BODY:
The providers of health care can hardly wait as the latest crop of 50-year-olds crosses the threshold to the aches and pains of middle age. Having grown up expecting and generally finding care that was both affordable and accessible, the graying boomers will now need it a lot more, and that should translate into bonanzas for drug makers, many physicians and hospitals, not to mention the makers of artificial knees for worn-out joggers who refuse to slow down.
"Inexorably, demand goes higher," said John F. Hindelong, a health care securities analyst with Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette. "The question is, who pays for it?" 
 Unlike their parents who were Depression era babies with low expectations for government help, many boomers view medical care as a right rather than a privilege.
But with the rising expenses that come with age and budget cutters preparing to raise the eligibility age to 66 or 67 for Social Security and Medicare, employers are likely to become nervous about the cost of continuing care, said Marilyn Moon, a health policy expert at the Urban Institute, a nonprofit Washington research center.
Known for wanting immediate gratification, the boomers' generation has always been strong on preventive health care and self-medication.
"Clearly we all want to live forever, and we all want to live as we lived when we were younger," said Kenneth S. Abramowitz, an analyst with Sanford C. Bernstein & Company. That could increase demand for angioplasty and other less invasive surgical techniques, "so we can rehabilitate ourselves as quickly as possible," he said.
For those still working for employers who provide health coverage, the checkout lines at drug counters will be even longer as more and more health plans help with the tab for prescription drugs. The potential customers for pharmaceuticals will swell as people of all ages increasingly get their care through health maintenance organizations. MILT FREUDENHEIM

HEADLINE: OUTLOOK '96: THE ECONOMY: Middle Age Catches Up With the Me Generation;
Changing the Shape Of the Housing Market

BYLINE: By DENNIS HEVESI 

 BODY:
After having "paired and nested," many members of the baby boom generation are now in the process of trading up to single-family homes, public policy analysts say.
"They are trading up to bigger homes and to communities where they will want to stay for quite a while," said James W. Hughes, dean of the Edward J. Bloustein School of Public Policy at Rutgers University. 
 Indeed, more than two-thirds of new single-family homes are now sold to trade-up buyers, said Michael Carliner, economist at the National Association of Home Builders.
That trend, experts say, will help shape the nation's housing market through the 1990's and past the turn of the century.
The baby boomers began flooding the real estate market in the 1970's, spurring a total of 2.4 million housing starts in 1972 -- the peak year since World War II. After a late 1980's slump in the market, housing starts in 1991 fell to a postwar low of 1.01 million units.
Mr. Carliner estimated there were 1.4 million housing starts in 1995.
While the boom of the 1970's was largely spurred by the construction of multifamily dwellings, with the Government providing subsidies for such construction, the current turnaround was prompted by the maturation of the baby boomers.
At least through the rest of this decade, said H. James Brown, director of the Center for Housing Studies at Harvard University, "trade-up households will dominate the market and housing construction."
Regional economies, of course, will give particular shape to local housing markets. The prevalence of trade-up buyers in the Northeast and California, where economic recovery has been slower, will be more evident than in communities like Denver, Phoenix or Las Vegas, Nev., where new jobs attract younger, first-time buyers.
Mr. Hughes of Rutgers noted that in 1994, 88 percent of the units constructed in New Jersey were single-family -- up from an average of 61 percent since 1960. "And that's typical of the suburban ring" of Connecticut, New Jersey and New York, he said. DENNIS HEVESI

HEADLINE: OUTLOOK '96: THE ECONOMY: Middle Age Catches Up With the Me Generation;
Replenishing the Ranks Of High-Skilled Workers

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER 

 BODY:
When the United Automobile Workers begin negotiations this year with the Big Three auto companies, the shifting of work to outside suppliers is expected to be its single biggest concern. But it may not be at the top of the agenda for many U.A.W. members.
For hundreds of thousands of auto workers, the protection and -- if possible -- the extension of retirement benefits are of paramount importance. Roughly half the combined hourly work force at the General Motors Corporation, the Ford Motor Company and the Chrysler Corporation will be eligible to retire within a decade. 
 To a lesser extent, the same rush to the exits is expected to sweep over other manufacturers nationwide. In the current tight labor markets, signs of wage pressures and shortages of skilled workers are already beginning to appear in the Midwest.
"The total number of jobs is not climbing much, but with retirements the demand to replace manufacturing workers is much higher than people realize," said Diane Swonk, deputy chief economist at the First Chicago NBD Corporation. "Entry-level wages are being bid up."
Manufacturers are already worried not just about the number of young people who will be available to replace retiring baby boomers but about their low skill levels. In turning to automation, many manufacturers are searching for abilities, like a familiarity with computers, that are in short supply among those looking for factory jobs. That problem has in turn encouraged many manufacturers to invest in still more automation so that they can get the most from the dwindling ranks of the experienced and highly skilled. And some are making big efforts to keep those they have.
"When people retire, we try to talk them into staying with us to work part-time," said Linda Decker, head of human resources for Hunter Automated Machinery, a foundry company in suburban Chicago.
The value of hanging on to experienced employees and the need to cut workers' compensation claims are contributing to a growing interest in workplace ergonomics.
Levi Strauss & Company, the jeans maker, has invested in variable-height work stations for folding, bagging and marking its products. And the Timken Company, which makes bearings for rail cars, has installed lifts that reduce the demands on its aging workers to hoist boxes of bearings. BARNABY J. FEDER

HEADLINE: OUTLOOK '96: THE ECONOMY: Middle Age Catches Up With the Me Generation;
Getting the Message To Aging Consumers

BYLINE: By STUART ELLIOTT 

 BODY:
The aging of the baby-boom generation will have profound implications for consumer marketers, who are scrambling to adapt to the needs, tastes and attitudes of the boomers. Significant changes are expected in everything from the kinds of products on store shelves to the look and tone of ads.
The companies most eagerly anticipating the coming wave of graying boomers are those selling goods and services to a preponderance of older users. 
 For example, those aged 50 to 55 and older consume "about twice as much soup as the younger demographics," said Aaron Wadell, business director for condensed soups at the Campbell Soup Company in Camden, N.J. Even so, he added. "you have to stay relevant, rejuvenate the business to make it contemporary with their growing and changing needs."
Campbell has introduced reduced-fat versions of its three best-selling cream soups: cream of celery, chicken and mushroom. And because boomers' palates are more diversified, Campbell will add varieties of soups to the 70 already being sold.
The boomers' crossing the threshold of 50 is "good news for greeting-card companies," said Sara Eames, a spokeswoman for the American Greetings Corporation in Cleveland, because "people buy more cards when they're 55 to 64."
So American Greetings is adding more "milestone products," birthday cards and party goods for specific ages. "The ages we identify are getting older," Ms. Eames said, "50, 60, 100. And we're gearing up for another milestone, 50th anniversaries."
The luxury segment of the automobile industry is thrilled as tens of millions of boomers begin entering the age bracket in which such cars are most frequently bought.
"The big question," said Chris Cedergren, a senior vice president with the Auto Pacific Group, an automotive consulting company, "is what are they going to buy."
"They'll want cars with similar attributes their parents and grandparents wanted -- more comfortable vehicles, easier to get in and out of -- but more individualistic and personality-oriented" than present-day Cadillacs and Lincolns, he said.
"For some brands like Buick," he added, "it will be very, very tough to get baby boomers to buy them even when they're in their 60's and 70's," because they are perceived as "the fuddy-duddy car your dad or granddad drove."
One auto maker already working on altering its models and marketing communications is the Mercedes-Benz of North America unit of Daimler-Benz. Smaller, less expensive cars aimed at boomers are being sold with advertising campaigns infused with whimsy, humor and nostalgia for the 1960's, most notably commercials for 1995 and 1996 models featuring the Janis Joplin song that begins "Oh Lord, won't you buy me a Mercedes-Benz."
There is "an opportunity to make Mercedes relevant to the boomers," said Ms. Cook of Lowe & Partners/SMS, the Mercedes-Benz agency. The Joplin tune, she added, recognizes that "boomers are reluctant to give up their music, their clothing, their consumption habits."
The outlook for new products is strong, marketing experts say, because of the interest among many boomers in health and fitness. They expect lines of so-called nutriceuticals and cosmeceuticals -- hybrids of foods and drugs and cosmetics and drugs.
"Any product that allows people to look or feel better will be as acne creams were in the 60's," said Mr. Dychtwald of Age Wave. STUART ELLIOTT

HEADLINE: Pataki's Budget Plan in Brief: Amid Austerity, a Tax Break

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Jan. 1

 BODY:
Reducing spending from state taxes for the second consecutive year, Gov. George E. Pataki's budget for 1996-97 promises an austerity not seen in Albany since World War II and a Governor named Dewey.
As a whole, the $63.8 billion budget that Mr. Pataki has proposed provides perhaps the clearest view yet of his three core political beliefs: that shrinking government and reducing taxes spur economic growth, that lengthening prison sentences deters crime and that sharply limiting welfare benefits encourages work and independence. 
 Democrats, not surprisingly, say that the Governor's budget will cause economic disarray in the health-care industry, danger in the prison system and despair among the needy. At the same time, they have signaled that they are going to pick their spots in the budget battle, indicating that they are willing to preserve the income tax cut and accept some welfare reductions if they can restore some spending for Medicaid and higher education.
Because 1996 is a legislative election year, this budget and its impact on New York will be debated not just in Albany, but on the campaign trail and in television advertisements as well. With so much fighting in store, few are predicting that this budget will be approved by the start of the 1996-97 fiscal year on April 1.
 
Tax Cuts
Earlier this year, when it became clear that Federal budget cuts and the state's own recurring fiscal problems would leave a $3.9 billion shortfall in the 1996-97 budget, legislators in both parties quietly suggested something that they had done several times before: defer a promised tax cut.
But Mr. Pataki, who as a state legislator chastised his colleagues when they deferred such cuts in the past, put the tax cut into his budget and has vowed to veto any efforts to delay it.
The clear choice for deferral would be the second installment of a three-year, phased cut in the state personal income tax. Under that plan, the top tax rate would drop to 7.125 percent from 7.59 percent in 1996, while the standard deduction for married couples and individuals would increase. When the cut is fully in place by 1997, a family of four with an annual income of $50,000 would save $663 in state taxes.
The second phase of the tax cut would reduce state revenues by $1.7 billion in 1996-97, or almost half of the projected shortfall. Deferring the second installment would enable lawmakers to avoid making cuts in their favored programs. Before Mr. Pataki took office in 1995, the Legislature had deferred a scheduled income tax cut every year since 1990.
Perhaps because of the Governor's firm stand, or because 1996 is an election year when delaying a tax cut could be political suicide, legislative leaders have said they would not defer the scheduled cut. Indeed, the Assembly Speaker, Sheldon Silver, leader of the Legislature's Democrats, the group considered most likely to advocate a deferral, has said he would fight to maintain the tax cut.
Mr. Pataki's budget also maintains the third installment of business tax cuts that would reduce state revenues by $300 million in 1996-97. And bowing to pressure from the Republican leadership of the State Senate, he has proposed a $50 million fund to provide tax relief to select companies that create or retain jobs.
Some Republican senators have talked of deferring the second year of the personal income tax cut, and granting instead a reduction in the gross receipts tax, a levy on utilities that has contributed to high electric and gas bills. Mr. Pataki's aides have said the Governor would oppose that.
Yet for all his insistence on maintaining tax cuts, Mr. Pataki's budget includes a proposal to allow cities to raise the local portion of the gross receipts tax. JAMES DAO
