HEADLINE: Pataki's Budget Plan in Brief: Amid Austerity, a Tax Break;
Welfare

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO 

 BODY:
The single biggest cut in Mr. Pataki's budget, after Medicaid, would be in welfare, where he is hoping to save $240 million through time limits on benefits and reductions in monthly grants.
Mr. Pataki is proposing a limit of 60 days per 12-month period for Home Relief, the state and local program mainly for single adults and childless couples. He would also set a lifetime limit of five years in the program, meaning a recipient could receive 60 days of Home Relief, five times in a lifetime. 
 Taking his lead from a similar Federal proposal, Mr. Pataki would also set a five-year lifetime limit on Aid to Families with Dependent Children, the Federal and state program that serves mainly single-parent families. And he would stop giving increased benefits to families who have additional children while on welfare.
Currently, there are no time limits on either Home Relief or A.F.D.C. There are 316,739 New Yorkers enrolled in Home Relief and 1.2 million others on A.F.D.C., of which about 773,000 are children.
The Governor's budget would also reduce monthly grants to the same level as New Jersey, about a 25 percent cut for both programs. A family of three living in New York City would see their monthly A.F.D.C. check shrink from $575 to $424.
Mr. Pataki contends that reducing monthly grants would discourage poor people from moving to New York in search of higher benefits. And he says that time limits would prod welfare recipients to find work and gain economic independence.
His budget includes some money for job training and day care to help parents move into the work force. It would also create a $100 million fund to provide food, clothing and shelter to people removed from the welfare rolls due to time limits.
But critics, including many Democrats and advocates for the poor, contend that Mr. Pataki has not provided enough money to prepare welfare recipients for work or to help sustain them once they are removed from the rolls. They say the state's monthly benefit levels are already insufficient and that reducing them will cause homelessness and suffering.
But some of the things Mr. Pataki wants to do are the subject of negotiations between Congress and the White House. If Washington approves time limits and other welfare reductions, the state might have to do the same because it would be unable to offset the Federal cuts.
For that reason, Democrats in the Legislature are already saying that they will accede to time limits if Congress and the President approve them. But the Democrats say they will fight any reductions in benefit levels. JAMES DAO

HEADLINE: Mexican Stocks Leap 5.4%, Injecting Optimism

BYLINE: By JULIA PRESTON 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Jan. 2

 BODY:
The Mexican stock market began the new year with a roaring start today by closing at an all-time high, giving a jolt of optimism to an economy that spent 1995 in deep recession.
The surge on the first day of trading in 1996 suggested that Mexico's leaders were making some headway in recovering the trust they catastrophically lost in the bungled peso devaluation of December 1994. 
 But Mexico still has a long way to go to rebuild its credibility, analysts and Government officials said, adding that the markets would remain skittish until signs of renewed growth became unmistakable.
The Mexico City stock market's leading index rose 150.96 points, or more than 5.4 percent, to close at 2,929.43. It surpassed a record of 2,881.17, set on Feb. 8, 1994, during the Mexican market boom of 1994.
In New York, American depository receipts of Mexican companies performed strongly, as did closed-end funds made up of holdings of Mexican companies and debt instruments. The bellwether Telefonos de Mexico rose $2.375, to $34.25, on the New York Stock Exchange. Grupo Televisa, a big entertainment conglomerate, was up even more sharply, gaining $2.625 to close at $25.125. B shares of the industrial company Cemex improved 43.75 cents, to $7.50. Among funds, the Mexico Fund gained $1.50, to $14.25. The Emerging Mexico Fund rose 62.5 cents, to $6.75, and the Mexico Equity and Income Fund was up 75 cents, to close at $9.375.
Mexico's national leaders, after some false starts, made a sustained effort in 1995 to pull back from their country's financial breakdown and to restart growth. But international investors did not seem to believe it. Just when the economy seemed to have stabilized last fall, nervous traders and investors dumped Mexican pesos, causing the already battered currency to drop a further 25 percent in two months.
Only in December, after Mexican finance authorities jumped into the markets to stop peso speculators, did the peso and the stock market begin to climb again.
President Ernesto Zedillo, a Yale-trained economist, and Finance Minister Guillermo Ortiz decided to confront the lack of confidence with their own consistency. They concluded that the answer was to stick closely to strict economic policies to satisfy investors that there would be no more unpleasant surprises.
"We don't want to talk people into believing us; we want to do things that convince people," Foreign Minister Angel Gurria, a former high-level Finance Ministry official, said in a recent interview.
Mexico stuck grimly to Mr. Ortiz's program of curbing inflation with tight money and a balanced budget at the cost of painful restraints on public spending. Mr. Ortiz, a former ranking official at the International Monetary Fund, made Mexicans swallow their bitter medicine in the midst of a 7 percent economic contraction, the sharpest in six decades.
As a result, Mexico ended the year on solid ground, and there is no sign that Mr. Ortiz will loosen up in 1996. The Government fulfilled its obligations on virtually all the $29.2 billion in dollar-denominated bonds known as tesobonos. Mexico did not use all the $20 billion in credit offered by the Clinton Administration and was repaying by selling longer-term bonds on international capital markets.
In 1996, Mr. Ortiz said, Mexico's cost of servicing its foreign debts will drop to a new low as a percentage of export income.
Exports, which rose to 30 percent of the gross domestic product last year, will be the winch that pulls the economy out of its hole, officials said. The budget is expected to be in balance again and inflation kept in check.
Mexican officials reading unemployment figures said that recovery had already begun, at least on paper. But in everyday life, most Mexicans see only hardship and frustration. Their protests, up to now restrained, could intensify if relief does not come soon. Uncertainty also persists about the ailing banking system. The Government costs for bank and debtor bailouts have risen to $10.9 billion, which taxpayers will be absorbing over the next three decades.
Looming behind the financial calculations is a larger doubt, shared by Mexican and foreign investors, about Mr. Zedillo's leadership. In a country accustomed to presidents of monarchical style, the mild-mannered Mr. Zedillo seeks to stress policy over personality and to build democratic institutions rather than presidential power. But while many Mexicans agree that the arbitrary rule of past presidents caused many of their current woes, they feel nervous without it.
"The Mexicans themselves are arguing that you can't liberalize without imposition by a strong political leader," said Sylvia Maxfield, a professor of management and political science at Yale University. "It's a contradiction in terms, but they are so used to a strong leader they just can't cope."
Mr. Ortiz has shown that he is a skilled policy maker, but seems to lack the larger-than-life quality that foreign investors have come to expect from Mexican finance ministers. As a result, as Mexico backs away from a suffocating one-party system that at least provided stability for 66 years, Mexican investors, in particular, will be skittish and highly sensitive to news events.
"The substance of the policy is right. The question is, can they communicate it?" said the United States Ambassador here, James R. Jones, a former chairman of the American Stock Exchange. Mr. Jones termed Mexico's current situation a "Bush recovery," alluding to the last year of President George Bush's Administration, when American growth had started, somewhat imperceptibly, to revive. Mexico's progress, specialists say, will not be felt at dinner tables until the third quarter of 1996.
Some Americans with long-term investments in Mexico, although shaken by the financial crisis, remain convinced that they made the right choice. Dale Robertson, head of Mexico operations at SBC Communications, a regional Bell company that spent $1 billion in 1990 to buy a stake in Telefonos de Mexico, sees telecommunications growth wherever he looks.
"I don't see any market out there that's set to decline," he said.

HEADLINE: Stocks Gain As New Year Starts Strong

BYLINE: By LEONARD SLOANE 

 BODY:
The stock market started 1996 the same way it finished 1995 -- with general optimism and a price rally.
"The market continues to perceive indications of slow growth and lower inflation numbers as positive," said Barbara C. Marcin, vice president of Citibank Global Asset Management. "But the rate of increase in earnings has definitely peaked." 
 The Dow Jones industrial average advanced 60.33 points yesterday, to 5,177.45. It was the best performance for the Dow since an 86-point day last May and would have been the second-best individual day of 1995.
But the Dow rose more than stocks in general, with the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index increasing 4.80 points, to 620.73. The Nasdaq composite index gained 6.52 points, to 1,058.65.
Among the three best performers in the Dow, AT&T climbed 2 5/8, to 67 3/8, after announcing yesterday that it planned to cut its work force by 13 percent in the next three years and take a $6 billion charge against earnings that would reduce its after-tax profit for the fourth quarter of 1995 by $4 billion. Du Pont leaped 2 1/8, to 72, on expectations that it would enjoy greater revenues this year. And Walt Disney rose 2, to 60 7/8, after being upgraded by Robertson, Stephens & Company.
AT&T was responsible for 7.6 index points in the Dow, while Du Pont's rise accounted for 6.1 points.
Index-linked trading also played a major role in the surge in the Dow industrials, triggering the New York Stock Exchange's so-called downtick rule at 2:30 P.M. when the Dow gained more than 50 points. According to Birinyi Associates, the Dow has moved up by at least 50 points on the first trading day in three of the last nine years.
The stock market also rose on news that manufacturing slowed for the fifth consecutive month in December, raising prospects that the Federal Reserve will lower interest rates soon to stimulate the economy.
The Dow was also pushed upward by a surprisingly weak December report by the Association of Purchasing Management, which said its Purchasing Managers' Index was up slightly to 47.3 percent from 46.5 percent in November. The reading below 50 percent indicated manufacturing activity contracted last month, although at a slower rate than in November.
The index was one of the few bits of economic data the market has seen due to the partial Government shutdown caused by the budget impasse in Washington.
Advancing issues on the Big Board exceeded declining one by 1,591 to 917. Volume rose to 364.3 million shares, from 321.3 million shares last Friday.
"No recession is expected anytime soon," said Sung Won Sohn, a corporate economist at Norwest Corporation in Minneapolis. But he added that "if a credible compromise on a balanced budget is not reached, the disappointment could hurt the financial markets and the economy."
Retail stocks were boosted when Merrill Lynch raised its rating on Sears, Roebuck -- also a component of the Dow -- to "buy" from "above average." Retail stocks had been beaten down last year and several analysts had predicted they would rise with the new year. Sears rose 1 3/8, to 40 3/8; Wal-Mart increased 1, to 23 1/4; the Gap advanced 2 5/8,, to 44 5/8, and J. C. Penney rallied 1, to 48 5/8.
Toys "R" Us, which said that same-store sales rose 2 percent last month, picked up 2 1/4, to 24.
Some technology stocks rebounded on projections of profit gains. Microsoft closed at 89 3/4, up 2; Micron Technology ended at 41 1/2, up 1 7/8; Intel closed at 58 5/8, up 1 7/8, and Novell finished at 15 3/8, up 1 1/8.
But shares of Silicon Graphics tumbled 16 percent when the company predicted lower earnings. The company's shares, which were the most actively traded yesterday, dropped $4.375, to close at $23.25 on the New York Stock Exchange, after trading at a new 52-week low of $22.
Airline stocks rallied as most major carriers chose not to collect a 10 percent Federal excise tax that lapsed over the New Year holiday, effectively cutting fares by the same amount. UAL, operator of United Airlines, jumped 3 3/8, to 181 7/8; AMR, the parent of American Airlines, gained 7/8, to 75 1/8, and Delta Air Lines rose 2 1/4, to 75 7/8.

HEADLINE: Big 3 Dispute Challenge Over New-Car Costs

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Jan. 2

 BODY:
One of the nation's top experts on measuring consumer sentiment warned today that car buyers were more concerned about prices now than at any time in the last decade, but top economists of the Big Three auto makers dismissed his contention.
The disagreement, coming at the start of what is expected to be a year of low growth, at best, in car sales, reflected an issue being discussed more and more often in the industry: whether consumers can still afford to buy cars at the pace of recent years. The prices of new vehicles rose an average of about 8 percent annually from 1973 through 1993, according to a study by the University of Michigan, and they are continuing to rise briskly. Family incomes rose about 5 percent annually during that period and have stagnated recently. 
 As car sales have slowed in recent months, auto executives have played down questions about affordability, pointing out that some of their best sellers are costly mini-vans and sport-utility vehicles and cars loaded with options. A rapid rise in trade-in prices for used cars over the last few years has allowed many buyers of new cars to purchase more expensive vehicles.
But Richard T. Curtin, the director of consumer surveys at the University of Michigan at Ann Arbor, predicted today that many Americans might remain reluctant to buy cars because of worries over prices. "Little in the way of further improvement can be expected until consumer attitudes toward interest rates and prices recover," he said at a gathering here of the Society of Automotive Analysts.
Economists at the General Motors Corporation, the Chrysler Corporation and particularly the Ford Motor Company took a different view, discounting concerns about affordability while predicting that sales of new cars and trucks in the United States would continue this year at roughly last year's solid but unspectacular level of 15.1 million vehicles.
Martin Zimmerman, Ford's executive director of governmental relations and corporate economics, emphasized that consumer spending on cars had held steady at slightly more than 4 percent of the nation's economic output for three decades and showed no sign of falling. Because sales of new cars are now growing at an average of only one-half of 1 percent a year, prices have inevitably risen faster as cars kept a steady share of consumer spending, he said.
G. Mustafa Mohatarem, the chief economist at G.M., and W. Van Bussman, Chrysler's corporate economist, made similar points, although Mr. Bussman noted that consumer installment debt had reached a record 19.7 percent of household disposable income, possibly limiting the room for many Americans to borrow more money.
Mr. Zimmerman was especially critical of the view that the widening gap in the distribution of income had left fewer Americans able to afford new cars. Car makers still market cars to buyers with a range of incomes, he said, and the poorest one-fifth of all Americans have never accounted for a large share of new-car sales.
But Sean P. McAlinden, the manager of automotive economic studies at the University of Michigan, said that there were signs that car makers were chasing ever more affluent consumers while charging higher and higher prices. "The middle market that G.M. built and that is the basis of Ford and Chrysler, is dying," he said.
Ford has been the most aggressive of the big car makers in pushing up prices recently, notably for its best-selling car, the Taurus. Sales of the redesigned Taurus have been weak, a pattern that Ford executives attribute to such factors as their decision to reduce sales to rental-car fleets because of the low profit margins for such transactions. But some Ford dealers have already been pressing for discounts on the Taurus.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
The Dollar Rises on a Quiet Day, A Peculiarity of 3-Way Trading

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar ended mostly higher against leading currencies in quiet trading yesterday, strengthening as the Japanese yen came under pressure in Europe.
Investors have been seeking currencies with better value than the yen, causing the Japanese currency to sink in recent days, traders said. The trend continued yesterday, exacerbated slightly by the absence of Japanese trading. Markets in Japan were closed until tomorrow for a three-day holiday. 
 "There's a lot of money coming out of yen into other currencies," said Margaret Kudarauskas, senior foreign-exchange analyst at Technical Data in Boston. "There's a general preference for higher-yielding currencies, and the feeling is that Japanese interest rates will not go up soon."
The dollar gained against the German mark, which was weakened in Europe, where the outlook for interest rates favored currencies like the Swiss franc and the Italian lira.
In late New York trading yesterday, the dollar was quoted at 103.92 yen, up from 103.40 late Friday. It changed hands at 1.4367 marks, up from 1.4366 on Friday.
The yen has weakened amid political uncertainty, weakness in banking and a stronger interest-rate outlook in Europe and the United States, compared with Japan.
Strength in some European currencies has also helped the dollar against the yen because investors must sometimes exchange yen for dollars before buying European currencies.
Dealers attributed the dollar's strength yesterday to that factor, rather than to any fundamental changes in perceptions of the dollar's strength. Trading was thin on the first market day of the new year, and the dollar was unable to break through the 104-yen level, a technical barrier that would presumably set off sell orders to capture profits.
"That kept the lid on dollar-yen," Ms. Kudarauskas of Technical Point said.
But the dollar is underpinned by surging American stock and bond markets and from expectations that Congressional leaders will reach an agreement with President Clinton to balance the budget.
In other currency trading, the Mexican peso strengthened against the dollar as the Mexican stock market rose sharply. In New York, the peso edged up to 13 United States cents from 12.9 cents on Friday.

HEADLINE: Silicon Graphics' Stock Falls on Profit Outlook

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE M. FISHER 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan 2

 BODY:
Shares in Silicon Graphics Inc. tumbled 16 percent today after the company said it expected to report lower earnings for its fiscal third quarter.
Silicon Graphics said its earnings would fall below both the comparable 1994 quarter and Wall Street analysts' estimates. 
 Filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission indicate Silicon Graphics executives sold shares prior to today's announcement. A spokeswoman said the sales reflected normal volumes for the executives named, plus one large sale by an executive whose company was acquired by Silicon Graphics last year.
Silicon Graphics shares dropped $4.375, to close at $23.25 on the New York Stock Exchange, after trading at a new 52-week low of $22, less than half the high of $45.625 reached on July 13. Analysts said the company was likely to underperform for the next two quarters as well, and that to the extent its disappointing results reflected broad economic trends, they could bode ill for competitors, like the Hewlett-Packard Company and Sun Microsystems Inc.
For the quarter ended Dec. 31, Silicon Graphics said it expected to report net income of approximately 30 cents a share on revenue of $675 million. The company had profit of 34 cents a share on revenues of $550 million for the comparable period a year earlier. Wall Street's consensus estimate was 42 cents a share. The company will announce actual results on Jan. 17.
"Our revenue growth rate in North America and Europe did not meet our expectations," Edward R. McCracken, Silicon Graphics' chairman and chief executive, said in a statement. "Contributing factors in North America include a slowdown in sales to the U.S. Government, caused in part by budget uncertainties, and lower revenues from our O.E.M. channels," he said, referring to original equipment manufacturers who resell Silicon Graphics products under their own brand names.
Mr. McCracken said the company's European results were affected by economic slowdowns in Germany, France and Britain.
Separately, filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission indicate Mr. McCracken sold 60,000 shares at $36 to $36.98 each in late November. Robert Burgess, a senior vice president who joined the company when it acquired Alias Research Inc., sold 150,588 shares worth about $5.01 million. Jill Grossman, a spokeswoman, said Mr. Burgess had been blocked from selling shares following the merger.
Doug van Dorsten, an analyst with Hambrecht & Quist, said Silicon Graphics was also struggling with introducing a new product and with an influx of new salespeople. "They've got a major product transition this month, so there's a certain amount of trying to sell old product and being supply constrained on the new," he said, adding that he did not expect a return to strong growth until the September quarter.
Although Silicon Graphics is best known for producing the computer work stations on which Hollywood film makers create special effects, the bulk of the company's business still comes from auto makers, military contractors and other customers more vulnerable to slowdowns in capital expenditures.
"Despite these disappointments, we believe that our revenue growth rate indicates increasing market share and that our operating profitability compares favorably with that of our industry," Mr. McCracken said. "Our fundamental competitive position remains favorable."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

AT&T to Cut 40,000 Jobs And Take $6 Billion Charge
AT&T announced that it would eliminate 40,000 of its 300,000 jobs -- mostly through layoffs -- over the next three years and charge $6 billion against earnings as it prepared to split into three companies. The goal is to compete better as technological change sweeps the industry. [Page A1.]
 
The cutbacks may portend job losses at the seven regional Bell companies, which have already slashed their payrolls by tens of thousands of workers. They must defend their local monopolies against new rivals. [D2.]
 
Profits Gush, but Dividends Trickle
American companies, though awash in profits, hardly raised dividends last year. Instead they plowed more money back into their businesses and set aside a lot for a rainy day. Still, with stock prices so much higher, shareholders have not been complaining. [A1.]
 
More Irresolution on Budget
Senate Republicans voted to reopen Government offices while Congress and President Clinton continue talks on balancing the Federal budget, but House Republicans showed no interest in going along. They say the shutdown is their only lever to force President Clinton into meaningful negotiations. [A1.]
 
Kerkorian Presses Chrysler
Kirk Kerkorian called on Chrysler to buy back $2 billion of its stock annually until the next recession. His deputy, Jerome B. York, said Chrysler could pay for the stock out of its cash flow without tapping its cash reserve. Chrysler spent $1 billion last year to buy stock. [D16.]
 
RJR Nabisco Loses Plea
The S.E.C., supporting two orders of Roman Catholic priests, rejected an attempt by RJR Nabisco to block a shareholders' proxy resolution calling for a rapid spinoff of the company's food business from its tobacco operations. [D3.]
 
Silicon Graphics Shares Tumble
Silicon Graphics' shares tumbled 16 percent, to $23.25, after the work station maker said it expected the recent quarter's earnings to be well below Wall Street estimates. S.E.C. filings show that the company chairman sold 60,000 shares at prices of $36 or higher in late November. [D5.]
 
In Netscape's Footsteps?
After Wall Street's embrace of Netscape, the Xylan Corporation is hoping for a similar reception when it goes public. Xylan makes a local networking switch, the fastest-growing part of the computer-networking business. Market Place. [D6.]
 
Forte Acts Against Granada
The Forte hotel group of Britain said it would raise its dividend and buy back shares worth more than $800 million in an intensified campaign to thwart a takeover by the Granada Group. Forte's stock rose on the plans, and analysts said Granada would have to increase its offer.[D6.]
 
Disney Picks Property Scout
The founder of Premiere magazine is joining Walt Disney, where she will buy and create properties for the motion picture and television groups. The executive, Susan Lyne, is well regarded in Hollywood, where she knows most of the top players. [D5.]
 
Competition for Utilities
Democrats in New York State put forward a plan to introduce competition into the utility industry by the year 2000. [B2.]
 
Interest Rates Creep Higher
Treasury securities fell in price despite signs that the manufacturing sector was somewhat weaker than the credit markets expected. A lack of progress in the budget talks in Washington contributed to the drop. The 30-year bond yielded 5.96 percent, up from 5.94 percent on Friday. [D13.]
 
New Blood for the Plaza
The new owners of the Plaza Hotel, who are a Saudi prince and a Singapore hotel group, plan to make a number of improvements this year to give the landmark more of the feeling it had when it opened in 1907. But some of the changes will be distinctly modern, like private fax machines. Business Travel. [D5.]

HEADLINE: Even With Peace and Rain, Ethiopia Fears Famine

BYLINE: By DONATELLA LORCH 

 BODY:
Ethiopia's farmers recently finished harvesting the biggest crop the country has seen in a decade. The rains were plentiful and, most important, there was peace and stability.
Yet the Ethiopian Government has appealed for 250,000 tons of food aid for 1996 to feed about three million of its people. Though the appeal will be for less than the 400,000 tons of food aid delivered last year, the famine of 1984-85, in which more than a million people died, remains a specter for Ethiopia. 
 "Ethiopians won't be as lucky as they have been this year, that's the problem," said Allen Jones, head of Ethiopia operations for the World Food Program, an arm of the United Nations. "All you need is for the long rains to end three weeks early and you're back in a massive crisis. Fifty-six million people are living right on the edge. It can go the wrong way just as easily as it can go the right way."
United Nations and American officials agree that Ethiopia has the potential to erase its chronic food deficit. But they say there are no quick fixes because Ethiopia faces a legacy of degraded lands, poor road networks, a high birth rate, disease and an agricultural base destroyed by years of civil war and Government policies.
Without aid, hundreds of thousands of Ethiopians will face the risk of starvation while the country is being rebuilt. But experts say that unless Ethiopia can strengthen agriculture, bring down the birth rate and create industries to earn foreign exchange, it will become ever more reliant on donated food.
"The long-term nature of the basic agricultural problem is tougher than anything else in Africa," said David Gordon, an official at the Overseas Development Council, a private research group in Washington.
And in an era of increasing competition for shares of a shrinking foreign aid budget, Ethiopia will have to convince American policy makers that it continues to deserve the large sums it has been receiving since 1991, when rebel groups toppled the Marxist Government and the United States committed hundreds of millions of dollars to help it make the transition to democracy.
"In the end, it largely has to be humanitarian-motivated," Mr. Gordon said of the rationale for continued food aid. "I don't know whether we will have the commitment."
In the Ethiopian countryside, about 80 percent of food aid is distributed in programs requiring recipients to work on Government-run projects in exchange for food as a way to limit dependency on aid. But the distribution of food to additional tens of thousands of poor city-dwellers is still lagging behind.
In the meantime, projections by experts suggest that Ethiopia will face more competition for food assistance in the next few years. By the year 2000, relief officials say, Africa will be growing less than three quarters of the food it needs. But as food requirements increase, aid is drying up. A recently released report by the Food and Agricultural Organization says that the global availability of food aid in 1996 will be 7.6 million tons, one million tons less than 1994 and the lowest since the mid-1970's.
"It comes down to the issue of allocation," said Margaret Bonner, director of the United States Agency for International Development in Ethiopia. "Where do you put your resources? In a place like Ethiopia, where you try to move people toward sustainability, or in Somalia or Rwanda? Part of the problem of foreign assistance is that we as the U.S. Government and people are very willing to respond in emergencies, but we don't have the funding to follow up."
Ethiopia is the world's poorest country after Mozambique. Until the early 1980's, it was self-sufficient in food, but its agricultural output was destroyed by the civil war, the policies of the Marxist Government of Mengistu Haile Mariam and the forced relocation of 1.5 million farmers.
All the while, the number of mouths to feed has continued to grow. Ethiopia's population is growing at more than 3 percent a year and is expected to double in the next 20 years. Only 4 percent of urban women use birth control and hardly any use family-planning methods in the countryside, Ms. Bonner said. With 50 percent of the population under the poverty level for developing countries, the average Ethiopian subsists on half the caloric intake of the average American.
But even though population growth has outstripped agricultural potential, focusing on population control without increasing incomes is "like putting the cart before the horse," said Tom Sheehy, a policy analyst at the Heritage Foundation, a conservative research center in Washington.
Even an extensive famine would do little to alleviate the country's long-term needs for food, analysts say. "The reduction of population is not the ultimate aim of development," said Henry Gordon, an economist and independent consultant who has worked in Africa for almost a decade. "You have to create the process to generate growth in the economy and that in itself will bring the population down."
More than 95 percent of Ethiopians are subsistence farmers, plowing their small plots with oxen and wooden plows. Fertile lands in the highlands suffer from severe soil degradation, erosion and extensive deforestation. In the lowlands, farmers must cope with malaria and tsetse flies, which can carry parasites that cause sleeping sickness. There are occasional but deadly infestations of locusts and army worms.
Experts agree that for Ethiopia to become self-sufficient, it must put more land under cultivation. But because land is still owned by the Government, farmers cannot use it as collateral to raise loans to expand their crops. Government officials say state ownership of land prevents farmers from selling their land during drought and joining the destitute in the cities. Yet American foreign policy analysts say the Ethiopian Government's reluctance to privatize land is a major stumbling block to receiving foreign aid.
Even if farmers have a good crop, they have no place to store it on their land and cannot solve problems relating to transportation and marketing. Roads are often unpaved and virtually impassable, complicating shipment of food to areas of the country in need and only aggravating gluts of food in areas of good harvests. Thus a bountiful crop will only flood the local market with food, bringing prices down.
"There's an awful lot that needs to get done, not just good rains," said Ms. Bonner of the Agency for International Development. Last year, she added, "shows there is a light at the end of the tunnel. But the problem remains. One year doesn't do it."
Asaye Demlay, a farmer in Lalibala, in the northern province of Wallo, is one of the three million Ethiopians who are in need of the food aid this year. Mr. Demlay said he had coaxed a stunted crop from his rocky fields, only enough sorghum, peas and tef, a cereal used to make Ethiopia's traditional bread, to last his family through the first four months of the year.
The harvest, in early December, was grim for many farmers in Wallo province, a barren and harsh region of immense, arid plateaus fractured by ravines and jagged canyons, where hundreds of thousands of farmers eke out a meager and almost always insufficient existence.
"I don't know about the future," said Mr. Demlay, 38, who has four children and grows his crops on about an acre. "Every year, we grow less and less food. My children eat meat only once a year, at Easter."
"This year I will sell my animals to buy food because I don't want to die," Mr. Demlay said. "After that? Then I will wait to die."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Even after the best harvest in a decade, Ethiopia has fallen short of being able to feed itself. Officials say foreign food aid will be needed for years while other international development programs provide more modern technologies to replace practices like the use of cattle to thresh grain; While the rugged landscape around Lalibala, Ethiopia, contributes to the difficulty of getting goods to market, uncertain rainfall is the leading natural barrier to the country's quest for self-sufficiency in food. (Photographs by David Guttenfelder for The New York Times)

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 5; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1094 words

HEADLINE: RECORD EARNINGS, BUT LESS SHARING

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
American companies, though awash in profits in 1995, decided not to make large increases in their payments to shareholders and workers. Instead they plowed more money back into their businesses and set aside a lot for a rainy day.
While more American companies raised dividends in 1995 than in any year since 1981, the increases did not come close to keeping up with rising profits, according to figures released yesterday. As a result, it appears that corporations paid out a record low proportion of their profits to shareholders. 
 "In terms of profits, dividends are rather sparse," said Arnold Kaufman, the editor of The Outlook, a newsletter published by Standard & Poor's, which calculates dividend figures. But he said that with stock prices soaring, shareholders have not been complaining and added that he thought companies "rather like the flexibility" provided by not devoting a lot of their profits to dividends.
If shareholders saw small gains, so did employees. Government figures indicate that compensation expenses for American business, including both wages and benefits, rose about 2.7 percent last year, the lowest for any year since the Government began to track that information in 1981.
Business also succeeded in bringing down its cost of health care, which fell for the first time since 1981, according to the Labor Department. For American workers, the stagnant paychecks came atop a wave of insecurities caused by countless job cutbacks in American industry.
Much of the money companies have spent has gone to investment in new plant and equipment, said Robert Barbera, the chief economist of Capital Investments International, a New York investment advisory firm. Such spending appears to have risen about 10 percent last year.
But a lot of the money has been salted away for a rainy day or perhaps more appropriately for a recessionary year by companies worried that the boom years will fade.
The figures released yesterday by S.& P. showed that 1,907 companies announced dividend increases in 1995, up 4.4 percent from 1,826 in the year earlier and the most for any year since 1981. At the same time, the number of companies announcing bad news -- either a reduction or elimination of a payout -- fell to 128 from 136 in 1994. It was the smallest such figure since S.& P. began keeping count in 1955.
Mr. Kaufman said that while final figures for 1995 profits would not be in for some time, the current estimate was that companies in the S.& P. 500 index paid out just 37.5 percent of their after-tax profits to shareholders. If that figure stands up, it will be the lowest since that statistical series began in 1928. The old low mark came in 1979, when just 38 percent of profits were paid out. In 1994, the ratio was 43 percent.
The figures indicate what a golden age this is for corporate managers. International competition has helped to hold down compensation costs for many companies, thus pushing up profits. But with shareholders generally happy, there has been little pressure to raise dividends, leaving companies with more freedom to invest the profits as they see fit. Over all, Government figures indicate that corporate profits amount to about 10 percent of national income, up from 7.5 percent as recently as 1991 and the highest since 1978, Mr. Barbera said.
Corporate profits last year hit a record in dollars, both for the economy as a whole and for the companies in the S.& P. 500 index, but they are not close to a peak in terms of national income. On that basis, the figure was at 14 percent in 1966, Mr. Barbera said.
As 1995 ended, it appeared that companies might be even less eager to pay money to shareholders.
The amount of cash paid to shareholders in S.& P. 500 companies in December was below the amount paid a year earlier, and the number of companies raising dividends was just 136, the lowest for any December since 1992 and 21 percent below 1994's level. It was the sharpest monthly plunge since July 1991, when increases were 23 percent below the figure a year earlier. Uncertainties brought on by the Persian Gulf war and the 1990 recession helped explain that decline.
While one-month figures can be volatile, and the November figure was strong, this one comes at the beginning of the heaviest period of dividend increases. Many companies make the decisions on annual payouts in December, January or February as annual profits become clear.
If there is to be a slowdown in dividend increases, it could indicate that companies are nervous about the continuance of the strong profits shown in 1995. It is humiliating for a company to raise its payout and then later have to lower it, and payout increases therefore often lag earnings growth. Mr. Kaufman estimated that earnings of the companies in the S.& P. 500 were up 19.9 percent in 1995, but the amount of dividends paid by those same companies rose just 4.6 percent.
Alternatively, the relatively low level of payouts could indicate that more corporations are concluding that they do not need to pay much in dividends to attract shareholders, who have profited greatly from rising stock prices. While it is widely believed that there has been a sharp increase in corporate stock repurchases -- an alternative way of getting cash to shareholders -- some studies have questioned whether that many shares are being bought on a net basis, after adjusting for shares issued through stock options programs for managers and other employees.
As stock prices soared in 1995, bears pointed to the plunging dividend yield on stocks as a sign the market was overvalued, while bulls insisted that stocks were not unreasonably priced relative to earnings expectations. At the end of the year, the stocks in the S.& P. 500 were paying dividends at an annual rate of $14.21, assuming that investors spent $615.93, the level of the index, buying fractional shares in each company. That produced an anticipated dividend yield of 2.31 percent, just above the record low of 2.29 percent, set earlier in December.
Before 1995, the dividend yield had never gone below 2.6 percent, and when it got close to that level, as it did in late 1972 and in the summer of 1987, it was a sign of impending bad news for the stock market. But so far this time, the stock market has moved onward and upward even as dividend yields plunged.
Relative to profits, however, the S.& P. 500 ended 1995 at less than 17 times that year's earnings, based on Mr. Kaufman's estimates. That is not a low figure, but it is well below the 1987 peak of about 22.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
U.S. Bonds Lower Despite Weak Data

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
The price of Treasury securities ended lower yesterday, despite signs that the manufacturing sector was somewhat weaker than the credit markets had expected. A lack of progress in the budget talks in Washington contributed to the price drop.
By late in the day the price of the 30-year bond was down 9/32 of a percentage point, to 112 20/32; its yield, which moves in the opposite direction, rose to 5.96 percent, from 5.94 percent on Friday. 
 The report from the National Association of Purchasing Management suggested that inflation was not about to accelerate. Other data released yesterday included the Johnson Redbook Service, which showed that sales at department, chain and discount stores declined six-tenths of 1 percent in December from a month earlier. That report underscored the sluggish pace of holiday sales.
At the Treasury's first weekly auction of new bills in the new year, rates came in mixed. The average rate for a three-month maturity rose 13 basis points, to 5.04 percent, while the rate for a six-month issue declined by one basis point, to 5.03 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
Matthew F. Alexy, chief market strategist of CS First Boston, said he believed the general trend was toward lower rates. "The idea of the market moving sideways," he said, "has to be understood as being in that definition of a lower rate environment."
Mr. Alexy said that rates over 6 percent would probably bring in buyers. Their only risk, he said, is if the economy proves to be slower than perceived.
"I'm not so sure that the entire movement we have seen in bonds is based solely only the idea of a budget agreement being reached," Mr. Alexy said. He also noted that overseas interest rates had also been moving steadily lower.
With prices moving higher last week in very little activity and in the absence of much economic information, "it's not uncommon to see the market go back to test those levels," Mr. Alexy said. "The reports we see today are consistent with what we've been seeing: a very slow and sub par economic growth."
Traders said the purchasing management survey of business conditions in December helped bring the market back from steep early losses. The National Association of Purchasing Management's index read 47.3 in the latest report, for December, versus forecasts by economists of 48.1, and compared with November's reading of 46.5.
A reading below 50 indicates declining activity in the manufacturing sector, while an index below 44 indicates a declining economy overall.
Analysts said that in the report, production rose, as did supplies, inventories, employment, imports and new export orders. But new orders and prices fell.
Many market participants were surprised that conditions were not as strong as reports issued last week by regional purchasing managers. The market sees weak economic data as increasing the chances of further interest rate cut by the Fed to help stimulate the economy, regardless of whether there is a budget settlement. The last rate cut two weeks ago came without a budget settlement.
Marilyn Schaja, an economist with Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, said the details of the purchasing managers' report "are extremely favorable from a bond market perspective, suggesting continued slow growth with little inflationary pressures." She added, "The importance of these data is even greater than usual due to the absence of the official set of Government statistics." Even if the Government agencies reopen this week, no official data are likely to be released before next week.
Elsewhere, municipal bonds were little changed as some investors predicted that the rally that propelled the market in 1995 would slow this year. But others remained optimistic.
"This year could mark the second year in a row that the municipal bond market may see the number of bonds redeemed outpace the number of new issues," said Michael S. Applebaum, senior vice president for investments at Paine Webber. Mr. Appelbaum said that in January alone, $30 billion in municipal bonds would be redeemed due to bond calls, pre-refunding or maturing issues. These dynamics should exert upward pressure on prices, he said.

HEADLINE: Kerkorian's Plan for Chrysler: Buy Back $2 Billion a Year

BYLINE: By ROBYN MEREDITH 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Jan. 2

 BODY:
Kirk Kerkorian's campaign for the Chrysler Corporation to give more cash back to shareholders called today for the auto maker to buy back $2 billion of its stock annually until the next recession.
Jerome B. York, the vice chairman of Mr. Kerkorian's Tracinda Corporation, which owns 14.1 percent of Chrysler stock, said in a speech here that Chrysler could pay for the stock out of its cash flow without robbing the cash reserve that the company says it has been saving for the next sales downturn. While Mr. York has been pushing for additional stock buybacks or dividend increases, his comments today represented the first specific numbers to date for what would satisfy Mr. Kerkorian. 
 "Chrysler can afford a minimum of $2 billion a year of share repurchase from 1996 and forward, at least until a recession comes," Mr. York said. Chrysler will have plenty in profits to pay out that amount to shareholders, he said. Chrysler spent $1 billion last year to buy back stock.
Mr. York previously criticized the company for setting a target of $7.5 billion for its cash reserves, which it has nearly met and which he argued was $2 billion to $2.5 billion too high. Mr. York said today that the buyback money should come straight from profits, and he did not repeat his call for Chrysler to cut its reserves.
Analysts said Chrysler was likely to be able to afford Mr. York's buyback demand. "Given analysts' estimates for 1996, it is highly feasible; a recession year is a different story," said Scott F. Merlis, the president of Merlis Automotive International, an independent automotive research company based in Westport, Conn.
The key question in Chrysler's struggle with Tracinda involves how much of a cash reserve the company needs to survive the next recession, and how much it needs to invest in new models and factories. Mr. York has said Chrysler is too conservative about its prospects.
Chrysler declined to comment on Mr. York's demands.
Mr. York said today that he had spoken to 15 of the company's institutional investors over the last month and that all but a couple of them expected continued economic growth. But the pessimistic investors are worried that the economy may already be heading into a recession, he said. Such investors might be expected to oppose Tracinda's efforts to push Chrysler into a more aggressive business strategy.
Mr. York said that "several" of the investors had volunteered to support Tracinda's efforts, although he had not yet asked for a commitment from them. He plans to speak this month to 25 more institutional shareholders.
Mr. York said in an interview after the speech that he would be satisfied if part of the $2 billion came in the form of dividend increases rather than share buybacks.
He reiterated that Chrysler should sell its $3 billion in nonautomotive assets, but that the stock buyback could proceed without the proceeds of such a sale.
Tracinda has been locked in a battle with Chrysler since last spring. Tracinda first tried to buy Chrysler but failed to line up financing for the deal.
Mr. York, a former Chrysler chief financial officer who spoke at a lunch here of the Society of Automotive Analysts, argued that Chrysler could afford the buybacks because it had an inherent profit advantage over other auto makers. Mr. York contended that because Chrysler produces more high-profit mini-vans and sport utility vehicles than other auto makers, it earns about $500 in additional profit per vehicle.

HEADLINE: Slowdown Goes On, Purchasers Say

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: TEMPE, Ariz., Jan. 2

 BODY:
The manufacturing sector slowed in December for the fifth consecutive month while prices that manufacturers paid fell to their lowest level in more than four years, the nation's purchasing managers said today.
The National Association of Purchasing Management, based in Tempe, said its index was up slightly in December, at 47.3 percent, from 46.5 percent in November. 
 Although the index gained, the reading below 50 percent still indicated that manufacturing activity was declining last month, although at a slower rate than in November. A reading above 50 percent indicates growth.
"The manufacturing sector contracted for the fifth month in December, with production, new orders, and employment all indicating decreased activity," said Ralph Kauffman, who heads the association's Business Survey Committee.
The group's price index fell to 40.8 percent last month from 44.5 percent in November, the lowest reading since July 1991.
Today's report was awaited with especially keen interest by the financial markets because the Government has canceled most economic reports during the budget impasse in Washington.

HEADLINE: Coptic Church in U.S. Receives a Bishop

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 30

 BODY:
Visiting 10,000 households would be a prodigious task for even the most enthusiastic politician or energetic salesman, but that is the promise Bishop Serapion of the Coptic Orthodox Church in Southern California has made to worshipers.
"It is a great task, but even if it takes three or four years I will do it," the newly appointed bishop said in an interview from his home. 
 After more than 10 years of requests to the patriarch in Egypt, Pope Shenouda III, the small but growing Coptic community here finally received word in November that it would have a bishop to lead and unify it. He is the first bishop of the Coptic Orthodox Church to be installed in North America. A second bishop has also been appointed to the Southern states and will be installed later.
When Bishop Serapion begins visiting community households -- five a day, three times a week for prayer and conversation -- he said he would not begin with the rich or the influential families as is often the case.
"The priests asked me," he recalled, " 'do you want to start with the top or the low?' I said with the low."
The Coptic community has grown steadily in the past 15 years. In 1980 Los Angeles had three Coptic churches. Today, 13 are spread across the county. Nationwide, the bishop estimates that 150,000 to 200,000 Copts form about 60 congregations, with about a third of the population making up 14 congregations in New York and New Jersey.
The growth of the church in the United States has been fueled by immigration from Egypt. While many Copts said they immigrated mainly for educational and economic opportunities, others acknowledged the difficulty of living as a Christian in the predominately Muslim Egypt.
"Copts in Egypt feel oppression," Bishop Serapion said, noting that even a good student at a university has little chance to enter a profession like teaching.
According to church tradition, the Coptic Orthodox Church was founded in the first century by St. Mark in Egypt. The church is part of the family of the Oriental Orthodox Churches of Syria, Armenia and Ethiopia and is historically related to the Eastern Orthodox churches, like the Greek and Russian Orthodox Churches. The church is similar to the Catholic Church in many ways, but the two disagree on some dogmatic issues.
The bishop's recent arrival was greeted with joy and relief from members of the community.
"It is like a dream come true," Wafik Bichai of Los Angeles said.
Father Bishoy Bastawros of St. Athanasius Coptic Church in Los Angeles stressed the importance of having "father for the fathers." "Some problems can't be solved by the priests," Father Bastawros said. "It is important to have someone who has the authority."
In the past, a couple requesting a divorce would have had to wait for a visit from a bishop in Egypt. Divorces are only granted in the church in cases of adultery or conversion, and not by priests. Other questions have also surfaced as a result of the blending of American and Coptic traditions, Father Bastawros said.
Some churches have come to celebrate the new year on Dec. 31 in addition to Sept. 11, the Coptic new year -- a practice some church members find objectionable. The bishop said he could resolve such disputes. But a more tangled and controversial question is whether to celebrate Christmas on Dec. 25 instead of Jan. 7, when the Orthodox churches celebrate the Nativity. This question can only be answered at the highest level of the church.
In addition to working within the church and providing pastoral care to the faithful, the bishop said he planned to form relationships with other churches and community groups.
With a bishop to represent the Coptic community, many here hope that the church will gain greater prominence within Los Angeles and that members will become more fully integrated into the political and social fabric.
"We are here in this society," the bishop said. "We like this society and we want to contribute to the society."
Many Copts living in the United States grew up under repressive Egyptian regimes and tended to be skeptical of the political process and were reluctant to take part. But the bishop said he hoped to change this by encouraging voter registration and full civic participation.
"Being part of society is not against your spiritual life," he said. "It is a duty."
But as Egyptians, the bishop said, community members sometimes face the added challenge of being stereotyped by some who believe that all Arabs are Islamic fundamentalists and terrorists.
"One of the personal problems is we dress like Khomeini," the bishop said with a hearty laugh, glancing down at his traditional black robes and gesturing to his silk headdress. But he said that with a little outreach and explanation, it would be possible to combat the stereotype.
A more pressing dilemma for the church, he said, is keeping the youth connected and interested. For children, the pressure to assimilate is great -- a problem faced by many immigrant communities, he said.
The bishop said he was not "advocating Egyptian culture" but rather trying to teach the younger generation to embrace Coptic Christian values. As for American culture, the Bishop said he hoped the young people would not "imitate everything," but rather pick the best things.
"They are facing the culture in the house and the culture in the society," Bishop Serapion said. "They want to be normal members of society, not strange members."
One change taking place to help youths feel more comfortable in the church is to use English rather than Arabic and ancient Coptic at services.
During much of his installation ceremony on Dec. 23, the bishop spoke in English. That touch, said Kamel Tadros, a church member attending the service, helped to include the young people.
The bishop said that, over all, he hoped to bring a unity to the community that was not possible while the churches operated independently without a bishop.
"I am like the thread that binds the balls of the rosary together," Bishop Serapion said he told a meeting of priests recently.

HEADLINE: Essex Chief to Enforce '78 Residency Law for County Employees

BYLINE: By NEIL MacFARQUHAR 

DATELINE: NEWARK, Jan. 2

 BODY:
For more than 17 years, Essex County has had a law on the books requiring employees to live within the county, but nobody paid attention. Today, the County Executive announced that he plans to enforce that law, giving hundreds of full-time and part-time employees the choice of moving by July or losing their jobs.
In announcing the unexpected change, which will almost certainly be challenged in court by labor unions, the County Executive, James W. Treffinger, said he had two aims: to make county employees more sensitive to the impact of their work and to plow their $44 million a year in salaries and benefits into the local economy. 
 The effects of the policy will be watched closely by other governments throughout the New York region since many have wrestled with both the legality and practicality of forcing employees to live where they work. It is a debate that goes back to George Washington, but there is no broad consensus on how it should be resolved. Nassau and Suffolk counties have residency laws, while Westchester County eliminated its law because soaring property values made some jobs hard to fill.
"If they live here, if they are themselves taxpayers, it makes them better realize that it is their money that they are dealing with," Mr. Treffinger said, noting that his two personal assistants and about eight senior department heads would be affected by the change. He said an initial search by the county's Personnel Department -- whose own chief does not live in the county -- turned up 600 to 700 people hired since the law was enacted in 1978 who do not meet the residency requirement. Mr. Treffinger, who said hundreds more may be disguising their actual residency, said he did not know why the Essex law had not been strictly enforced.
The County Executive said he did not know what immediate symbolic or practical impact the change might have on the government in Essex County, which has a total 770,000 residents spread among some of the richest neighborhoods in the state, like Short Hills, and some of its poorest, most crime-ridden urban blocks, in Newark. But he argued that a government facing a $161 million deficit in a county with a 7.5 percent unemployment rate had to do everything within its means to improve local economic conditions.
Union officials said Mr. Treffinger, who has said repeatedly that county government should be eliminated entirely and who has cut more than 400 county jobs, was using this as a means to reduce the public payroll.
"It will be a severe hardship for people to uproot themselves and their families to come to Essex County to live," said David H. Weiner, president of Local 1081 of the Communications Workers of America, which represents 800 employees. "Forcing people to chose between where they have put down roots and where they work is insensitive, to say the least."
Union lawyers said they were still waiting to see the exact wording of the policy to grapple with how it might be challenged in court, especially on constitutional grounds. Although many municipal governments enacted residency requirements after a 1978 state law that overcame a previous constitutional challenge, enforcement has been spotty.
Richard A. Dann, president of the Communications Workers of America local in Gloucester County, which also has a residency requirement, said most city and county governments do not want to go through the sleuthing through driver records and tax returns required to find out who is obeying the law.
"As a practical matter, most municipalities don't care too much because it is a nuisance to enforce," Mr. Dann said. "If they applied it strictly the way the law required, they would lose a lot of employees. People will say, 'If I have to live here, then I quit.' "
The policy announcement today put Mr. Treffinger, a Republican who took over in 1995 after years of Democratic rule, at loggerheads with some of the most high-profile figures in his government. Sheriff Armando B. Fontura said he thought his 470 officers and other employees would be exempt, but the County Executive stressed that he would keep exemptions to a minimum, including law enforcement officers.
Ray Weiss, the spokesman for County Prosecutor Clifford J. Minor, said the prosecutor would be making a statement about the issue, but none was released. Many of the 120 lawyers in his office are believed to live outside the county, and several live outside the state. A combination of laughter and disbelief spread through the office as employees photocopied the letter announcing the policy that is being mailed to all 4,950 employees today.
"I don't think it is fair to force people to live here," said Robert Storino, a clerk for an Essex County judge. Mr. Storino said he hoped he could continue living in Bergen County until his clerkship ended in September. "I think ultimately they are going to limit the pool of applicants for jobs here."
Mr. Treffinger's office and union officials identified the most senior figures living outside the county as Brenda Veltri Possumato, the director of personnel; Wayne Hassenbalg, the treasurer; Paul Goldenberg, director of the Department of Citizen Services; Barry L. Ruben, head of employment and training; Jeff L. Bertrand, head of community development, and Ronald Manzella, head of the Department of Corrections. None returned telephone calls seeking comment.
Anyone hired before the law took effect in September 1978 would not be required to move into the city. Mr. Treffinger said he was creating a special committee to enforce the policy and to hear any appeals. The law states that anyone with special expertise might be considered exempt, but the County Executive said he was confident that clause would be little used.
Most counties in the region that do have residency requirements exempt specific blocks of employees. In Nassau County, for example, the 10-year requirement that anyone hired be a resident for at least one year does not apply to about 3,000 employees of the Police Department. Suffolk, on the other hand, makes few exceptions for its 10,000 employees and they have to be approved by the County Legislature case by case, said Tim Ryan, the spokesman for the Suffolk County Executive's office.
In New Jersey, Hudson County exempts hospital workers and employees in the prosecutor's office from the residency requirement under a law that allows for outside hiring when there are not enough qualified residents. Of 3,071 county employees, 159 are nonresidents, said Brian K. Dorf, a spokesman for the County Executive's office.

HEADLINE: Special Charges At PNC Bank

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The PNC Bank Corporation announced yesterday that losses from the sale of interest-rate-sensitive securities and costs related to its purchase of the Midlantic Corporation would sharply reduce earnings for 1995.
PNC, the nation's 11th-largest bank company, said it would record $190 million in losses from the elimination of derivatives and other securities in its portfolio, in an effort to reduce its exposure to interest-rate fluctuations. 
 PNC, which is based in Pittsburgh, said it would incur another $190 million in costs in the acquisition of Midlantic, which was completed Friday.
All told, PNC said it expected to post earnings of $410 million, or $1.18 a share, for 1995. Analysts had estimated profits of $2.41 a share, according to Zachs Investment Research.
PNC shares fell 75 cents yesterday, to $31.50, on the New York Stock Exchange.
PNC said that excluding the charges, it would earn $790 million, or $2.28 a share.

LENGTH: 379 words

HEADLINE: Save Allegany State Park

 BODY:
Allegany State Park covers 100 square miles in western New York State, just north of the Pennsylvania border. Established in 1921, it contains a unique blend of old-growth hardwoods, including stands of ancient cherry unmatched anywhere else in the country. The state's Commissioner of Parks, Recreation and Historic Preservation, Bernadette Castro, is considering a plan to open the forest to commercial logging. A similar plan floated in 1982 was rejected after a public outcry. This one should be rejected as well.
Commercial timber interests have their eyes on the 100-year-old cherry stands. Unfinished logs, shipped to Japan or Europe for veneer, can bring in as much as $15,000 apiece. Ms. Castro's office says the decision will be made purely on the grounds of science, not economics. This is heartening, because outside of short-term economic gain there is no rationale for opening this forest to logging. 
 The case for logging is couched in euphemistic language that never mentions cutting trees but refers instead to "resource management." The argument is that the old-growth trees do not allow for "intermediate succession" species, and the wildlife that prefers that kind of growth. But the kind of wildlife that likes that sort of landscape -- deer -- are already plentiful in the region, as is the "intermediate succession" forest, 750,000 acres of which surround the park now.
The park abuts the Allegheny National Forest on its southern border and is surrounded to the west, north and northeast by the Seneca Indian reservation. It is home to many species that require big, contiguous expanses of forest, including the black bear, bobcat, sharp-shinned hawk and pileated woodpecker.
The "management plan" makes a specious claim to be promoting biodiversity while doing exactly the opposite. In the name of creating room for species already common throughout the state, it would destroy the park's unique ecosystem.
The ancient hardwoods in Allegany State Park are worth millions if harvested, but they cannot be replaced for generations. If Commissioner Castro truly intends to keep economics out of her decision, there is no rationale for this plan. The forest has been doing very well by itself. It does not need this sort of "management."

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Our 2 Cents' Worth

BYLINE: By Carol Ann Rinzler and Perry Luntz; Carol Ann Rinzler is the author of "Estrogen and Breast Cancer: A Warning to Women." Perry Luntz, her husband, is the publisher of an international trade newsletter.

 BODY:
Almost exactly a year ago, Congress passed the Congressional Accountability Act, a much ballyhooed measure that requires the House and Senate to abide by the workplace and civil rights laws they enact for the rest of us. Alas, like so many things in life, this long-overdue legislation turns out to be less than meets the eye.
In an effort to minimize the effects of the Government shutdown on their constituents, Republicans in the House proposed last week that furloughed Federal employees go back to work without being paid, surely a new idea in free-market, conservative economics. 
 Afterward, someone asked Representative Tom DeLay of Texas, the House majority whip, whether he would consider giving up his own salary during the crisis. No way, said Mr. DeLay, explaining that, like every other member of Congress, he isn't a Federal employee -- he is a "constitutional officer."
Well, we've reread our copy of the Constitution, and frankly the distinction seems a bit arcane to us.
True, members of Congress are specifically mentioned in the Constitution. Article I, Section 6, says that "Senators and Representatives shall receive a compensation for their services, to be ascertained by law and paid out of the Treasury of the United States." Cabinet members and Federal judges also get a mention, later on, but other workers -- curators at the Smithsonian, say -- do not.
But every Federal paycheck originates in an appropriation requiring money from the Treasury, whose funds come, in large part, from income taxes. That should give everyone of us the inalienable right to put in our 2 cents. Or to take it out.
Members of the House and Senate earn a base salary of $133,600 a year (those in leadership positions get more). And don't forget the generous benefit package: life insurance, health insurance, per diem travel and a nifty pension. Mr. DeLay's base salary alone costs each of America's more than 115 million individual taxpayers 1.2 cents a year.
As conscientious citizens, we have always paid our taxes, regardless of our political gripes. Even though one of us was tear-gassed in 1971 by an overzealous guard at the Nixon White House, protecting it from throngs of balding, middle-aged Vietnam War protesters and their children, the Internal Revenue Service got paid the following year anyway.
This time, however, we plan to draw a line in the sand. Having voted to obey its own laws, members of Congress should be man (or woman) enough to live up to that requirement. Before Tom DeLay votes for trimming Medicare, he should whittle down his own government-financed health insurance. If he expects Federal workers to show up for free, so should he.
Until then, he can forget our helping to pay his salary. Come April 15, our joint tax return will be 2 cents short. That ought to send a message: keeping Congress in line is a hard job, but somebody has to do it.

HEADLINE: The Time Bomb in Governor Whitman's Tax Cut

BYLINE: By Neil Upmeyer; Neil Upmeyer is the president of the Center for Analysis of Public Issues, a public policy research institute.

DATELINE: PRINCETON, N.J.

 BODY:
When her 1993 gubernatorial campaign was faltering only two months before Election Day, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman turned to Steve Forbes, her neighbor and childhood friend and now a Republican candidate for President, for help. His advice? Call for a 30 percent cut in state income taxes.
Mrs. Whitman quickly made the idea a campaign theme, arguing that putting $1.2 billion in tax revenues back in citizens' hands would stimulate economic growth. Despite uniform skepticism voiced by pundits and the press about the plan, the proposal struck a responsive chord among tax-weary New Jersey voters and helped Mrs. Whitman eke out a narrow victory over Gov. Jim Florio, the incumbent Democrat. 
 Mrs. Whitman made good on her promise. This week, New Jerseyans will be getting the final installment of her promised 30 percent tax cut. A middle-class family earning $50,000 a year will have an annual tax bill that is $300 less than it was in November 1993.
Fulfilling a key campaign promise -- and a year ahead of schedule -- has made Governor Whitman popular at home and has catapulted her to stardom in the Republican Party, where she is mentioned as a contender for the Vice Presidential nomination. But what is the price of this popularity?
Democrats have argued for two years that an income tax cut would mean less money for local governments and would force them to raise property taxes. But property taxes have risen only at about the rate of inflation. The real impact of the tax cut may not be on property taxes but on the limitation it imposes on the state's ability to respond to needs that only government can meet: problems like correcting inequities in public school financing and providing charity hospital care, which can only be accomplished with the support of the state's taxing authority.
In effect, the Whitman tax cuts are both a time bomb and a Trojan horse. The Governor's tax-cut rhetoric has painted the state's politicians painted into a corner, and the cuts themselves have jeopardized the state's ability to meet its current obligations.
How is New Jersey able to forgo $1.2 billion in revenue each year and still maintain a balanced budget? It's not because government spending has been slashed. The current budget is actually higher than the one the year before.
Nor is it because the tax cut has spurred the economy as promised. As a result of corporate restructuring and relocations, the state has suffered from the loss of thousands of skilled and high-paying jobs in telecommunications, pharmaceuticals and banking. The exodus of manufacturing jobs continues unabated and is unaffected by tax cuts.
The state's unemployment rate hovers around 6 percent, higher than the national average of 5.6 percent. Over the last year, job growth has slowed to an anemic pace, and the jobs created since taxes were first cut are more likely to be in fast-food restaurants than in office suites or laboratories.
Alarms are beginning to sound in Trenton that the Whitman administration's assumptions of economic growth and its projections of tax revenue may have been overly optimistic.
Without spending cuts or the revenues accompanying increased economic activity to fill the state coffers, to balance the books Governor Whitman has had to raid the state pension fund, persuade state workers to accept a two-year wage freeze and reschedule payments on the state's bonded indebtedness, leaving future taxpayers to pay the bill long after the Governor has left office.
This anti-tax baling-wire approach to budgeting has left the Governor and her Republican majority in the Legislature little leeway in meeting needs as they arise.
Those needs are about to spiral upward as the Federal Government heads toward balancing its own budget by 2002 -- a path that could cost New Jersey $350 million in grants next year. Over seven years, the loss of Federal funds would total an estimated $11 billion. Despite warnings last year about the impact of impending Federal cuts, Governor Whitman pushed ahead with the tax cut's final phase, which is worth $600 million a year.
Now weighty decisions about whether or how to replace lost Federal dollars and whether or how to cut the services underwritten by the Federal grants are being made even more difficult by the shortsighted commitment to tax cuts.

HEADLINE: Slovakia Is Committed to Democracy

 BODY:
To the Editor:
I have to express my concern regarding your news article "West Says Slovakia Falls Short of Democracy" (Dec. 26), where you draw the conclusion that Slovakia is "less democratic" than other post-Communist countries.
Your conclusions are based mostly on quotations from people who, for many reasons, are skeptical or say they are skeptical about the democratization process in Slovakia. It is certainly a part of a journalist's job to bring various opinions to the reader's attention, but it is too risky to draw any final conclusions from a one-sided source. 
 You point to the language law. Knowledge of a state language is a basic requirement for obtaining citizenship. To fully participate in the social and economic life of the Slovak Republic it is necessary to speak Slovak. The laws adopted previously make it obvious that the citizens of minority groups will and should retain their language.
Other examples, which lead you to a conclusion that Slovakia is "falling short of democracy," are drafts circulating in the Slovak Parliament that are presumed to centralize more power, reduce autonomy of universities, restrict the activities of private organizations, etc. Even in developed democracies, it takes a long time for a bill to become a law.
The difficulties that Slovakia is coping with now are difficulties of the entire Slovak society, not exclusively the Government. As Juraj Schenk, Slovak Minister of Foreign Affairs, said, "We emphasize the importance to solve the problems by constitutional and democratic ways."
It is not true that Slovak senior officials are "often unavailable to explain their positions to visiting foreigners." The evidence could be found in the large number of periodicals where interviews with Slovak officials have appeared. Slovak representatives welcome the opportunity to inform journalists about their positions.
 
BRANISLAV LICHARDUS
Washington, Dec. 29, 1995
 
Slovak Ambassador to the U.S.
