HEADLINE: The Safety of 2 Classes of Cholesterol-Cutting Drugs Is Debated

BYLINE: By JANE E. BRODY 

 BODY:
TWO physician-researchers who previously questioned the economic and medical wisdom of universal cholesterol testing and treatment are now questioning the long-term safety of the leading cholesterol-lowering drugs.
In an article being published today in The Journal of the American Medical Association, Dr. Thomas B. Newman and Dr. Stephen B. Hulley of the University of California at San Francisco maintain that two classes of drugs, the fibrates and the statins, used by tens of millions of Americans, could possibly cause cancer. But an editorial by two doctors in the journal disputes the thesis. 
 At issue is whether a seemingly healthy person with an elevated cholesterol level can expect benefits from long-term use of a cholesterol-lowering medication that would justify any risks associated with the treatment. The researchers maintain that treatment with the two classes of drugs should be reserved for patients already known to have heart disease or at very high risk.
In the past decade there has been more than a tenfold increase in prescriptions for cholesterol-lowering drugs, mostly for the statins and fibrates; in 1992, the latest year for which data are available, more than 26 million prescriptions were written.
"Cholesterol-lowering drugs are not like most drugs, which are given to people who are sick in hopes of making them well," Dr. Newman said in an interview. "You can tolerate greater risks in people who are already sick. But cholesterol-lowering drugs are being taken for decades by people who are well in hopes of keeping them well. For them, the projected benefit is smaller and thus the possible risks are more important. Our concern is that the drugs might be associated with an increase in cancer and that this may not be noticed for 20 or more years."
Dr. Hulley said: "We don't want people who should be on cholesterol-lowering drugs to become alarmed by our report. People with a high enough short-term risk of developing coronary disease should not worry about the hypothetical possibility of cancer, which could be decades away." He listed as being at high risk anyone who already had coronary disease and men over 45 and women over 55 with high cholesterol that did not respond adequately to dietary changes, especially people with other major risk factors like smoking, diabetes, obesity or high blood pressure.
The evidence the researchers cite is circumstantial, mainly studies showing an increase in cancer in laboratory rodents treated with doses that result in blood levels that are not much higher than the levels reached in people taking the drugs.
While they concede that there has been no definitive evidence of a cancer risk among people taking the drugs, they point out that the most popular drugs, the statins, have not been used long enough to have caused cancer among users.
Studies of the older fibrates are worrisome, the researchers say, because they reveal a 33 percent increase in deaths from noncardiovascular causes, including cancer. The cancer risk, however, was not statistically significant. For those who need long-term drug treatment, Dr. Hulley said that two other kinds of cholesterol-lowering drugs, the resin cholestyramine and the vitamin niacin, appeared less likely to have long-term adverse effects.
In the accompanying editorial in the journal, two doctors from the University of Arizona College of Medicine in Tucson discounted the possibility of a cancer risk associated with the fibrates and statins and challenged the evidence on which the concern was based. The authors, Dr. James E. Dalen, a cardiovascular epidemiologist, and Dr. William S. Dalton, an oncologist and cancer researcher, stated that rodents were poor predictors of the ability of a chemical to cause cancer in humans. Although nearly all human carcinogens are also carcinogenic in rodents, the reverse is not true.
The Arizona doctors noted that "approximately 50 percent of all chemicals tested in rodent bioassays will be identified as carcinogens, a highly implausible proportion."
Furthermore, they said, the doses of the cholesterol-lowering drugs used in the rodent studies are many times greater than people take, and at such high doses toxic effects could possibly produce cancer in animals. In an interview, Dr. Dalton said that at the drug-exposure levels reached in patients, there was no increase cancer increase in the animals.
Dr. Hulley and Dr. Newman countered that most other drugs, including 85 percent of the drugs used to lower blood pressure, did not cause cancer in rodents. They argued that it was inappropriate to discount the significance of cancer tests in rodents. They cited the World Health Organization's statement that when data on humans were lacking, it was "prudent" to regard evidence of cancer in experimental animals as indicative of a cancer risk to humans.
Dr. Newman and Dr. Hulley performed no new tests for cancer-causing potential. Rather, they based their warning on rodent studies that had been submitted to the Food and Drug Administration before the drugs were approved for sale. The drug agency apparently did not consider the findings cause for keeping the medications off the market, although the agency did limit their approval of the fibrate gemfibrozil to certain high-risk patients.
The main hope from the beginning was that these medications would prevent cardiovascular disease, not just delay the inevitable in patients who already had damaged hearts or clogged arteries, Dr. Dalen said.
Although most studies showed that cholesterol-lowering medications had the greatest benefit for cardiac patients, a study in Scotland published in November showed that the statin drugs could prevent the development of heart disease in healthy middle-aged people with high cholesterol levels. In the study, pravastatin reduced by 31 percent the risk of heart attack and cardiac death in healthy men aged 45 through 64 who had elevated cholesterol levels. The overall death rate among the men taking the drug was reduced by 22 percent, with no cancer increase.
Still, Dr. Newman, who is a pediatrician, and Dr. Hulley, an epidemiologist, questioned the wisdom of treating elevated cholesterol levels in young men and women. "In general, these are people who are at very low short-term risk of developing heart disease, and it is not clear that the benefits of treatment are worth the risks," he said. "If you wait to lower cholesterol when people reach middle age as in the Scottish study, it will work about as well. We think it is better to wait until heart disease is a likely enough occurrence to justify the costs and long-term risks of treatment."
He also expressed concern that the availability of the statins, which are effective and well-tolerated drugs, had prompted an undue focus on cholesterol levels and a tendency by patients and doctors to "ignore other coronary risk factors that are equally or more important, like smoking and lack of exercise."
He said it was easier for doctors to write a prescription for a drug than to provide counseling that would help patients improve their diets and other heart-damaging habits. He added, "Physicians are more successful at reducing cholesterol with a drug than they are at getting people to stop smoking and start exercising."

 BODY:

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 3; National Desk 

LENGTH: 3516 words

HEADLINE: Long, Costly Prelude Does Little To Alter Plot of Presidential Race

SERIES: THE CONTENDERS -- Last of nine articles

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 2

 BODY:
Contenders for the White House in 1996 have already spent at least $60 million in by far the costliest run-up to a Presidential campaign in history, and one of the most energetic. Their television commercials have flickered for months in battleground states. In Iowa alone, candidates have collectively devoted a record 379 days to courting supporters.
But the competitors' industriousness and huge investments have done little to change the Presidential sweepstakes. President Clinton is unchallenged for his party's nomination, just as he was one year ago. Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the majority leader, still holds a commanding lead over his Republican rivals, who now number eight. 
 And so, while the country has amply showed its hunger for a fresh face -- with the start of actual voting only about a month away -- voters may well have to choose between two of the most familiar around: an incumbent President and a Senator who has served on Capitol Hill since the year John F. Kennedy entered the White House.
Judging by interviews throughout the country this year, and by opinion polls, voters are as restless as they were when Colin L. Powell, the widely popular retired general coveted by both parties as the candidate of the future, toyed with a Presidential bid and backed away. Ross Perot's talk of running a third-party candidate seeks to feed on that discontent.
With the stalemate over the Federal budget seeming to drag on endlessly, voters are quick to express dissatisfaction with the leadership in Washington. It is just not clear who or what they are actually looking for. Voters say they want a balanced budget, but they do not want to cut cherished programs to make that happen. They say Speaker Newt Gingrich is too harshly ideological, yet they like some of his notions, like curbing welfare payments.
Tom Brugger, 49, an accountant from Easton, Pa., says he usually backs Republicans but is dissatisfied with the options in 1996. What does he think of Mr. Dole? "Too wishy-washy." Senator Phil Gramm of Texas? "Too conservative." He said he would prefer a candidate who shared Mr. Gingrich's political philosophy but was not as extreme because "Gingrich has got some crazy ideas." But no one running meets his criteria.
Democrats are just as picky about their choices, or lack of choice. "I don't clearly see what Clinton's done, which is bad," said Mary Weigel, 23, a musician in Tacoma, Wash. But she said she would probably vote for him again if for no other reason than that "he's better than the alternatives."
The lingering dissatisfaction suggests that, once again, the status quo may be vulnerable in 1996. That may explain why two Republicans who began the year as asterisks on the Republican candidate roster, and who have a slim chance at the nomination, have made an unexpected splash: Patrick J. Buchanan, a former conservative commentator, and Steve Forbes, a publishing magnate.
And it may explain why some Republican strategists still expect a contender to emerge and, at the very least, rough up Mr. Dole a bit in the early going. Nelson W. Polsby, a political scientist at the University of California at Berkeley, said that news organizations, "trying desperately to breathe novelty into the campaign," will seize on any sign of a Dole upset, which will result in a flurry of publicity for whoever makes the strongest showing against him in the early contests in Iowa (on Feb. 12) and in New Hampshire (on Feb. 20).
"Any little thing that twinkles out of the manure pile, you're going to claim as a diamond," Mr. Polsby said.
Mr. Buchanan, who drew 37 percent of the vote as a protest candidate against President George Bush in the New Hampshire primary four years ago, is holding his own by tapping into voters' economic insecurity with his "America First" pronouncements about economic nationalism and elimination of foreign aid. And though he is still far behind Mr. Dole, Mr. Forbes has managed to outpoll the other Republicans by spending more than $7 million from his personal fortune on television commercials proclaiming his plan for a flat tax as the salvation for the American taxpayer.
Despite the spurts of interest in Mr. Forbes and Mr. Buchanan, Mr. Dole's competitors -- who have been sniping at him all year -- are still almost complete unknowns. Many candidates still complain that they are not drawing much attention, even though the contenders spent more in 1995 than in any other run-up to a Presidential year. For example, Mr. Dole spent about $20 million last year; Mr. Clinton raised only about $3.5 million in 1991, the year before his first run for President -- and that was far more than his Democratic competitors.
By toying for months with the notion of running, Mr. Powell and Mr. Gingrich underscored a discomfort with Mr. Dole among Republicans. But practically speaking, they also diverted attention from the Senator's rivals as they were desperately trying to solicit donations and get noticed.
Mr. Gramm likes to boast that he is the logical -- and more conservative -- alternative to Mr. Dole, but he has been the most surprising in his failure to do better. He started the year with an enormous fund-raising and organizational edge, but Mr. Buchanan has forced him to fight for conservative support that he had expected to gain easily.
Former Gov. Lamar Alexander of Tennessee, a disciplined, aggressive campaigner who fashions himself as the outsider in the race, has plodded along with little noticeable gain. Senator Richard G. Lugar of Indiana, with even less money and organization, has also been campaigning for months, but so far his Eagle Scout persona and command of foreign policy have failed to captivate the voters.
 
Measuring the Importance
A Watershed Year, Or More Ambivalence?
 Experienced politicians differ about how important the election results will be in setting the tenor of the American political scene at the end of the century. The American public rejected a Republican President in 1992 and turned out the Democratic Congress in 1994. That has set the stage for a Presidential year that could resolve this ambivalence in favor of one party or the other, or not settle anything but prolong the amorphous sense of disenchantment with politicians.
"There's an awful lot riding on the next Presidential campaign," said Representative Henry J. Hyde of Illinois, a prominent conservative. "The Republican revolution has only scratched the surface. Without a President to sign the end product, we're still a minority."
On the surface, Mr. Dole and Mr. Clinton seem in powerful positions.
Not since 1984, when former Vice President Walter F. Mondale was tagged early as the Democratic front-runner and no Republican dreamed of taking on President Ronald Reagan, have the Democratic and Republican fields seemed so set so early. Mr. Dole is as much as 40 percentage points ahead of his rivals in national polls.
Four years ago, there was no clear front-runner to take on the President; instead, the top choice among Democratic voters was former Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California, who was drawing 11 percent support. Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas was tied for fourth place with Senator Tom Harkin of Iowa, according to The New York Times/ CBS News poll.
That Mr. Dole is so much more dominant may have less to do with popularity than with the fact that he has been around for so many years and has long been prominent on the evening news.
"Dole and Clinton are very predictable characters who seem to have the inside track," said Mr. Brown, who now has a talk radio program in Oakland, Calif. "It just seems like the process has become more stale and more self protective even as candidates becomes further out of touch."
For the moment at least, Mr. Clinton and Mr. Dole can savor their preeminent positions.
 Mr. Clinton is the first incumbent Democrat in modern political history who does not face a competitor in his own party. And he enjoys a built-in edge: the surest place from which to be elected President is the White House.
Mr. Dole, in his fourth run for national office, also should be in an enviable position: in every election since that of Dwight D. Eisenhower, Republicans have nominated an established party figure -- generally, one who has run before for president or vice president, or been nominated, or served in one of those offices. Moreover, the Republican candidate who collects the most money the year before the election almost always captures the nomination. Mr. Dole has far outpaced his rivals by amassing nearly $25 million.
On the Democratic side, one measure of the tenuousness of this campaign is that White House officials are as bewildered as they are relieved by the fact that Mr. Clinton begins the year on the political offensive. The absence of a challenger, they say, was a combination of good fortune and well-rehearsed strategy: Mr. Clinton scared off competition by raising money -- $26 million -- for the primaries more quickly than any incumbent in the past, and by dispatching organizers to important states to begin preparing for the race.
The lack of competition will help assure Mr. Clinton a powerful position leading into the nominating convention in Chicago next August. The White House theory is this: While the Republicans are ganging up on one another, Mr. Clinton can devote millions of dollars to strengthen his state campaign apparatus and, if he wants, wait until the spring to unleash television advertisements promoting himself or attacking the Republicans.
But for Democrats, there is a worrisome side to the fact that Mr. Clinton has no competition: the Democratic Party is still so bereft after its beating in 1994 that there are no obvious, popular figures who could take him on.
Mr. Clinton's advisers are well aware that their good fortune now does not mean that the President is invincible.
"It's a long way to go, and I think we have a more mature view of how fragile this can be," said Douglas Sosnick, the White House political director. But, he added with a smile, "I don't think overconfidence is one of our weaknesses."
 
Partners and Opponents
In Ideological Times, Two Compromisers
 While some view the election as a referendum on Mr. Clinton's victory in 1992, or on the rise of conservatives in Congress in 1994, the twist is that Mr. Clinton and Mr. Dole are pragmatic, split-the-difference politicians, not known for their ideological fervor. Another twist is that they must work together to try to reach an accommodation on the budget -- and how the outcome plays may help determine who becomes President.
Both men also share a benefactor of sorts: Speaker Gingrich. The contrast with the Speaker, whose popularity has plummeted, has helped Mr. Clinton and Mr. Dole considerably in approval ratings.
Mr. Clinton is now ahead of Mr. Dole in the polls, but those numbers mean little this early, given that the Senator may not win the nomination.
Also, though no independent candidate has taken off, there is still the very real prospect that one could significantly alter the dynamics next November. Few strategists in either party gave much credence at this time four years ago to Mr. Perot's chances of affecting the 1992 elections.
Mr. Perot has established a third party for himself or another candidate, and has not said whether he will run. Though his popularity has declined somewhat since he drew 19 percent of the vote in 1992, polls still show that there could be significant backing for an independent candidacy. That could be particularly helpful to Mr. Clinton, assuming that more Republicans than Democrats defect for the independent.
Last summer, several potentially appealing candidates were musing about running, from General Powell to Senator Bill Bradley of New Jersey to former Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. of Connecticut. But no contender has yet gotten off the ground and begun preparing for a race.
That may be because aside from General Powell, there was no groundswell for any candidate. Also, possible candidates perhaps faced up to the fact that to run competitively, an independent has to overcome seemingly insurmountable hurdles to raise money and get on the ballot.
Mr. Clinton's biggest fear in that regard was that Jesse Jackson would make good on his musings about staging an independent bid. No matter how well he did, Mr. Jackson would peel away the support of black voters, who are among the more loyal Democratic backers.
Mr. Jackson has not ruled out a run, but he is sounding more and more supportive of Mr. Clinton. He seems to be satisfied that the President did not fold on efforts to turn back affirmative action. In addition, the White House has been particularly attentive in working more closely with Mr. Jackson in recent months.
Still, numerous issues could erode Mr. Clinton's head start. Republicans are not about to let Whitewater fade. A sour economy could damage the President, as could foreign conflicts that go awry.
"Bosnia is a ticking time bomb at the heart of the White House," said Mark Mellman, a Democratic pollster and informal White House adviser. "Any day, something awful could happen that could have very significant political ramifications. Every day you wake up and hope it doesn't happen -- more importantly for the soldiers involved."
The campaign was not supposed to start with Mr. Clinton and Mr. Dole looming so formidably. After all the high hopes about contenders who might enliven the race -- voters still lament that General Powell is not in the mix -- some strategists are acting as if the primaries are over. White House officials are preparing for a campaign against Mr. Dole, and the 72-year-old Senator is already taking aim at the more youthful President, asserting that it is time for "grown-up leadership."
"If Dole gets far enough ahead in the primaries, and no one catches up, the primaries are just going to be the beginning of the general election," said Stephen Ansolabehere, a political science professor at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.
But campaigns rarely play out as scripted. While Mr. Dole and Mr. Clinton now seem untouchable in their own parties, that should not mask the fact that both also have underlying weaknesses. Mr. Clinton, for one, is not particularly popular, and polls show that many people do not trust him on fundamental issues.
For the next few months, though, the President has the luxury of sitting back as Republicans try to beat up Mr. Dole. Many Republicans view the Senator as a deserving but not particularly mesmerizing nominee. Conservatives fear that he would return to his more centrist past during a general election. Even Mr. Dole's aides worry that voters will think he is too old to withstand the pressures of the Oval Office.
Yet the Senator can take heart in that his competitors, thus far, have not excited the Republican electorate. While Haley Barbour, the Republican national chairman, describes his party's field as "an embarrassment of riches," many Republicans agree with the assessment of one of the long-shot candidates, Representative Robert K. Dornan of California, that his rivals are "charismatically challenged."
"We've already opened next year's presents," said J. Bradford Coker, a pollster from Columbia, Md., whose company has conducted surveys on the 1996 race in 30 states. "Now, everyone's looking around and saying, 'Shoot, who are we left with?' Most of the excitement is about who hasn't run."

 
 
Not This Time
The Nonstarters And Early Departers
 Indeed, the biggest surprises so far have been which candidates dropped out of the race and which ones have not fared better. Discouraged, in part, by the fund-raising demands, several prominent Republicans did not run: former Vice President Dan Quayle; Jack F. Kemp, a former Housing Secretary; Dick Cheney, a former Defense Secretary, and William J. Bennett, a former Education Secretary.
The candidate with one of the most impressive political resumes, Gov. Pete Wilson of California, pulled out in late September, followed by another contender who favored abortion rights, Senator Arlen Specter of Pennsylvania. While those candidates were the most moderate of the field, ideology was only part of the reason their candidacies never took off. For one thing, money is crucial to staging a competitive race, and neither Mr. Wilson nor Mr. Specter began his financial drive early enough. And their fund-raising efforts were virtually frozen when the speculation turned to General Powell. In addition, neither candidate appeared to have a convincing or inspiring message.
It has also been difficult for the Republicans to differentiate themselves on the issues because the party's fresh ideas seem to be coming from Capitol Hill. "The whole set of Republican initiatives has defined the political landscape more sharply than it ordinarily is defined," said Thomas E. Patterson, a political science professor at Syracuse University. "It's forced a degree of conformity on the bunch."
Mr. Dole's rivals have a simple strategy: emerge from the pack as the obvious alternative and hope that voters reject the Senator as too old or too much the insider. Most Republican analysts contend that given their financial positions and political appeal, Mr. Gramm and Mr. Alexander are in the best positions to give Mr. Dole a run for the nomination should they catch fire early, though few dismiss the possibility of early upsets by Mr. Buchanan and Mr. Forbes.
Many candidates view Mr. Dole as in a similar position to Mr. Mondale in 1984: Mr. Mondale was the easy favorite on the eve of the primaries, with by far the most money and most endorsements. But Senator Gary Hart of Colorado scored a stunning upset in the New Hampshire primary. He got 37 percent, while Mr. Mondale drew 28 percent. Ultimately, Mr. Mondale won the nomination because Mr. Hart could not capitalize on his victory to raise money fast enough and had little organization in other states.
This time, since the primaries are squeezed together, Mr. Dole's rivals hope they can score big early and grab the nomination before the Senator has a chance to get back on his feet. Mr. Gramm has a particularly strong organization in the South, and Mr. Alexander has been working to build an organization should he do well early.
But Republican voters have long been more disciplined than Democrats and are viewed as more likely to stick with the heir apparent than even Democrats were with Mr. Mondale. Even Mr. Hart said, "This calendar favors Dole" for the nomination.
While the first ballots will be cast at district conventions in Louisiana on Feb. 6, the two most crucial early tests continue to be the Iowa caucuses and the New Hampshire primary. Mr. Dole is the overwhelming favorite in Iowa because he is from the neighboring state of Kansas. As a result, the competition there may be for a candidate to emerge with a strong second.
Candidates are competing even harder in New Hampshire, which is the first major contest where no contender has a particular geographic advantage. Though Mr. Clinton came in second there four years ago, the victor in New Hampshire historically winds up with the nomination.
A memorandum, titled "Common Sense," is pasted on a wall in a back corner of Mr. Lugar's campaign headquarters in Indianapolis, but it could well have been written by strategists for any of the Republican contenders: "The campaign strategy is based on doing well in Iowa and leveraging a good showing there. This is the supreme political objective of the campaign. Doing well in New Hampshire is a very close second, and only second because it recognizes that failure to do well in Iowa kills us in New Hampshire."
Whatever the outcome, the process may more resemble "a Presidential quickie," as Richard Bond, a Dole strategist, puts it, than a normal nominating season. That is because several states leapfrogged one another, moving up their contests to influence the outcome. But so many states changed dates that few will carry much more weight than in the past. Still, the entire nomination battle could be over in late March.
Because of the truncated primary season, most candidates, including Mr. Clinton, began their advertising early. Voters in Iowa and New Hampshire have never been inundated with so many commercials so early.
"You got to see candidates -- you got to hear them speak," Silvano Wueschner, the Republican chairman in Wapello County, Iowa, said of past Presidential campaigns. "Now, they're selling themselves like a pair of Calvin Kleins."

 CORRECTION:
An article on Jan. 3 about the prelude to the Presidential race overlooked an exception to the record of Republican Presidential choices since Dwight D. Eisenhower's nomination in 1952. Unlike other nominees since then, Senator Barry Goldwater of Arizona, the choice in 1964, had not previously run for President or Vice President or been nominated or served.

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: January 4, 1996

SECTION: Section D; Page 1; Column 1; Business/Financial Desk

LENGTH: 690 words

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Stalled Budget Negotiations Incite Republican Squabble
As the Federal budget crisis plodded into a fourth month and a Government shutdown passed its 19th day, House Republicans squabbled over tactics, voting down a proposal by Senator Bob Dole to reopen closed offices briefly while budget talks continued. President Clinton moved quickly to exploit the differences, accusing Republicans of following a "cynical political strategy."
Nevertheless, by one account, prospects for a compromise were brightening at the negotiations in the White House. [Page A1.]
 
Stocks Mixed in Heavy Trading
With stock traders nervous over the stalled budget talks, shares closed mixed in heavy volume. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 16.62 points, to 5,194.07, but the technology-laden Nasdaq composite index fell 12.39 points, to 1,046.26. [D6.]
 
Treasury securities rose in price, sending the long bond's yield down to 5.95 percent. [D18.]
 
At AT&T, the Agony of Not Knowing
Thousands of AT&T employees who will learn their fates between now and next summer talk anxiously of their career limbo. "The message is there -- it's not necessarily a lifelong career anymore at AT&T," said Lee Smith, a 49-year-old financial manager with three sons to educate. [D3.]
 
HFS Shareholders Richly Rewarded
As HFS Inc., a leading hotel company with a number of chains, has expanded its franchise to include preferred vendor agreements with a wide array of companies, shareholders have profited. The company's stock soared from $25.25 at the start of 1995 trading to $79.625 at yesterday's close. And analysts are still bullish. Market Place. [D6.]
 
MGM Fraud Charges Settled
Giancarlo Parretti, the Italian financier and former owner of MGM studios, and two associates settled Federal securities-fraud charges related to the 1990 takeover of MGM without agreeing to financial penalties. [D2.]
 
John Hancock Insurance Fined
John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Company said it had paid a $1 million fine to the New York State Insurance Department for improper advertisements and sales practices, including "churning." A department spokesman said investigations were under way at several other companies, which he declined to name. [D2.]
 
United Parcel Raises Some Rates
United Parcel Service said that it was raising prices for ground shipments and changing the rate structure for domestic air delivery to reflect the distance involved. [D14.]
 
K.K.R. to Cut Safeway Stake
A Kohlberg Kravis Roberts group said it planned to cut its stake in Safeway Inc., the Oakland, Calif.-based grocery chain, to 53.4 percent from 61 percent by selling 16.25 million shares in a secondary offering. [D14.]
 
G.M. Chief Sets an Asian Goal
John F. Smith Jr., G.M.'s chief executive, said the company would try to capture a 10 percent share of the Asian market for cars and trucks within 10 years, up from 4.6 percent at present. His comments, made at the North American International Auto Show in Detroit, were in contrast to the company's avoidance in recent years of setting market share goals. [D2.]
 
Assiduously Seeking Tourists
After Hurricane Marilyn devastated the Caribbean last fall, the U.S. Virgin Islands is commencing a $12 million campaign to attract American tourists. Advertising. [D5.]
 
No Cheers for Tequila Industry
Can success spoil tequila? Mexican makers of top-quality tequila contend it can, and a fight led by Guillermo Romo de la Pena, head of a small 225-year-old company named Tequila Herradura, to require only the purest product is splitting an industry that has seen its American sales burgeon with products that include 49 percent cane or corn sugars. [D5.]
 
H. B. Fuller Sued Over Glue Death
The family of a Guatemalan teen-ager who died in 1993 after sniffing glue has refiled a suit in Federal District Court in St. Paul accusing the H. B. Fuller Company, which is based there and dominates the Central American adhesives market, of being responsible for the boy's death. The company contended it was not a matter for American courts. [D4.]

SECTION: Section B; Page 3; Column 4; Metropolitan Desk 

LENGTH: 945 words

HEADLINE: Security a Top Issue in Municipal Pact

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

 BODY:
When hundreds of school crossing guards and school aides braved sleet and slush on Tuesday night to vote on the municipal employees contract, they viewed the labor agreement far more charitably than New York City's teachers viewed their roughly similar accord.
The school aides, near the bottom of the city's economic pecking order, were delighted that the contract promised three years of job security, a promise that many said would keep their families off welfare. But the teachers, with their prestigious jobs and university degrees, cared hardly at all about job security, while caring a great deal about a two-year pay freeze at a time when the Mayor and other officials were getting large raises. 
 As a result, Sandra Feldman, president of the New York City teachers' union, suffered a stinging rebuff last month when city teachers rejected the contract she negotiated for them. But Charles Hughes, president of the union local representing school aides and crossing guards, achieved an overwhelming vote in favor of the contract, with 99 percent of the 350 members attending Tuesday's meeting voting for ratification.
Even though those voters represent only a small fraction of the 19,000 members of the local, supporters of the contract say the overwhelming support that Mr. Hughes's local gave it is the best evidence so far that more than 120,000 municipal employees will part ways with the teachers and ratify the five-year accord in a series of votes over the next month.
Like the teachers' accord, the municipal employees' agreement includes job security for three years, a pay freeze for two years and a 13 percent raise over the last three years.
In emphasizing the job security promised by the contract, Mr. Hughes has struck a chord that resonates with his local's low-paid members in a way that Ms. Feldman failed to connect with her members. Indeed, many of Mr. Hughes's members said they would support the contract because if it was good enough for their local's fiery, longtime president, it was good enough for them.
"I'm 56 years old, and what will I do if I lose my job now?" Leona Morton, a school aide in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, said. "I have two cousins in New Jersey who are losing their jobs with A.T.&T. I'm just grateful this contract protects our jobs."
Some members of Mr. Hughes's local, most of whom have neither college degrees nor specialized skills, are so happy to have a job and be above the poverty line that they hardly complain that their wages have been frozen for two years.
"The city has no money, and it's the best we can do," Edward Vasquez, a lunch duty worker in the South Bronx, said.
Mr. Hughes's group, Local 372, is just one of 56 locals in the giant, 120,000-member union representing the city's nonuniformed municipal workers: District Council 37 of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees. A few locals began voting on the contract in early December, but the voting will not be completed until the end of January.
For Stanley Hill, the executive director of District Council 37, the 99 percent vote of Mr. Hughes's local, one of the largest locals in the union, was in ways a resounding victory. But it was also a dud.
Because only about 350 people attended the meeting, the 99 percent vote put only about 350 names in the pro-ratification column.
Moreover, the vote was easily outweighed by the vote by Local 420, which represents aides at municipal hospitals. That local has fought against the contract because it does not promise hospital workers the same job security offered to other workers. In polling last week at their workplaces, 4,402 members of Local 420 voted against the contract while only 34 were in favor.
"This vote sends out a message," said James Butler, Local 420's president. "This is a real vote coming from the rank and file. It's not in a conference room with a small percentage of the membership."
Despite Local 420's overwhelming vote against it, Mr. Hill is confident the contract will be approved. "It's going to be a tough vote, but I'm optimistic," he said.
According to Mr. Hill's aides, he urged Mr. Hughes to change the constitution of his local so his members could vote by mail ballot, a method that would have helped maximize the number of voters. "It's always a concern when you don't have a maximum number," Mr. Hill said.
His big hope is that District 37's largest component, Local 1549, which represents more than 20,000 clerical workers, and another large local, Local 375, which represents engineers and architects, will register thousands of yes votes when they vote by mail ballot.
But opponents are hoping that a third large unit, Local 371, representing social workers, will counter with a mountain of no votes because the president of that local is campaigning against the contract.
Kirby Lindell, a social worker in Queens, said he opposed it. "I think the contract should be turned down," Mr. Lindell said. "The guarantee of job security doesn't hold water because the city can declare there is a crisis at any time and scrap the job-security clause. And with the increase in transit fares and in the cost of living, it's hard to wait two years for a pay increase."
Mr. Hughes defended his decision to hold the vote at an open meeting, saying he wanted to give his members an opportunity to discuss, criticize and pose questions about the contract.
"With the type of weather we had, even if Santa Claus was in town, he would have hesitated to get on the sled to come down," Mr. Hughes said. "I was glad that about 2 percent of my membership was dedicated enough to come down and vote on the contract."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Mexican Stocks Gain, as Do Bonds and Peso

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Jan. 3

 BODY:
Mexican stocks rose sharply today for a second day, as benchmark one-month interest rates fell and the peso strengthened.
Led by shares of construction companies, retailers and Telefonos de Mexico, the main Mexico City stock index closed up 75.35 points, or 2.57 percent, at 3,004.78, another record. On Tuesday, the index gained 5.43 percent. 
 Telmex's American depository receipts rose $1.75 in New York trading, to $36, on volume of 12.7 million units, the highest on the Big Board. Stocks that did well here included Grupo Dina, a bus and truck maker, which rose more than 20 percent, and Desarrollo S.A., a leading construction company, which closed up 14.8 percent.
Charles Myers, a partner at Caspian Investments, said in New York: "With people realizing there won't be another record year in U.S. markets, they're sending their money abroad. There's a lot of renewed interest in Latin America."
Indeed, the main stock index in Sao Paulo, Brazil, surged 6.64 percent today, and in Buenos Aires, Argentine stocks were up up 4.34 percent. Chilean stocks gained a modest eight-tenths of 1 percent.
Mexican stocks rose as the peso improved to a rate of 7.575 to the dollar, or 13.20 cents each. Lower interest rates also helped propel stocks. The one-month interest rates fell 211 basis points, to 44.7 percent, in the Mexican central bank's weekly auction of Government debt. It was the third straight week of improved debt prices, which move in the opposite direction from yields.
A stronger currency makes peso-denominated securities, like stocks, worth more.

HEADLINE: PATAKI'S MESSAGE: THE OVERVIEW;
Pataki Says Backing Spending Cuts Will Help State Thrive

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Jan. 3

 BODY:
Gov. George E. Pataki today urged a Legislature that is wary about spending cuts in an election year to back the austerity budget that he sent it last month, promising lawmakers that the state would flourish under his proposals to reduce government.
Mr. Pataki used his second annual address to the Legislature to drum up support for his $63.8 billion budget, a plan that calls for some of the deepest spending cuts in New York in recent decades. 
 Mr. Pataki's speech, which some Democratic leaders here quickly termed hollow oratory, opened a legislative session expected to be one of the most contentious in memory. The Governor is seeking to close a $4 billion gap in the state budget through cuts in Medicaid, welfare, higher education, mental health and other programs.
Mr. Pataki sought to show lawmakers that the agenda he pushed through the Legislature last year -- which cut spending and taxes -- had already turned the state around.
He tried to send this message by dwelling on what he said were his accomplishments since taking office as the first Republican governor in the state in more than 20 years: more jobs, fewer regulations, less crime and a drop of 172,000, or 10.4 percent, in the number of people receiving welfare.
And he contended that the cuts in business and income taxes he had championed were revitalizing New York's economy, repeatedly stressing that by lowering costs in the state, companies would thrive.
"The program I outline to you today will build on the great successes we achieved in one short year, and continue New York's rise to its proper place of leadership among the states," he said.
In an indication of his strategy in lobbying the Legislature, Mr. Pataki spoke of the benefits of reducing government but rarely referred to any details of the spending cuts adopted last year or proposed for this year. But many of the lawmakers who listened to the Governor as he talked in the Assembly chambers made it clear afterward that they understood that he hoped to convince them that the pain would be worth it.
Mr. Pataki's budget is also running into criticism because it would alter the way much of the state's money is to be spent, allocating funds in block grants that would give localities more say in running programs.
Further complicating the debate in Albany is the turmoil in Washington. President Clinton and Congress remain at odds over how to revamp welfare and Medicaid, the program that pays for medical care for the poor. How much Federal money is allocated to New York -- and how it can be spent -- will greatly influence the budget battle here in the coming months.
All this is occurring as members of the Republican-controlled Senate and the Democratic-controlled Assembly prepare for their re-election campaigns. Last year, Mr. Pataki received mostly solid support from the Republicans in the Legislature, but this year, some of them are privately expressing concern about the depth of the Governor's proposed cuts.
Governors typically use their State of the State speeches to give glimpses of their budgets, which are usually announced in the middle of January. But Mr. Pataki issued his budget on Dec. 15, a month early, seeking to shift the blame if it is passed late to the Legislature.
With the budget already unveiled, this year's speech had few new major proposals. Mr. Pataki instead spent most of his time on a glowing review of his first year, imploring the legislators to follow through on the initiatives that he has proposed.
"It's been a spectacular year," he said. "It's been an historic year, a year full of accomplishments for the people. We can be proud because we have made life better for New Yorkers -- after all, that is our purpose."
The Assembly Speaker, Sheldon Silver, who as the Democratic leader is Mr. Pataki's chief rival, scoffed at the Governor's assessment of his tenure. Mr. Silver said Mr. Pataki had glossed over the potential effects of the proposed cuts.
"There is reality, and there is the speech," Mr. Silver said.
The third member of the triumvirate that dominates Albany, Joseph L. Bruno, the majority leader of the State Senate, praised his fellow Republican, saying that Mr. Pataki had "reinforced his vision for continuing the dramatic turnaround we began a year ago."
Mr. Pataki did announce some modest new proposals, calling for studies of the state's workers' compensation and unemployment programs, as well as its public education system. He also said he would work to clean up Long Island Sound and seek legislation to guarantee women insurance coverage for two-day hospital stays after giving birth. And he said the state would buy a 375-acre parcel of land in the Adirondacks.
But Mr. Pataki, who does not have a reputation as a great rhetorician, spent most of the speech on broad themes, seeking to link his proposals to figures as diverse as Theodore Roosevelt, the crew of the Apollo 13 mission and a Rochester police sergeant who was shot in the line of duty.
The speech got off to a rocky start when Lieut. Gov. Betsy McCaughey Ross introduced the Governor and he failed to appear for a few minutes. And at one point in the middle of the speech, he inserted the words "thank you" into his prepared text after giving a rousing defense of tax cuts, and some in the audience seemed to believe that the speech was over.
He drew laughter, though, when he recounted several instances of what he said were government rules run amok. He described how a Jewish nursing home in the Bronx was sanctioned for not serving pork and how another nursing home in Syracuse received a violation for permitting creamed corn to run into meatloaf on a resident's plate.
He tied those regulatory gaffes to his belief that government must reduce its role in the life of the state's citizens. Part of that, he said, means that the state should turn over to private companies duties that it has been performing.
He praised the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey for recently selling the New York Vista Hotel at the World Trade Center, and he called on the bistate authority to sell the rest of the trade center. He said the proceeds should be given to the state to help finance the reconstruction of Pennsylvania Station in Manhattan and other projects.
The speech had a mostly optimistic tone, though Mr. Pataki did reserve a few barbs for his Democratic predecessor, Mario M. Cuomo.
"This year, we restored New York's future by replacing the old darkness with a light that comes from a people whose ideas, leadership and creativity are the best in the world," he said.

HEADLINE: Dow Is Ahead 16.62 on Day Of Big Swings

BYLINE: By LEONARD SLOANE 

 BODY:
Stocks were mixed yesterday on heavy volume as the stalled Federal budget negotiations caused some sharp swings in trading.
The Dow Jones industrial average ended up 16.62 points, at 5,194.07. It had surged almost 30 points, but then plunged when President Clinton made pessimistic comments about the prospects of ending the partial Government shutdown. 
 Later, the Dow bounced back to regain some ground. A deal in Washington that would lead to a balanced budget would help the markets.
The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index inched up 0.59 point, to 621.32, but the technology-laden Nasdaq composite index dropped 12.39 points, or 1.17 percent, to 1,046.26.
"It was a day with some big winners and some big losers," said E. Wayne Nordberg, equity manager of Lord, Abbett & Company. "Specific company fundamentals dictated whether stocks were up or down."
Advancing issues on the New York Stock Exchange topped decliners, 1,521 to 932. A huge volume of 469.2 million shares changed hands, the seventh highest in history, compared with 364.3 million shares on Tuesday.
The Big Board also announced yesterday that its market capitalization -- the value of all shares listed -- reached a record $6 trillion at the end of 1995, seven months after passing the $5 trillion mark.
With value investors taking a new look at the groups with poor performance last year, some of the retail stocks moved upward. Dayton Hudson rose 7/8, to 77 1/2, and Wal-Mart advanced 1/4, to 23 1/2.
Bottom-fishers were attracted to industrial-material issues with good prospects of growth in 1996. Alcoa closed at 55 1/4, up 7/8; Dow Chemical at 72 5/8, up 1 1/2; Georgia-Pacific at 70 5/8, up 1 1/8, and Allied Signal at 50 1/2, up 1 1/4.
Utilities were also strong, pushing the Dow Jones utilities index up 0.84 point, to 228.27, its highest level in two years. Higher utility-stock prices are usually seen by traders as indicative of lower interest rates in the future. The bellwether 30-year Treasury bond eased to 5.95 percent yesterday from 5.96 percent on Tuesday.
Among the utilities gaining ground were Cinergy, up 3/8, to 31 1/8; Public Service Enterprise, up 1/4, to 31 1/8, and Peco Energy, up 1/2, to 30 3/4.
Technology stocks slumped after some downgradings were issued by Paine Webber, Alex. Brown and Bear, Stearns. Among them were Applied Materials, down 3 7/8, to 37 1/2; Sun Microsystems, down 3 1/2, to 41 1/4; Digital Equipment, down 3 1/4, to 59 5/8, and LSI Logic, down 2 1/2, to 31 1/8.
Profit taking forced a number of international drug stocks lower even though the dollar had its largest one-day gain versus the yen in seven weeks. Merck closed at 63 3/8, down 7/8, and Eli Lilly closed at 53 3/8, down 2. A notable exception was Johnson & Johnson, which rose 3 3/8, to 87 5/8, after its Renova ointment was approved by the Food and Drug Administration to reduce facial wrinkles.
Natural gas issues fell on speculation that the increase in spot prices might come to an end. Enron fell 1/8, to 37 5/8; Apache dropped 1 1/4, to 27 3/4, and Burlington Resources declined 1, to 38 3/4.
Hondo Oil and Gas fell 3 7/8, to 10, on news that regulations in Colombia may hurt its business. The PNC Bank Corporation dropped 113/16 , to 29 3/4, after three investment firms cut their ratings on the stock. And Concentra plunged 39/64 to 5 5/8, a day after it said that fiscal third-quarter results would be worse than anticipated.

HEADLINE: Anxiety at AT&T as Layoffs Loom

BYLINE: By ROBERT HANLEY 

DATELINE: BASKING RIDGE, N.J., Jan. 3

 BODY:
Lee Smith and Fred Dellanno shared lunch and anxieties today in the cafeteria at the AT&T Corporation's headquarters in the snowy woodlands of this quaint village.
Both are managers in the financial department that handles budgets for the long-distance company's customer-service representatives across the country. Mr. Dellanno, 44, seemed relaxed; he was recently told that his job and 13-year career is secure. But Mr. Smith, a 49-year-old father of three sons, has received no assurances that he would survive the 40,000-job cutback the telephone giant announced Tuesday. 
 And so, like tens of thousands of AT&T employees who will learn their fates between now and next summer, Mr. Smith finds himself in career limbo.
Mr. Smith's oldest son, Rick, is a freshman at Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute in Troy, N.Y. His other two sons, Michael, 16, and Dan, 12, plan to head to college all too soon. Mr. Smith, who has 26 years with AT&T, has survived three retrenchments since 1990; he is not sure about his fate in the fourth.
"The message is there -- it's not necessarily a lifelong career anymore at AT&T," Mr. Smith said. "I'm cautiously optimistic and I feel somewhat confident, but I've dusted off my resume. I'm looking at 10 years of college education I have to pay for somehow. I'm not anxious to change careers, but if I have to I'll deal with it."
Few here talked about lifetime guarantees. "Tell me what companies today provide job security for life," Mr. Dellanno asked. "I don't think you can name one."
Both men were eligible for the voluntary buyout that AT&T offered 72,000 managers last November, and which 6,500 people had accepted by last Friday's deadline. Mr. Dellanno did not take the buyout option because he had been assured he had a place, for now, in AT&T's future. Mr. Smith turned it down because he felt he could not afford to walk away from his job, even if he may soon be forced to take a comparable severance package.
So today at AT&T headquarters, where some 4,000 people are employed, as the last flakes of an overnight snowstorm fell outside the cafeteria's glass walls, stress accompanied the luncheon specials of roast turkey and pasta.
And in the offices of experts who watch New Jersey's economy, the potential impact of AT&T's cutbacks on the state was a prime topic.
The company is New Jersey's largest private employer, with 49,000 workers in 326 offices and facilities around the state. Each year, AT&T pumps about $6.6 billion into the state economy through salaries, pensions, taxes, purchases and philanthropy, said Kim Pryor, an AT&T spokeswoman.
Between 6,000 and 7,000 of the 49,000 jobs are expected to be eliminated in the first half of 1996 as part of the nationwide job reduction of 40,000, said Burke Stinson, a company spokesman.
James W. Hughes, dean of the Edward J. Bloustein School of Planning and Public Policy at Rutgers University, said it was important to place the job cuts in the context of the state's economy, which has about 3.6 million jobs. The positions AT&T is shedding amount to only 0.2 percent of those, he said.
But percentages mean little to individuals who may soon be looking for work. Among others facing the uncertainties here were Sheryl Rossman, a manager in corporate finance, and her husband, Robert Holtgrefe, a manager in the equipment systems department. She has worked for AT&T for 19 years, and he has 30 years with the company.
"Hopefully one of the two of us will be able to stay," Ms. Rossman said. "I don't think both of us will be fired. But if we are, we'd just up and leave the state and go someplace else with a lower cost of living."
But Mr. Hughes of Rutgers, suggested that New Jersey was not the worst place to be for people who lost AT&T jobs. "It is not the people who have become obsolete," he said. "It is the jobs that have become obsolete. If other companies are looking for skilled middle managers they have a better chance of finding them in New Jersey than they do in some rural backwater."
AT&T has said that those who are laid off will receive a financial package including eight weeks of pay; a lump sum ranging from 5 to 35 weeks of pay, depending on length of service; a bonus amounting to 20 percent of that lump-sum payment, and an additional $10,000 for the cost of moving and new job training.
Mr. Smith, the father of three, said that he believed that about three dozen of the 360 employees in his department would leave. He said 22 had already accepted AT&T's buyout package. That leaves perhaps 14 people in his department facing dismissal, Mr. Smith said.
Across the cafeteria, David Levine, a manager in the personal telephone-number department, was eating lunch with his daughters, Kathryn, 9, and Sarah, 7, who had come to his office after the snow closed their school. Mr. Levine, with AT&T for 11 years, said he was confident he would be retained because he had not been among those offered a voluntary buyout package.
He called the cutback a wrenching experience for employees. His father-in-law spent 25 years with the New York Telephone Company before retiring in 1984 during the breakup of the Bell System, installing telephone lines and later supervising repairmen. Mr. Levine said his father-in-law often spoke of the telephone company as a family and a provider of a lifelong job.
"I don't think he'd recognize this company now," Mr. Levine said. "Everyone's concerned. I don't think you can be with AT&T and not be concerned when you're aware the world of work has changed and you're keeping your skills up and always learning about changes in technology. This is a tough industry."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Lee Smith and other AT&T managers are nervous about their fates as the company prepares to eliminate 40,000 jobs. "The message is there," said Mr. Smith, shown in the cafeteria at AT&T's corporate headquarters in Basking Ridge, N.J. "It's not necessarily a lifelong career anymore at AT&T." (Angel Franco/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Strike Threatened Today At 1,000 Office Buildings

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

 BODY:
The union representing elevator operators and maintenance workers at about 1,000 large New York City commercial buildings threatened yesterday to begin a strike today unless progress were made in contract talks.
Management spokesmen said that if there were a strike, the office buildings would remain open and be run largely as usual, except that tenants would be asked to empty wastebaskets themselves. 
 As of 2 this morning, negotiators for both sides were huddled in talks at a midtown hotel.
The union, Local 32B-32J of the Service Employees International Union, is threatening a strike after management demanded a cut of nearly 50 percent in the starting salaries of building service workers. For example, the management group, the Realty Advisory Board on Labor Relations, wants to cut the starting salary of janitors to $300 a week from $573 a week now.
"The industry is looking for some economic relief," said Jim Grossman, a spokesman for the building owners and managers. "The big issue is the starting wage." He insisted that current workers would not be hurt by management's efforts to establish a new, lower starting wage. Currently, he said, all workers make the same salary.
Labor and management representatives have been locked in intense negotiations at the Sheraton New York Hotel since the local's contract expired at 12:01 A.M. on Jan. 1.
"The negotiators characterize their positions as being very far apart," Dennis Sheehan, a union spokesman, said yesterday afternoon. "Management is seeking a whole list of givebacks."
Spokesmen for the union and management predicted that negotiations would go into the early hours today before union officials decided whether to begin a strike.
The negotiations involve elevator operators, porters, doormen, concierges, handymen and janitors. The contract will also cover security guards, although their contract does not expire until Feb. 29.
Mr. Grossman, the management spokesman, said the service workers last staged a major strike against commercial buildings in New York in 1948. But in 1991, 30,000 members of Local 32B-32J carried out a 12-day strike against 2,800 residential buildings.
Management insists that the service workers are already well paid, and that the $29,796 annual salary for janitors and porters makes them among the nation's highest paid building service workers.
Under the agreement that just expired, the building service workers received a 10.5 percent increase in wages and benefits over three years.
Several labor leaders said that if a strike occurred, many other unions would honor the picket line, partly because John J. Sweeney, the new president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., used to be president of Local 32B-32J.
The Realty Advisory Board is giving tenants what it calls a preparedness manual. It calls for closing all bathrooms open to the public and for putting large containers in a central place on each floor where employees can empty their wastebaskets.
Mr. Grossman said he did not think elevator service would be disrupted because the elevators are automatic in virtually all modern commercial buildings in New York.

HEADLINE: The Art and Science of Alan Greenspan;
How to Stay Popular in a Divided Washington, and Keep Inflation in Check

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Sometime this winter, President Clinton will decide whether to give another term to Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve -- a Republican operating in a Democratic Administration whose decisions will play a key role in shaping the economy as the Presidential election approaches.
Right now, the odds appear to be heavily in Mr. Greenspan's favor, largely because he has proved to be as adept a politician as he is an economist. Even in times as ideologically charged as these, Mr. Greenspan seems to move comfortably in both the Democratic and Republican camps, all without diverging from his avowed objectives -- keeping inflation at bay and the economy growing. 
 Consider the events of Dec. 19. At midday, the nation's financial markets, battered by a huge selloff of stocks the day before, waited to see whether the Fed would come to their aid by cutting interest rates. President Clinton, meeting with his advisers in the Oval Office, discussed his hopes for a credit easing. On Capitol Hill, Republicans were just as ardently rooting for the status quo.
Just after 2:15 P.M., fax machines around Washington spat out the Fed's decision. Its top policy-making committee reduced rates -- but by the smallest fraction possible, shaving a quarter- point from one of the two rates it controls. Wall Street's anxieties were calmed, the stock market resumed its climb, the Democratic White House was satisfied -- and there was not a peep of Republican protest on Capitol Hill.
It's times like this that make Mr. Greenspan, now in his ninth year in office, look indispensable. The Republican Congress, after all, is far more likely to reconfirm a conservative economist first appointed by President Ronald Reagan than anyone else Mr. Clinton might name. And President Clinton has benefited from Mr. Greenspan's discreet help in a number of ways, from his support for bailing out Mexico to urging an increase in the nation's debt limit to avoid a government default that some Republicans seemed willing to tolerate to force a budget deal.
Mr. Greenspan is hard to predict, and some say he does not always practice what he preaches. He has urged the Government to meddle as little as possible in the economy -- but has himself tried to fine-tune it with endless tweakings of interest rates.
He has advocated political passivity for the central bank -- but has played an activist role in political events, from last winter's bailout of Mexico to the continuing debate over how to calculate inflation adjustments for Social Security.
And he has enjoyed a long career as a Washington insider, moderate in tone and unflappable in his pursuit of the economic center, while retaining a deeply held personal philosophy of libertarianism, born of a friendship with the late Ayn Rand, the writer who argued that Government was a barely necessary evil.
Mr. Greenspan's job as the nation's No. 1 inflation fighter is the touchstone to which he always returns. Though he regularly befuddles Congressional questioners with his soporific syntax, he spoke clearly and passionately at a meeting of the Fed's Open Market Committee in June 1988, when he had been in office for less than a year.
The Fed "went through the torture of the damned" to bring inflation under control after the 1970's, he said during the closed-door meeting, not knowing the transcript would become public years later. Lecturing a monetary hard-liner, the chairman warned against jeopardizing that success by pushing too fast with high interest rates.
"I think that if we squeezed to that point, the economy would go into recession and political pressures would overwhelm us," Mr. Greenspan snapped.
Mr. Greenspan has been watching the economy since 1954, and that experience helps him use an extraordinary array of often obscure economic statistics for clues to the economy's health. In a speech last June, for example, he spoke of weakness in "Class 8 truck orders," sending even veteran statistics watchers to the reference books to figure that out he meant very heavy trucks, particularly 18-wheelers.
This habit of analyzing everything from gold prices to retail sales does not sit well with monetarists, who believe he should focus on long-term growth of the money supply. "Greenspan articulates a fine set of long-range goals, but it's pretty clear that the committee under his leadership has responded to monthly changes in economic indicators, and that's as ad hoc as you can get," said H. Erich Heinemann, an economic consultant in New York.
He warned that Mr. Greenspan's current tight monetary policy may yet throw the economy into a recession during an election year -- a minority view among economists who mostly give Mr. Greenspan high marks..
Other critics have accused him of citing whatever recent economic statistic best justifies his current interest-rate policies -- an assertion Mr. Greenspan rejects.
"What we try to do is to create a body of information which gives us a sense of what the underlying forces driving the economy are," he said in testimony on Capitol Hill in 1994.
In public life, Mr. Greenspan's image has been centrist, and he has kept his own beliefs largely to himself. Congressional interlocutors do not hear from Mr. Greenspan about Ms. Rand, the prophet of unfettered capitalism who died in 1982. Even as her brand of strict individualism has become more politically acceptable over the last 20 years, Mr. Greenspan has become more reticent about his beliefs. But on the rare occasions that he has spoken of their friendship, he has described it as one of the most important factors in his life and thinking.
Mr. Greenspan took his first Washington job in the final weeks of the Nixon Administration, serving as chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers under both Mr. Nixon and President Gerald R. Ford. Appointed by President Reagan to head a commission on the future of the Social Security system, he displayed what admirers called political savvy -- and critics termed overcautiousness -- by proposing a modest tax increase and a slight decrease in benefits.
In June 1987, President Reagan nominated him as Fed chairman, succeeding Paul A. Volcker, who had achieved a towering reputation as the man who throttled double-digit inflation, though at the cost of the 1982-83 recession.
Mr. Greenspan did not have a long honeymoon. In September, he and Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d clashed over the Fed's decision to raise interest rates. Then, in October, the stock market fell dramatically. Mr. Greenspan issued a one-sentence statement saying that money would be available to support the nation's financial system. Some on Wall Street clamored for more help, but as the dust cleared Mr. Greenspan's restrained approach won much praise.
But the friction with Mr. Baker continued into the Administration of President George Bush, whose opinion of Mr. Greenspan did not rise during the recession that began in 1990 and eventually helped scuttle Mr. Bush's hopes of re-election. Bush officials wanted Mr. Greenspan to move more quickly to stimulate the economy through lower interest rates, and the President let the chairman dangle in uncertainty for several months in 1991 before reappointing him.
Mr. Greenspan's relations with the Clinton Administration, by contrast, have been far warmer -- often to the point of making his Republican friends uncomfortable, as when he sat next to Hillary Rodham Clinton at President Clinton's first State of the Union Message.
Last year, he gave comfort to the Administration by lobbying Congress to support the President's bailout of Mexico. And he has offered other, less obvious assistance, as well. Mr. Greenspan has warned in several recent speeches about the dangers of middle-class wage stagnation. Administration officials have quietly encouraged Mr. Greenspan to continue with these remarks, which echo one of President Clinton's campaign themes.
Still, in political quarters, most criticism of Mr. Greenspan's performance comes from the President's party. Congressional Democrats, led by Representative Henry Gonzalez of Texas, the ranking Democrat on the House Banking Committee, have accused him of being too secretive and pursuing an excessively tight monetary policy.
Indeed, Mr. Greenspan has appeared eager to help Republicans in their efforts to cut the deficit -- providing them with some cover, for instance, on the politically risky idea of revising the formula used to determine cost of living increases for Social Security. And while many House freshmen may be suspicious of him, he has forged close ties with a number of important moderates.
"As Fed chairman, he has brought some skills of a personal nature that are very impressive," said Representative Jim Leach, the Iowa Republican who heads the House Banking Committee. "I seek Fed advice on almost every serious issue before us, whether from Alan or his staff."
The partisan verdict on Mr. Greenspan, of course, is likely to ride on the economy's performance in the next 11 months. If the current expansion falters, the blame may fall on Mr. Greenspan, but the victim could be President Clinton's re-election prospects.
