HEADLINE: PATAKI'S MESSAGE;
Excerpts From the Governor's Address in Albany

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from Gov. George E. Pataki's State of the State Message yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times.
. . . It's been a spectacular year. It's been an historic year, a year full of accomplishments for the people. We can be proud because we have made life better for New Yorkers -- after all, that is our purpose. For the first time in over a decade this government stands as the servant of the people and not the other way around. This is what New Yorkers want their government to be and we have heard them. 
 This past year people across our state and nation saw the movie "Apollo 13." It's an inspiring story of three American astronauts who overcame grave dangers and incredible odds to complete a journey around the moon. The story began with this simple statement from the Apollo 13 commander: "Houston, we've got a problem." And that's when the whole team went to work. With courage and confidence they were able to save the lives of those brave astronauts.
In contrast to that can-do attitude of the Apollo 13 team, the people of New York for too long heard from their government that events were beyond their control. State government had lost confidence, state government was accepting a loss of hope, a belief in lowered expectations and a loss of opportunity for our people. In November of 1994, the people said, "Albany, we've got a problem." But it isn't us. It's our government. . . .
Over the past year we have set out to undo the damage done by the failed policies of the past. You and I together, with enthusiastic support from our people, created new programs to meet the people's challenges. I'm happy to report to you today that we have met many of those challenges. But we still have a long way to go.
We created a more efficient and more effective state government; one more responsible to the people; a government that provides the services people need and deserve and does so while living within the people's means. . . .
Today, we have cut taxes on middle-class families. Today, we have reduced bureaucratic waste. Today, we have lowered state spending for the first time in generations. Today, our streets and our communities are safer than they've been in years: violent crime down by more than 13 percent; robbery down 19 percent; murders down over 24 percent and violent crime by inmates on work release is down 89 percent.
Two weeks ago, I told you that our welfare rolls were down by about 100,000 people when I presented the budget. Well, the year-end numbers are now in. Home Relief caseloads in this state are down by over 25 percent. And today we have 172,000 fewer people on welfare than last January. That is truly historic change. And today, as well, we have created more than 100,000 new private-sector jobs this year for our people. . . .
We began this journey at a distinct disadvantage. We inherited a state government that led the nation in high taxes, pointless regulation and a welfare system out of control. We inherited policies that discouraged work, downplayed individual responsibility and trampled personal freedoms. Too many of our best and brightest people were leaving our state to find hope and opportunity elsewhere. They were leaving because we had a New York State government that too often acted without reason. . . .
JOBS AND TAXES
 After decades of losing jobs we are now a national leader in creating jobs. And we're first in the nation in cutting taxes. Because we have made government work better for our people we are now becoming the nation's leader in statistics that make us proud. . . .
The changes we made this past year, returning government to its proper role as the servant of the people, are working. In Skaneateles Falls, Welsh-Allen created 50 new jobs. That's not just 50 people. That's 50 families -- families that have more hope today than they had a year ago. Industrial Ceramics created 100 jobs in Livingston County. Toshiba Display Devices is adding 100 jobs in Horseheads. Pratt Industries is creating 400 new jobs on Staten Island. . . .
We will not promise one thing in 1995 and deliver something less in 1996. We will keep the promise to cut taxes.
And then we will cut taxes again. Think of the taxes we cut, together, in a bipartisan way, in 1995. We cut the personal income tax, the corporate tax surcharge, the gross receipts tax and the subchapter S taxes subject to the surcharge. We cut the diesel fuel tax, the aviation tax, the beer tax, the soda tax. We cut the estates tax and the parimutuel tax. That's a long list and you are to be congratulated. But we can, we must and we will do more.
We must keep cutting the gross receipts tax on energy. We must cut the Cuomo tax on real estate, cut the sales tax on clothing and we must continue to attack the high property taxes that threaten the American dream of home ownership. . . .
We will continue to say yes to jobs and opportunity by reforming workers' compensation and unemployment insurance. These programs were intended to bring fairness to the workplace. But today, they not only do not fairly serve workers, they also fail our employers. In recent years, costs skyrocketed and the injured worker received no better service or better medical care. Some good changes have been made. We've introduced managed care into workers' comp. Employers are providing safer workplaces. This year, we decreased workers' comp rates by 5 percent. . . .
Today, I am directing Labor Commissioner John Sweeney, Workers' Compensation Board Chairman Robert Snashall and Director of Regulatory Reform Bob King, whose office has made great strides in restoring sanity to our regulatory process, to submit to me within 90 days, a sweeping reform plan for workers' comp and the unemployment insurance program. . . .
LAW ENFORCEMENT
 No duty is more fundamental to government than the duty to protect the right of the people to live in safety. In just one year, you and I together have made our neighborhoods safer places to live and to work. We have made our communities safer places to start a family and to raise a family, safer places to grow and to prosper. We restored the belief that justice can and will be served in our state by reinstating the death penalty after 18 years. We changed the system of criminal justice so that violent criminals pay the price when they break the law. We established truth in sentencing. We increased sentences for violent felons and eliminated parole for repeat violent felons, and we signed "Megan's Law." . . .
This year I will submit legislation that allows police officers to do the jobs they were entrusted to do. . . . The Police and Public Protection Act of 1996 that I will compose will insure that evidence obtained within standards of the U.S. Constitution can and will be used in our state courts to convict those who break the law.
Two weeks ago, we unveiled a new attack on crime, a 10-point plan that targets gang members, gun traffickers, felons who prey on children and criminals who assault police officers. We fight juvenile crime by holding violent youth to new levels of responsibility for their actions. . . . Under our plan, criminals who commit one violent felony will not, and cannot ever be released on parole.
Persons convicted for the second time of molesting a child will serve at least 15 years to life in jail. Penalties will be increased for crimes involving the sale of firearms and our plan further protects police officers, the guardians of the people's safety. Someone who seriously injures a police officer while committing a crime should and will spend at least 20 years in prison. . . .
WELFARE AND EDUCATION
 Today . . . the spirit of too many New Yorkers is being destroyed by welfare. Welfare has made too many New Yorkers all too dependent on an uncaring bureaucracy. Welfare has failed. While many have benefited, welfare had trapped many more in a system of counterfeit compassion that never met its purpose.
It's clear more welfare is not the answer; it is the problem. The answer is to encourage incentives to work. This past year we took giant steps towards replacing New York's failed welfare system with a system that encourages work. These changes are working. Today 172,000 fewer people are on welfare than a year ago. And today, more than 36,000 New Yorkers are earning their benefits through workfare, by working in parks, municipal offices and in public buildings. . . . Rewards and incentives are the key and there's no reward like work. . . .
And as we face the 21st century, our challenges continue to grow. So must our commitment to excellence in our schools. . . .
But standing in the way is an educational bureaucracy that is simply too large, too burdensome and too stifling. New York spends nearly $10,000 per pupil, more than virtually every other state. Despite this great investment, our schools are not keeping pace to prepare our children for the 21st century. In part, that's because only half the money -- only about half of what the state sends to local schools -- ever gets into the classroom. That is simply wrong. It must end. And it will end. . . .
ENVIRONMENT
 This year, we will work to replicate our successes, this time in the Adirondacks and along the shores of Long Island Sound. The ecology of the Sound is fragile and further neglect threatens our future. I intend to lead a bistate effort with Connecticut and the Federal Government to begin the long process of cleaning up Long Island Sound. It's time for New York to have a solid action plan to restore the greatness of the Sound. And with your help we must begin this effort this year.
The Adirondacks are also a magnificent resource. They link us to our past. They provide a glimpse into our future. Our efforts in the Adirondacks will further demonstrate our vision of developing a consensus that will make New York State the leader in environmental protection, while allowing for economic prosperity.
Today, I'm announcing that the state has purchased an important portion of the Whitney Estate, known as Canoe Carry East in the town of Long Lake in the Adirondacks. The purchase of more than 375 acres with Environmental Protection Fund money will preserve public access to Fourth Lake and the Raquette River along a popular canoe route in the heart of the Adirondack park. As we add more than $100 million to the Environmental Protection Fund this year, and fund a new class of environmental conservation officers to enforce our laws, we can, we must and we will regain New York's role as an environmental leader.
HEALTH AND ENERGY
 The people of New York State have a right to expect the finest health care in the nation and at a cost that can be afforded. But in recent years costs have soared while the quality of care did not improve with it. In 1995 we made great progress towards making sure our citizens received quality, efficient and effective health care. Through managed care more Medicaid recipients are receiving the important preventive and primary care they need to get healthy and to remain healthy. Costly use of emergency rooms for routine care is down. More people are using family doctors to treat their everyday illnesses and to provide the care needed to insure healthy families. . . .
We can and we will design a health care system that insures that our people continue to receive the highest quality health care and at lower costs. . . . I will propose that we guarantee insurance coverage for at least two days of hospital maternity care to assure that both the mother and the infant are healthy before they go home. This is a decision that should be made by doctors and by mothers, not by insurers and H.M.O.'s. . . .
The opening of the electric utility industry to competition is a major sea change facing our state and facing our nation. We are ready. We are taking steps to insure that the people of New York and their employers receive efficient and affordable energy. As we work to reduce the gross receipts tax, we must encourage still lower rates by opening New York State's electric markets to the competitive forces of the free market. . . .
There are only four years to the millennium. There is so little time to set New York State right again. There is so much still to do. But if we keep our resolve and our courage, stand up to the barriers that have stood in our way, we can bring greatness back to our people. Together we can unleash the spirit of New York. Freedom, personal responsibility and individual liberty need to be the hallmarks of our commitment.
By lowering taxes, protecting our people and making government less intrusive in our lives, by creating a safer New York State at home in the workplace and in the classroom and by creating a healthier environment, we will continue down the path to the renewal of greatness this state and its people deserve. The mandate is to each of us. . . .

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Text

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;
After a devastating hurricane, the U.S. Virgin Islands is stressing American values for tourists.

BYLINE: By Anthony Ramirez 

 BODY:
FOR Todd Godwin and C. J. Waldman, it was like winning the lottery: whisked away from Manhattan to spend Labor Day weekend tooling around the United States Virgin Islands to brainstorm, ever so lightly, a tourism ad campaign.
The sun was high, the hilltop trade winds gentle, their island guide colorful. Mr. Godwin, a copywriter at Lowe & Partners, an agency of the Interpublic Group of Companies, and Mr. Waldman, an art director at Lowe, developed the basic campaign on the first day of their trip last year. 
 Two weeks later, a hurricane struck.
Hurricane Marilyn, by far the most destructive storm in a record hurricane season, smashed through an already battered Caribbean. Winds of more than 100 miles an hour killed nine in the Virgin Islands and damaged or destroyed more than 90 percent of the buildings on St. Thomas, the hardest hit of the three islands. The $12 million advertising campaign, set to begin at Thanksgiving, was canceled.
Then, all of a sudden, it was on again. Lowe, best known for its Diet Coke television commercial featuring the hard-body construction worker, introduced the results of its on-again-off-again Virgin Islands campaign yesterday.
Roy L. Schneider, a surgeon who was elected governor of the Virgin Islands the year before, had campaigned on a platform of change and decided a new approach was essential to replace the old American paradise campaign from another agency.
Tourism accounts for 70 percent of the islands' $1.2 billion economy and keeping the old campaign would not do, especially now that worried tourists thought the Virgin Islands had been blown off the map.
No matter that the ads would start appearing the second week of January, long after Puerto Rico and Jamaica had started advertising and well into the December-to-March tourist season. Lowe & Partners would just have to scramble.
The campaign's slogan is: "The U.S. Virgin Islands. They're your islands." It is designed to distinguish the territory's American heritage from that of other Caribbean resorts like Jamaica, with its British heritage, and Martinique, with its French heritage.
Virgin Islanders use American dollars, as do Puerto Ricans. But unlike Puerto Rico, which is a commonwealth with a more independent government, St. John, St. Thomas and St. Croix are administered by the United States Secretary of the Interior. Also, unlike in Puerto Rico, the principal language is English, a fact that Lowe highlights in its campaign.
What is more, a fact that is not directly mentioned in the campaign, the ads are designed to show that the Virgin Islands have recovered. Many of the hotels and most of the main airport have been repaired. All of the scenes in the broadcast and print campaign were taken after Hurricane Marilyn.
All four commercials show an elegant white-bearded black man sitting in a straight-back chair near the beach. A goat is at his feet. In one, a steel guitar can be heard in the background as the Jelly Boys sing, "Never Find a Lover Like Me." A man, wearing a white hat, white shirt and white pants, and his goat turn toward the camera and he says: "You know we've been thinking. Our Virgin Islands are just like all the other Caribbean islands. With some minor exceptions.
"You won't need passports," he continues, in a lilting Caribbean accent, "language dictionaries, foreign currency and you won't go crazy talking to non-English-speaking operators. Hey, you can even rent videos. So come to think of it, we're nothing like those other islands."
The camera pans to the goat with a television remote control in its mouth. "Hey," says the man, "gimme back that remote."
Mr. Godwin and Mr. Waldman got the idea for a storyteller-guide from the example of their island guide on St. John, who also told them a fable of the islands as three brothers, which is also incorporated into the campaign.
"You can't just laundry-list a place's virtues," said Mr. Godwin, the copywriter, "but you can tell them through a character, who is a little eccentric to help make him memorable." When, on the way down from a hilltop on St. John's, Mr. Godwin and Mr. Waldman's vehicle was blocked by a herd of stubborn goats, they got the quirk they were looking for. "We made his best friend a goat," said Mr. Waldman, the art director.
They found Olric Carrington, who plays the storyteller, after auditions of many actors in New York, Los Angeles, Miami and the Virgin Islands. A native, Mr. Carrington is a 71-year-old retired postmaster, amateur actor and, after profiles of him appeared in the local news media, the islands' version of Brad Pitt.
Of course, advertising can't cure everything in Hurricane Marilyn's wake. Of the Virgin Islands' two million tourists, about 1.2 million come from cruise ships on grand tours of the Caribbean. Most, if not all, of those passengers are back.
But the number of other visitors may be down as much as 30 percent. And only 50 percent of St. Thomas's 4,800 rooms are back in commission. Still, the Virgin Islands may have another powerful draw: rooms that usually go for $150 to $500 in the winter are going for half off at many hotels.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasuries Up as Traders Seek Information

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Expectations of a breakthrough in the Federal budget impasse were a principal factor in lifting the prices of Treasury securities yesterday, as the market, lacking hard economic data from the Government, searched for other sources of usable information.
The 30-year bond rose 4/32 , to a price of 11224/32 ; its yield, which moves in the opposite direction, slipped one basis point, or one-hundredth of a percentage point, to 5.95 percent, from 5.96 percent on Tuesday. 
 Technical trading dominated in the absence of reports by the Government, which were postponed because of the partial Federal shutdown.
The Federal Reserve said that the release of data on industrial output and capacity utilization at factories would probably be delayed. And at a news conference in Washington, Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich said that the December Producer Price Index, scheduled for release on Jan. 11, and the Consumer Price Index, scheduled for release on Jan. 12, would be delayed at least two weeks. In addition, he said, publication of the December employment report, which is scheduled for Friday, will also be delayed at least two weeks.
The absence of information could hamper the Fed's decision about whether to cut interest rates again when its monetary-policy arm, the Federal Open Market Committee, meets for the first time this year on Jan. 30 and 31, analysts said.
Mr. Reich said he would review the laws regulating Federal employment to see whether data collectors could be put back to work, adding that if the partial Government shutdown ended this week, the employment report could be released sooner than expected.
In the day's only release of economic data, the Mitsubishi Bank-Schroder Wertheim weekly report on sales at chain stores said that sales rose 1.8 percent in the week ended Dec. 30. It was a brighter picture of store activity than that which prevailed through most of December, but the strength of the report did not keep the market from advancing.
With the market so positive, few investors have had the courage to bet against it by short-selling, or selling borrowed securities in the hopes that their prices will fall, at which time the traders would buy them back, paying off the loan and profiting from the difference. Every attempt to do so recently has backfired.
Early in the session yesterday, word came that Representative John A. Boehner of Ohio, the leader of the House Republican Conference, had said that the House would not vote on a stopgap financing bill to restart the Government; such a bill was approved by the Senate on Tuesday. The news caused bond prices to slip momentarily.
John Burgess, managing director at Bankers Trust Investment Management, said the market had gotten off to a good start from overnight trading.
But the retail sales report, he said, was surprisingly stronger than what the market had been hearing about holiday sales. Mr. Burgess said traders coupled that report with bearish statements by a few Fed governors, causing some buyers to move to the sidelines.
Pulling in favor of bonds was the dollar, which rose out of its recent trading range with the Japanese yen and other currencies.
Mr. Burgess also said that with no fundamental economic data, traders were conducting their own informal surveys and were "trading on both the Spartan data and euphoria of the budget process being done."
Coming into the new year, the market is also awash with liquidity, Mr. Burgess said. Much trading now may simply involve putting money to work while investors wait for clues to the direction of interest rates.
"Inflation still looks good," Mr. Burgess said, "and as a result, people are comfortable and not afraid to buy longer maturities."
Doug Burtnick, a fixed-income analyst at Technical Data in Boston, said that the firm's survey of portfolio managers indicated that managers were switching to neutral positions, "which would behave well if the yield spread between the short and long maturities widens between now and March."
In the municipal market, where supply remains thin, investors should see a fair number of redemptions of bonds.

HEADLINE: Time for Change in Saudi Arabia

 BODY:
Saudi Arabia is the world's largest oil producer, Washington's largest ally in the Persian Gulf and one of the world's last absolute monarchies. So when its ailing King steps aside and hands control of the country to his half-brother, Americans need to pay attention.
In the short run, the transition from King Fahd to Crown Prince Abdullah, which may only be temporary, is likely to be a smooth one. But unless the new ruler and his successors begin to create more representative political institutions and take steps to restore the kingdom's fiscal equilibrium, domestic tensions could become unmanageable in the next decade, raising serious problems for American foreign policy. 
 Crown Prince Abdullah, like King Fahd, is a son of Saudi Arabia's founder, Abdul Aziz Ibn Saud. Abdul Aziz's many sons have ruled the kingdom in succession since the founding monarch died in 1953. Enough younger brothers-in-waiting remain to keep the royal succession predictable for another decade or more, assuming the monarchy itself endures.
Crown Prince Abdullah will likely hew to the same general policy lines followed by King Fahd -- keeping up oil exports, building alliances to contain potential threats from Iran and maintaining close military cooperation with the United States. But while King Fahd was unabashedly pro-American, Crown Prince Abdullah may give these policies a conservative flavor, showing more sympathy for Arab brethren like Syria and even Iraq, and less warmth toward Washington.
Still, Saudi policies derive as much from the kingdom's basic geographic and economic situation as from the inclinations of its monarchs. Steady, substantial export revenues are needed to sustain the high living standards Saudis have come to expect and to pay off the high cost of the Persian Gulf war. Iran is a continuing worry. It is far more populous than Saudi Arabia, it exports terrorism and Islamic militance and it may be acquiring nuclear weapons.
These factors would seem to make Saudi Arabia a natural ally of the United States, but a similar logic once fed American complacency about ties with the Shah's Iran. Like Iran in the 1970's, Saudi Arabia is not only a key oil exporter but a major purchaser of advanced American weaponry. In Riyadh as in Teheran, a closed political system, corruption and insensitivity to the concerns of Islamic believers can create explosive domestic pressures that could detonate without much warning and with enormous international consequences. Last month's bomb blast outside an American military training facility could be a portent.
In recent years, King Fahd has tried to address these pressures by appointing a consultative assembly. He also began to reduce expensive subsidies on key consumer products. Neither move went far enough, and it will now be up to the more traditionalist Crown Prince Abdullah to speed the momentum of political and economic reform. Opening up a closed system has its risks, but it is the most prudent way to maintain his family's throne.

HEADLINE: How To Avoid These Layoffs?

BYLINE: By Robert B. Reich; Robert B. Reich is the Secretary of Labor.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
If the Federal Government is to do less, then the private sector will have to do more. But AT&T's stunning announcement on the first business day of 1996 that it would permanently lay off 40,000 employees raises profound questions about the private sector's ability to take on more responsibility for Americans' economic well-being.
I do not mean to pick on AT&T. It is but one in a long list of companies that have delivered large numbers of pink slips in recent years, despite record profits. Wall Street's initially positive response to AT&T's announcement suggests that the company may have done exactly the right thing by its shareholders. But this is precisely the issue. Do companies have obligations beyond the bottom line? 
 It has become politically fashionable to argue that movie studios and television networks (and their advertisers) should avoid lewdness or violence, even though these dubious themes generate large audiences and fat profits. Well, what about a corporation's duty to its employees and its community? The sudden loss of a paycheck can be more damaging to family values than a titillating screen performance.
Corporate executives claim, with some justification, that they have no choice. Investors demand that companies become ever leaner and ever meaner. If employees' wages and benefits don't generate a sufficient return, the jobs have to go. And if an entire community loses its economic base because the company can do its work more efficiently elsewhere, so be it.
Chief executive officers once sang a different tune. In a 1951 address that was typical of the era, Frank Abrams, chairman of Standard Oil of New Jersey, proclaimed, "The job of management is to maintain an equitable and working balance among the claims of the various directly interested groups . . . stockholders, employees, customers and the public at large." That very year, Fortune magazine lectured executives on their duty to be "industrial statesmen" who worked for the good of their employees and communities as well as shareholders.
What has changed? Competition. American businesses have been transformed from comfortable and stable rivals into bloodletting gladiators. Airlines, telephone companies, utilities, common carriers -- and Wall Street itself -- have been deregulated. Global competitors threaten the very survival of American manufacturers. In addition, information technologies have radically reduced the transaction time between suppliers, wholesalers, retailers and customers. Entry barriers such as preferential access to capital markets have dropped, allowing small companies to grab market share from big ones.
Because of all these pressures to increase earnings, investors face an ever-wider array of choices of where to put their money -- and enjoy ever-greater ease in moving their money around. Electronic capitalism has replaced the gentlemanly investment system that had given "industrial statesmen" the discretion to balance the interests of shareholders against those of employees and communities. Now, any chief executive who hesitates before doing everything possible to maximize returns to shareholders risks trouble.
Paradoxically, this transformation of the corporation into the agent of the shareholder alone has been accompanied by a growing skepticism about the capacity of government to protect the rest of society.
Regardless of how the current budget negotiations are settled, in the future the Federal Government will have a more modest role in safeguarding the economic security of Americans. States and localities may have more leeway, but will have far fewer resources. And because they will compete with other states and locales to attract companies, they will be reluctant to impose higher taxes or any other extra burdens.
AT&T workers who receive pink slips are fortunate that the company is offering lump-sum severance payments based on years of service, along with extra health benefits. That's more than most companies are providing.
But with less public financing available, the former AT&T employees, like other newly laid-off workers, are likely to have less access than did workers last year to publicly supported retraining, job-search assistance, extended unemployment insurance, health care, food stamps and other props to help them get back on their feet.
The ostensible purpose of eliminating the Federal budget deficit is to give the private sector more capital to invest, thus widening opportunities and raising earnings for all Americans. But as we all see, there is no guarantee that corporations will use the extra resources in this way.
Maximizing shareholders' returns may require investing the extra dollars in production abroad, or in labor-saving equipment intended to reduce wages and cut jobs, or in mergers, acquisitions and divestitures that result in mass layoffs.
How, then, to get the private sector to take more responsibility for their employees and communities?
Exhortation will have, at best, a modest effect. The most eloquent moral appeal will be no match for the dispassionate edict of the market. Nor should we seek a return to the era of industrial statesmanship. Even if we could turn the clock backward and enlarge upon the C.E.O.'s former discretion in balancing the interests of shareholders against those of employees and communities, it is far from clear that society should vest such power in unelected officials.
There is another way. The corporation is, after all, a creation of law; it does not exist in nature. The corporate form of business carries special advantages: Investors are not personally liable for damages or debts. A corporation has the same rights of free speech and legal action that an individual has -- but can live forever. There are disadvantages as well: Corporations must pay taxes on their incomes, as do the investors who receive dividends, resulting in double taxation.
If we want corporations to take more responsibility, we will have to alter this mix of advantages and disadvantages to provide the proper incentives. If we want profitable companies to keep more employees on their payrolls or to place them in new jobs that offer similar wages and benefits, to upgrade their skills, to share more of the profits with them and to remain in their communities, we have to give them an economic reason to do so.
Perhaps the benefits of incorporation should be reserved for companies that demonstrate such responsibility. Alternatively (and more realistically in these parched political times), perhaps corporate income taxes should be reduced or eliminated entirely for companies that do so.
As corporations have focused more and more intensely on increasing shareholders' returns and less and less on improving the standard of living of their workers, it should be no surprise that the stock market has soared while pink slips have proliferated and the paychecks of most employees have gone nowhere.
Do not blame corporations and their top executives. They are behaving exactly as they are organized to behave. If we want them to put greater emphasis on the interests of their workers and communities, society must reorganize them to do so. In this era of smaller government, such steps seem warranted.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Paying to pollute: a free market solution that's yet to be tested.

BYLINE: By Peter Passell 

 BODY:
THE 1990 amendments to the Clean Air Act give electric power companies the right to pay to pollute, much the way sinners bought indulgences in the Middle Ages. Yet although the trading of sulfur emissions between utilities is now permitted, there is not much activity in this market, and prices of marketable permits are far below initial projections. Does that mean the system is not working -- that free market environmentalism is being sabotaged by myopic corporate executives or hostile state regulators?
According to the latest studies, the answer is both cheerier and more complicated. So far, it seems, trading among utilities has not been needed to meet Federal standards. Indeed, A. Denny Ellerman, director of the Center for Energy and Environmental Policy at M.I.T., argues that thanks to the plunging price of low-sulfur coal "compliance has been essentially free" in some parts of the country. 
 It is not yet known, though, whether the utilities will exploit the advantages of trading when pollution controls are tightened in coming years. "The issue has yet to be tested," says Daniel J. Dudek of the Environmental Defense Fund.
Federal law requires utilities to limit the sulfur emissions from the country's 110 dirtiest plants -- all of them coal-fired -- to 2.5 pounds for every million British thermal units of energy generated. In 2000, the limit will be extended to all power plants and maximum sulfur emissions will be pared to 1.2 pounds to a million B.T.U.'s. (A million B.T.U.'s is enough heat to make about 100 kilowatt-hours of electricity, a little less than the typical American household uses in a week).
Unlike earlier legislation, the Clean Air Act of 1990 applies to the corporate emissions average: a utility may exceed the limit on one plant by running a very clean operation at another. What's more, it allows individual utilities to buy permits from other power producers, or to bank excess compliance for future use.
In 1990 the Environmental Protection Agency estimated that the right to emit of ton of sulfur would be worth about $750. The figure represented the agency's best guess about the cost of the alternatives -- shutting dirty plants, switching fuels and adding catalytic sulfur scrubbers. But permits have generally run below $150 a ton, and organized trading on the Chicago Board of Trade has been far lighter than expected. Just one utility in six is using the market to comply with the law.
One explanation is that the market has been sabotaged. If, for example, state regulators allow utilities to earn a guaranteed return on outlays for expensive scrubbers, but don't allow them to profit from skillful emissions trading, there would not be much demand for marketable permits.
In fact, there has not been much trading because utilities have taken advantage of their newly won flexibility to offset emissions by cleaning up other plants within their own systems. "Two-thirds of gains have come through intra-utility trading," said Robert N. Stavins of the Kennedy School of Government at Harvard.
One key has been access to cheap, clean fuel. Increased competition among railroads, made possible by rail deregulation, has sharply reduced the price of low-sulfur coal mined in the Plains states for delivery to the Midwest and the South. That allows utilities to burn coal in some plants with as little as a half-pound of sulfur in each million B.T.U.'s, reducing overall utility emissions to the allowable tonnage at little or no cost.
Dallas Burtraw, an economist at Resources for the Future, also notes that new technology has lowered the cost of meeting the sulfur standard. Fuel blending -- mixing low- and high-sulfur coal -- has proved easier than expected. And the price of scrubbing sulfur from smokestacks has fallen by half since 1989.
What's yet to be determined, though, is whether utilities will use the market when pollution requirements tighten and the economic advantages of emissions trading emerge. A number of states are putting pressure on power producers to buy high-sulfur coal from local mines. Indeed, last year a Federal appeals court struck down Illinois legislation that would have required utilities to install scrubbers -- and thus become a captive market for high-sulfur coal.
Even the states without such parochial agendas are sending out mixed signals. Some environmental groups are still ready to cheer on local regulators who frown on utilities that choose to "pay to pollute." And no state has ruled that utilities with the foresight to buy marketable permits cheaply will be allowed to keep the benefits.
Perhaps the best hope is that the wave of electric utility deregulation will end the states' will or capacity to micromanage environmental fixes. If states forgo the right to dictate who sells power at what price -- if electricity is sold in a national market -- competition will force producers to minimize costs. "At least a billion dollars a year in savings" is on the line, Mr. Burtraw says.

HEADLINE: OLYMPICS;
North Korea To Join World In Atlanta

BYLINE: By JERE LONGMAN 

 BODY:
North Korea agreed yesterday to send its athletes to Atlanta next summer, meaning that, for the first time in the century of the modern Olympics, all invited nations have agreed to participate in the Summer Games.
Although it ignored last November's deadline, North Korea reconsidered after recent communications with former President Jimmy Carter and with Juan Antonio Samaranch, president of the International Olympic Committee. 
 The former President, considered a pariah by some in the Olympic movement for the United States boycott of the 1980 Summer Games in Moscow, is now partly responsible for what will be the most inclusive participation ever in the Summer Olympics.
The parade of nations at the July 19 opening ceremonies is scheduled to include 10,700 athletes from all 197 national Olympic committees, a number swelled by the breakup of the former Soviet Union and the splintering of Yugoslavia. Because of political boycotts, war and economic difficulties, some invitations to previous Summer Games have invariably been declined.
"This is great news," Billy Payne, Atlanta's chief Olympic organizer, said yesterday in a telephone interview. "It's something we had hoped for for years, believing that with the wonderful goals and purposes of the Games, they are best fulfilled when you have the entire world present."
North Korea will send approximately 16 athletes to Atlanta to compete in weight lifting, track and field and shooting, along with an unspecified number of athletes to compete in boxing, judo and gymnastics, Francois Carrard, the I.O.C.'s director general, said in a telephone interview from Lausanne, Switzerland.
"It might be easier to get all of the nations to participate in a small, neutral country that doesn't make political waves," Carrard said. "Getting them all together for the centennial Games is a really great thrill."
North Korea boycotted the 1984 Summer Olympics in Los Angeles in response to the Carter-enforced boycott of the 1980 Games in Moscow. North Korea also boycotted the 1988 Summer Games in Seoul because of its continuing hostilities with South Korea. It participated in the 1992 Summer Games in Barcelona, Spain, but was the only nation other than Afghanistan not to respond to Atlanta's invitation by the November deadline.
Afghanistan, citing a simple communications problem with the I.O.C., last month agreed to participate, leaving out only North Korea, which had seemed to grow as isolationist in its sporting endeavors as in its politics.
Olympic officials inside and outside the United States said they did not know why North Korea had initially ignored Atlanta's invitation, although they speculated about possible political and economic reasons, such as friction over its nuclear program, and food shortages that have reportedly led to famine in parts of the country.
But Carter had contacts with the North Koreans, having conducted nuclear diplomacy in Pyongyang in June 1994 with the North Korean President, Kim Il Sung, who has since died. Carter wrote a letter early last month asking Communist officials to reconsider their participation in Atlanta.
"Because of his relationship and ability to communicate with the North Koreans, he was able to help reopen lines of communication between the I.O.C. and North Korea," Carrie Harmon, a spokeswoman for the Carter Center in Atlanta, said yesterday. Aides said Carter was not available for comment.
On Dec. 18, Samaranch sent a letter to Pak Myong Chol, president of North Korea's Olympic committee, and a day later, Carter reported that the North Koreans were reconsidering. Yesterday, they officially agreed to participate. Still to be worked out are "wild card," or automatic berths in Olympic events for which the North Koreans have missed the qualifying tournaments. To defray costs, North Korea and other participating nations can count on the I.O.C. to pay the expenses of six athletes, a program that began in 1984.
Carter's role as Olympic diplomat is in stark contrast with his unpopular decision -- at least in Olympic circles -- to boycott the 1980 Moscow Games because of the Soviet Union's invasion of Afghanistan.
Brought together in Atlanta by Payne several years ago, Carter and Samaranch discussed their differences and, in Payne's words, "departed as friends and agreed to look to the future and not backward."
"I applaud Mr. Carter for his efforts, large or small, in bringing North Korea into the Olympic Games," said John Lucas, an Olympics expert at Penn State University. "The cynics will say, 'so what?' But Mr. Carter has made an effort for world peace and international understanding."
Still, even 15 years later, the Carter-mandated boycott of 1980 lingers with former American Olympians who were left with no place to compete.
"He has made some impressive efforts at world peace, but he missed one of the big ones," said Anita DeFrantz of Los Angeles, a rower on the 1980 Olympic team and now a member of the I.O.C. "People felt sorry for him because he so clearly misunderstood what the Olympics were about. He was dead wrong. But if he did something with the North Koreans that helped, thank you."

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH 

COUNTRY: KOREA, DEMOCRATIC PEOPLE'S REPUBLIC OF (95%); UNITED STATES (92%); KOREA, REPUBLIC OF (92%); AFGHANISTAN (87%); SWITZERLAND (79%); RUSSIAN FEDERATION (72%);

HEADLINE: BATTLE OVER THE BUDGET: THE EFFECTS;
Paralysis Brought On by Shutdown Begins to Seep to the Private Sector

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 3

 BODY:
As the Federal Government wound through the 19th day of its partial shutdown, effects of the budget impasse rippled across the country, closing state unemployment offices in Kansas, leaving complaints about workplace safety unanswered and causing the Environmental Protection Agency to suspend clean up operations at scores of toxic waste dumps.
The second shutdown in a month began in mid-December, closing two-thirds of the Cabinet agencies and putting 280,000 Federal employees out of work. And as the weeks pass, more programs are running short of money. 
 As a result, the shutdown's effects are spreading beyond the Federal work force, 15 percent of which has been furloughed, and beyond the disappointed tourists denied admission to national parks and museums.
In highlighting an array of Government services that were coming to a halt, President Clinton said today that the Meals on Wheels program, which provides food for the homebound elderly, will run out of money this week. And by the end of the week, 11 states, the District of Columbia and the United States Virgin Islands will have used up money to run unemployment offices.
In late December, White House officials said, states received only 40 percent of the quarterly matching payments they had expected from the Federal Government to pay for Medicaid, the insurance program for the poor. The Federal matching money for Medicaid and its 36 million beneficiaries will run out entirely in late January, they said.
The chairman of the executive committee of the Judicial Conference, which supervises the Federal courts, warned today of severe consequences if the shutdown continued much longer. "Federal courts will very shortly run out of money to operate, imperiling the judges' ability to administer justice," said the chairman, Judge Gilbert S. Merritt of the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit.
Judge Merritt said that his committee determined today that the Federal courts could be maintained only until mid-January unless money was made available.
Judges would work without additional financing, Judge Merritt said, but other court personnel would not. That could mean, he said, that judges would not be able to conduct trials, that defendants might have to be released because of the Speedy Trial Act and that air and water pollution decrees might go unenforced.
The shutdown has also taken a toll on companies that rely on the Government as a major customer and those that need special Federal approvals to carry out their business. Commerce Department officials say, for example, that more than 1,000 applications for export licenses, which are required for the export of some strategically important goods, are not being processed.
The Environmental Protection Agency, meanwhile, has issued orders this week to stop work at 450 to 620 Superfund cleanup sites, idling as many as 10,000 contractors, subcontractors and others.
One victim is Insitu Inc., a 60-employee company in Laramie, Wyo., that normally sells $20,000 of groundwater monitoring equipment daily. Today, Insitu did "nothing," the company's chief executive, Chester McKee, said, adding that the budget impasse had already cost the family owned company $100,000 in profits.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Furloughed Federal workers are flooding their credit unions to apply for loans to compensate for their salaries. John Santarpia, the chief executive at the Central Federal Credit Union at the Department of Veterans Affairs, helped Edie Makse in advising Tonya Frazier, left, and Joyce Lewis on loans.; Furloughed workers of the Department of Housing and Urban Development in Los Angeles demonstrated outside their building yesterday to protest the showdown. Vicky Lawson, a pregnant worker, was comforted by her friend Shannon Timmons and her husband, Ruperto Lawson. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: BATTLE OVER THE BUDGET: THE EFFECTS -- In Washington;
Indirect Victims Of the Stalemate

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY, By The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 3

 BODY:
When Constance Conrad died last month, the responsibility of running her management company passed to her 29-year-old nephew, Thomas. One of his first decisions was to furlough 20 employees, because the Federal agencies with which he has contracts had shut down.
Today, with the shutdown no nearer to an end, Mr. Conrad was still agonizing over the layoffs. 
 "Even though it's not my fault, I feel responsible," he said. "These people have mortgages to pay, children in school, car notes. Most never believed they lived paycheck to paycheck until something like this happens. Now they do, and some of them, I know, are in dire straits."
Small-business owners like Mr. Conrad, and the workers they employ, form what Eleanor Holmes Norton, the District of Columbia's delegate to the House of Representatives, calls "the concentric circles" of the budget stalemate: people whose livelihoods depend on a Government operating at full capacity and who, unlike Federal workers, have no reason to expect retroactive pay once a budget agreement is reached.
Ms. Norton was joined at a news conference today by Mr. Conrad and several other such people, and said they were the "untold story" of the shutdown. They included Senaite Assefa, who said she had been forced to shorten the hours of the delicatessen she runs three blocks from the White House; Tom Mack, the owner of a tour-bus company who has laid off 40 drivers because of the closing of landmarks, and Edward Orechowski, president of Catholic Charities of Washington, who said the agency had been besieged by requests for financial assistance.
Emily Vetter, president of the Hotel Association of Washington, said the six-day Government shutdown in November and the current closings had cost local hotels almost $20 million.
Worse than that, Ms. Vetter said, they have shaken Washington's reputation as a tourist stop, threatening future bookings by sending a message to would-be visitors that "ours is not a reliable destination."
Ms. Norton said that while "an astonishing number of communities" were reporting major losses from the shutdown, Washington, as the seat of the Federal Government, was the biggest loser, with tourism and other businesses that fuel its economy "collapsing like dominoes."
Indeed, some parts of the capital have taken on the look of a ghost town. Streets are empty. Offices appear dark. Cabs are easy to find.
Safwat Ezzat, who has a vending cart on a corner two blocks from the White House, said the shutdown had cut his daily sales to less than $100, from $400, and had prevented him from replenishing stock. "Look," he said, pointing to a bin usually overflowing with sodas and ice teas. "I have no money to buy new supplies. Same with candy."
A woman appeared, asking for a hot pretzel.
"Sorry," he said. "I have no more." MICHAEL JANOFSKY

HEADLINE: BATTLE OVER THE BUDGET: THE EFFECTS -- In Kansas;
No More Benefits For Unemployment

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Jan 3

 BODY:
The Kansas Department of Human Resources, which distributes unemployment benefits across the state, put up signs on Tuesday at its eight district offices saying the offices would be closed until further notice, "due to the impasse in Washington." As a result, many out-of-work Kansans wanting to collect their unemployment checks are out of luck.
The problem is not a lack of money to pay the benefits; it is a lack of Federal money to pay the salaries of the people who run the unemployment offices and disburse the benefits. 
 "The pot of money that pays for unemployment is out of Washington," said Angela Goering, director of communications at the Kansas unemployment service, "and that money just ran out."
About 400 state employees who work in the unemployment offices have been furloughed, Ms. Goering said, and as a result, many of the estimated 19,000 out-of-work Kansans -- about 3.9 percent of the state's population -- will not receive their unemployment checks starting this week. The average weekly check, she said, is $194.
Other states, like neighboring Missouri, have borrowed from other state funds to pay employees and have not had to shut their unemployment offices. And some unemployed people in Kansas have crossed the border to Kansas City, Mo., to try to file their Kansas claims, said Jackie Jackson, manager of the Kansas City office of the Missouri Department of Employment Security. Ms. Jackson described Tuesday as "a real wild day."
"It's a double whammy for these people," Ms. Jackson said. "They're already unemployed; now they have to deal with not getting their unemployment checks."
Ms. Jackson said that more than 25 people from Kansas came to the Missouri agency's office in downtown Kansas City and either applied for new benefits or applied to receive this week's benefits. "But with no one at work in Kansas, the requests will just sit in the computer," she said.
Missouri officials have said they have money to keep their state's unemployment office open for the next four to six weeks regardless of whether the impasse in Washington is ended.
New Jersey, Maine, New Mexico and Rhode Island are among other states that are running out of Federal money to administer their unemployment programs, Federal officials in Washington said.
In Kansas, Ms. Goering said state offices have been fielding calls from the unemployed for two days.
"They're angry already," she said, "but as far as I know, there's been no organized effort to do anything about this on the part of the unemployed."

HEADLINE: Central Asia Should Win the New 'Great Game'

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re your editorial "The New Great Game in Asia" (Jan. 2): The original Great Game, between imperial Russia, China and Britain, brought nothing but misery and destruction to its playing field, Asia's heartland. The game was settled amicably in the 1940's by the wartime alliance of the major players. Each power took its share of Central Asia's vast natural wealth, while the titularly independent states of Afghanistan, Mongolia and Nepal (and originally Tibet) were created -- not as genuinely autonomous republics but as "neutral" buffer states, confined to desolate and impoverished lands to keep the main imperial armies from direct confrontation.
While the game in Central Asia has always been between three Great Powers (with the United States now substituting for Britain), the important struggle has been between the people of Central Asia and the combined imperial powers. 
 Seen in this light, it is wrong to suggest, as you do, that a solution lies in "equitably sharing profits" among all those with historic or economic claims. You say that Moscow's claims go back to the czarist conquest (although the Central Asian khanates were never "Islamic emirates," as you call them, having always been heterodox and heterogeneous in terms of religion and structures of authority). Why does some past brutal military conquest give an imperial power a valid current claim? Does Spain have some claim to the oil wealth of Venezuela? Can Japan claim a share in the riches of the Philippines?
You say that "everybody could benefit . . . by agreeing to split the winnings," and you hasten to mention the necessity of "Western and Japanese capital." But it is doubtful that your "everybody" would include anybody -- any single ordinary person -- in Central Asia. So far, the generous infusion of capital and technology from the United States, Japan and the Persian Gulf has meant skyrocketing inflation throughout the region, the creation of a new and onerous comprador class and the impoverishment of the general population.
A real solution to Central Asia's dilemma does not lie in any pipeline deal, nor in any distribution of the region's wealth among the Great Powers -- Chevron, Exxon and Mobil among them. Rather, Central Asia should be reclaimed by Central Asians. Chechnya, Tatarstan, East Turkestan (Xinjiang), Tibet and Kashmir, at the least, should have their autonomy -- if not independence -- respected. Mongolia should be restored to twice its current size.
Instead of agreeing to divide the spoils in Central Asia, the Great Powers should learn the lesson of the old Great Game and agree to withdraw their covert agents and support for their puppet politicians. In such case, the despotic regimes in the region would crumble and the Central Asian peoples could decide how best to steward their resources -- for their benefit and, ultimately, ours.
 
GEOFFREY SEA
Oakland, Calif., Jan. 2, 1996
 
The writer is a historian of science with extensive experience in Central Asia.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Letter

HEADLINE: Add Fertility Contol To Ethiopia Equation

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In "Even With Peace and Rain, Ethiopia Fears Famine" (news article, Jan. 3), the consultant Henry Gordon claims that generating growth in the economy will "in itself bring the population of Ethiopia down." Dr. Gordon asserts that economic, rather than demographic, considerations should be foremost in the effort to create sustainability in Ethiopia. In the same article, Tom Sheehy even goes so far as to say that focusing on population control without increasing incomes is "like putting the cart before the horse." 
 Certainly, economic development is important in providing for sustainability in Ethiopia. But as the article points out, the population is doubling every 20 years. Does Ethiopia have time to focus solely on economic matters while the average woman bears seven children in her lifetime? Even with improved infrastructure and privatized land, will Ethiopia be able to produce food for the projected 90 million citizens in the year 2010? How long will it take for improved economic conditions to start reducing fertility?
Reducing fertility is not the sole answer to improving the welfare of Ethiopians, but it should be part of the equation.
 
JANE S. DE LUNG
Pres., Population Resource Center
Princeton, N.J., Jan. 4, 1996

HEADLINE: HOCKEY;
Brendan Byrne Arena Goes Continental

BYLINE: By RICHARD SANDOMIR 

DATELINE: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Jan. 4

 BODY:
For nearly 15 years, it was officially the Brendan Byrne Arena. But that political homage to the former Democratic governor was covered forever today by a banner heralding the benefactor paying $29 million through 2007 as title sponsor of the arena: Continental Airlines.
The 20,000-seat facility at the Meadowlands Sports Complex is now the Continental Airlines Arena. 
 "This is not politically motivated," said Michael Francis, chairman of the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority, which runs the complex, during a news conference at the arena's center court. "If a Republican's name had been on it, it would have come down. There's nothing personal. This was based solely on economics."
Those economics were imposed upon the sports authority during the often-acrimonious negotiations that led to the Devils' new lease to continue playing hockey at the arena. The agency had to provide a guaranteed cash flow for the team's use in securing a 12-year, $25 million loan.
The Devils will get 30 percent of Continental's payments. The Nets' share has not been determined.
Continental will pay $750,000 this year, $1.5 million next year, $2.25 million in 1998 and $1.5 million a year from 1999 to 2007. It will also provide the sports authority with $700,000 worth of travel annually, which may be used for the Devils and Nets' travel, but can also be resold at 80 percent of the tickets' face value. Continental can cancel with two years' notice, starting in 2000.
"But we intend to be here for a very long time," said Gregory Brenneman, the airline's chief operating officer.
Robert Mulcahy, president of the sports authority, said Continental is paying more than any other arena title sponsor in the nation. "The others average about $1 million each," he said. "Ours is the best."
Mulcahy, who served Byrne as chief of staff before running the sports authority, said old ties with the former governor had to give way to improving the arena's finances.
"When you deal with friendship, it's very difficult," he said, "but my responsibility as the C.E.O. is to run this facility as well as possible."
Continental is the eighth airline to put its name on a sports facility, including America West Arena in Phoenix and the Delta Center in Salt Lake City.
Over all, two dozen companies have their names on major sports facilities, including Bank One Ball Park, in Phoenix ($66 million for 30 years), Fleet Center in Boston ($30 million for 15 years) and CoreStates Spectrum in Philadelphia ($40 million for 20 years), according to I.E.G. Sponsorship Report.
"You pay a ton of money, but you get a lot of visibility," said Lesa Ukman, I.E.G.'s editor. "When you're the title sponsor, you ride free on lots of visibility. Events will be advertised as taking place at the Continental Arena. If their teams made the playoffs, it's great publicity."
But there is no actual gauge for the efficiency or impact of a sponsorship.
"It's hard to weigh the value of the association," Brenneman said, "but being with the arena helps us build a long-term image."
Continental believes its sponsorship will enhance its local name recognition as the biggest employer and airline at Newark International Airport, one of the airline's three United States passenger hubs. "We need to support the community in our hub cities and this is a great way to do it," Brenneman said.
Kevin Murphy, an airline analyst at Morgan Stanley, said: "It's worked well for other airlines. It's good corporate awareness. Continental is New Jersey's airline. They've made great strides to improve service at Newark."
The airline also wants to capitalize on the exposure derived from its pilots identifying the arena to passengers on flyovers; from its name being seen on the arena's ice and hardwood floor, and from being seen and cited during broadcasts of Nets, Seton Hall and Devils games and the National Collegiate Athletic Association men's basketball Final Four this spring.
"If you establish the value of the TV exposure we will get during games, it well exceeds what we're paying," Brenneman said.
It also wanted to reward employees and passengers with free tickets to the arena's events. A dozen employees, all in uniform, today received free tickets to Friday's Nets game in honor of their perfect attendance.
Brenneman said that those who come to the arena have the financial wherewithal to fly, and Continental will set up a ticket office at the arena.
In the past year, the once-bankrupt Continental's financial fortunes have revived dramatically, as has its on-time performance and luggage handling.
From a 1994 loss of $613 million, it produced net income of $183 million through last November. But the airline industry is notoriously cyclical and can turn black ink to red quickly.
"Whether we're in good times or in slight dips, we will be in Newark and be a large force to be reckoned with," Brenneman said.
Mulcahy added, "They've been a sponsor here since 1991 and always paid their bills."
Mulcahy said the Giants have a lease provision that would let them sell their own title sponsorship to Giants Stadium, and there have been no corporate takers to rename the Meadowlands Racetrack.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Statistical Casualties in Battle of the Budget

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 4

 BODY:
On the first Friday of almost every month, the Government publishes statistics on employment, its single most important set of figures on the economy, watched by business people and ordinary workers as well as economists, bond and stock traders.
The 21-page Employment Situation release, along with a hearing on it conducted by the Joint Economic Committee of Congress, is a regular part of the city's enduring rituals. On occasions over the last four decades, Labor Department officials have slept in their offices to make sure that blizzards would not prevent its release. But what storms cannot do, the budget impasse has. The partial shutdown of the Federal Government has furloughed most workers in the Federal statistical system, and the numbers will not appear. 
 "This is the first employment release we've ever missed," lamented William G. Barron Jr., Deputy Commissioner of the Bureau of Labor Statistics. "It's unthinkable in the B.L.S. work ethic."
The postponement of the labor-market data is the latest and most important in a series of statistical casualties since mid-December that has already claimed figures on housing, incomes, international trade, orders for durable goods and an updating of total economic output for the quarter that ended in September. Reports on consumer prices and producer prices for December, scheduled for next week, will also be delayed.
Although the situation is not yet desperate -- and apparently has not had a major impact on financial markets so far -- that could change. In the absence of the normal barrage of economic data, a report today that a round of budget talks had been called off was enough to send the Dow Jones industrial average down more than 50 points, and it finished off 20.23 points, at 5,173.84. [Page D6.] Bond prices also fell sharply, with the yield on the 30-year bond jumping back above the 6 percent level, to 6.02 percent, from 5.95 percent on Wednesday. [Page D16.]
And officials and private analysts say the need to get statisticians back to work by mid-January has now become urgent. Indeed, this week two governors of the Federal Reserve Board, the vice chairman, Alan S. Blinder, and Janet Yellen, have said the lack of data is already starting to impair the central bank in its conduct of monetary policy. That concern could easily move markets if the dearth of data continues.
The Fed's policy body is scheduled to meet at month's end to decide, most immediately, whether the economy needs the spur of another cut in short-term interest rates.
Specialists say that the paucity of data is almost certain to cause increasingly erratic movement in bonds and stocks. "We are going to see more volatility in markets," said Everett M. Ehrlich, Under Secretary of Commerce for Economic Affairs.
Today, the National Association of Business Economists expressed its concern about the situation, contending that lack of information could prove so inhibiting that companies as well as the Federal Reserve would make poor decisions and even push an already weakened economy into a recession.
"While the limited, privately provided economic data available can give us some indication," said the group's board of directors, "they are no substitute" for the official numbers. "A serious slowing of the economy that is not recognized because of a lack of data could unnecessarily risk tipping the economy into recession."
Mr. Ehrlich put it more simply. "Information," he said, "is the lubricant of the economy."
And while the December data for all the major indicators have been collected, they remain unprocessed and this could cause a problem for January collection by the Bureau of Labor Statistics of, for example, the Producer Price Indexes, since the preceding month's responses are often used to "frame" subsequent questions.
And the accuracy of the Consumer Price Index would be at least slightly impaired by the inability of surveyors to work as scheduled this week, thus distorting comparison with other months because they include prices gathered during the first week of the month. "Now it's a question of comparability," Mr. Barron said.
Bruce Steinberg, a senior economist at Merrill Lynch, expressed no particular concern for the numbers delayed so far but said "that is about to change" because of the postponement of the Producer Price Index, the Consumer Price Index and retail sales reports for December -- all initially scheduled for next Thursday and Friday.
And the report on January employment, scheduled to be released on Feb. 2, is now almost certain to be delayed with at least some loss of accuracy, officials said.
"The longer it lasts, the less certain we are of having a good sense of where the economy is really going," Mr. Steinberg added. "Both the markets and the Fed are increasingly going to be flying blind."

HEADLINE: U.S. to Apply New Vigor in Policing Trade

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 4

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration plans to announce a broad initiative to enforce dozens of trade accords with China, Japan, Canada and other big trading partners, in a move that appears directed at protecting President Clinton from Republican accusations that his free trade agreements are costing jobs in the United States.
Administration officials said today that as part of the initiative, the United States trade representative, Mickey Kantor, would create an enforcement office, charged with forcing several nations to live up to their agreements. 
 But Mr. Kantor, who was President Clinton's campaign chairman in 1992, said that the effort to be announced on Friday would be much broader, involving the Commerce Department and other agencies.
"We're convinced that you've got to be willing to show the sword to get results," said Stuart E. Eizenstat, President Jimmy Carter's domestic-policy adviser, who was nominated by President Clinton this week to be under secretary of commerce for international trade. "We know that making the case for free trade also means showing that we are not going to tolerate violations of the agreements we have already reached."
Administration officials have frequently spoken of a more rigorous monitoring of trade accords. And to get those agreements, the Clinton White House has threatened sanctions against trading partners, including close allies, far more often than previous administrations.
But after grabbing considerable attention with its threats, especially during the protracted dispute with Japan last year over automobile trade, the Administration stopped short of invoking many of those sanctions, declaring that last-minute agreements made them unnecessary.
Until now, however, there has been no formal system for resuscitating agreements that are failing, whether with South Korea, Canada or others.
And while Administration officials say that they are simply carrying through on three-year-old promises to enforce American trade laws, the new and tougher tone seems prompted, at least in part, by fear that Patrick J. Buchanan, along with other Republican Presidential aspirants, is striking a chord in voters by arguing that the Administration has become a paper tiger on trade matters -- threatening, but rarely acting.
If a major showdown develops this election year, many trade experts and some Administration officials say, it will probably be with China.
So far, the Beijing authorities have done very little to enforce a significant agreement struck last February to crack down on the piracy of music, movies and computer software. American officials say that 29 Chinese factories churning out huge volumes of counterfeit compact disks are still running at top speed.
Mr. Kantor has set a deadline next month for China to change its ways and avoid a renewal of trade sanctions against exports to the United States.
The issue is also politically charged in Congress, where Republicans and Democrats both say that Beijing's continued repression of dissidents, combined with the soaring American trade deficit, has undermined the Administration's policy of "comprehensive engagement.". The term describes a strategy in which economic and commercial ties are used to attempt to influence countries' political behavior.
Publicly, the Clinton Administration continues to defend its China policy, arguing that it was right to stop linking the renewal of preferential trade status for the Chinese to their record on human rights. In private, though, there is increasing nervousness that Mr. Clinton is open to the same accusation that he leveled at George Bush in 1992: that the United States is coddling China's leaders to benefit American exports.
Assailing China's failure to comply with trade accords has the political advantage of getting tough without bringing human rights into the discussion.
"The pattern has been that the United States calls on China to remedy its trade sins, China agrees to do so, then China breaks its promise," Greg Mastel, a China expert at the Economic Strategy Institute, wrote recently. "The credibility of U.S. trade policy around the world will be severely undermined if such blatant disregard goes unanswered."
In a speech scheduled for Friday, Mr. Kantor is expected to steer clear of the matter of intellectual-property rights, another area in dispute with China, because negotiations are under way to resolve it without threatening to reimpose $1 billion in trade sanctions.
He is, though, expected to announce a series of enforcement actions involving other countries.
One of the first is with Canada, which recently placed an 80 percent tax on advertising carried in Canadian editions of Sports Illustrated, a Time Warner property. American officials view the tax as an effort to protect Canadian publications from competition, and argue that it violates both the North American Free Trade Agreement and the world trade accord signed last year.
Another early action expected would seek enforcement of Japanese obligations -- not those involving last year's agreement over autos and auto parts, which the Administration says is being faithfully observed -- but Japan's refusal to protect music recordings made between 1946 and 1971.
It may be the first time, Mr. Kantor conceded today, that he has come to the defense of Frank Sinatra, the Beatles and Bo Diddley -- artists whose early recordings have remained popular in Japan.
Another important American ally, South Korea, will also be a target: It reached an agreement last year to permit American meat to be sold in its grocery stores, but it has missed several deadlines to file the agreement with the World Trade Organization in Geneva.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
A new survey seeks to gauge the research needs of American companies as they look abroad.

BYLINE: By Stuart Elliott 

 BODY:
THE association representing companies that conduct marketing and opinion surveys for corporate America has conducted a survey of its own.
The Council of American Survey Research Organizations, known as Casro, is releasing the results of its initial survey, which canvassed 313 executives at large and midsized corporations. The study, conducted during the summer, focused primarily on issues related to the growing globalization of American businesses and their intentions toward using research in markets overseas. 
 Annual revenue for the research industry in this country is estimated by Casro at $3.5 billion to $4 billion. Seven members of the association contributed their services to the survey, which has roughly the same purpose as a campaign that an advertising agency creates to help promote itself to marketers.
"This is our first foray into the public arena in terms of getting information out about the value of research," said Diane Bowers, executive director of Casro in Port Jefferson, L.I., which represents 165 companies responsible for about 85 percent of all survey research in the United States.
"The goal of the survey researcher is to be thought of as a consulting expert on how to market your products and services based on what your customer or your potential customer thinks," she added. "From the positive side, we're finding that research is being looked at more as a part of the marketing function" at corporations.
The survey found that a corporation spent on average almost $5 million on research pertaining to international markets. But 84 percent of that spending went to in-house efforts rather than hiring outsiders -- members of Casro, say -- to gather the data.
"There are still some corporations that feel they don't need formal research, particularly if they have sales reps in the field from whom they get feedback," said Nicholas Tortorello, a senior vice president at Roper Starch Worldwide in New York, one of the seven Casro members contributing to the survey.
"But most are starting to realize that they need objective research because they can't really rely on what they hear from people who work for them," he added.
When asked in the survey why they conduct research internationally, 43 percent of the respondents said they sought to assess international business opportunities or wanted a better understanding of the potential of international markets. Seventeen percent said they were interested in assessing how their products were or would be received overseas.
When the respondents were asked where research was conducted during the last three years, Latin America and Mexico was the No. 1 answer, at 80 percent, followed by Western Europe, at 79 percent, and Asia, at 77 percent. Asked to predict where they would conduct research in the next three years, Asia moved into first place, at 84 percent, followed by Latin America and Mexico at 80 percent and Western Europe at 74 percent.
Though only 40 percent of respondents said they conducted research in Eastern Europe during the last three years, 60 percent said they planned research in that region in the next three years.
There was another large increase in a question about Africa: though 22 percent of respondents said they conducted research there during the last three years, 32 percent said they intended to do so in the next three years.
One reason Casro commissioned the survey, Ms. Bowers said, was to help distinguish the survey research industry from "other industries that it so often gets caught up with," like telemarketing and direct marketing. She lamented what she described as the problems caused "by '900'-number telephone polls, which aren't legitimate research based on statistically representative samples," and "the confusion between telemarketing and survey calls."
Survey research executives have now coined words for those difficulties, Ms. Bowers said. Misrepresentation under the guise of conducting a survey is "mugging," selling under the guise of research is "sugging" and polls that are statistically shaky are "pugging."
Mugging and sugging and pugging, oh my!
The other Casro members that contributed to the survey, in addition to Roper Starch, were: AUS Consultants/ICR Survey Research Group in Media, Pa., owned by AUS Consultants; Audits and Surveys Worldwide in New York; the Gordon S. Black Corporation in Rochester; Chesapeake Surveys in Owings Mills, Md.; Coast to Coast Telephone Center Inc. in Stamford, Conn., owned by Rothstein-Tauber, and the Total Research Corporation in Princeton, N.J.
