HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Prices Plummet On Delay in Budget Talks

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities fell sharply late yesterday as budget meetings in Washington were unexpectedly postponed and investors grew wary about the progress of those talks.
Bonds, headed for a second consecutive day of gains, bounced in choppy trading, with the market supported by a strong dollar in overseas trading and expectations that a budget resolution was near. But early optimism turned to late disappointment as market participants were suddenly forced to come to grips with the probability of no budget agreement this week, as the budget talks were called off. 
 The price of the 30-year bond fell 1 5/32 of a percentage point, to 111 22/32; its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from its price, rose back above the 6 percent level, to 6.02 percent, from 5.95 percent on Wednesday.
Early into yesterday's session, prospects of a budget agreement helped to both bolster the dollar and indirectly support bonds. A strong American dollar in foreign currency trading makes dollar-denominated investments like Treasury securities more attractive to foreign investors with weaker currencies.
Some investors who had been waiting for a budget agreement to sell because they feared missing a strong rally were tempted to make a move often yesterday by headlines on electronic news services that pointed to questions about whether a deal could be struck, to the fact that there were still fundamental differences and to talk of Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin's impeachment if he should continue to bypass Congress to avoid the national debt limit.
Donald Fine, chief market analyst at Chase Securities, said: "The stalemate in Washington is clearly a pain to a lot of people and caused the market to go into a funk this afternoon. But at the same time, it's part of the democratic process. Who among us would prefer an alternative system?
"Even a near-term solution to the current paralysis in Washington, either with a budget accord, or more likely, another continuing resolution, would only partially solve some of the issues currently facing the market," Mr. Fine said.
"Indeed, when the Federal Open Market Committee meets on Jan. 30 and 31, it will have only slightly more data to peruse than what was available at the December meeting, and in most cases the additional data will merely confirm the anecdotal evidence that the Fed had when it eased back last month," Mr. Fine added, noting that he thinks the Fed will most likely keep monetary policy unchanged at the end of January.
Mr. Fine said that the Fed might have to wait until March, when February data become available, to consider a move in monetary policy.
"There is also some question," he said, "as to the integrity of some of the upcoming economic releases, particularly the Consumer Price Index and retail sales reports for December, but also for a number of indicators in January as well," because the Government may be rushed to collect and crunch the numbers.
After January, the next meeting of the Fed's monetary policy committee will be on March 26.
Mr. Fine said that sales for December at chain stores were "slightly to the weak side" and that motor vehicle sales were "clearly stronger than anticipated," suggesting a moderate increase in retail sales for the month.
In futures trading, which affects the cash price of current issues being traded, the March bond contract dropped below a support price of 121 23/32 and near the close plunged to as low as 120 20/32, before settling at 120 21/32. However, since the longer-term trend remains bullish for the market, traders said, pullbacks continued to represent buying opportunities.
Robin Mesch, chief fixed-income analyst with Thomson Research of Boston, said: "Bonds are entering into a short-term consolidation period during which bond prices could test 120 2/32 to 119 27/32. Don't mistake the short-term neutral to bearish price actions as a signal that bonds are peaking, or that the long-term bullish structure has been negated. However, do interpret the price changes as suggestive of a downturn that will give us an excellent buying opportunity in all maturities."
The Treasury sold $18.75 billion of new one-year bills yesterday at an average discount rate of 4.89 percent, down from 5.06 percent last month and the lowest in almost two years.
Dealers said the ratio of orders to the actual amount sold was healthy, with retail interest showing improvement. Traders said the strong demand for the securities during budget negotiations was an encouraging sign.

HEADLINE: Mayor Calls Pataki's Cuts Too Painful for New York

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Jan. 4

 BODY:
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani intensified his criticism of Gov. George E. Pataki's proposed budget today, telling state legislators that its deep cuts would create pain for New York City residents and fiscal problems for city government.
In testimony before a joint legislative budget committee, Mr. Giuliani said that the Governor's budget would provide the city as little as $150 million in savings through cuts to health and welfare programs, far less than the $955 million Mr. Pataki had projected and even less than estimates produced by the City Council Speaker, Peter F. Vallone. 
 The Mayor, who says he needs $675 million in savings from the state to help balance next year's city budget, said that Mr. Pataki's spending plan could force the city to reduce already pared-back city services.
Noting that Mr. Pataki's budget calls for 25 percent reductions in some block grants for mental health and health care, Mr. Giuliani said, "At 25 percent, we are going to be faced with a choice of either hurting people or taking money out of other programs."
The comments, Mr. Giuliani's most detailed yet on the Pataki plan, contrasted vividly with his testimony before the same committee last year, when the Mayor not only endorsed many of Mr. Pataki's proposed budget cuts but also recommended that some of them be larger.
While infusing his testimony with praise for Mr. Pataki's overall goals to shrink government, rein in health-care spending and cut taxes, Mr. Giuliani, who, like Mr. Pataki is a Republican, expressed many of the same concerns about the Governor's plan that Democrats have.
He said the state was shortchanging the city on school aid, giving it 34 percent of state education spending even though the city has 37 percent of the state's students. He said Mr. Pataki's proposal to reduce cash grants to welfare recipients would "ravage" assistance to the truly needy.
And while generally supporting the Governor's proposal to create block grants that would cover many social programs, he said he was concerned that the plan would proceed too quickly and was being used to mask deep cuts to those programs.
City Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi, a Democrat and frequent Giuliani rival, said of the Mayor's comments: "His spin is more complimentary to the Governor than mine, but we're essentially coming down in the same place. This is an important change. It is a less ideological view of the realities of governing."
Today's testimony seemed to open a new chapter in Mr. Giuliani's constantly evolving relationship with Mr. Pataki. That relationship hit a low point in 1994 when Mr. Giuliani endorsed Gov. Mario M. Cuomo over Mr. Pataki, but improved somewhat in 1995 when the Mayor supported Mr. Pataki's budget even as it cut spending for the city. Today, Mr. Giuliani, who is up for re-election in 1997, seemed to be searching for a middle ground from which he could applaud Mr. Pataki's philosophical positions while attacking the substance of his plans.
Mr. Giuliani said he changed his message this year because the city had already made deep reductions in social programs that had helped the state, which shares in the costs of those programs, to save money. Asking the city to make even deeper cuts in those programs would be unfair, he said.
And he suggested that sharp state budget cuts could enervate the city's economy. "It is important to understand that the city is an economic engine for both the state and the nation," he said.
Aides to Mr. Pataki said they had not heard many of Mr. Giuliani's concerns before today. They played down his criticisms, noting that he continued to praise the broad themes underlying Mr. Pataki's budget.
"Clearly he has the same goals we do, which is to reduce government spending and provide services at a lower cost," said Zenia Mucha, Mr. Pataki's director of communications. But she added, "This is not a situation where we have unlimited funds."
Other Republican state officials said that they thought Mr. Giuliani's comments today could damage his relations with the Governor. "The Governor won't be a happy camper," said one Republican official, speaking on condition of anonymity.
Unlike Mr. Hevesi, who called today for a delay in a scheduled cut in state income taxes, Mr. Giuliani said he supported further tax reductions. Indeed, he called on the Legislature to allow the city to eliminate its 4 percent sales tax on clothing costing less than $500. Speaker Sheldon Silver of the Assembly has proposed a similar plan for the rest of the state.
Though the proposal could reduce city revenues by $300 million a year, Mr. Giuliani said the increase in retail trade caused by the tax cut would more than offset the loss.
Mr. Giuliani began his Albany trip by visiting the Republican Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, and Mr. Silver, a Democrat of Manhattan. The Mayor and Mr. Silver clashed often last year and have barely spoken since February.
But today's meeting marked a continuing rapprochement between the two men, who appeared before reporters after their 10-minute session sitting side-by-side on a green leather couch in Mr. Silver's office.
In a signal that he may join forces with Assembly Democrats to fight many of Mr. Pataki's cuts, Mr. Giuliani said he would continue to meet with Mr. Silver on the budget for weeks to come.
Mr. Giuliani did not meet with Mr. Pataki, who was in New York City today.

HEADLINE: Dollar Rallies Against Yen, But Loses Ground to Mark

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
The dollar continued its rally against the Japanese yen yesterday, briefly rising to levels last seen 21 months ago before falling back on word from Washington of the latest breakdown in negotiations over the Federal budget.
Despite the retreat, which took place in afternoon trading, the dollar nevertheless registered an advance against the yen. And, given the weakness of the Japanese economy and comparatively favorable conditions in the United States, some traders and analysts said the dollar could continue to strengthen against the yen for some time yet. 
 "Relatively low real interest rates in the world suggest you go to the country that has done the most amount of monetary policy easing, and has the least amount left to do," said Richard E. Witten, a partner at Goldman, Sachs & Company.
"Japan has more easing to do, as does Germany. The United States, by contrast, doesn't have as much to do. And the performance of American financial assets, which continue to do extremely well, is attracting capital."
In late New York trading, the dollar was quoted at 105.30 yen, up from 104.87 late Wednesday, but well below the 106.50 yen level it reached earlier in the day. That rate was the highest for the dollar since March 24, 1994, when it reached 106.62 yen.
While the latest upswing in the dollar began as 1995 was drawing to a close and has continued into the New Year, its rise against the yen is merely a continuation of a move that began in June.
Currency traders and analysts began to feel better about the dollar's prospects at that time because of a decision by the Japanese Ministry of Finance to entice Japanese financial institutions to invest abroad, as well as the conclusion of a bilateral auto agreement that staved off a possible trade war between the United States and Japan.
At that point, the dollar was trading in the low 90's against the yen, well above the record low of 79.75 yen reached on April 19, but more than 12 percent under where it is now.
And the rally against the yen has not led to a corresponding surge against other major currencies like the German mark.
"The dollar has not clearly rallied against the mark, even though economic fundamentals in Germany suggest that it should," said David Buchen, a managing director in charge of North American foreign exchange operations at Citibank.
"With both Japan and Germany mired in stagnation and deflation, the markets generally expect the dollar to do well this year."
In fact, yesterday the dollar lost ground against the mark. It was quoted at 1.4430 marks late yesterday in New York, down from 1.4453 late Wednesday.
The dollar's ascendance, Mr. Witten said, "is mostly a Japan story."
"Money is very easy there, the economy is still very weak, their trade surplus is declining," he said. "All of those things suggest a further weakening."
To a certain extent, traders said, the dollar's recent spurt could be attributed to an anticipated budget agreement, a deal that for a while at least would address a problem that has been hampering the dollar on world currency markets for more than a decade.
"I think the dollar is shaking off its legendary problems of being inflation-prone and deficit-prone," Mr. Buchen said. "But the market needs to see the proof of the pudding. What we are getting instead is a comedy in Washington."
Still, even though they say a balanced budget agreement would be favorable, currency traders and analysts acknowledge that the political bickering about the budget deficit masks the real condition of the budget.
"Right now the budget deficit in the United States is the lowest in the industrialized world," said Ron Leven, J. P. Morgan's global currency strategist.
"The deficit is not an issue right now because we don't have a problem with it," Mr. Leven said. "Getting rid of the fiscal deficit is not a major factor for the economy."
Still, unlike Mr. Witten and Mr. Buchen, Mr. Leven said he did not expect much from the dollar during the first half of 1996.
Part of the reason for that, he said, is political.
"The Clinton Administration has no incentive to allow the dollar to get any stronger," against the yen, he said. "If the dollar moves higher still, U.S. competitiveness will start to be compromised, and one sector that is particularly sensitive to that is organized labor."

HEADLINE: Mixed Results in December As Auto Sales Slip for Year

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Jan. 4

 BODY:
Auto makers ended 1995 with some surprisingly good and some surprisingly bad sales, capping a year that on the whole failed to live up to the industry's high expectations.
The General Motors Corporation and the Chrysler Corporation both beat analysts' projections for December with solid sales gains over December 1994. The Ford Motor Company, however, posted disappointing sales, especially of its restyled Taurus. 
 Over all, Big Three vehicle sales dropped two-tenths of 1 percent in December, while sales for the year slipped 1.7 percent, reflecting an economy characterized by wary consumers.
For the full year, auto makers sold 15.1 million cars and trucks, compared with 15.4 million in 1994.
Passenger car sales for the year totaled 8.64 million, down nearly 4 percent from 1994, according to company reports. Light-truck sales totaled 6.13 million, up 1.2 percent, according to the Autodata Corporation, a consulting firm based in Woodcliff Lake, N.J.
According to the companies, General Motors' market share, not including sales of Saab cars, fell half of 1 percent, to 32.2 percent, in 1995, while Ford's market share, not indluding sales of Jaguar cars, rose four-tenths of 1 percent, to 25.5 percent, and Chrysler's market share was flat at 14.3 percent.
Consumer demand appears to be in the same doldrums experienced by retailers, who at Christmas found shoppers worried about high credit card bills and job security. And just as department stores slashed prices at year-end sales, auto makers offered big cash rebates on some cars.
"The last week of December was a great week," said Georges Daaboul, sales manager at Bud Davis Cadillac in Memphis, where last month buyers could get $2,000 off the price of two luxury models.
G.M.'s sales rose 2.6 percent in December compared with December 1994. G.M.'s car sales rose 1.1 percent, to 215,989, while sales of trucks rose 7.4 percent, to 181,617. The company's sales for the year fell 3.4 percent from 1994.
"We did very well on cars, considering the market shifted away from luxury cars," said G. Richard Wagoner Jr., president of G.M.'s North American operations.
Ford shocked analysts with a 9.2 percent drop in United States sales in December and further evidence that the introduction of its new Taurus is struggling. Taurus sales fell 35 percent in December from sales of the old Taurus in December 1994. It was the third consecutive monthly decline in Taurus sales since the redesigned car was introduced in September. Sales fell 16 percent in October and 27 percent in November from corresponding months in 1994.
"If they want to keep it the No. 1- selling car in America, they are going to have to come up with more inventive pricing," said Michael Schmall, director of automotive forecasting for J. D. Power & Associates.
Ford's car sales plunged 19.3 percent, to 125,890 in December, compared with December 1994. Truck sales rose 1.9 percent, to 144,573. For the year, Ford sales were down one-tenth of 1 percent.
Chrysler surprised industry followers with a 9.8 percent jump in United States sales in December. Analysts had been expecting a 6 percent increase.
Chrysler's truck sales, which include mini-vans and sport utility vehicles, were up 20.9 percent in December, to 122,468, aided by a record month for the Dodge Ram. Car sales totaled 55,335, down 8.7 percent from December 1994. For the year, Chrysler sold 2.16 million vehicles, down 1.5 percent from 1994.
Japanese auto makers also posted mixed results in December.
General Motors shares fell 62.5 cents yesterday, to $51.25, while Ford fell 25 cents, to $29.625, and Chrysler fell 75 cents, to $55.

HEADLINE: Metro Digest

 BODY:

NEW YORK CITY
 
Maintenance Workers on Strike
More than 30,000 maintenance workers at 1,000 large New York City office buildings went on strike after negotiations broke down over management's demand that new workers start at a far lower salary than current building workers. But building managers insisted the strike would not affect daily operations at office buildings. [Page A1.]
 
Office workers seemed fairly oblivious to the strike, but some worried about the long-term effects of life without janitors. [B4.]
 
A Firefighter Mourned
About 8,000 to 9,000 firefighters, in their crisp dress blues, joined mourners at Our Lady of the Snow Roman Catholic Church in Blue Point, L.I., for the funeral of Lieut. John M. Clancy, who died on Sunday in Queens when the floor of a burning house collapsed and he plunged into the flames. It was an obligation many had performed several times recently; Lieutenant Clancy was the ninth firefighter in two years to die in the line of duty. [A1.]
 
Red Hook in Standoff Over Plan
Less than a year ago, Red Hook's ambitious plan to remake itself was hailed as a paradigm of late-20th-century urban renewal. But a year later, the community plan is at the center of an angry standoff. Some business leaders say the plan would stifle economic growth; others in the neighborhood have accused them of narrow self-interest. [B1.]
 
A Little Less Risk in Walking
Pedestrians may finally be getting some respect from the Giuliani administration and from the City Council. NYC by Clyde Haberman. [B1.]
 
Mayor Warns of Deep Cuts
Mayor Giuliani intensified his criticism of Governor Pataki's proposed budget, telling state legislators at a hearing in Albany that its deep cuts will create pain for New York City residents and fiscal problems for city government. [B3.]
 
Water Main Rupture Puzzling
The 60-inch water main that broke in Astoria, Queens, on Tuesday night, flooding a residential neighborhood, had been put into service only last summer, city officials said. Its rupture continued to mystify officials, who say the pipe was originally installed 7 1/2 years ago. [B3.]
 
Study Reviews Health Plans
A yearlong study of a dozen leading health-maintenance organizations in the New York City area found that the quality and generosity of their health plans vary widely and that company representatives frequently give out wrong information over the phone, the city's Public Advocate, Mark Green, announced. [B4.]
 
REGION
 
Hospital Faulted in Some Cases
State health investigators said that a cluster of deaths and serious injuries that occurred after surgery at Long Island Jewish Medical Center last spring did not reflect system-wide problems at the hospital, but they cited the hospital for delivering substandard care in some cases. [A1.]
 
Challengers Fight Way to Ballot
Two Republican presidential candidates -- Steve Forbes and Patrick J. Buchanan -- said that they had gathered enough signatures to enter the March primary in New York against the front-runner, Senator Bob Dole. But Mr. Dole's supporters vowed to try to force the challengers off the ballot. [B1.]
 
Child Abuse Laws Proposed
In a plan to revamp Connecticut's child-protection system, Gov. John G. Rowland proposed legislation that would make it easier to remove children from troubled homes and put them up for adoption. The measure also would ease confidentiality requirements that have hampered agencies from sharing information about cases. [B1.]
 
Aide Files Harassment Suit
A senior legislative assistant to Chuck Haytaian, the Speaker of New Jersey's Assembly and chairman of the State Republican Party, filed a lawsuit against him, accusing Mr. Haytaian of making repeated, unwelcome sexual advances in his State Capitol office. [B4.]
 
Bribery Conviction Overturned
A Federal appeals court has overturned the 1993 bribery conviction of Richard Foley Jr., a five-term member of Connecticut's House of Representatives and the former chairman of the state's Republican Party. A jury had found him guilty of accepting $25,000 in bribes to influence fellow lawmakers. [B5.]
 
Arbitration Bill Is Voted Down
Despite an intensive, last-minute lobbying effort, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman failed to persuade the State Assembly to approve a bill she said would save cities and towns money by reining in salaries for police officers and firefighters. The measure, fiercely opposed by the state's powerful police and firefighter unions, would have given arbitrators more power in settling pay disputes. [B5.]

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

A Recessionary Feeling To Stores' Christmas
Retailers reported their worst December sales since the 1990-91 recession period. While they gave all sorts of reasons, the weakness suggested that the economy was likely to grow slowly in the months ahead.
The tidings were grim for specialty stores. Analysts said that the country may have more stores than its shoppers need and that many could well have to close. [Page A1.]
 
Hopes for Federal Workers
House Republican leaders abandoned the idea of using closed Federal offices as a lever to force President Clinton to agree to a seven-year balanced budget. But they were apparently unable to persuade their rank and file, who revolted at an evening caucus. Speaker Newt Gingrich canceled a scheduled news conference. [A1.]
 
Dollar Strengthens Against Yen
The dollar continued to rally against the yen, briefly rising to levels last seen 21 months ago. Later the dollar fell back in a move related to the budget talks. But some traders said the dollar could rise for some time yet. [D2.]
 
Adobe Shares Plunge
Adobe Systems reported a fourth-quarter loss and operating income well below expectations. Its stock tumbled $13.50, to $45. [D4.]
 
Stocks Fall; Technology Weak
The stock market was on a seesaw, influenced by budget talks in Washington. At one point when both sides called off talks, the Dow industrials tumbled 50 points, before ending down 20.23 points, at 5,173.84. Big Board volume was the fourth highest on record. Nasdaq stocks fell 16.44 points, to 1,029.82, as technology issues fell on profit warnings. [D6.]
 
Prices of Treasury securities plunged. The 30-year bond fell 1 5/32 of a point, to 111 22/32 ; its yield rose to 6.02 percent from 5.95 percent on Wednesday. [D16.]
 
Strong Results on Wall St.
Morgan Stanley and Lehman Brothers reported strong quarterly earnings, benefiting particularly from their healthy investment banking businesses. The results augur well for other Wall Street houses. [D16.]
 
Surprising Auto Sales
Detroit's auto makers ended 1995 with surprisingly strong sales. General Motors and Chrysler surpassed analysts' projections, but Ford had disappointing sales, especially of its restyled Taurus. [D4.]
 
General Motors said it would start to make electric cars this fall, even though analysts doubted that many would be sold. [A10.]
 
Higher Charges for Fast Phone Line
Two big phone companies in the West are asking for rate increases that would more than double the price of consumer-oriented digital telephone services, known as I.S.D.N. [D2.]
 
London Exchange Chief Ousted
The London Stock Exchange dismissed its chief executive after months of feuding with big securities firms over his plans to introduce a new form of share trading. [D5.]
 
AT&T Detours to the Web
AT&T is phasing out its Interchange on-line service a year after buying it for more than $50 million. Instead, the company will move its operations to the World Wide Web. [D6.]
 
Tobacco Class-Action Suit Approved
Flight attendants can mount a national class-action suit against tobacco companies, a Florida appeals court ruled. [A10.]
 
Masco Deal Falls Through
Masco's $1.1 billion sale of its home furnishings unit to Morgan Stanley fell through. Masco would not say whether Morgan Stanley found something that made it uncomfortable about the deal or the price. But it was apparently not a problem with the unit's financial performance. [D17.]
 
Disney Merger Advances
Shareholders of Walt Disney and Capital Cities/ABC approved their $19 billion merger. It is still subject to regulatory approval. [D5.]

HEADLINE: BATTLE OVER THE BUDGET: THE OVERVIEW;
LEADERS IN HOUSE DROP G.O.P. PLAN ON U.S. WORKERS

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 4

 BODY:
Weary of taking the blame for the continuing Government shutdown, House Republican leaders today abandoned their strategy of using closed Government offices as a lever to force President Clinton to agree to a seven-year balanced budget, but their rank and file revolted.
The proposal to put all Government workers back on the job, with pay until at least March 15, met a sometimes hostile reception in a Republican caucus tonight. When it ended, Speaker Newt Gingrich canceled a scheduled news conference to avoid speaking to reporters. 
 He and other leaders had worked hard all day to sell their plan to their often obstreperous freshmen, but apparently failed. After a meeting with Mr. Gingrich this afternoon, Representative David M. McIntosh of Indiana said flatly, "We will not reopen the Government." And tonight a second-term ally of his, Representative Ernest Jim Istook Jr. of Oklahoma, said, "They floated an idea, and it did not float well."
After tonight's meeting ended, Representative John A. Boehner of Ohio, chairman of the party caucus, told reporters: "There is no resolution. There are lots of proposals on the table. But, frankly, what we have decided is to take a couple of more days" to figure out what to do next.
The White House immediately took political advantage. Michael D. McCurry, the President's spokesman, said in a statement, "The repudiation of the House Republican leadership is most troubling to the President." He said, "A willful, extreme minority in the House Republican caucus is apparently holding common sense and the American people hostage."
The Republicans' desire for consensus has been required for the last year by their relatively narrow majority, and Mr. Gingrich has consistently pledged to the rank and file that he would not advance policies over the objections of any sizable group of Republicans.
The Republican leaders' view was that the partial Government shutdown had distracted attention from their prime issue, the balanced budget. "Somewhere along the way, we have gotten off message," Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the majority leader, said tonight.
The leaders said they hoped that if steps could be taken to get the Government reopened and workers paid, they could send their members home for two weeks and begin a Republican election campaign at all levels, stressing the necessity of balancing the budget. They would not abandon negotiations with President Clinton, whom many junior members denounced tonight as untrustworthy. But they were not expecting them to succeed.
Many Government offices are shut because Congress has not passed -- or the President has vetoed -- legislation to pay for its operation this year. Until now, House Republicans have refused to consider stopgap legislation to keep things running, fearing that retreat would let President Clinton off the hook on the balanced budget issue. But polls show that the American people blame Republicans more than the President for the impasse.
White House officials said tonight that the Administration was likely to go along with the Republican plan to get workers back on the job.
Earlier, the Republicans had put off today's scheduled negotiations with President Clinton at the White House. But they said they wanted to meet on Friday. Tonight Senator Dole told the Senate, "By early next week, we should have an agreement." After a pause, he continued, "or disagreement."
Many Republicans were deeply pessimistic. Senator Thad Cochran of Mississippi told the Senate, "It is becoming more obvious every day that the White House is not prepared to reach an agreement with the Congress to balance the budget." Representative John R. Kasich of Ohio, chairman of the House Budget Committee, said, "I have seen no visible signs of progress."
Behind closed doors, Mr. Gingrich and Representative Dick Armey of Texas, the majority leader, spoke even more sharply. One freshman at their meeting said, "Speaker Gingrich said he does not believe President Clinton is serious about balancing the budget." He said the Speaker told them Mr. Dole had agreed.
The plan the leaders were shopping to their followers had these elements: One bill would put the 280,000 furloughed Federal workers and the 480,000 working without pay back on the job, and pay them until March 15. But one Republican leader said they would come back on very stringent terms, with "no grants, no travel money, no toilet paper." Just how much of their regular jobs they would be able to do under those conditions was not clear.
The second element would be a bill to provide money for the rest of the fiscal year, a variety of grants for high-profile Government services now threatened -- from state unemployment offices to food for the elderly. "No member can afford to defend a shutdown of Meals on Wheels," one Republican strategist said.
Other programs likely to be covered by that bill would include child welfare programs, welfare for American Indians, railroad retirement payments, visitor services at the national parks, passport and visa services, veterans compensation, pension and education programs, and some functions of the government of the District of Columbia. The bill would also finance, but only until March 15, Aid to Families with Dependent Children and foster care and adoption assistance to states.
Finally, Republicans would seek to wrap all the appropriations bills still to be enacted into a single omnibus measure. Republican leaders said the bills would be adjusted to meet some of the objections in President Clinton's veto messages, but certainly not all of them.
That bill would end some Government programs Republicans have opposed, one highly placed Republican said, carrying the message to Federal workers: "Come March 15, some of you had better make plans, because you're not coming back, even if there is an agreement. Some of the Government is gone."
Democrats are unlikely to oppose either the return-to-work bill or the high-profile grants. Senator Thomas A. Daschle of South Dakota, the minority leader, said, "Anything is better than nothing, so we might as well take what we can."
The Republican leadership plan acknowledged that the current approach was not working politically, a view being pressed on them increasingly by restive moderates led by Representative Marge Roukema, an eight-term New Jersey Republican who said, "It's beginning to look like we can't run the Government."
But the issue was still embattled. Representative Steve Largent of Oklahoma, another leader of the 73 freshmen, said, "The only leverage we have left against the White House is the temporary shutdown." He added, "If we put these workers back to work, there never will be a balanced budget."
When the talks halted on Wednesday, Mr. Clinton and Republican leaders had been discussing a possible compromise on Republican tax cut proposals.
Public opinion polls have consistently shown more Americans blaming Republicans than Democrats for the budget impasse. A CBS News survey released today found that 44 percent of the public blamed Republicans more, while 33 percent blamed President Clinton more.

HEADLINE: Retailers Call Sales in December Worst Since '90-'91 Recession

BYLINE: By JENNIFER STEINHAUER 

 BODY:
In the culmination of a dismal year for retailers that may well lead to a further industry shakeout in the next few months, the nation's merchants reported the worst December sales figures yesterday since the 1990-91 recession.
Retailers cited all sorts of reasons for poor sales, half-empty stores and indifferent shoppers, and the overall weakness among consumers suggested that the economy was likely to grow at best only slowly in the months ahead. 
 The special circumstances ranged from women's fashions that failed to catch fire to warm weather in November that hurt sales of heavy clothing to snowstorms in December that kept many shoppers at home. And consumers, after piling up mountains of debt, started to retrench, resisting practically everything not on sale at deep discounts.
Apart from the recession at the beginning of the decade, it was the worst December for retailers in recent memory. And with the economy still growing, it made for grim tidings for many retailers, particularly those selling specialty goods, who must now face the fact that America may simply have many more stores than buyers need.
"The number of stores has expanded faster than consumer demand," said Carl Steidtmann, an economist at Management Horizons in Columbus, Ohio, a unit of the accounting firm Price Waterhouse.
According to the Goldman, Sachs same-store sales index, which compares stores open at least a year, retail sales were up only 2 percent in December, compared with the same month a year earlier. Sales were up 5.4 percent in December 1994 and 5.7 percent for December 1993. The only worse year since the investment firm began compiling figures in the late 1980's was 1990, when same-store sales eked out a gain of nine-tenths of a percent.
Same-store sales, generally considered to be the best example of a retailer's condition, were weak in almost all sectors. J. C. Penney reported that same-store sales fell 4.2 percent, and Dayton Hudson, which owns the Target chain of discount stores as well as other more upscale chains, rose just 3 percent. Among off-price and discount merchants, Filene's Basement was down 3 percent, Kmart was up 5.5 percent with heavy discounting, and even the once-invincible Wal-Mart Stores -- the nation's largest retailer -- barely squeaked in a gain of 1.1 percent at its stores. Among consumer electronics chains, which were the hottest sector the last two to three holiday seasons, Tandy same-store sales rose just 2 percent and Best Buy gained 3 percent.
"This all reflects factors that are not going away," said Jeffrey M. Feiner, vice president of retail research at Salomon Brothers.
The consequence, analysts said, is almost certainly a new round of store closings. Those most unlikely to survive to 1997, they said, include some regional discounters and a number of apparel merchants.
"Christmas is just an expansion of what has been going on all year," Richard N. Baum, an analyst at Goldman, Sachs, said. With many retailers now expected to post sharply lower profits or outright losses, those unable to generate enough cash in the months ahead, he said, "will be subject to consolidations or face the specter of bankruptcy."
A few winners emerged from the general carnage. Sears, Roebuck & Company surprised even the most bullish analysts with a rise of 6.8 percent among stores open at least a year and Pier 1 Imports chalked up one of the few double-digit increases with a 16.1 percent gain. Gap Inc. sailed in with a rise of 6 percent.
"The Gap was successful because they focused right on fashion," said Barry Bryant, the senior director of equity research at Rodman & Renshaw. "At Sears, they had an ad campaign that everyone seemed to be singing to themselves, the quality was there and the fashion worked."
In contrast to retailers catering to the middle class, luxury merchants danced through the season, showing strong sales from early November all the way through the last weekend. Tiffany & Company, for instance, reported a same-store gain of 13 percent. At Sak's Fifth Avenue, sales of jewelry and cosmetics soared.
By the end of the season last weekend, the most successful stores looked like apartments that had played host to good parties: everything was a bit of a wreck and the shelves were picked clean. At Barneys New York, for example, women were knuckle to knuckle rummaging through the remains on a decimated rack of pants.
With few exceptions, those who sold Christmas gifts did so at their own expense this season, and profit margins suffered. Retailers marked down prices on sweater sets, televisions, dolls and skates almost before people had finished cleaning up their Thanksgiving turkey. The discounting continued into the new year.
There are many in the industry who argue that Christmas is no longer the spur to shoppers it once was.
"You've got a lot of retailers selling the same goods to consumers," Mr. Steidtmann, the economist, said. "And the only way they have to distinguish themselves is through price. This was a very promotional Christmas where the balance of power was with the consumer."
Indeed, those merchants with a specific focus or clever merchandising were the only ones to register good numbers. The Sunglass Hut, for instance, increased same-store sales by 10.3 percent. West Marine, a San Francisco seller of boat accessories and apparel, reported a rise in same-store sales of 8.8 percent.
Those who deal in goods enjoyed by the wealthiest and largest demographic group also had happy holidays. Middle-aged baby boomers, who now seem to have all the clothing they need, have become obsessed with making their homes cute. Pier 1 and Bed Bath and Beyond took advantage of that trend. "Pier 1 had higher-margin merchandise and was not very promotional," said Walter Loeb, a retail consultant. "The customer was interested in home merchandise."

HEADLINE: Egyptians Get a New Premier And Hopes for the Economy

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS JEHL 

DATELINE: CAIRO, Jan. 4

 BODY:
A new Prime Minister and Cabinet were sworn in today in a shuffle that has raised hopes that Egypt will speed efforts to revitalize its stagnant economy.
The new Prime Minister, Kamal al-Ganzoury, is an American-educated economist who is regarded as somewhat more likely to embrace a free market than his predecessor, Atef Sedki, who held the office for nine years. 
 With public discontent still high after parliamentary elections that were marred by violence and accusations of fraud, President Hosni Mubarak's principal goal in installing Mr. Ganzoury may have been to demonstrate that he and his governing party were not averse to change, diplomats and experts said.
As Egypt begins to grapple with the certainty that the $2.3 billion it receives each year in American economic assistance will be reduced, Mr. Ganzoury and his team are also being seen as the force that could help make the country more attractive to foreign investors.
After 16 years in power, Mr. Mubarak himself said earlier this week that he had ordered the shakeup in an attempt "to change blood and put more energy" at his Government's top ranks. And today, Mr. Ganzoury struck a progressive tone after taking the oath of office, telling reporters that his goal would be to "open the door to foreign investment."
Until now, Egypt has been slow to dismantle its enormous state-run corporations and a monolithic civil service. With a high poverty rate already helping to build support for Islamic militants, the diplomats and experts cautioned that the fear of adding to social discontent means that rapid change remains unlikely.
At a time when the United States and international financial organizations are pressing Egypt to privatize companies and encourage foreign investment, a senior Western diplomat said he regarded the shakeup as "a sign that President Mubarak is really committed to stepping up the pace of economic reform."
Under Mr. Mubarak, the authority of Egypt's prime minister has been limited mostly to economic matters, and it was only in that sphere that the new Cabinet reflects major changes. The Government's three most powerful ministers -- for foreign affairs, defense and the interior -- remained in their posts.
Along with fresh faces at the ministries of finance and planning, the new Cabinet includes a new Economy Minister, Nawal al-Tatawi, the first woman to hold the job. She is an American-educated banker with experience at the United Nations and the World Bank.
Because Mr. Ganzoury, who is 62 years old, has been Deputy Prime Minister since 1987, some analysts dismissed the prospect that he would bring anything new to the Cabinet table.
"Both the new Prime Minister and the old one are the same," said Abdel Monem Saeed, deputy director of the Al Ahram Institute for Strategic Studies here. "Both are cautious. Both are firm believers in gradual change. They fear adventures and drastic measures."
But as Egypt prepares to resume discussions later this month with the International Monetary Fund, most analysts here said they expected that Mr. Ganzoury would at least bring new energy to the quest for an economic overhaul plan that could win the organization's approval.
Such an agreement would clear the way for Egypt's creditors to waive a final tranche of debts worth $4 billion. But Egypt and the I.M.F. must first resolve longstanding differences over the country's reluctance to move more swiftly toward economic reforms.
Egypt announced last month that the annual rate of inflation here had dropped to 4.9 percent, a 32-year low. But while the population is growing at a rapid rate, economic growth is still hovering around zero.
American officials here have been blunt in warning that improvement will not come until Egypt can persuade foreign investors that it is truly committed to the free market. Vice President Al Gore is expected to pay a visit here later this month.

HEADLINE: As Russian Vote Nears, U.S. Fears for Fate of Reform

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 4

 BODY:
Senior Administration officials, once invariably chipper about President Boris N. Yeltsin, are taking a markedly more shaded and wary tone about him these days.
After the strong Communist showing in Russia's parliamentary elections last month and Mr. Yeltsin's second episode of heart disease, American officials are expressing considerable concern about the presidential election scheduled for June and the chance that pro-reform candidates will fail to unite behind a single candidate. 
The Bush Administration was criticized for sticking with Mikhail S. Gorbachev too long as the last Soviet President. Officials in the Clinton Administration do not want to make the same mistake with Mr. Yeltsin, who has been politically weakened by more than four years of social upheaval and an unpopular simmering war in Chechnya.
At the same time, they do not want to further damage, undermine or offend Mr. Yeltsin, who may yet turn out to be the strongest pro-reform presidential candidate, and who just returned to work after two months' convalescence.
The presidency dominates Russian political life, and the victory of a Communist or ultranationalist in June would send Russia on a very different path and deeply discomfit President Clinton in an election year. American officials are particularly worried that the squabbles of Russia's pro-reform politicians will undermine their chances.
Mr. Yeltsin perceives his historical role as an anti-Communist. In December, however, capitalizing on a residual national organization and voter unhappiness with the pain of social change, the Communists won 22.3 percent of the party vote and nearly 35 percent of the seats at stake in the lower house of Parliament.
That result is likely to push Mr. Yeltsin to run again, officials say, despite his frailties and the opposition of his wife, Naina. Mr. Yeltsin says he will announce his plans in February.
While American officials say they do not doubt Mr. Yeltsin's commitment to democracy and economic reform, they see him as politically damaged and physically weakened, and no longer as a figure that all reformers can easily support.
The question is whether Mr. Yeltsin runs or not, and then if he does, whether he remains healthy and has a chance of winning, the officials say. They fear that if Mr. Yeltsin does seek re-election, he will keep Prime Minister Viktor S. Chernomyrdin from running, and then perform badly or suffer another heart attack, while younger pro-reform candidates like Grigory A. Yavlinsky do not back him, splitting the vote.
If no candidate wins over 50 percent of the vote in the first round (as Mr. Yeltsin did in 1991), there is a run-off between the two top finishers.
"The real worry is that Yeltsin doesn't make the run-off and stops other liberals from making it," a senior official said. "The nightmare scenario is a run-off between two openly anti-reform candidates."
Secretary of State Warren Christopher, speaking at a year-end news conference, said the elections, with their high turnout of some 65 percent, showed that "democracy has taken strong root" in Russia, but also revealed the stresses of change.
The United States intended "to continue to support economic and political reforms and reformers," Mr. Christopher said. But then in pointed remarks that made some of his aides uneasy, he urged Russia's pro-reform politicians to "put to one side their differences and come together to find a strong candidate" for the presidential election in June.
The Americans are doing a lot of thinking about Mr. Yavlinsky, 43. He was the only liberal whose party, Yabloko, received more than 5 percent of the popular vote. But Yabloko received only 6.9 percent, and Mr. Yavlinsky, who is young, brash and whose mother is Jewish in a country with a history of anti-Semitism, may be too thin a reed on which to build a pro-reform coalition.
Some American officials wondered whether Mr. Yavlinsky might in the end support a Yeltsin candidacy, by itself an indication of their quiet distress. Mr. Yavlinsky has made it as clear as he can that he wants to supplant Mr. Yeltsin.
American officials are relatively sanguine about how the new legislature, elected for four years, will behave over the next six months, however, when all parties want to appear "presidential." The officials point out that the bloc of Communists and nationalists is no larger than in the last Duma, the lower house of Parliament, though the Communists will be more cohesive than the ultranationalists.
Members elected as independents make up the second-largest bloc, followed by Mr. Chernomyrdin's party, Our Home Is Russia, and American officials expect both groups to join with Mr. Yavlinsky's 45 members and the 15 or 20 other liberals on crucial votes.
"No one in Washington is going to try to tell Yeltsin what to do," one senior official said. "He and Chernomyrdin are far better judges of Russia's political reality than any outsider. But we must be clear about what we stand for in a positive way. It's up to the Russian people and polity to decide whether to participate in what's on offer in the outside world, or to follow a path that will only isolate them."

HEADLINE: BATTLE OVER THE BUDGET: THE WORKERS;
Added Bite For Many On the Job

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 4

 BODY:
Phil Glover was beside himself in anger and frustration.
Unlike 280,000 Federal Government employees denied work and pay by the budget impasse, Mr. Glover is among 480,000 employees deemed essential -- and is thus working without pay. He is a prison guard in Loretto, Pa., helping supervise as many as 900 inmates. 
 "This is crazy," Mr. Glover said today, fulminating over the slow pace of negotiations between Congress and the White House that has kept Government offices closed a 20th day and put thousands of Government workers in financial peril.
"Why should we have urine and feces thrown at us for no pay," he asked. "It's ridiculous what's going on. I'll tell you what, we have maybe 50 Republicans and 50 Democrats in our union, but it's starting to get to where it doesn't matter what you are. We're ticked off. It's as simple as that."
For most Government employees, working or not, the financial crunch has begun in earnest. Their last paycheck, on Tuesday, covered the two-week period in which the shutdown began, included half the usual pay but the full two weeks of deductions. Dr. Lawrence Flesh, chief executive of the Stratton Veterans Administration Medical Center in Albany, N.Y., said that one employee had received a check for $9 and that the hospital had recently set up a food bank for workers running out of money.
With bills due for mortgage, rent, gas, electricity and school tuition, thousands of Government workers around the country have begun asking creditors for more time and lending institutions for loans. Unions like the American Federation of Government Employees and the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees have set up loan programs as well as telephone hot lines to answer questions about the impasse and advise members how to solve financial problems.
But the angst of financial insecurity is slightly different among the so-called excepted workers compared with those on furlough, who are concerned about whether to believe budget negotiators when they say all Government employees will be paid retroactively once an agreement is reached.
While excepted workers have the same worry, many are also stirred by a clash between their moral obligation to work and outrage over a situation in which some people are forced to work and others are forced to stay home -- with the promise that all of them will be paid.
'It's unfair," said Aleta Hicks, a secretary at the Justice Department and a single mother. "To me, it's a higher class of slavery. They are not physically preventing me from going home. But if I choose to, I risk repercussions later on, a reprimand, a warning, even loss of my job. I don't want to go through that. That's only more stress."
Ms. Hicks, a mother of a 2-year-old daughter who makes about $25,000 a year, said her landlord had agreed to accept half the rent for January.
"But that was my whole check," she said of the amount she received this week. "I have nothing left over for phone, utilities and food. I have to rely on family and friends, but they're going through the same situation. I know the landlord said he'd be lenient this time. But if this thing goes on any further, my next check will be zero, and what's he going to do the next time?"
Among all Federal agencies, the Justice Department has the highest percentage of its employees working, more than 87 percent of 98,000 people. For some, like Eileen Sheehan, an Assistant United States Attorney for the District of Columbia, her anger over "ego-driven" budget negotiators is tempered by civic pride.
"I'm one of the more idealistic people here," she said. "For me, it's less the finances than the moral obligation. I prosecute some of the most violent people in society. Just because Congress cannot reach consensus on how to proceed with a budget doesn't mean that that I don't show up and we let the bad guys out of jail.
"We all feel helpless and unappreciated, like children caught in a bad divorce. But I've dedicated my life to public service, and I feel very strongly about that."
But Ms. Sheehan said her fortitude was bolstered to some degree by savings, the $845 she receives in rent from two roommates and knowledge that it would take a bank quite some time, presumably longer than the life of the current budget impasse, to foreclose on her house if she missed a mortgage payment or two.
"To me," she said, "the mortgage industry cannot take adverse actions on 150,000 people who can't make mortgage payments. You're not going to have that many foreclosures. But this could do damage to my credit rating."
Other Government workers on the job were far less sanguine about the impact of the impasse. Mr. Glover said his family cut back on Christmas dinner and declined to visit relatives to save money on gas. He also said he and his wife had begun snapping at each other.
Ms. Hicks said she did not know whether to buy a half-dozen eggs for now or a buy a dozen to save some for the future.
William Thompson, who processes tax bills, said he did not expect his financial crunch to hit for another week. But he said he had found that his creditors beyond the Washington Beltway were far less sympathetic to those living here.
"The electric company, the gas company, they're very understanding," he said. "My mortgage holder is in Indiana. They're less sensitive to what's happening in Washington."

HEADLINE: TV WEEKEND;
Off Information Highway, A Busy Red-Light District

BYLINE: By WALTER GOODMAN 

 BODY:
You can hit the hot spots on the information superhighway tomorrow night, when "Wired for Sex" provides a peek at how some of the oldest human urges are being serviced -- well, virtually serviced -- by the latest in electronic stimulators.
There are relatively conventional innovations like classified ads for seekers of romance, be they couples who conduct keyboard courtships in hopes of developing more tangible connections, prostitutes exhibiting their wares or folks seeking congenial company in a bondage-and-discipline data bank. A police officer tells of tracking down people who use computer games to inveigle youngsters into other sorts of games. 
 The anonymity of Internet communication seems to be aphrodisiac. A man named Steve tells of achieving arousal in his own little room by pretending to be a woman named Rose and engaging in computer communications with (presumably) another man somewhere out there, who seems to have been similarly excited. Bill Kurtis, the evening's guide, calls it "making out in cyberspace."
The highlights, or lowlights, of the hour are glimpses of soft-core software, not much different from what in primitive times were called dirty pictures. For $100 a year, one businessman says, his customers "get to see something they don't see every day." A wag describes S & M enthusiasts, seen here doing a little lethargic flogging for the camera, as the "digitally humiliated." More advanced and expensive interactive games give players the power to order fleshy and amenable young women on the screen to remove this or that article, assume this or that position and do this or that. One CD-ROM peddler announces, "Computers and sex are a perfect marriage."
Efforts are being made to contain the high-tech pornucopia, but as Mr. Kurtis observes, the stuff flows easily across national borders, and in the United States its merchants enjoy some First Amendment protections. This picture of the great new information superhighway, celebrated as carrying us into vast vistas of knowledge, being reduced to a red-light district may not be heartening. But virtual fantasy has a bright side: it's absolutely safe sex.

Dateline
 Drug Trials
 NBC, tonight at 9
 (Channel 4 in New York)
Tonight's edition of "Dateline" follows three people who were selected in 1993 to participate in an experimental treatment for AIDS. It's an affecting report, though similar to many others that keep making the point that AIDS patients -- like the two men and the woman chosen tonight -- do not belong to a different species. (See "Positive: Life With H.I.V.," on Channel 13, Sunday at 10:30 P.M.)
The new treatment, a drug combination known as Drug 241, evidently increases the number of the body's T cells, which help the immune system resist infection. The "Dateline" report records the ups and downs of both T cells and emotions during the lengthy tests at New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center. The drug still raises hopes, but "Drug Trials" is careful not to raise them too high.

A Citizens' State of the Union
 PBS, tonight at 9
 (Channel 13 in New York)
This earnest 90-minute program is the first in a five-part series, "Citizens '96," devoted to the concerns of Americans in this election year. Tonight, people in Idaho, Texas, North Carolina, California and Washington State talk, unsurprisingly, about urban violence, low-paying jobs and economic insecurity.
Next month, on the eve of the Iowa caucuses, a town meeting in Des Moines attended by Presidential candidates will be carried live. Later in February, New Hampshirites will take over the screen, heralding their state's primary.

HEADLINE: Inside Art

BYLINE: By Carol Vogel 

 BODY:

Old Masters for Sale
Next week, Sotheby's and Christie's will hold the biggest Old Masters painting sales either auction house has seen in five years. Simultaneously, many Manhattan dealers in Old Masters are mounting special exhibitions timed to the New York sales. 
 From the look of things, it seems business is booming. Among the painting fields, Old Masters provide one of the steadier markets; the work is less vulnerable to the ups and downs of, say, contemporary art, where trends and fashions, not to mention the economy, dictate whether prices rise or fall.
"While the market has risen somewhat over the past year," said Nicholas Hall, president of the Colnaghi gallery in New York, "it is still not at a temperature which would account for the quantity of works coming on the market. It defies a simple explanation."
In the hopes of snagging collectors who come to New York for the auctions, dealers like Mr. Hall have planned impressive exhibitions. While Colnaghi is mounting a tightly focused show, "The French Portrait: 1550-1850," most galleries are showing selections of their recent acquisitions. Jack Kilgore's gallery on East 71st Street, for example, is to exhibit works that he acquired with Emmanuel Moatti, a Paris dealer. "Auctions have a sense of immediacy, and so we have to create our own sense of immediacy and excitement in the form of exhibitions in order to compete," Mr. Kilgore said.
While dealers still assert that galleries are the best place to sell art, there's an interesting contradiction at work. Galleries are not the only place dealers are offering their paintings this season. Some of the finest works for sale at Sotheby's and Christie's next week are being sold by dealers, which might suggest that dealers believe the auction room is a better venue than their own galleries.
On the cover of Sotheby's catalogue is Joachim Wtewael's "Adoration of the Shepherds" (1600-1605), which is being sold by the dealer Richard Feigen. The Mannerist painting has hung in his bedroom since he bought it from Benedict Nicolson, the London art historian, in 1974. Sotheby's has put a hefty $2.4 million to $2.8 million estimate on the painting. Christie's is also selling an important painting from a New York dealer: Il Bacchiacca's "Lady With a Cat" (1525-1530), which is owned by Martin Zimet of French & Company and carries an estimate of $400,000 to $600,000. Mr. Feigen declined to say why he chose to sell a painting from his private collection at auction. Mr. Zimet said only that his painting no longer fitted in with the Dutch, Spanish and French paintings he sells at French & Company.
Dealers and collectors agree that New York is the place to sell paintings, rather than London, long the traditional center of the Old Masters market, because the United States is now where the money is. But the number of works up for sale next week is so large that many question whether the market can absorb them.
"It's hard to tell," said Ian Kennedy, the president of the Simon Dickinson New York gallery. "I see this as a good opportunity to find some things at reasonable prices."
 
 
 
One Popular Catalogue
 Have you called Sotheby's main number in Manhattan lately?
A recording comes on: "Thank you for calling Sotheby's. If you are calling to order a catalogue for the estate of Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis, please press 1 now. For all other inquiries, please press 2 now."
When the auction house announced last month that it would sell Mrs. Onassis's personal property this spring in Manhattan, Sotheby's officials said that no fancy marketing or special advertising would be used. They also said that none of the thousands of objects would travel to Europe or Asia, which is how Sotheby's and Christie's normally trumpet their plum offerings. (To some, Sotheby's restraint seemed admirable; but one wonders how many Europeans or Asians would in fact be interested in owning John F. Kennedy Jr.'s high chair or President John F. Kennedy's golf clubs.)
Sotheby's hired Trase-Miller Teleservices, a Chicago-based company that handled ticket sales for the super-successful Monet retrospective last year at the Art Institute of Chicago. And this explains the recording.
Calls to Sotheby's main number have been routed to Trase-Miller because the auction house's switchboard was inundated by people wanting the catalogue. Calls about the Onassis sale are handled by Trase-Miller; others automatically bounce back to New York.
Several hundred catalogues have been ordered by phone every day since the sale was announced on Dec. 15. So far, 3,950 have been sold. The price is $45 for the soft-cover version or $90 for the hardback. But that's just the beginning. A toll-free number for catalogue orders (800-601-6155) has been set up. Sotheby's plans to advertise the number in several newspapers around the country next week.
The all-color catalogue has 700 illustrations, including many pictures of Mrs. Onassis's Fifth Avenue apartment, and is itself considered a collector's item. But buying one is also the only way anyone can hope to view the contents of the sale in person. Admission to the four-day viewing, which begins April 19, will be by ticket only. Sotheby's estimates it can handle 30,000 people, to be drawn by computer from among those who buy the catalogue.
Proceeds from the catalogue's sales are to go to the John F. Kennedy Library Foundation in Boston.
 
 
 
More Mondrian
 People worried about missing the Museum of Modern Art's popular Mondrian retrospective, originally scheduled to close on Jan. 23, have been granted a reprieve. The show has been extended a week, through Jan. 30.
If the Modern had its way, the show would run even longer. But some of the Mondrians will be moving uptown for "Abstraction in the 20th Century: Total Risk, Freedom, Discipline" which is to open at the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum on Feb. 9.

HEADLINE: Standoff Over Red Hook Renewal;
Businesses Fear a Plan to Remake a Neighborhood

BYLINE: By JOE SEXTON 

 BODY:
Less than a year ago, Red Hook's ambitious plan to remake itself was hailed as a paradigm of late-20th-century urban renewal. City officials, residents and politicians spoke enthusiastically of the plan's scope and realism, its lack of ideology and its abundance of consensus.
The plan was a blueprint laid out by and for the people of that troubled section of Brooklyn. It envisioned hundreds of units of new housing, a new 500-student high school and a revitalized waterfront, an enterprise with the potential for returning Red Hook to the working-class maritime village it had been decades ago. 
 "The process behind the plan and the product itself should be a model for how neighborhoods plan for themselves in the future," Joseph Rose, chairman of the City Planning Commission, said of the plan last January.
But a year later, what had been widely trumpeted as the most sophisticated and practical effort at city planning since the 1989 revision of the City Charter gave community boards the authority to map their own futures is at the center of an angry standoff. Some of Red Hook's business leaders say the plan would stifle economic growth; others in the neighborhood have accused them of narrow self-interest. The plan has not even been approved by the Planning Commission.
As a result, the Red Hook plan might well have become an example of something else: just how hard it is to get anything done in the city, regardless of the quality of intentions or inspiration.
Mr. Rose said: "What this experience has demonstrated is what we have always known: planning is not easy. It's a process that can be controversial. There can be the kind of personal antagonisms we in the public sector experience all the time. The process requires patience. People across the city would do well to learn from this example."
Some representatives of businesses in Red Hook have asserted that they were excluded from the process and that the plan endangers the neighborhood's economic future. Other people have charged that avarice caused the opponents to retreat from their initial support. Residents of the public housing projects that dominate much of Red Hook have asserted that the Planning Commission does not want to see grass-roots urban renewal succeed.
"I think everyone assumed realistically that there would be problems implementing all of the aspects of the plan," said Edward Bautista, a lawyer who has advised the residents of the Red Hook Houses. "But never in my wildest imagination did I think the process itself would become so fragile."
The echoes of those words reverberate grimly for many in Red Hook, people with resignation and cynicism soaked into their consciousness by years of economic neglect, environmental abuse and epic failures at urban renewal.
"The hopes of the entire community were manifest in that plan," said John McGettrick, chairman of the Red Hook Civic Association, who remains adamant that the plan go forward.
The crux of the dispute is whether the 88-page proposal, full of charts and graphs, adequately reflects the concerns of industry.
Bette Stolz, the head of the South Brooklyn Local Development Corporation, has said that business people were repeatedly rebuffed in their attempts to help create the plan. Ms. Stolz, who made her complaints at a Planning Commission hearing last July, said business representatives were not allowed on the committee that devised the plan, and that their lack of influence is reflected in what she regards as dangerous aspects of the plan.
She said the plan's proposal to rezone parts of Red Hook from manufacturing to mixed-use zones for both residential and commercial use threatens to limit, and even drive out, industry. Ms. Stolz said Red Hook had gained 70 new businesses since 1993, to a total of 280. Greg O'Connell, a developer who has turned old Red Hook piers into vibrant locales for light manufacturing, has said the plan is "badly slanted" toward residents' concerns and is a "kick in the teeth" to business.
The supporters of the plan portray the detractors as "a tiny minority," who have reneged on their previous support in retaliation for the decision by Community Board 6 to delay acting on a proposal for a Business Improvement District in Red Hook.
To the proponents, the opposition is a power play by Mr. O'Connell, who they said profited enormously from the neighborhood's support of his early projects. They say there are signatures of 100 Red Hook business people who support the renewal project, known as a 197-A plan. They note that the committee that drafted the plan has already agreed to reconsider the siting of the proposed Education Plaza, the complex that would include a 500-student school for grades 7 to 12 as well as centers for teen-agers and job-training. And the committee agreed not to take any private property.
"People rightly feel shocked and betrayed," said Bruce Mesh, a member of the committee that produced the plan. "We worked on it for three years, held public meetings, welcomed all who wanted to participate. These same people offered letters of support. That a limited number of people could block this begs the question of what a 197-A plan is. The success of this plan is not only vital for Red Hook, but for the rest of the city."
That new legislation was drawn to let the residents of individual neighborhoods draw up their own ideas of how their communities could be revitalized. Red Hook took the proposition seriously.
Using the ideas of day-care workers and statisticians, public housing leaders and academics in civic engineering, the planners put together a package of designs that increase Red Hook's population (it had fallen to 11,000 in 1990 from 21,000 in 1950), and beautify the neighborhood of vast waterfront and physical charms of space and light.
They acknowledged that they faced a monumental bureaucracy (23 government agencies were cited in the plan), but they noted the plan's advantages. Its residential housing proposals would not require much new construction. The neighborhood's appeal to manufacturers is that a quarter of all of Red Hook's land stands vacant. And its ideas for economic development relied on private financing. The Community Board passed it 38-0; the Borough President agreed to it and formed a task force to begin putting it into effect; city planners from around the world wanted to study it.
"It was hailed as a model," said Edward Rogowsky, a member of the City Planning Commission. "All of a sudden, the model didn't work. Maybe they were too specific in their proposals. Maybe they hadn't done enough outreach."
The sides have dug in hard. Mr. O'Connell, a former New York City police detective, said, "Businessmen have realized what was happening with this plan, and they are afraid." Richard Barschow, who runs a scrap metal business in Red Hook, said the plan was essential to getting banks to lend money to people in the neighborhood, and added, "Red Hook will remain a ghost town if the plan dies."
Symbols for the dispute are the buildings at the base of Van Brunt Street, Red Hook's main commercial strip. The plan called for the city-owned buildings to be converted into a residential and commercial complex.
Mr. Mesh endorses the action as an economic stimulus. But Mr. O'Connell maintained that taking over the buildings would put the current tenant out of business in Red Hook.
Alan Schoenberg, a salt distributor in Red Hook and an admirer of much of the renewal plan, fears for its future: "If neither side moves, it won't be resolved, and in my opinion the plan will die. There is an emotional personality to what is going on, and it's eating up the people and the good energy that is here."
The Planning Commission last summer returned the plan to Community Board 6 for revisions to address the opposition's concerns. After the board submits that revised plan in the coming months, Mr. Rose said, the commission will decide whether to send the plan on to the City Council for approval.
"The essence of the plan is for a mixed-use neighborhood, and that is what I think will emerge," Mr. Rose said. "But even a plan that had as much merit as Red Hook's is not perfect."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Trims Losses Late in Day As House Acts to End Shutdown

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar settled lower against other leading currencies yesterday, recovering a bit in late trading after the House passed a bill to end the partial shutdown of the Federal Government.
But analysts saw more uncertainty ahead until a final budget-balancing deal was reached. 
 In late New York trading, the dollar was quoted at 105.27 yen, down from 105.30 yen late Thursday. The dollar was worth 1.4385 German marks in New York, down from 1.4430 marks late Thursday. The British pound edged up to $1.5512 from $1.5510.
The dollar came off its lows of 104.70 yen and 1.4346 marks when the House voted to end the latest Government shutdown and return some 280,000 furloughed Federal employees through Jan. 26.
President Clinton said he would sign the bill if it was passed by the Senate as expected.
Financial markets have been rising and falling lately along with the shifting sentiment on the future of the stalemate between Mr. Clinton and Republicans over how to balance the Federal budget.
A dollar rally early this week was cut short Thursday after budget talks collapsed and the currency continued its slide yesterday until the House action.
"There's nothing for the market to get its teeth into," said Tom Benfer, director of foreign exchange at Bank of Montreal's New York office.
The dollar will likely rise when an agreement is reached because the markets see declining deficits as anti-inflationary and helpful to the dollar, he said.
Chris Iggo, economist at Chase Manhattan Bank in New York, said the longer the budget stalemate dragged on, the less enthusiastic the market was going to be when a deal was reached. That could account for yesterday's relatively weak upward bounce from the House vote.
"The figures are going to be fudged to some extent and it won't be a credible package, so there's not much reason to be bullish and the market is, I think, reflecting that," he said.
The market largely ignored the resignation of the Prime Minister Tomiichi Murayama of Japan, with analysts saying that his departure had been widely anticipated and that Japan's future economic policies remain a question mark.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
China Says Growth and Inflation Eased in 1995

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: BEIJING, Jan. 5

 BODY:
Chinese economic growth slowed slightly last year, the State Statistical Bureau said today, but that was in keeping with the Government's efforts to curb inflation, which slowed considerably.
Economic output increased 10.2 percent last year, down from the 11.8 percent increase of 1994 but above the Government's target of a rate between 9 percent and 10 percent. Retail prices rose 14.8 percent, considerably slower than 1994's increase of 21.7 percent and meeting the Government target of an increase of less than 15 percent. 
 In an effort to cool the overheated economy, the Government has imposed price controls and limits on the amount of credit available to companies. A record grain harvest last year also helped reduce price pressures.
Foreign analysts use the Government statistics to track trends in China, but they note that the data are often unreliable. The Government itself has found that as many as one-third of local officials fudge their books, sometimes wildly misreporting figures.
According to today's report by the Statistical Bureau, China's trade surplus widened sharply last year, to about $20 billion from $5.3 billion in 1994, as total trade volume grew 18 percent, to $280 billion. The wide Chinese surplus has generated trade tensions with the United States.
Per capita income rose by an inflation-adjusted 4 percent in China's cities last year, to $464, and by 5 percent in rural areas, to $186.75.
The economic expansion has caused retail sales to grow steadily, an important factor driving the economy, Ye Zhen, an official of the Statistical Bureau, said. Sales of consumer goods rose 11 percent in 1995, to $240 billion. The percentage increase is not adjusted for inflation, however.
Rising demand for a wide variety of consumer goods not previously available or affordable is expected to continue to fuel economic growth.
Nevertheless, China's economy still has serious structural problems, economists said. "The base of agricultural production is weak," Mr. Ye said. "Prices are still on a high level; the task for curbing inflation is still arduous. Some of the enterprises have difficulties in management and operations."
Many of China's state-owned companies continue to be unprofitable. In particular, the heavy industries are mired in debt and burdened with huge numbers of redundant workers.
Still, industrial output increased 14 percent last year, to $277 billion.
Unemployment remained steady at 2.9 percent of the labor force in 1995, the bureau said, as officials and industries struggled to find new places for workers laid off from state-owned factories.
Some estimates in the official media put unemployment as high as 3.8 percent. Foreign analysts said that the methods for calculating unemployment in China tended to understate the problem because many people officially remained on payrolls without actually working and while receiving little or no pay.
