HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
In Rebound From Weak Year, Chinese Stocks Are Surging

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

DATELINE: HONG KONG, Jan. 5

 BODY:
Shares in Chinese companies have been surging on world markets since the year began, a marked contrast to their weakness in 1995. While analysts and fund managers say that some of the stocks are likely to maintain their gains, they warn that other issues have been merely pulled up in the excitement and could fall sharply if corporate earnings weaken.
Lifted by an improving Chinese economy, an appetite among American investors and strength among Asian stocks over all, Chinese share prices rose sharply this week on the New York Stock Exchange, in Hong Kong and on China's two stock exchanges. Because the shares fell sharply last year, investors are buying them at bargain prices. 
 "China has engineered a very good economic landing, and conditions will improve this year," said Ean Wah Chin, a Singapore-based managing director at Morgan Stanley Group Inc., which manages $4 billion in Asian equities outside of Japan. Fund managers in the United States, flush with cash from investors betting that American stocks may run out of steam, are looking for inexpensive stocks in Asia, she said.
But Simon Lee, manager of the $8.8 million China Fund at Sun Hung Kai Fund Management, was cautious. "The consolidation should happen any time now," he said. "Share prices have been going up 50 percent and 60 percent and no one can explain it."
Mr. Lee said that low trading volumes in some of the stocks suggested that investors with large holdings were trying to manipulate prices to feed the frenzy.
Chinese stocks have drawn attention in the United States this week. On Thursday, for example, five of the eight leading percentage gainers on the New York Stock Exchange were Chinese companies. The issues ended the week with strong gains. Among them, Brilliance China Automotive Holding closed today at $7.25, up 87 percent from its closing price at the end of 1995, and China Tire Holding closed at $8, up 47 percent.
Overseas, the index of stocks in Chinese state-owned companies that trade in Hong Kong rose 2 percent, bringing its gain for the week to nearly 19 percent. Last year, the index fell 29 percent, in contrast to a gain of 23 percent in the Hang Seng Index, which tracks the stocks of major Hong Kong companies.
In trading in China today, B shares, which are shares in Chinese companies that foreigners can buy, rose 1.8 percent on Shenzhen's stock exchange but fell nine-tenths of 1 percent on Shanghai's exchange. So far this year, B shares are up 7 percent in Shanghai and 1.2 percent in Shenzhen.
Through the close of Hong Kong trading today, the CLSA China World Index, which tracks leading Chinese companies listed on world exchanges, was up 13 percent for the week. It had fallen 11 percent during the last two months of 1995.
One reason for the strength in share prices is the improving state of the Chinese economy. The Government announced in Beijing today that economic growth slowed slightly last year but still remained above the official target. The Government has been trying to hold down growth to restrain inflation, which did show a sharp slowdown last year.
Another factor aiding stocks is an absence of changes in Chinese taxes that would hurt corporate earnings. There had been speculation that such changes were near, but the Beijing Government, which usually announces any tax changes on Jan. 1, did not disclose any revisions as the year began.
"If there were any more tax reforms, they would have come out by now," said Sonja Jong, assistant director at Mees Pierson Capital Management, which has $1 billion invested in Asian equities. "People think it's safe to get in, especially at these low levels."
The improvements in China's economy have come at a cost, however. As part of its efforts to fight inflation, the Government restrained credit last year, making it difficult for companies to finance operations and expansions.
As a result, analysts expect some companies to report 1995 earnings that were weaker than had been expected. The analysts said they did not expect earnings to improve until this year's second half. Corporate reports for 1995 are due in April.
"Some of the buying was indiscriminate," Graham Muirhead, director of HSBC Asset Management, said about this week's activity. "There is an improved economic environment, but slower economic growth means severe problems for companies." HSBC oversees $200 million in specialized China investment funds.
The earnings reports may not tell the whole story. Many state-run enterprises are poorly managed and are routinely late in informing investors of negative news. Even well-managed companies can have clients that refuse to pay their bills.

HEADLINE: Long Bond Ends Lower in Day of Mixed Prices

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities were mixed yesterday, with the longer maturities moving lower.
Market participants remained edgy with more reported delays of Government statistics because of the partial Government shutdown -- now in its third week -- and, with headlines about Washington's stalled budget negotiations moving on the business news wires, few were in a buying mood. 
 The price of the 30-year bond fell 9/32 of a percentage point, to 111 13/32 ; its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from its price, rose to 6.04 percent, from 6.02 percent on Thursday. A weaker dollar and rising commodity prices also kept the long maturities under selling pressure.
"Normally the market would be eagerly anticipating the release of the December nonfarm payroll report this morning," said Carroll J. Delaney, director of research at Stires, O'Donnell & Company, "but we all know that dog isn't hunting at the moment."
Mr. Delaney said that while it might be a little early to characterize the selloff that occurred late Thursday as anything more than a healthy correction to an overbought market, it should be remembered that the swift and precipitous decline in yields occurred with only a paltry few corrective hiccups since last July, when the yield on the long bond was 6.96 percent. And if all parties in Washington have not been scared into negotiating by now, he said, then the Treasury market might be extremely vulnerable to a major rout.
The slumping dollar was also exerting pressure on prices, since a weak dollar makes dollar-denominated investments like Treasury securities less attractive to foreign investors.
Futures were lower, with the March bond contract down from the outset. One large investment bank started the selling at a price of 120 16/32 , and other dealers promptly followed. The session high was 120 24/32 and the low was 119 19/32 ; the price settled at 120 8/32 .
Thomas E. Donne, vice president and a senior portfolio manager at Banc One Investment Advisors in Columbus, Ohio, said that in a market already troubled by the budget talks, the mention Thursday of possible impeachment proceedings against the Treasury Secretary, Robert E. Rubin, by Representative Gerald B. H. Solomon, the upstate New York Republican who is chairman of the House Rules Committee, led to the heavy selling. "That put things on different plane," he said.
Mr. Donne said the selling was largely concentrated in the futures market, as investors there felt that the budget deficit reduction agreement which appeared so close at hand a week ago, was now questionable. If there were to be a a missed interest rate payment and dafault, "it would set Government credibility back years," he said.
Market losses were trimmed in the afternoon when the House passed a bill to return Government workers to Federal payrolls, suggesting that some of the heated rhetoric and posturing of the last few days has cooled, even though the measure cannot be enacted unless the Senate also passes it and President Clinton signs it, both of which appeared possible. "The market regarded the passage of the bill as a step forward in the negotiations," Mr. Donne said, "with the sides at least not backing away from each other."
Elsewhere, Wall Street firms will not be receiving delivery of $750 million of Government National Mortgage Association securities that they expect by the end of January, if the Government's partial shutdown drags on for two more weeks, Ginnie Mae's president, Kevin Chavers, said on Thursday.
Wall Street firms may already have committed to sell the mortgage-backed securities to investors, further complicating the issue, Mr. Chavers said.
Congress has failed to provide Ginnie Mae with the authority to provide those mortgage-backed securities, Mr. Chavers said.

HEADLINE: Shaking Up Czech Industry;
A Western Entrepreneur Plays Capitalist Hardball

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ 

DATELINE: PRAGUE

 BODY:
When Michael D. Dingman, an American executive with a nose for value and a reputation for rapid restructurings, acquired stakes in a smorgasbord of Czech companies, the cozy business community here sat up.
Soon after announcing his $200 million package of investments in late October, Mr. Dingman, the former president of Allied Signal Inc., engineered a board-room shake-up that prevented a Swedish paper giant from taking control of the Czech Republic's biggest paper company. 
 A month later, on his first visit here -- the irrepressible Mr. Dingman, 64, bought his Czech portfolio long distance from his beachfront home in the Bahamas -- he informed Plzensky Prazdroj, a beer company in which he holds an indirect interest, that he wanted to install an American manager. A brash marketer from archenemy Anheuser-Busch peddling prestigious Pilsner Urquell? The Czech brewery couldn't quite believe it -- and balked.
Mr. Dingman's investment in beer, paper, oil, shipping and other businesses represents the first effort by a big foreign entrepreneur to shake up slumbering Czech industry since Eastern Europe's most sweeping mass privatization program was completed here a year ago.
While multinationals like Volkswagen and Philip Morris have made their mark here by buying plants directly from the Government, Mr. Dingman's investment is the largest transfer of publicly traded Czech equity to a single owner. He bought the shares from Viktor Kozeny, 32, the founder of the Harvard Capital and Consulting Corporation, the country's biggest investment fund, which amassed an estimated $1 billion worth of holdings in Czech companies during the privatization process.
To hear Mr. Dingman tell it, his foray into the Czech Republic was a deliberate choice of one emerging market over another: Eastern Europe, neglected by American investors because of uncertainties about politics and profits in ex-Communist countries, over the more familiar and booming Southeast Asia.
Mr. Dingman is betting he can make that choice pay off by playing the same kind of capitalist hardball that he practiced for many years in the United States. Having helped build Allied Signal into a giant conglomerate, he took the pieces that didn't fit and formed another company, the Henley Group. Mainly through cost-cutting efforts and financial incentives to line managers, he turned this ragtag collection of 35 lackluster businesses around -- and then spun them off to Henley shareholders or took them public, making a fortune for himself in the process.
Whether Mr. Dingman can perform more magic here is an open question. He has a wily partner in Mr. Kozeny, who knows all the players and which buttons to push even though he, too, now makes his home in the Bahamas.
But the fact that Mr. Dingman has already run into some opposition -- at the beer company, for one, which is still balking, though negotiations continue -- is an indication of the high anxiety level over his rough-and-tumble business style. Most privatized companies are owned by passive investors through mutual funds managed by Mr. Kozeny and others -- and hard decisions about making the companies more competitive internationally, including the need for layoffs in some cases, have been rare.
Indeed, Mr. Dingman says he will bring to Czech corporate culture what has been lacking: hands-on management by a real owner. In so doing, he told Czech officials and managers during his two-day meet-and-greet visit in late November, he would "unlock the value of the assets."
He is working, he said, with Mr. Kozeny, who is his neighbor in the Bahamas, to buy plants in Russia that will complement the Czech companies and form the basis for an industrial empire in Eastern Europe and the former Soviet Union. In the last month, Mr. Dingman has reached agreements to invest in two Russian companies whose businesses relate to some of the larger holdings in the Czech Republic.
Western "troubleshooters" -- buddies of Mr. Dingman's from his network of contacts in the United States -- will lead the charge. One is installed at Ceska Namove Plavba, or Czech Ocean Shipping, the national cargo carrier in which Mr. Dingman and Mr. Kozeny have a 69 percent stake. And retired executives from Texaco have looked over Moravske Naftove Doly, the country's sole oil and gas exploration company, in which the partners hold a minority interest. The new arrivals will help tighten financial management while broadening marketing efforts, Mr. Dingman said.
"The historical education of Czech managers is different from American and Western managers -- in marketing, where you need to sell as opposed to allocate, and in the area of cost control," Mr. Dingman said.
William Genco, an analyst at Merrill Lynch who has long followed Mr. Dingman's career in the United States, notes that "he has a track record of attracting extraordinary managers."
But at the beer company, Mr. Dingman faces a well-entrenched management, proud of its history and unused to aggressive marketing. And at Sepap, the paper company, he will have to show industry professionals that he brings as much expertise to the table as did AssiDoman, the company's Swedish partner that Mr. Dingman outflanked in the board-room battle.
For these and other reasons, several market analysts here expressed reservations about Mr. Dingman and his Nassau-based Stratton Investments Company.
"There is no question that industry needs a shake-up," said Alex Angell, a director of Wood & Company, a leading brokerage firm in Prague. "But whether the best results will be encouraged by fear remains to be seen," a reference to the shake-up at Sepap that resulted in the removal of its manager from the board.
Elisa Mazan, an analyst with Oppenheimer & Company in New York, said: "Stratton will be judged by what they do. People are optimistic that Stratton will bring in know-how. But they haven't made any moves yet."
Mr. Dingman got on the road to Eastern Europe shortly after he renounced his American citizenship in 1994 and moved to the Bahamas, a tax haven. He began to study emerging markets and became friendly with Mr. Kozeny, who had moved to the Bahamas after Czech prosecutors started investigating his involvement with a Government official convicted of selling state secrets. (The Government has since made it clear that Mr. Kozeny would not be prosecuted if he came back, but he has chosen not to return.)
"Ten months ago, Viktor pulled out a map of the industrial world," Mr. Dingman recalled. "He said: 'In Eastern Europe and Russia, all the facilities are in place.' The roads, the pipelines, the factories, the aluminum smelters. There's no serious industrial infrastructure in Southeast Asia. It already exists in Central Europe and clearly this offered extraordinary opportunities for fungible products like paper, cement, aluminum and steel."
And Mr. Kozeny, a Harvard-educated Czech-American, offered access. He got that access by gambling big on privatization's future. When the country's state industries went on the block, each Czech got the right to buy vouchers to purchase shares. More than 800,000 Czechs entrusted their vouchers to Mr. Kozeny, who promised a tenfold return within a year in return for a management fee. The market went up sixtyfold.
According to Mr. Dingman's representative in Prague, Daniel J. Arbess, Mr. Kozeny has sold holdings in seven companies to Mr. Dingman's Stratton Investments. Mr. Kozeny then went back into the market to acquire more stock and surrendered to Stratton the attached voting rights in return for 10 percent of future gains in the holdings originally sold to Stratton.
Mr. Arbess, until recently the Prague-based head of the worldwide privatization group at White & Case, a New York law firm, said Stratton and Mr. Kozeny's Harvard Capital have majority stakes in Sklo Union, a glass manufacturer, in addition to the shipping company and Sepap. The two also have minority stakes in Spolana, a chemical maker; Prazska Teplarenska, a heating utility; Moravske Naftove Doly, the oil company, and Biocel Paskov, a pulp producer. As for the beer company, Stratton has a contract with Harvard Capital to share in the appreciation of the fund's 31 percent stake, Mr. Arbess said. (Harvard Capital has no affiliation with Harvard University.)
On top of all that, Stratton recently agreed in principle to buy a 15 percent stake in Premiera TV, a television broadcaster based in Prague.
At Sepap, one of the best managed of the Czech Republic's newly privatized companies, Mr. Dingman defeated AssiDoman in a proxy battle orchestrated by Mr. Kozeny.
For Sepap's 43-year-old general manager, Tomas Sabatka, Stratton's takeover was both flattering and bewildering: though removed from the board, he was allowed to keep his position as operational manager.
Mr. Sabatka had pummeled the company, based in Steti, 60 miles north of Prague, into better shape. Since 1990, Sepap shed nearly half of its 6,000 workers, sold off two unprofitable subsidiaries and paid off debts.
At AssiDoman headquarters in Stockholm, there were questions about whether Mr. Dingman knew what he was doing by entering the paper industry. Ragnar Qarnstrom, manager of AssiDoman's heavy paper products, said he believed Mr. Dingman had paid too much for his share of Sepap, particularly at a time when the paper industry was due for a cyclical downturn. Sepap, he said, needed an estimated $500 million in investment in the next 5 to 10 years. The paper plants in Russia that Mr. Dingman was considering buying were also facing a downturn, Mr. Qarnstrom said.
In any event, for every hard-charging Mr. Sabatka, Mr. Dingman faces many more managers out of the classically stodgy Czech mold, like those at the beer company.
"The perception from the Czech Republic is that 'We own the market; no one will mess in this territory,' " Mr. Dingman said. "But coming from a Western market and being frightened to death of Western consumer companies who are so good and so cunning, I'd be concerned."
Of his own future here, though, Mr. Dingman seems to have few concerns, even after his shaky start at the beer company. "I'm disappointed," he said, "but not deterred."

HEADLINE: One Type of Bond Fund That May Have Crested

BYLINE: By LESLIE WAYNE 

 BODY:
After five years in which hundreds of single-state municipal bond funds have been started, mutual fund companies are quietly closing or consolidating some. This is a result of a lack of interest from investors, and, in some states, a scant supply of municipal bonds.
Even though the number of single-state mutual funds is at a high, the countertrend is developing. Some big mutual fund companies, like John Nuveen & Company, have consolidated many single-state closed-end funds into one larger fund to achieve economies of scale. Other fund companies, like Prudential Mutual Funds and the Dreyfus Corporation, a unit of the Mellon Bank, have eliminated some state funds entirely and rolled them into big national funds -- where, the companies say, investors can earn even higher returns. 
 While the number of fund consolidations is not large, they are seen by some as a sign that the boom in single-state funds may be ending. There may be too many small and fragmented funds to meet a declining investor appetite for municipal bonds, municipal bonds experts say.
States like New York, Pennsylvania and California have high tax rates and issue a large number of bonds, and residents of these states can gain a tax break by buying the bonds of their own states. But some say that the mutual fund industry has aggressively marketed single-state funds that make no economic sense -- offering funds, for instance, for states where the income tax rates are so low that the after-tax returns from these funds are not competitive with other investments. In some cases, single-state funds have been offered for states where there are no state income taxes at all -- and therefore no need for a tax-sheltered investment.
In the last few months, Dreyfus has rolled a Colorado and an Arizona fund into its national municipal bond fund. Nuveen, which has more single-state funds than any other mutual fund company, has merged 37 closed-end state funds into 16 state funds and has more consolidations in the wings. And Prudential has rolled funds from Arizona, Georgia and Minnesota into a national fund.
In many of these national funds, investors will get higher yields, which can more than offset the reduction in any tax benefits from a single-state fund.
"For us, this consolidation was part of an overall review of our fund family," said Terry Hamacher , president and chief investment officer for Prudential Mutual Funds. "Some of these funds were very small and we were having difficulty in finding a lot of good new municipal issues. We felt our shareholders would be better served being in our national municipal fund, where the after-tax yields would be higher."
Single-state municipal bond funds are being buffeted by the same forces that are hurting the municipal bond market in general. A falling volume of securities issued by cities and towns means fewer securities to buy -- the 1995 volume of new municipal issues is about half the $300 billion issued in 1993. Investor concerns about a flat tax, which could undermine the value of tax-exempt bonds, has cut demand for municipal bonds in general. And the bankruptcy of Orange County, Calif., has added to investor jitters.
"Basically, we are faced with a lackluster market," said Diane Coffey, a spokeswoman for Dreyfus. "A lot of these states don't even issue enough securities. Then, you've had competition from a bull stock market and the administrative costs of some of these funds has been high. It just made more sense to take some of these small funds and roll them into something bigger."
Between 1990 and 1995, the number of single-state municipal bond funds exploded. Lipper Analytical Services reported that in 1990, there were 267 single-state municipal funds; by 1995, this had grown to 731 funds. The assets in these funds in 1990 were $46 billion, and by 1995 they had grown to $113 billion. So while assets in these funds were growing by 27 percent a year over this period, the number of funds was rising by 37 percent a year.
"There has been a huge glut of these funds on the market and it has been hard to separate one from another," said Patricia Brady, an analyst with Morningstar Inc., which researches mutual funds. "It got to the point that there was no reason to buy one fund over another. And a lot of those single-state funds should never have existed. For instance, there are a huge number of Florida municipal bond funds, but there are no state taxes. Those people would be better off in a national municipal bond fund."
But Jon Teall, a municipal bond research coordinator at Lipper, said that it might be too early to tell if a broad consolidation was under way.
"The evidence of consolidation is not compelling to me," Mr. Teall said. "It seems that all fund companies that were planning to introduce single-state funds already have, so perhaps we are seeing a topping out. The engine of growth behind these funds is showing signs of slowing, so maybe we are at the peak. Yet I'm not certain that the factors behind consolidation have really taken root and are beginning to influence events."
Kathleen Flannagan, vice president for mutual fund organization at Nuveen, said the driving force behind Nuveen's single-state consolidation move was a desire to reduce the fund's administrative costs and provide higher returns to investors. In addition to consolidation that has already taken place, Nuveen plans to merge two California and two New York funds in the next few months and will continue to look for other possible consolidations.
Ms. Flannagan said that the cost savings to the funds from these consolidations had ranged from a few basis points -- a basis point is a hundredth of a percentage point -- to as much as 27 basis points.
"This is a matter of creating efficiencies for our shareholders," Ms. Flannagan said. "We've taken funds that had $10 million in them and rolled them into funds with $200 million. There are a lot of administrative costs that are fixed for any fund regardless of size -- legal, custodial and customer-related expenses -- and the only way to gain economies of scale is to join a larger fund."
In some states, because of their low taxes, investments in bonds in the state become questionable when other investments can offer investors better returns on an after-tax basis. For instance, Texas and Florida have no state income taxes. But there are currently 13 Texas municipal bond funds and 57 Florida funds.
"There is no reason for anyone to buy a municipal bond fund of a state where there are no income taxes," Ms. Brady of Morningstar said. "But look at the huge amount of Florida funds out there. These investors are being hoodwinked."
The Norwest Corporation, which is based in Minneapolis, recently closed its Arizona fund, largely because the firm had little presence in Arizona and there was little demand for the product, said Lee Chase, who runs the company's mutual funds. Ms. Chase, however, said that Norwest had no plans to close its Minnesota and Colorado single-state funds.
"It's a combination of factors," Ms. Chase said. "There is the question of how much paper is available, the size of the market in the state and the marginal tax bracket of the people in the state. More mutual funds companies are slicing up a very small market in each state, so the potential for us to reach a critical mass with our fund was very low."
"We looked at the market," Ms. Chase added, "and found it was very limited."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Surprise Tax Bill Pushes Down Taiwan Stocks

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
It may be reassuring to know that political peregrinations someplace other than Washington can also stir up financial markets.
Comments coming out of the budget battle between Republican lawmakers and the Clinton Administration have whipsawed American stock and bond markets in recent days. But those swings have been mild compared with the wild plunge in Taiwan's stock exchange yesterday caused by 37 legislators in Taipei. 
 On Thursday, with most of the nation's 150-member Parliament out to lunch, the 37 members of the opposition D.P.P. party rammed through a bill that would impose a capital gains tax on profits from stock transactions.
The bill was unexpected, and Taiwan's weighted price index, which posted a 30 percent decline in dollar terms last year, plummeted another 6.7 percent yesterday, its biggest one-day loss in more than five years.
Lin Chen-kuo, the Finance Minister, said that the Government opposed the new law, but analysts said President Lee Teng-hui, who faces opposition in the country's first independent elections, in March, would have little choice but to sign it.
As of late yesterday, however, it appeared that an alternative Government-supported bill intended to rescind much of what was passed on Thursday would be introduced early next week.
The index fell slightly in today's two-hour trading session, dropping 47.91 points, or almost 1 percent, to 4,847.21.
The bill left analysts amazed, in large part because the Government spent much of last year enacting laws intended to encourage foreign investment in Taiwan securities.
"This came out of the blue," said David Ishibashi, a portfolio manager at Smith Barney International. "I was in Taiwan right before Christmas, and the issue was never discussed."
Alex Baez, a vice president at J. P. Morgan Investment Management, said that "throughout 1995, Taiwanese authorities gave the impression they were welcoming and encouraging foreign capital, and we were very encouraged by the moves."
"But this capital gains tax stance is very disappointing to us," Mr. Baez added. "We hope it will be reconsidered."
Nicholas Horsley, co-manager of the Warburg Pincus Emerging Markets Fund, was less diplomatic.
"They rammed this through, and it was a total ambush," he said. "Whoever is the Government whip in Parliament ought to be drawn and quartered."
This episode adds to the list of imponderables facing those who have invested in or are considering entering Taiwan's riotous stock market, where local investors routinely turn their portfolios over once a week.
But Mr. Horsley said that potential investors should ignore the capital gains issue, as well as the approaching election and the nature of Taiwan's future relationship with China, and focus on the fundamentals.
"Ignore the politics, go ahead and invest," he said. "The economics are compelling."
In Mr. Horsley's view, the facts worth considering are: an economy that is likely to expand at better than a 7 percent rate; high corporate earnings growth; a very low rate of inflation and a country that has the world's second-highest level of foreign reserves, after Japan. Moreover, given the magnitude of the sell-off last year and so far in 1996, stock prices seem highly attractive.
Mr. Baez, who was not quite so bullish, conceded the latter point.
"On a historical basis, the market looks pretty cheap," he said, noting that in recent years the average price-earnings ratio for the market has been about 30, but is now about half that.
After acknowledging that Taiwan has "great companies," Mr. Ishibashi said that for the time being he intended to stay away.
The events of last year -- including Chinese missile tests over Taiwan as well as trial amphibious troop landings conducted by Beijing on the Chinese coast -- upset investors and Taiwan citizens alike.
"The overriding consideration is the elections," Mr. Ishibashi said. "At some point, I will be getting into the market. But until March the market will move in a sawtooth pattern."

HEADLINE: Japan Premier Resigns in Sign Of a Party Shift

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Jan. 5

 BODY:
The abrupt resignation today of Prime Minister Tomiichi Murayama stunned Japan and triggered a political struggle that will lead not only to a new prime minister but perhaps also to a major political realignment.
The resignation of Mr. Murayama, 71, who was regarded by much of the electorate as equally honorable and incompetent, is expected to lead to a generational shift toward younger and more dynamic leaders. 
Although Mr. Murayama did not formally name a successor, he is said to have privately anointed Ryutaro Hashimoto, the Trade Minister and leader of the Liberal Democratic Party, which is in coalition with Mr. Murayama's Socialists.
The elevation of Mr. Hashimoto, 58, would signify a remarkable recovery for the Liberal Democratic Party, which governed Japan for nearly four decades before being ousted in elections in 1993. Then ridiculed as corrupt, exhausted and devoid of ideas, the party now seems set to regain the top spot in the Government.
The Liberal Democrats were sobered by their time in the political wilderness, however, for Mr. Hashimoto does not fit the stereotype of a corrupt power broker. Instead, he was chosen partly because of his appeal to voters, based on a clean record and a telegenic ability to speak his mind and project energy.
The change would not immediately affect the coalition or the balance of power in Parliament. But the longer-term implications could be profound.
Mr. Hashimoto is of a younger and more assertive generation, and his ascendance would set up a head-on clash with another hard-charging leader, 53-year-old Ichiro Ozawa of the New Frontier Party, the largest opposition group. Some see in this clash the emergence of a stable two-party system in Japan.
And no matter who wins that contest, Japan appears likely to adopt a foreign policy profile more in keeping with its status as a global trade giant, ending a half-century of timidity since its defeat in World War II.
"I've never avoided taking responsibility," Mr. Hashimoto told reporters today, with a candor that might have been considered unseemly by the old rules of Japanese politics. "I'll pursue the same line, and whenever I have to assume responsibility, I will do so."
Mr. Hashimoto beamed at the prospect of moving into the Prime Minister's residence next week, and he seemed the second-happiest person in Japan today. The happiest was perhaps Mr. Murayama, who has been regularly plumbing new lows in public opinion polls, and he looked thrilled and relieved as he announced his resignation.
The rise of Mr. Hashimoto could spell difficulties for the United States, for he has been unusually forceful and feisty in dealing with America.
Last year he led Japan's resistance to American demands for changes in its automobile market, and in the 1980's as Transport Minister he fought American attempts to win construction contracts for a huge airport near Osaka. Japanese officials reportedly once explained that American contractors would be inappropriate because "Japan has different dirt."
Yet some Americans argue that a more assertive and decisive Japan is not just inevitable but also healthy for relations between the two countries.
"I think that U.S.-Japanese relations should improve if Hashimoto becomes Prime Minister, in the sense that Hashimoto is much more direct and straightforward about asserting Japan's positions on issues," said Glen S. Fukushima, an American businessman and vice president of the American Chamber of Commerce in Japan. "Although there are concerns about Hashimoto's assertiveness, in the long run it's better to know what Japanese leaders are thinking."
As the world's second-largest economy, Japan is often ridiculed as an oddity: a first-rate nation with third-rate politicians. Over the last decade, Japan probably has had more prime ministers and fewer leaders than any other major country. Yet with the resignation of Mr. Murayama, that may be changing.
The axis of power appears to be shifting to Mr. Hashimoto and Mr. Ozawa. Both men are often criticized as arrogant, headstrong and prickly. But there is also no doubt that they are leaders and that they envision a role for Japan that is more independent and self-assured than in the past.
But Mr. Hashimoto, a devotee of kendo, or Japanese fencing, who practices with his sword on the roof of the Trade Ministry, is more comfortable than Mr. Murayama with the American military bases in Japan. So discussions about security cooperation, which are to be the focus of President Clinton's visit to Japan in April, may go more smoothly.
Although he says he favors a loosening of government regulation of the faltering Japanese economy, he does not go nearly as far as Mr. Ozawa, and the Liberal Democratic Party is backed by constituencies -- like farmers and small businesses -- that rely on existing rules to protect them from competition.
Mr. Hashimoto's elevation would be a chance for the Liberal Democratic Party to show voters a new face in power before the next elections, helping erase the memories of decades in which party leaders were so accustomed to power that they seemed to regard it as their birthright. Japan in those days was sometimes called a one-party state.
But since the Liberal Democrats fell from power, some political scientists have suggested that the country may be moving toward an American-style system in which two main parties compete for votes and power switches back and forth. With Mr. Hashimoto running Japan as head of the Liberal Democrats and Mr. Ozawa excoriating him as head of the opposition, the outlines of such a two-party system would become visible.
Parliament is expected to meet in special session beginning on Thursday to choose the next Prime Minister. A variety of officials in the governing coalition made it clear that Mr. Hashimoto was expected to be named.
"As for the Liberal Democratic Party, Mr. Hashimoto is the only choice," said Koichi Kato, the secretary general of the Liberal Democrats.
To win, Mr. Hashimoto needs the votes not only of the Liberal Democrats but also of the Socialists and of a third, minor party in the coalition. Some members of the smaller parties may balk at voting for Mr. Hashimoto, but they have a strong incentive to stick together: Otherwise, there may be immediate elections, under a new system of single-seat constituencies, and the small parties could be wiped off the political map.
Mr. Ozawa, who was just elected opposition leader a week ago, immediately pressed his demand for a snap election.
"The Government should dissolve as soon as possible, to ask voters whether they want this Government to stay in power," he told reporters. "If this Government is re-elected, then they'll have a mandate to be in power."
All of Japan's leading newspapers have already called for prompt general elections -- in any case they must be held by July 1997 -- and major business leaders also urged that general elections be held early. Business executives said they welcomed the announcement, and stock prices rose slightly.
"It's an appropriate time for a change of Government," said Kosaku Inaba, the head of the Japanese Chamber of Commerce and Industry. "I was hoping for a change of Government sometime this year," he added. "This came earlier than expected, but it'll still have a positive effect."
Mr. Murayama said that he had decided over the New Year holiday to resign.
"On New Year's Day, under the blue sky, I looked back at the road I've taken," he said at a news conference. "I thought that I'd pretty much performed the historical role that had been handed to me. Luckily, the omens of economic recovery can be seen, and it's now time to inject fresh blood into the leadership."
By some accounts Mr. Murayama was also upset that he faced opposition in his race for re-election as head of the Socialist Party. And he may have hesitated to lead the country into new elections in which his party is expected to perform poorly, perhaps even to be obliterated.
Although he won little respect for his leadership, Mr. Murayama was widely admired for his decency. He was never accused of corruption or putting on airs, and he always spoke with the accent of his native Oita Prefecture, on the southern island of Kyushu, where he grew up as one of 11 children in a fisherman's family.
Even as Prime Minister, he was utterly unpretentious, so that when he fell sick two years ago at the summit meeting of the Group of Seven industrial democracies, the Japanese Government spokesman casually explained that the Prime Minister "often gets diarrhea."
As Prime Minister, Mr. Murayama not only faced economic stagnation and a banking crisis, but also a catastrophic earthquake in Kobe, a poison gas attack on the subways and the trauma of facing the 50th anniversary of the end of World War II. In August, Mr. Murayama delivered the most sweeping apology any Japanese leader has ever made for the war.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Congress Votes to Return Federal Workers to Payroll
Congress voted to put 760,000 Federal workers back on the payroll for three weeks, and to reopen politically visible Government operations from the national parks to the payment of veterans' pensions until September.
Republicans insisted the partial reopening would enable them to refocus public attention away from sad tales about the effect of the 21-day partial Government shutdown, and toward President Clinton and what they called his refusal to propose a Federal budget that would be balanced within seven years. [Page 1.]
 
Furloughed Federal workers in New York whose jobs and paychecks have been stopped since mid-December by the national budget imbroglio will be allowed to delay paying their Consolidated Edison bills and to take out interest-free loans under private industry programs announced in Washington. [8.]
 
S.E.C. Expected to Charge Trader
The S.E.C. will soon bring civil fraud charges against Joseph Jett, the former head of Kidder, Peabody's government securities desk who has been accused of generating $350 million in phantom profits, people familiar with the case say. It is unclear whether the S.E.C. will act against others at Kidder Peabody who were involved in supervising Mr. Jett and his trading. [1.]
 
Commodity Index at 5 1/2-Year High
The Commodity Research Bureau index of 17 commodities, an indication of inflation, surged to a five-and-a-half-year high. Pushed largely by rising futures prices for oil and gold, the index was up 1.29 points, at 246.78, its highest since May 21, 1990. Crude oil prices rose above the psychologically important level of $20 a barrel on reports of supply restrictions, gaining 35 cents, to $20.26 a barrel, on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Gold neared $400 an ounce, closing at $396.50, up $1.10. [32.]
 
Dow Reverses Course to Gain 7.59
Stock prices were whipsawed in heavy trading, with shares recovering in the afternoon after the House moved to end the partial Government shutdown. The Dow industrials closed up 7.59 points, at 5,181.43, after slumping more than 40 points earlier. The broader Standard & Poor's 500 index eased 0.99 point, to 616.71, and the Nasdaq composite index increased 3.65 points, to 1,033.47. [37.]
 
Yield on Long Bond Rises to 6.04%
The bellwether 30-year Treasury bond moved lower in price, sending its yield up to 6.04 percent from 6.02 percent on Thursday. Analysts cited Republican talk of impeaching Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin. [36.]
 
The dollar fell to 105.27 yen, from 105.30 yen late Thursday, and to 1.4385 German marks, from 1.4430. It recovered from its session lows after the House passed the bill to end the partial Government shutdown. [32.]
 
Phone Rivalry in Connecticut
Connecticut appears to have gone further than any other state in encouraging competition in local telephone service. It ordered Southern New England Telephone to sell competitors access to its network at discounted rates. [24.]
 
Hypermarkets a Hit in Spain
Spanish shoppers are crowding into hypermarkets -- giant discount supermarkets cum general stores -- to the consternation of siesta-prone traditional shopkeepers, who have persuaded their Parliamentary allies to enact legislation limiting the markets' hours on Sundays and holidays. As the number of working women has grown, the stores with their longer hours, have gained. [34.]
 
Chinese Economic Growth Slows
 China reported its economic growth slowed slightly last year, in keeping with the Government's efforts to curb inflation. Economic output increased 10.2 percent, down from a rise of 11.8 percent in 1994, while retail prices rose 14.8 percent, considerably slower than 1994's increase of 21.7 percent. China's trade surplus widened sharply last year, to about $20 billion from $5.3 billion in 1994. [34.]
 
Chinese Shares Surge Abroad
Shares in Chinese companies have been surging on world markets since the year began, in contrast to their weakness in 1995. On Thursday, for example, five of the eight leading percentage gainers on the New York Stock Exchange were Chinese companies, including Brilliance China Automotive and China Tire, which gained sharply. [34.]

HEADLINE: U.S. Rights Group Asserts China Lets Thousands of Orphans Die

BYLINE: By PATRICK E. TYLER 

DATELINE: BEIJING, Jan. 5

 BODY:
A New York-based human rights organization asserted today that thousands of children have died in China's state-run orphanages from deliberate starvation, medical malpractice and staff abuse.
The group, Human Rights Watch, said it was impossible to obtain "a full accounting of the total number" and of the safety and health of China's orphan population, but based on detailed medical records smuggled out by a doctor from a large Shanghai orphanage, and on a limited set of statistics relating to nationwide orphan mortality, there is cause for great alarm about the fate of countless abandoned infants, most of them girls. 
 "The brutal treatment of orphans in Shanghai, which included deliberate starvation, torture and sexual assault, continued over a period of many years and led to the unnatural deaths of well over 1,000 children between 1986 and 1992 alone," the group concluded in the report issued today.
"This campaign of elimination could be kept secret through the complicity of both higher- and lower-level staff," the report said, "and because the city's Bureau of Civil Affairs, responsible for the orphanage, also runs the crematoria, where starved children's corpses were disposed of with minimum oversight, often even before a death certificate had been filled out by the attending physician."
Nationwide in China, the group said, high mortality figures indicate the strong possibility of a policy of deliberate starvation and severe abuse of orphans, especially girls and mentally and physically handicapped children. Though most of the evidence was gathered from 1988 to 1992, the organization said the policy is probably continuing, and it called on China to open its orphanages to international inspection.
"We have to acknowledge that we can only take this investigation so far," said Robin Munro, the organization's Hong Kong director.
Human Rights Watch based much of its report on the testimony, medical records and photographs taken out of the country by the Chinese physician, Zhang Shuyun, who fled China last year after an unsuccessful campaign to expose abuses at the Shanghai Children's Welfare Institute. The information provided detailed medical histories and case studies on dozens of orphans who died from 1988 to 1992, showing that healthy infants admitted to the Shanghai institution often died of severe malnutrition weeks or months later.
"There is compelling evidence that these astonishing death rates are the result of a deliberate policy to minimize China's population of abandoned children, many of whom have been born in violation of the country's family planning regulations and are sometimes physically or mentally handicapped," the group said in a news release today.
The records show inappropriate changes in medication, the failure to treat severe malnutrition at its onset and blatant medical neglect of life-threatening infections and other conditions, the doctor said.
The doctor's testimony is buttressed by that of Ai Ming, who was taken to the Shanghai orphanage as an abandoned child and spent 20 years there before leaving China last year. In 1992, he secretly photographed the emaciated bodies of dead or dying children who were allegedly chosen for "summary resolution," or death, by staff members seeking to minimize the orphan population.
"The fact is that the evidence is really shocking," said Mr. Munro, who collaborated with Dr. Zhang and Jeff Rigsby, a freelance journalist, in producing the report.
Mr. Munro said that even though the organization already had statistics showing high orphan mortality in early 1995, it was unwilling to confront Chinese officials with the evidence until it issued the report today.
"Given that there has always been unremitting hostility in China's responses to our organization, we didn't feel that they would engage us in any way," Mr. Munro said. "So we decided to put out our version first knowing that they would respond."
Human Rights Watch officials said political considerations played no role in the timing of the report, although it will have an inescapable impact on the deliberations of the United Nations Human Rights Commission in March in Geneva. The United States and European nations have unsuccessfully sought for the past six years to have the commission approve a resolution condemning China's human rights record.
China would like the United States to drop the annual confrontation, but human rights organizations have been pressing the White House to mount another effort this year, especially in light of the continuing harsh treatment of dissidents.
In recent years, thousands of American and European couples have gone to Shanghai, Beijing and other Chinese cities seeking to adopt abandoned Chinese infants from the same orphanages where the abuses are said to be occurring.
According to officials of Adoptive Family of America in Minneapolis, the national clearing house for adoptive parents, the State Department issued 1,369 visas for Chinese children in 1990-94. The group estimates that an additional 1,000 children came over for adoption since then.
The new allegations follow earlier reports of "dying rooms" in Chinese orphanages, where unwanted or handicapped orphans were left to die of malnutrition. The Communist Party leadership has vigorously denied these allegations in each instance and has said it has a commitment to "nourish, treat and teach" orphans.
Today, China's State Council under Prime Minister Li Peng issued a statement saying, "The so-called accusations of 'torture and abuse of disabled children' by the Shanghai Welfare Institute are completely groundless." It said that after a "careful and thorough" investigation, "the relevant department of the Shanghai municipal government denied" the allegations.
The State Council accused Human Rights Watch and the Chinese who collaborated in the investigation of instigating "anger," "hostility" and "political conspiracy" toward China.
Reached by telephone in London, where she is collaborating on a television documentary about her experiences in Shanghai, Dr. Zhang said she decided to leave China with her husband because she and some of her colleagues had "exhausted all our efforts to report what we had discovered in the orphanage and get the problem corrected."
"I had no other alternative but to turn to the human rights organizations," she said, "and now I want all the people in the world who believe that justice prevails to know about this." She said increased adoption of Chinese infants by Western couples was saving only a "small number of children from mistreatment and from being starved to death," adding, "This alone cannot change the Communist Party's policies toward orphanages."
Dr. Zhang's campaign to expose alleged abuses at the orphanage attracted significant support from members of the Shanghai People's Congress, a Communist Party organization, along with several Chinese journalists and lawyers. They joined in pressing for a full investigation of conditions at the Shanghai institution, but their efforts failed in 1992 after party leaders in the city warned that a public airing of charges would open China to criticism from human rights groups.
One of the most vocal of the Shanghai party members who supported Dr. Zhang in 1992 was Hong Dalin, an economist at the Academy of Social Sciences in Shanghai.
Reached by telephone today, Mr. Hong said he could not discuss the investigation because he was no longer a member of the Shanghai People's Congress. Dr. Zhang maintains that all of the local delegates who supported her efforts were subsequently purged from jobs or party positions.
"I hope to call the attention of the whole society to stop the Chinese Government from persecuting the orphans and witnesses who told us what they saw and because of that have lost their jobs or been persecuted in other ways," she said.
The report describes abuses in Shanghai in the 1980's, during the tenure of Communist Party officials who went on to become senior leaders in Beijing, including President Jiang Zemin, who served as Mayor and Communist Party secretary of Shanghai from 1982 to 1989.
Zhu Rongji and Wu Bangguo, now deputy prime ministers under Li Peng, both served in top municipal posts in Shanghai as the investigation unfolded within the party.
The Human Rights Watch report singles out Mr. Wu as chiefly responsible for quashing the investigation, overseeing a campaign of persecution and banning any mention of the accusations in Shanghai's state-run news media. Mr. Wu declined requests to comment.
Huang Jiachun, the deputy director of the Shanghai orphanage, said in a telephone interview that Dr. Zhang's allegations and evidence were "fabricated" and that the Shanghai Supervision Bureau, an investigative arm of the Communist Party, had proved that the charges of abuse and neglect "were wrong." Orphanage officials have invited foreign journalists to visit the orphanage on Monday.
Human Rights Watch said its investigation indicated a "sinister" effort by administrators to improve the outward appearance of the Shanghai orphanage since 1993, and alleged that many infant and handicapped orphans are now being transferred to a heavily guarded Shanghai orphanage and mental institution on an island in the Yangtze River. The group warned that continued abuse of orphans has been reported there.
After spending "nearly a year gathering and analyzing documentary, testimonial and photographic evidence on the treatment of orphans and abandoned children in state institutions," Susan Osnos, the group's communications director, said in a statement accompanying the report, "the material reveals a pattern of cruelty, abuse and malign neglect in child welfare work which now constitutes one of the country's gravest human rights problems."
In June, when a British television network broadcast a documentary titled "The Dying Rooms," the Chinese Embassy in London issued a statement saying, "China has all along attached great importance to the healthy development of children, and is committed to the substantial protection of the rights of children, orphans in particular, by legislative, judicial and administrative means.
"The rights of children, including those of orphans, are protected by the Constitution of the People's Republic of China. Chinese laws prohibit the abuse of orphans and anybody who violates the relevant laws will be brought to justice."

GRAPHIC: Photos: A report by Human Rights Watch released yesterday included photographs and medical details on children said to have been deliberately starved and abused at orphanages in China. No cause of death was indicated in records of the state-run crematorium. HEADLINE: Experts on Crime Warn Of a 'Ticking Time Bomb'

BYLINE: By FOX BUTTERFIELD 

 BODY:
Despite recent reports that crime is decreasing, violent crime in the United States is a "ticking time bomb" that will explode in the next few years as the number of teen-agers soars, an organization of prosecutors and law-enforcement experts said in a report issued yesterday.
The group, the Council on Crime in America, painted a bleak portrait of the criminal justice system, maintaining that it remained a "revolving door" that allowed large numbers of violent felons to go free and commit more crime. About a third of all violent crimes in the United States are committed by people who, though technically "under supervision," are on probation, parole or pretrial release, the report said. 
 The council suggested that state governments needed to "reinvent probation and parole" by devoting far more resources to them and, in the process, finding ways that are more restrictive to monitor felons under supervision. According to the report, state governments currently spend only about $200 a year per probationer, compared with $25,000 per prison inmate.
The council is a nonpartisan group headed by William J. Bennett, who served the Reagan Administration as Director of National Drug Control Policy and then as Education Secretary, and Griffin B. Bell, the Attorney General in the Carter Administration. Mr. Bennett spoke at a Washington news conference where the report was issued yesterday, joined by three other members of the council: Lynn Abraham, the District Attorney in Philadelphia; Gale Norton, the Attorney General of Colorado, and Stephen Goldsmith, the Mayor of Indianapolis.
The report was compiled by John J. DiIulio Jr., a professor of politics and public affairs at Princeton University.
Professor DiIulio said he believed recent reports from New York, Houston and a number of other large cities that their crime rates have dropped in the last few years, at least in part because of new, more aggressive tactics by the police. But he cautioned that crime remained "at a historically high level."
Moreover, drawing on the work of James Alan Fox, dean of the College of Criminal Justice at Northeastern University, Professor DiIulio said that given demographic trends, he was concerned that "we are in the lull before the crime storm."
Between now and the year 2005, the number of male 14- to 17-year-olds will increase by 23 percent. This coming jump in the youthful population is worrisome, the professor said, because criminologists have found that while adults are committing less violent crime, the rate of violent crime among teen-agers has skyrocketed over the last decade.
As a result, the report recommended that governments attach much more importance to preventing youths who are at particular risk of becoming criminals from turning into juvenile delinquents.
"As every study now shows," the report said, "after all is said and done the most serious criminals are males who begin committing crimes at a very early age," often before they reach puberty.
The report also offered a scathing indictment of the criminal justice system, suggesting that the first responsibility of government, and one that all Americans can agree on, is to protect its citizens. At that, it said, governments around the country are failing.
The total cost of crime to victims in the United States is now about $450 billion a year, the report said. Further, it said, real crime rates are actually as much as 5.7 times as high as those reported by the police, and each generation of teen-agers since the 1950's has been more violent than the last.
In addition, in one of its most controversial findings, the report concluded that the high cost of building and operating prisons actually saved taxpayers money when compared with the price of crime. For every dollar it costs to keep the typical prisoner behind bars, "society saves $2.80 in the social costs of crime averted," the report said.
"Prison pays," the report concluded, and America can easily afford to build more prisons because "over all, Americans spend barely a penny of every tax dollar on prisons and jails."
But Franklin Zimring, the director of the Earl Warren Legal Institute at the University of California at Berkeley, challenged a number of those economic findings.
Professor Zimring said the figure of $450 billion in total costs of crime was based on hypothetical judgments that juries might award in personal injury cases.
"The problem is," he said, "if you ask what is it worth not to be raped or murdered, you can add up to a figure greater than the gross national product pretty quickly."
Professor Zimring said that inasmuch as the United States had tripled the number of its prisoners in the last 20 years, "there ought to be some extraordinary public savings that these guys can demonstrate." But no one, he said, has been able to find the evidence for it.

HEADLINE: 'Dikakis' (The Movie)

BYLINE: By Howard Kaminsky; Howard Kaminsky is the co-author, with Susan Kaminsky, of "Talent," a novel.

 BODY:
Recently, a copy of the shooting script of Oliver Stone's next film, "Dukakis," was delivered to my office by a man wearing green fatigues. He seemed to have a slight Cuban accent.
Filmed in total secrecy, this movie, the logical successor to the director's explosive "JFK" and his corrosive "Nixon," reveals the enigmatic former Presidential candidate in a startling and potentially commercial way. Here are excerpts. 
 Exterior. Cornfield in Iowa. Day.
Lots of cameras and press. Michael Dukakis (played by Keanu Reeves) talks to a farmer (Charlton Heston).
Dukakis: Your corn crop looks real good. Real tall.
Farmer: Just so-so this year.
Dukakis: You know in Massachusetts we've had an economic miracle by diversifying. Have you thought of growing something other than corn -- say, Belgian endive?
Farmer: Huh?
Dukakis: Or you could try cilantro. There's mesclun, which I love and --
Farmer: Mescaline? Isn't that a drug?
Dukakis: Bok choy is also a marvelous vegetable. Of course, there's a rising demand for broccoli rape and savoy cabbage.
Farmer: What are you talking about?
Press aide (Wesley Snipes): Governor! We have to go now. We have an event at a piggery in 10 minutes.
Dukakis: And I forgot to mention sorrel and zucchini blossoms. Though cannellini beans are --
As the farmer reaches for his pitchfork, cut to:
Interior. Tank. Day.
Dukakis is strapping on a helmet. The tank's interior is so cramped only three aides can fit inside with him.
Dukakis: This thing is too tight.
Aide No. 1 (Gerard Depardieu): Ici, Gooveneur, try zees one on.
Dukakis: Now that's better.
Aide No. 2 (Demi Moore): I think it might be a little large.
Dukakis: But it's comfortable.
Aide No. 3 (Mickey Rourke): Talk up, Governor. I can barely hear you. The helmet's covering your mouth.
Dukakis: You still think this is the right image for me? What about fighting a Communist hand to hand?
Aide No. 2: That's a risk, Governor. You never finished your self-defense seminar with J. Edgar --
Dukakis: (completely inaudible as helmet slips further down).
Cut to:
Interior. Debate auditorium. Evening.
Vice President George Bush (Charlton Heston, again, this time with lots of makeup) sips nervously at a glass of water. Bernard Shaw (playing himself) prepares to ask the first question.
Shaw: Governor Dukakis, crime is a big concern with voters. What would you do if you saw your wife shoved into a Cuisinart?
Dukakis: I believe that the American people --
Shaw: Vice President Bush, what would you do?
Bush: I would blast away if anyone placed a finger on Barb, though she's a tough bird and could probably handle it by herself. Once when we were clamming in Kennebunkport, she --
Dukakis: Mr. Shaw, could I have another go at that question?
Cut to:
Interior. Boston hotel suite. Night.
Television sets tuned to election coverage. Room crowded with campaign workers (Anthony Hopkins, Joe Pesci, Uta Hagen, Jose Feliciano, Nicholas Cage, Pete Seeger, Emma Thompson, Lainie Kazan).
Dukakis: It looks bad, doesn't it.
John Sasso (Chazz Palminteri): Yeah, real bad.
Dukakis: I see the fingerprints of the C.I.A. all over this. They're working for Bush.
Sasso: What do you mean?
Dukakis: It's payback time.
Sasso: For what?
Dukakis: I had a summer job back in '62 at the Dallas Book Depository. The Trafficante family helped me get it. It paid better than minimum wage. They know I know too much.
Sasso: Look! Bush just took California.
Dukakis: Well, it could have been worse.
Sasso: What do you mean?
Dukakis: Imagine if I had smoked pot or dodged the draft or . . .
Final credits roll, followed by 60-second trailer for Oliver Stone's "Cuomo," coming next year to a theater near you.

HEADLINE: U.S. Likely to Issue Transit Visa for Taiwanese Official

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER S. WREN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 5

 BODY:
Despite the risk of touching off new protests from China, the State Department appears likely to issue a transit visa sought by Taiwan's Vice President.
"We have issued such transit visas in the past, and it would certainly not be inconsistent with our unofficial relationship with Taiwan were we to issue one in this case, or any other in the future," said the State Department spokesman, Nicholas Burns. 
 Mr. Burns said at a news briefing today that the State Department was still discussing the visa with Taiwan and would make a decision shortly.
[Taiwan's Foreign Ministry spokesman, Rock Liang, said on Saturday that the United States had issued a transit visa to Vice President Li Yuan-zu, Reuters reported from Taipei.]
The State Department appears to have been urging Vice President Li Yuan-zu to make a refueling stop that would not involve staying overnight in the United States. He wants to fly through Los Angeles to Guatemala to attend the inauguration of its President on Jan. 14. Guatemala is one of several dozen small countries befriended by Taiwan, often with economic aid, to offset the diplomatic isolation imposed by China.
Mr. Li's request highlights once again the delicacy of the United States' relationship with Taiwan, from which it withdrew diplomatic recognition to establish relations with China in 1979. The State Department maintains an office called the American Institute in Taiwan.
Beijing objects to any dealings by Washington with officials from Taiwan, which it regards as belonging to China. Until last year, the United States discouraged even private visits by Taiwanese officials.
Opposition to Mr. Li's proposed stopover was expressed on Thursday in Beijing by Chen Jian, a Foreign Ministry spokesman, who asked the United States "not to do things that would harm the relations of the two countries" or "hurt the feelings of the Chinese people."
"We are resolutely opposed to the Taiwan authorities using so-called transit diplomacy and other means to engage in activities in countries which have diplomatic relations with China," Mr. Chen said.
But the Taiwan Foreign Minister spokesman, Rock Liang, was quoted by Reuters as saying that "the U.S. policy states that it will grant transit visas" to Taiwan officials.
The Clinton Administration consented last year to such a policy, which is now being tested by Taiwan, since Mr. Li's official aircraft could in theory also refuel in Mexico.
China raised vociferous objections when the Administration granted a visitor's visa last June to Taiwan's President, Lee Teng-hui, so he could travel to his class reunion at Cornell University. Its retaliation included initial refusal to accept a new United States Ambassador, Jim Sasser, a former Democratic Senator. Mr. Sasser is to be sworn in here next week and will leave for China this month.
The visa issue injected a chill into a fragile relationship already riven by disputes between Washington and Beijing over trade, China's suppression of human rights and its sale of nuclear technology to other nations. Beijing's anger lingered even during President Clinton's meeting with the Chinese President, Jiang Zemin, in New York in October.
Mr. Burns acknowledged "there is a sensitivity here" and said the State Department wanted to consider all the issues before making its decision on the visa. But he also played down its significance, noting that Mr. Li had been given a transit visa once before.
"It should not be a big deal for U.S.-China relations, and it should be seen for what it is, if this visa is issued," Mr. Burns said today, "and that is the mere transit of an authority from Taiwan to the inauguration of a president in this hemisphere."

HEADLINE: CONGRESS VOTES TO RETURN 760,000 TO FEDERAL PAYROLL AND RESUME SOME SERVICES;
Republicans' Boomerang

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Saturday, Jan. 6

 BODY:
Republicans in Congress insisted on Friday that by abruptly ending a Government shutdown, they were only regrouping their forces for a long and dug-in battle with the White House over how to balance the Federal budget.
But outside Congress, the party's war with President Clinton over whether to balance the budget seemed for the first time to be in retreat, much in the manner of Napoleon's ill-fated assault on Moscow. 
 Strong in numbers and steeped in their principles, Republicans in the House nevertheless looked as though they had seriously overreached after three full weeks of using a crippled Government to pressure Mr. Clinton into a budget deal.
House leaders argued, credibly in the view of many, that the White House had no real reason to make serious concessions in budget talks if the President could veto Republican spending bills with impunity. But by the end, the shutdown had boomeranged into a powerful force against Republicans, who were seen as wreaking havoc on Federal workers and innocent citizens to score political points.
And Mr. Clinton's stubborn refusal to cut a deal, seen all last year as evidence of political weakness, suddenly began to look like courage in the face of an enemy siege.
"We'll make the case that the Republican view is pretty harsh," the White House spokesman, Michael D. McCurry, said on Friday of the Congressional budget plans. "We've just had a pretty vivid demonstration of just how harsh it can be."
Republicans insisted on Thursday and again on Friday that their cause had suffered no serious setback. With an election year still ahead, they may be right. But even many Republican leaders agreed that in this struggle, they had played a strong hand poorly and that Mr. Clinton had played a weak one exceedingly well.
Democratic accusations that Republican spending plans were an "extremist" attack on the poor and elderly did not gain much purchase until this winter. It was Speaker Newt Gingrich who, in delivering a string of intemperate remarks and complaining of being snubbed on Air Force One, helped put a human face on his opponents' attacks.
Mr. Gingrich lowered his profile. But Democrats shifted their focus on the House's even more fiery freshman class, which applauded the shutdown and showed no inclination to move out of the spotlight.
Against this backdrop, Mr. Clinton has sought with some success to play the role of reasonable grown-up. After offering a budget in February that assumed $200 billion-a-year deficits -- and taking a severe pounding -- he has edged closer and closer to his opponents' fiscal positions.
Since budget talks began in November, he has embraced the concept of a seven-year balanced budget, has effectively endorsed the Congressional economic projections used by Republican fiscal experts, and has said repeatedly that he believes that reasoned debate will produce a compromise spending plan. He has talked endlessly with Republican leaders and bargained with them over dinner in the White House residence.
But in those three months, Mr. Clinton has yet to produce a written budget that uses the Congress's economic projections and reaches balance by 2002. By not doing so, he has kept Republican spending proposals the focus of political attack and has reassured his party's liberal base.
And he has incensed Republicans. By the time the budget talks hit their latest wall, on Tuesday, the White House and Republicans had agreed on $141 billion of the $661 billion in savings that Congress said was needed to reach fiscal balance in seven years.
But $81 billion of that was earmarked almost a month ago, when the most recent round of bargaining began, and the other $60 billion was savings in interest costs that both sides assumed would result from a compromise budget.
Republicans said the White House had refused to accept any further savings in Medicare or Medicaid spending -- the two big-ticket items on the table -- beyond those it had already publicly proposed last year. Nor, they said, would the White House accept any further structural changes in Medicare beyond those it had proposed. Mr. Clinton was open to a cut in the capital-gains tax, a Republican icon, but remained far from the party's other tax proposals.
It is not stretching matters to say that most Republican leaders had concluded this week, rightly or wrongly, that the White House had agreed to talks not for the purpose of reaching a compromise, but for honing its own political positions and attacks on the Republican plan.
"No way can we concede to everything they want on the spending side, have them give us half of what we want on the tax side, and call it progress," a senior Republican aide involved in the talks said on Friday.
Mr. Gingrich said Friday that Republicans in the Househad "no faith that the President is negotiating in good faith" and "no faith that the President will in fact ever provide a balanced budget." Privately, some Republicans involved in the talks said that beyond giving each side a chance to present its positions, the meetings had mostly been unproductive.
Democrats retorted that in the last major budget crisis in 1990, President Bush met with Democratic negotiators for perhaps 15 minutes, whereas Mr. Clinton had spent untold hours in talks with House and Senate members. Any suggestion that the President is bamboozling Republicans, the House minority leader, Richard A. Gephardt, said on Friday, is "abhorrent."
Regardless, the talks will go on, in part because neither side can back out without appearing irresponsible. The legislation that Congress passed on Friday, and which President Clinton signed just after midnight, will give the parties three weeks of breathing space during which furloughed Federal workers will go back to their jobs at full pay. The legislation also provides money for politically sensitive programs through 1996.
Mr. Clinton can strike a deal, averting another crisis around the time of his State of the Union speech later this month, or, Republicans say, he can reject any deal and take responsibility for another shutdown. "If he wants to spend the entire year arguing about a balanced budget," said Representative John A. Boehner of Ohio, a member of the Republican leadership, "we're certainly going to give him that opportunity."
In this way, Republicans are trying to shift public outrage away from the shutdown and back to the balanced-budget plan, where they believe they hold the high ground.
