HEADLINE: ARCHITECTURE VIEW;
Buildings Born of Dreams and Demons

BYLINE: By HERBERT MUSCHAMP 

 BODY:
THIS IS NOT A STORY ABOUT a new movement in architecture. It's a story about an old art movement that has resurfaced in contemporary architecture with startling vigor. Surrealism, which flourished between the world wars, was largely driven by Freud's theories. Surrealist painters, writers and film makers hoped to transform culture by injecting it with the powerful energies generated by subconscious mechanisms. The irrational, the erotic, the controlling, devouring, conflicted and repressed: artists like Breton, Miro, Bunuel, Magritte and Dali sought to draw into the daylight the primitive impulses Freud tried to understand through the interpretation of dreams.
Frank Gehry, Rem Koolhaas, Jean Nouvel, Philippe Starck, Raimund Abraham -- some of the most highly regarded architects of today -- do not describe themselves as Surrealists. Nor will they necessarily welcome being tagged with the name of an art movement that not long ago was thought to have passed irretrievably into history. Their work is emphatically of the present. But, like Surrealism, it reckons with the dark turbulence and contradictions of the inner life. It challenges the conventional view of architecture as the art of putting an ordered public face on things. 
 Intentionally or not, every building says something about the psyche. But in the century following Freud's earliest research, architects have not made conspicuous use of his ideas. In theory, at least, the modern movement took its cue from industrial technology. The standardized, the rational, the functional: modern architects embraced values they took to be consistent with scientific objectivity.
Post-modern architecture, as practiced by Robert Venturi and Denise Scott Brown, Robert A. M. Stern, Michael Graves and Charles Moore, is one line of development leading out of the disillusionment with modern orthodoxy. But in the mid-1970's another path was opened by architects who resisted the post-modern infatuation with period styles. Emilio Ambasz, James Wines, Aldo Rossi, Peter Eisenman, the Miami firm of Arquitectonica, Bernard Tschumi, Mr. Gehry, Mr. Koolhaas: in the work of these architects, subjectivity takes command. Like Surrealists, these architects seem determined to blur the border between waking reality and the dream state. A range of projects, newly completed or under way, has broadened this line of development into a major theme: the playful, the fantastic, the morbid, the mad, the aggressive, the absurd. Introducing such ideas into architecture will strike some as perverse, willful or contrary. It may be, however, that the perverse and contrary is the most sensible response to a changing public realm.
 
The Skyscraper As Guillotine
Leave it to a native of Freud's hometown to design a New York skyscraper's nightmare of its own castration. Louis Sullivan, considered the father of the skyscraper, once said its main feature is that it is tall. When the Austrian Cultural Institute, designed by the Vienna-born Raimund Abraham, finally is built on East 52d Street, near Fifth Avenue, it may be the first skyscraper to confess the fear engendered by the fantasy of tallness: a building that appears to slice itself down to size even as it rises.
A slim, midblock tower that tapers as it rises to a height of 20 floors, the building will be clad on the street side by three overlapping planes of glass that jut out sharply, like blades, on their lower edges. Mr. Abraham has compared the facade to a guillotine, a comment that has provoked the displeasure of those who see something uncivil in such a violent image. That's not surprising. Urban life is violent enough as it is. Architecture itself can be violent. Buildings blot out light and views as effectively as blindfolds. They menace cherished landmarks and the memories associated with them. They displace people from their homes. Do we want buildings to dramatize architecture's incessant assault on the city? Wouldn't we prefer architects to mask their aggressiveness behind polite facades? By restricting architects to the safe, the pleasant, the familiar, are we not condemning them to practice their art as a kind of decorative repression?
No design can settle the questions raised by Mr. Abraham's plan. It is enough that he has raised them. Unfortunately, the Austrian Government has stalled construction of this project because of political wrangling back home. Austria has given us Sacher torte and crystals, Lippizaner stallions and the Vienna Boys Choir, but surely it is Freud who has had the greatest impact on contemporary New York culture. Mr. Abraham has honored that impact with a design of uncommon elegance, honesty and insight.
 
Philippe Starck's Labyrinth of Style
There's no name out front, just an imposingly tall, dark green hedge beneath a pristine white Art Deco facade. This is the Delano, currently Miami Beach's most fashionable hotel. Designed by Philippe Starck, the Delano is the creation of the former nightclub impresario Ian Schrager. Together, the pair have collaborated on the Royalton and the Paramount, two of the most imaginatively designed public spaces New York has seen in years. The Delano is their most impressive work thus far.
The hedge outside is the box tree that mazes are made of. Pass behind it, and you fall into a labyrinth of style. Billowing white curtains frame the terrace at the Delano's entrance, and a huge white lamp shade hangs over it. In the breeze, the shade jerks around like a ghostly, demented bell; at night, the swaying cone of light turns the terrace into a stage for shadow dancing. Beyond the front doors, the whole hotel is aligned around a single grand axis, extending from the lobby past sitting areas, breakfast room, bar and restaurant to the lush pool area in the rear. The elongated perspective is hypnotic; you feel tugged forward, as in a trance, through endless white curtains. It is the scene a Hollywood set designer would envisage for an exquisitely choreographed dream sequence in which a movie star searches for an elusive lover.
Philippe Starck is the most explicitly Surrealist designer in practice. White cast-iron lawn furniture installed in the shallow end of the pool, living room furniture beneath trees outdoors, European-style street lamps suspended between rows of palms: Mr. Starck's indoor-outdoor reversals and juxtapositions call forth a Magritte apparition beneath a Miami moon.
The Delano's most surreal element is surely its fabulousness, its unrelenting flow of wit and chic. Fabulousness is intimidating, at least for those who court it. It is selective, yet cannot be considered undemocratic; entree depends not on birth or money or even achievement but on sensibility, a quality theoretically anyone can acquire. Moreover, fabulousness is most likely to intimidate those who already have entree, for who can ever be as fabulous as their image?
This is most evident in the hotel's all-white guest rooms. By convention, a hotel room is a place of privacy and security, a home away from home, where you can feel free to be yourself. That freedom is elusive at the Delano, however, where the unrelieved whiteness of walls, floors, fabrics and fixtures reminds you, nannylike, of how you fall short of perfection. Hair in the sink, socks on the floor, these come popping out of the whiteness like dark stains on your cool reputation. Immense mirrors in gilded frames throw in your face the physical flaws that the hotel's basement gym, its penthouse spa, fail to erase. What you need here is not a hairbrush but an airbrush, and perhaps an art director on call at all times.
I loved my stay there last fall precisely because of the self-consciousness the hotel can induce. If Mr. Starck is an artist (I think he is first rate), his artistry goes way beyond his celebrated visual flair. He grasps the social drama being acted out by the sophisticates his flair appeals to. He sees the powerful connection between advanced sophistication and primal fear. Stylishness does not exist in isolation. It must be displayed. And the desire to display a sense of style is inseparably linked to the fear, even the hope, that one's ordinariness will one day be exposed.
 
In Paris and Berlin, Nouvel at Play
Advertising, an industry based on dreams, is responsible for some of the most inventive designs in recent years, like the Venice, Calif., offices of TBWA Chiat/Day, commissioned by Jay Chiat, from Frank Gehry and Gaetano Pesce. Two recent projects by the Parisian architect Jean Nouvel show that he is sharply attuned to the culture of advertising and to the creative challenges it offers architects.
Mr. Nouvel understands the importance of play. He demonstrates this with great wit in the Paris headquarters of CLM/BBDO, which he designed in 1988: the interior resembles a sports arena, in fact games like basketball and badminton are sometimes played there. Ringed by three tiers of offices, the elliptical atrium has a hardwood floor and is furnished with silly, oversize sofas upholstered in a nubbed rubber fabric that recalls basketballs. The stadium illusion is heightened by hydraulically operated skylights that swing upward, like wings, opening the building's interior to the sky.
His Galeries Lafayette on Friedrichstrasse in Berlin, to be completed next month, transports advertising from sender to receiver, from image makers to consumers. The design updates the department stores that stretch along Boulevard Haussmann on the Right Bank of the Seine. These now quaint establishments drew on the most advanced art and techology of their time, and so does Mr. Nouvel.
At the building's core are two cones of glass, touching base to base at the ground-floor level. One points down, admitting natural light into the basement office floors; the second, larger cone rises dramatically, punching holes through the seven selling floors. Like a compressed indoor version of Times Square, the cone is a bombardment of light and color. Designer labels and other signs are projected as holographs onto the glass, which serves as a giant store directory. The effect is like being inside the brain of a compulsive shopper, driven into a frenzy by recurring fantasies of Cacharel, Kenzo and Yves St. Laurent. Perhaps the mind is that of post-Cold War Berlin, now frantically shopping its way back to the West.
 
Frank Gehry's Message of the Rose
In recent years, Frank Gehry has been struggling to translate his personal idiom from the small scale of private houses to the epic scale of major public works. Mr. Gehry's design for the new Guggenheim Museum in Bilbao, Spain, scheduled for completion in 1997, may turn out to be the fulfillment of this profoundly social ambition. The building, part of an immense effort to rejuvenate an aging port city, reflects two of his ruling passions: the industrial cities of the 19th century and a romantic belief in the power of art.
Mr. Gehry's design pays homage to Frank Lloyd Wright's Guggenheim while acknowledging its distance from Wright in time and space. At Bilbao, the central space, like Wright's, is a rotunda, but instead of being tightly wound into a coil the exterior splays emphatically outward. It is as if Mr. Gehry has released the pent-up energy in Wright's spiral by taking a knife to its sides. Strips of metal, marking the scale of the museum's floors, ripple and flare outward into the city in a bold expression of centrifugal force.
Mr. Gehry has called this central form a metallic flower. It's typically generous of him to tease us with a figurative reference; we get to tease him back, with free associations of our own. Like Wright's spiral, Mr. Gehry's flower evokes a metaphor of organic growth while it also restates Wright's religious view of art. In New York, Wright conveyed this idea with the ziggurat, or world mountain, an ancient religious form. In Spain, a predominantly Roman Catholic country, Mr. Gehry delivers the same message with a rose. The central symbol of buildings raised in the Virgin's honor, his flower asserts art's claim to a spiritual dimension. Yet the industrial material from which he fashions the rose brings the form down to earth, honoring the Surrealist idea that art should perform the Promethean task of injecting creativity into everyday life.
 
Rem Koolhaas Is Thinking Big
Most architects talk about scale. Rem Koolhaas talks about "Bigness." In his new book "Small, Medium, Large, Extra Large," a collaboration with the graphic designer Bruce Mau, the Dutch architect equates architecture with the primitive desire to dominate. Big muscles, big cars, big bank accounts, big hair.
Architecture does seem to be going the way of bigness, with the proliferation of superstores, superstadiums, elephantine convention centers, multi-acre residential developments and industrial parks. Some regard this with horror; it allows quantity to displace quality. Mr. Koolhaas takes a more analytic approach. Looking at what scares us can tell us who we are.
The architect has had the opportunity not only to think about bigness but also to build it, as the master planner of Euralille, a major office complex and convention center in Lille, in northern France. The project was designed to take advantage of Lille's proximity to major trading centers of the European Economic Community and the Chunnel. A highway, a metro and a high-speed train converge in the center of the complex. Here Mr. Koolhaas has created an artificial cavern called the "Piranesian Space," after the 18th-century architect best known for his drawings of imaginary, multilevel prisons. By carving away portions of the underground floors, Mr. Koolhaas turns infrastructure into urban spectacle.
Modern architecture could be "surrealist" in this way. The machine imagery of modern buildings exposed the engineering hidden beneath masonry facades, but a modern architect would not deliberately evoke the image of a prison. On the contrary, the machine represented liberation for the modernists, a release from the stifling confinement of outmoded styles. In styling his space after Piranesi, Mr. Koolhaas conveys the image of something infernal. What we see here is not a scene of mechanical efficiency but a spookily Nietzschean display of power.
What do these projects all add up to? That architects can now do weird, scary things? Yes, and also that the public sphere has become weird and scary, at least to those who are made uncomfortable by the degree to which the line between public and private realms has become porous. These are all public buildings. But they project subjective points of view. And they reflect the increasing transformation of the public realm into a stage for the acting out of dreams.
With good reason, people fear that this is a time of withdrawal from the public realm, a time in which objective reality has become an embattled concept. The public realm, it often seems, has been reduced to an arena in which everything is an opinion, all opinions are equal, and truth doesn't stand a chance. These feats of architectural imagination offer no reassurance that such fears are groundless. They do, however, confront those fears, with awareness, sensuousness and rigor. And they suggest that the public realm, while an indispensable fantasy, is a fantasy nonetheless.

HEADLINE: FROM THE INTERACTIVE ENCYCLOPEDIA, 2015 EDITION: WELFARE, END OF

 BODY:
DeParle's "back to the future" look at the United States in 2015 contends that Aid to Families With Dependent Children is the glue that holds this country together and that in its absence chaos will ensue. However, a look at the past 20 years hardly suggests that A.F.D.C. has solved the problems of the poor. If anything, the increases in single-parent families, teen-age pregnancies, teen-age unemployment and crime, child abuse and other markers of social decline seem to indicate just the opposite. 
 I have no way of knowing what effect block grants will have on welfare recipients. Neither does DeParle. What we both should know, however, is that the current system needs to be rethought. And rather than politicize the process, Democrats and Republicans should be actively collaborating on experimental efforts to reverse the social blight that A.F.D.C. was intended to erase. If block grants don't work, let's try something else. But let's stop the finger-pointing and the mindless defense of a system that has clearly failed to live up to its promise.

MICHAEL A. COHEN
New York

HEADLINE: SOAPBOX;
Good for Business, Not New Jersey

BYLINE: By ROBERT ANGELO; Robert Angelo operates Capitol Ideas, a consulting firm to unions that specializes in legislative, educational and workplace services.

DATELINE: MILLTOWN

 BODY:
A FAMILIAR roadside billboard offers this message: "A Better Business Climate Means More Jobs." It's a catchy little phrase, a variation on the old adage, "What's Good for Business Is Good for America." They both have the ring of common sense. But last week's bombshell from AT&T -- the decision to lay off 40,000 employees, including as many as 7,000 in New Jersey -- shows how wrong common sense can be.
Over the last year, New Jersey corporations have re-engineered hundreds of jobs out of existence, while hundreds more have been lost when companies moved out of state. The recent closing of the Wonder Bread bakery in East Brunswick alone cost the state 500 jobs. 
 Companies have yielded to the demands of their investors who want their financial position maximized, even if it means undercutting or eliminating the positions of loyal and skilled workers. The record of recent business downsizings shows that the more severely a company cuts wages, benefits and the work force, the more respect it gains in the financial community. Lean and mean corporations are the darlings of Wall Street.
Workers in New Jersey are having a lot of trouble coming to terms with the mean side. What happened to the lessons learned in schools, churches and homes that hard work and a clean record are rewarded with a solid job and at least a measure of economic security? What happened to the hallowed notion that companies have some measure of loyalty to their workers and their communities? Or that American workers share to some degree in the fruits of increased productivity?
And beyond all that, what happened to our assumptions that our elected representatives would fight for the rights of workers?
The pro-business agenda, so popular these days in Trenton, simply reflects the philosophy of those highway billboards: Let business do what business "must" do. If that means leaving the state or paring jobs to the bone, so be it.
Last year, Governor Whitman bragged about the new jobs that have been created by her administration, which she attributed to her tax cuts. The theory is that New Jersey will attract more businesses because their employees will be paying lower tax rates. In fact, the vast majority of these new jobs are minimum-wage or part-time work. That must be of little solace to the thousands of New Jerseyans who learned last week that they are not needed anymore, and who will now pay a high social, personal and economic price.
The truth is that the vaunted Whitman tax rollback has done little to halt or even slow down the loss of quality jobs in our state. The emphasis has been on finding ways to pay for the tax cuts with raids on pension funds, stretching out debt payments, privatization and optimistic revenue predictions. A tax reduction cannot seem like much of an answer for the thousands of New Jerseyans who have lost their jobs to corporate downsizing or privatization schemes.
Instead of accepting the human tragedy of unemployment as merely the cost of doing business in a global economy, the Governor should step forward on workers' behalf and let the corporate community know that the "better business climate" they want so badly must include a sense of fair treatment, human compassion and community responsibility.
Then, she should start using the tools we have, and find new ones, to preserve our quality jobs, and to develop a new generation of skilled and knowledgeable workers capable of attracting new employers to the state.
For example, she should demand additional funds for successful training initiatives like the New Jersey Work Force Development Partnership Program. She should give community colleges incentives to provide more educational options in forward-looking areas like healthcare and technology. She should increase the use of state programs that reward employers who maintain or develop new quality jobs.
The AT&T layoffs should send a strong message to Trenton: There comes a time when what's good for business may be bad for the rest of us, and that time has come to New Jersey.

HEADLINE: Bad for Real Estate, Good for the Arts

BYLINE: By AMY D'ORIO 

 BODY:
DAVE BORAWSKI of East Hartford decided to have an art show this spring, but he didn't approach galleries or museums. Instead, he approached city landlords.
Within the time it would take galleries just to view a few slides, Mr. Borawski said, he secured space, and free space, too, for his one-day show. The space was empty, so why not, said John Pinone, one of the owners of Hartford's Civic Cafe. Mr. Pinone even called it good business because many of his restaurant patrons support the arts. 
 This was not Mr. Borawski's first time setting up a temporary gallery in empty office space. Last year, he received permission to have a monthlong show in an empty building in Middletown. Some of his friends, he said, used an old Shelton girdle factory for an exhibition.
Not all is free, but space has certainly become less expensive to rent, making it possible for a group of young artists in Danbury, among others, to start a gallery to display their work every day.
One of the artists, Chris Durante, said trying to get a show at a gallery is hard enough, being young and unconventional makes it almost impossible. To have their own gallery, and one that's only a few steps from Main Street, definitely changes their prospects. Mr. Durante said the low rent made the gallery, called 13, financially possible.
Indeed, because of Connecticut's glut of empty office and industrial space, artists are finding opportunities they did not have in the bustling 1980's.
"It almost seems like a windfall," Mr. Pinone said.
Especially since artists do not have the best reputation as good tenants, said Michael Roer, president of the Bridgeport Innovation Center. Besides taking up only small spaces, artists often do not pay on time and many try to live in studios, which can create zoning problems, he explained.
Mr. Roer says he rents to artists because he believes it is good for the community. Other business executives do not share his views, but they too are currently carving up large warehouse spaces and creating studios for artists because the real estate market dictates it.
Some landlords even offer free exhibition space to attract the artists. "We are getting a lot of cooperation from the depressed real estate market," said Linda Dente, a Connecticut Commission on the Arts program manager.
These opportunities have resulted in slightly offbeat showcases, but it has stimulated the arts community, she said.
"Strange venues," Ms. Dente said. "Then, again, if you live your life in the arts, it is not so strange."
Artists are often the first to arrive in a depressed area, attracted to the low rent. They help revitalize the community, Ms. Dente said.
This cycle is so well established that business organizations actually seek out the partnerships when tough times come.
"It is a 20-year cycle that keeps happening," Ms. Dente said. "The arts are always the first to come back to urban centers. Then, things begin to percolate."
While the arts are good for revitalization, revitalization is not always good for the arts. Once there is a healthy real estate market, rising rents make it hard for many arts organizations and artists to exist, Ms. Dente said.
She said she hoped the business community would protect the artist during this cycle because the arts deserved a permanent home in each community.
In the 1980's in downtown Hartford, the real estate boom took a thriving arts community and slaughtered it, said Will K. Wilkins, executive director of Real Art Ways of Hartford.
Organizations were forced from their downtown locations because of incoming highrises.
Real Art Ways moved three different times.
"We were one of the few that survived," Mr. Wilkins said, adding that he does not intend to subject his organization to such tumult again.
In 1989, he moved his organization from downtown Hartford to a place where he hopes is a haven from the ups and downs of real estate: Arbor Street in Hartford's Parkville section.
"It is a working-class neighborhood, so it won't ever be gentrified," he said.
Real Art Ways signed a 30-year lease for a 12,500-square-foot space and is planning a major renovation of it.
If the money can be raised, as it is hoped, the organization plans to expand by building a 200-seat movie theater, a 235-seat performance theater, three gallery exhibition spaces, a cafe for 125 people and an outdoor concert arena.
The landlord, Paul Sciarra, owns 225,000 square feet of space on Arbor Street. He said he never planned to rent to artists, but he could not afford to turn them away.
"My motto was, 'Just fill it,' " he said.
In hindsight, renting to Real Art Ways turned out to be a good business decision, Mr. Sciarra said. After Real Art Ways set up on Arbor Street six other arts-related organizations followed.
Now, he estimates about 20 percent of his tenants are artists or art-related businesses.
Not only do they rent from him, but he has found their presence helps him market his building, because they attract publicity and foot traffic.
Mr. Sciarra and Mr. Wilkins seem to have formed an alliance, one that portends to be long term.
Mr. Sciarra said he no longer expected to lease to large companies even if the economy approves. His game plan is to keep the arts organizations and artists -- as well as other small businesses -- in his buildings.
Joan Appicelli, manager of Erector Square in New Haven, has a similar situation.
Erector Square is a 400,000-square-foot complex in Fair Haven.
Gardella Brothers, a trucking business, purchased the property in 1969 because its customers needed warehouse space. Slowly, this need diminished and the Gardella Brothers rented to a few large companies.
But these companies moved out one by one, as part of the overall exodus of manufacturing from Connecticut.
"We got more and more calls from artists," Ms. Appicelli said.
With the 400,000 square feet of space to rent, Ms. Appicelli was not keen to let out small spaces to individual artists, but one floor of Erector Square was divided up into studio space.
"We could not get the walls up fast enough," she said.
Now, about 30 percent of her tenants are artists. Ms. Appicelli is certain large-scale manufacturing will not return to Erector Square. Large companies find it more efficient to operate in other parts of the country, plus, they prefer buildings that do not have multiple floors.
She said artists and small businesses are now part of her permanent market, and therefore, she has cultivated an environment to attract these customers. She provides juried shows and runs a gallery. Erector Square sponsors shows, and artists are also allowed to rent space for their own exhibitions.
Like Mr. Sciarra, she too has found the artists have helped promote her buildings. She said some tenants were initially not pleased with the Fair Haven neighborhood, but then they see the gallery "and it changes their outlook."
Some large landlords may always need to rent to artists now that major manufacturing has left Connecticut Mr. Roer said.
When the economy gets better, however, they will again be the exception and not the rule. As Mr. Roer sees it, communities must engineer a way for the arts to exist in every economic condition because the arts are good for business in good times as well as bad.

HEADLINE: The View From: Westport;
The Curious Case of a Cobblestone, 7-Sided, 19th-Century Barn

BYLINE: By BOBBI P. MARKOWITZ 

 BODY:
A CURIOUS-SHAPED cobblestone barn, nestled behind the Westport Historical Society's headquarters in the center of town, is finding a new career as a municipal museum.
The Bradley-Wheeler Barn and the Wheeler House headquarters were purchased by the historical society in 1981. Although the house had been inhabited and well-maintained from 1795 to 1980, the barn, which was built between 1846 and 1857, had been neglected since the 1920's. Having raised enough money to complete restoration of the Italianate house, it was time to concentrate on the collapsing barn. 
 In 1984 a 12-member committee was formed to consider the building's future. The crumbling carriage barn would be a challenge indeed. The committee, headed by Leo Cirino, a longtime resident of Westport and a teacher in Bridgeport, hired an architect, Robert T. Gault, to provide some guidance.
"We had a deteriorated historical structure which was unsafe and literally collapsing," Mr. Cirino said. "When we started we had absolutely no idea as to where we were going and what costs would be involved because there was no precedent. We took it step by step."
The committee determined a working construction budget of $300,000 to $350,000. Eve Potts, an active proponent of preserving the history of Westport and a founding member of the barn restoration committee, said: "It's always expensive to do a project like this. Funding is invariably a problem, and this was no exception. It has taken us 10 years because of the ups and downs we've had with financing."
Ms. Potts researched and wrote proposals for grants. "You really have to fish around and do your homework," she said. "In order to receive grants, you first need to have a viable project. However, the Federal Government has just about dried up as has state funding."
The project received some money from the state's Economic Development Agency and a grant from the Connecticut Historic Commission. Fund-raising events included everything from selling cobblestones to peddling popcorn. Joanne Woodward and Paul Newman stepped in. "Joanne was honorary chairman at our very first fund-raiser," Ms. Potts said. "She's done everything from stuffing envelopes to running galas." And the popcorn was Newman's Own.
Because the fundamental goal of the barn committee was to preserve the integrity of the building, among its first undertakings was determining its original use. From the fall of 1985 through the spring of 1986, an investigation by a then-graduate student in archeology at Yale, Cindy McWeeney, yielded valuable information.
The barn, which has an octagonal roof, has only seven side walls. With excavation it was determined that the structure was not a true octagon and perhaps had been connected to another building at some time. Ceramic shards, glass, food remains and other items found during the dig provided the historical society with clues to the culture of the time, and how to proceed with an authentic restoration.
The exact use of the cobblestone carriage house was never fully established, but speculation fueled lively discussion. Perhaps the cellar was a storage place for vegetables, or even ice. A blacksmith shop theory was quickly nixed because there was no outlet for the top of the chimney and no soot deposit in the flue or any evidence of it ever having been used. Ms. McWeeney thought the light paint and cool interior suggested the barn might have been used for a dairy.
Experts from the Society for the Preservation of New England Antiquities, the National Trust for Historic Preservation and the Historic Connecticut Historic Commission also lent their expertise to the barn project. In addition, engineers were consulted for masonry restoration, strengthening the foundations and deploying the hydraulic jacks necessary for the final exterior restoration.
Mr. Gault described the difficulties inherent in restoration architecture. "Essentially, you're doing things backwards," he said. "You have to take things apart, repair them and put them back. At the same time, you have to be careful not to destroy something from history."
Some supporters, however, were anxious to accomplish the goal quickly and get the museum into use. But others feared a speedy approach might have jeopardized the historic preservation aspect. Three structural engineers advised the committee to just take down the building. But Mr. Gault kept exploring alternatives.
The process began with analysis of the mortar, to formulate what would be used in restoration. It followed with stabilization of existing mortar materials and with the shoring up of the cobblestone walls as well as putting a temporary enclosure over the barn.
All the stones were photographed, removed, numbered and stored away. Liquid grout was pumped into the walls to fill the void. Likewise, the rafters were removed, labeled, documented and replaced. The barn doors and all wood framing were restored. Window repair and rehanging plus a new wooden roof (including soffits, lath, plaster and wood shingles) were completed in the fall of 1994.
And yet, Ms. Potts said, all of this work was preliminary to the true task of the historical society: turning the interior space into a working museum that will tell the story of Westport.
The committee is again at work, this time with a fund-raising campaign to cover costs of interior finishing, lighting and exhibits is under way. Naiad and Walter Einsel, artists who have designed exhibits for Epcot and the Barnum Museum, are working on plans.
The museum will include a time line using photographs and artifacts to teach the history of Westport's past, from its days as a sleepy farming village through its years when a thriving market economy was based on farm products and oysters, and on to the boom years when onions were exported.
Featured will be many of the businesses and industries that flourished as the town grew. Its development as a resort community, with seasonal estates on former farmland, the Irish and Italian immigrants, its discovery by artists and illustrators, the summer colonies at the beaches and the suburban growth after World War II will all be documented.
With the objective in sight, Ms. Potts said, "Westport is really an unusual town. We look forward to giving people an overview of its history."

HEADLINE: A Veto Upsets L.I. Vintners

BYLINE: By JOHN RATHER 

 BODY:
GOV. George E. Pataki's veto of a bill that would have allowed small wineries to ship directly to out-of-state customers has left a sour taste on the East End. Vintners there and the New York Farm Bureau said the proposal, which would have permitted shipping two cases a year to customers in the 12 states that allow out-of-state deliveries, would have benefited premium-wine producers and helped tourism and the economy.
"Right now, we can't ship anywhere outside of New York, which is very limiting for our sales," said Kip Bedell of Bedell Cellars, a 30-acre winery in Cutchogue. "People come in from all over the country to buy our wines. They may take a few bottles, but they can't carry a case home with them on the plane. They want it shipped." 
 Mr. Pataki said in his veto message that the measure would hurt state-licensed liquor stores. He said it might also backfire on the small vineyards by unleashing a flood of mail-order wine from California. California is one of the 12 states with reciprocity. The others are Colorado, Illinois, Indiana, Maine, Minnesota, Missouri, New Mexico, Oregon, Washington, West Virginia and Wisconsin.
A spokesman for the Farm Bureau in Albany, Mark F. Emery, said California wines were already plentiful in liquor stores. "There are already other wines coming in, and they have good access to the New York marketplace," Mr. Emery said.
The East End has 17 wineries and more than 30 vineyards, mostly on the North Fork. Other wine-growing regions are in the Hudson Valley, Chautauqua County and the Finger Lakes, JOHN RATHER

HEADLINE: Pataki's Budget: Mixed Reactions

BYLINE: By JOHN RATHER 

 BODY:
THE $63.8 billion state budget that Gov. George E. Pataki has proposed is causing consternation and winning good reviews on Long Island -- simultaneously.
The reactions, which mirror widely differing opinions about how Mr. Pataki has treated the Island in his first year in office, shows a widening gap between people who applaud Mr. Pataki's goals to shrink government and lower taxes and people who say his policies abandon the poor, penalize the middle class, gut health care and endanger public education. 
 All sides agree that the coming budget struggle reflects the national debate over the role of government that is unfolding in Washington, where the budget deadlock between President Clinton and the Republican-controlled Congress highlights many issues that Mr. Pataki is addressing.
Like the Republicans in Congress, Mr. Pataki, a Republican who was elected last year on a platform that promised lower taxes, spending reductions and tougher treatment of violent criminals, is focusing on health and welfare programs for major cuts.
His proposed budget would cut $1.1 billion from the $9.1 billion state outlay for the Medicaid program for low-income people. The cut, the biggest in the budget, would help Mr. Pataki follow through on his pledge to reduce taxes.
Supporters point out that Mr. Pataki is only containing the explosive increases in Medicaid costs that are higher in New York than in any other state. Detractors say the cuts are especially harmful to Long Island, because of its sizable elderly population. The critics say many families depend on home-care programs to help tend to the aging.
The budget would also reduce welfare programs and place time limits on eligibility. The plan includes $476 million to add 8,000 prison beds, and in a controversial step it would order that violent prisoners be doubled up in cells.
Although the two county jails on Long Island would not be directly affected, longer sentences approved in Albany last year, coupled with reductions in legal aid, are increasing the number of inmates.
Mr. Pataki proposed no cuts in operating aid for school districts. But education officials on Long Island said cuts in spending on special education would have deep effects on the Island, a region that they say is a leader in such programs.
The proposed budget would also deliver a $300 million reduction in business taxes, benefiting a sector that has been among Mr. Pataki's strongest supporters.
"Most people in the business community would say he is heading the state government in the direction we need it to head in," the president of the Long Island Association, Matthew T. Crosson, said. "The business community recognizes that in order for New York to be economically competitive again the level of taxation has to be reduced."
Critics said spending cuts, in addition to burdening the poor and elderly, would inevitably result in higher property taxes.
"I don't know too many people who make $200,000 a year," the minority leader of the Suffolk County Legislature, Maxine S. Postal, Democrat of Amityville, said. "But those are the people who are going to benefit from the Pataki tax break. These cutbacks in programs are going to impact all the rest of us. What he is doing is terribly harmful to the middle class.
"The impact on local property taxes will be tremendous, because we will have to take up the burden of paying for these programs, and the way we pay is with the local property tax, the least fair way to do it."
The Legislature created a commission last month to study ways to eliminate the property tax. Presiding Officer Donald R. Blydenburgh, Republican of Smithtown, said last week that eliminating the tax would be his highest priority. He proposed a referendum, for November 1997, to eliminate the property taxes that are paid to local school districts. Under such an approach, the property tax could be replaced by higher sales taxes, an income tax or another taxing mechanism.
School officials said a more immediate concern was a failure of the budget to restore financing that they said was lost in a deficit-reduction program five years ago.
The president of the Nassau and Suffolk School Boards Association, Lorraine Deller, said the funds had been restored for other regions of the state. But she added that $191 million in aid that Long Island lost had never been returned. That would be 22.5 percent of the state aid to Nassau and 12 percent of the Suffolk total.
Mrs. Deller said the districts' costs had increased in the last five years by 13.7 percent in Nassau and 9.7 in Suffolk.
Mrs. Deller said the proposal to deny increases in operating aid despite higher enrollments and rising costs was "dangerous not only to the stability of our local school systems, but adds to the burden on local taxpayers."
She said many of the 126 districts had cut costs dramatically in recent years but had run out of areas for additional savings.
An effort to shift special-education costs from the state and counties to local districts is troubling, she said, adding:
"With the state's continuously pulling back on its share of funding for education schools have no other choices but to cut back on programs or go back to the local taxpayers." "It's almost like one hit after another," the executive director of the school boards association, Alice F. Willett, said. "Districts that were getting along pretty well before are now almost hitting bottom."
But many elected officials, groups that advocate tax cuts and business leaders say that high taxes for schools are a leading problem and that education costs grew too swiftly in recent years and had to be pruned.
"I think it is the widespread view of the business community," Mr. Crosson said, "that better business practices, or actually basic business practices, applied to most school districts would allow you to supply better education at significantly lower cost."
In other areas health agencies are bracing for reduced state spending. At the Nassau County Medical Center in East Meadow, the executive director, Joseph R. Erazo, said he could not make "any kind of observation at this juncture" about whether county subsidies would be needed if the proposed Medicaid cuts were enacted.
"We are not the only hospital that will be hit," Mr. Erazo said. "But we will be the hospital of last resort for people who are turned away at other hospitals."
At the county hospital Medicare and Medicaid payments account for 70 percent of the $230 million budget.
Mr. Erazo said the possibility of deep Federal and state cuts in medical programs for low-income people and the uninsured might mean that the hospital would have to be ingenious in carrying out its mission to serve poor people.
"We can't spend what we don't have, and we are facing a phenomenon of such magnitude it is hard for us to plan for it," he said. "Local government is being strained enormously by some of the things being done in Washington. The Governor is piggybacking his budget based on what he is prognosticating will happen in Washington. So we are in a very difficult situation."

HEADLINE: HEALTH AND WELFARE;
As Cutbacks Loom, Advocates for Poor Brace for a Hard Year

BYLINE: By BARBARA STEWART 

 BODY:
No year is bountiful for the people who feed and house the poor, the hungry and the homeless. But the prospects of this particular new year are making people at New Jersey's nonprofit social-service agencies flinch.
It is not so much that lawmakers in Washington are shifting responsibility for welfare and other social services into the hands of the states, and requiring single mothers on welfare to find jobs. It is that the programs that would enable these parents to succeed -- job training, literacy classes, subsidized day care and housing, emergency meals and medical care -- are being drastically cut as well. 
 "I grimly predict that 1996, for so many nonprofits, will be sliding back down the ladder to survival mode," said Anne Miller Christensen, director of development at Let's Celebrate in Jersey City. This center, organized by a group of local churches, runs 15 emergency food pantries and 4 soup kitchens that serve 83,000 lunches a year; it has social workers who counsel 2,500 people a year, and it operates a culinary-arts training school for the homeless. Running such a nonprofit agency for the poor, she said, is "like being on a squirrel-cage wheel."
Directors of nonprofit social-service agencies say donations of time and money from individuals have been and will probably continue to be reasonably generous, considering the extent to which most people are pressed for each. But there are fewer and fewer Federal dollars, which provide the backbone of nearly all of New Jersey's social services.
Republicans in Washington disagree that the 1996 budget will hurt New Jersey's poor. "We're not cutting government spending," said Representative Jim Saxton, the Burlington County Republican who is vice chairman of Congress's Joint Economic Committee. "We've just slowed the pace down from what the big spenders in the White House would prefer. Under the Republican seven-year balanced budget plan, most Federal programs will receive more dollars in 1996 than they did in 1995."
New Jersey may be a relatively rich state, with the country's second-highest per capita income. But an unusually high percentage of its poor residents are badly in need of adequate housing -- the state ranks seventh in percentage of low-income residents with severe housing problems.
Although the Federal budget stalemate makes it impossible to predict how much money the state will receive for social-service programs in 1996, advocates widely expect that grants for many social services will be cut in half. That is the money that provides, for instance, nearly 60 percent of the support for the 20-week job-training program at Let's Celebrate in Jersey City. The paradox, Ms. Christensen said, is that without such training, many people on welfare will have no way to become self-reliant.
Most of the 70 or so people who graduate each year from the Jersey City culinary arts school -- who learn cooking, reading and math -- get jobs and keep them. Currently, 66 percent of its graduates are working full time in restaurants or catering companies, including a number of single mothers newly able support themselves and their children.
"The program has been working, but it can't work without funding," said Ms. Christensen. "Everybody thinks: Grumble, grumble, I'm working so hard -- these people don't want to work. That's just not true. There's such a yearning desire of people we know to move up and out. What these folks need is some of the ingredients, in the right order and the right strength. If the right ingredients are missing, it's never going to work."
Barbara Aaronoff, director of the Interfaith Council for the Homeless in Union County, echoes those sentiments. Proposed cuts in state human services money, including money for subsidized day care, will prevent those on welfare from becoming self-supporting, she said.
"Most of the clients I see want to work," she said. "But they need training, education, child care. There needs to be some process so they can go to work."
Advocates for better housing say the prospects for the homeless are no better. "We're going backward," said Matthew Reed, director of the Tenants Preservation Project in Trenton, a group that represents 60,000 subsidized rental households. "Funding is terrible, and the programs themselves are under attack. It's one thing to have to tell people, 'Things are going to get tight.' It's another to say, 'Next year there's no way to tell if you're going to have a place to live.' "
About 120,000 New Jersey families are on waiting lists for subsidized housing. Because no new units are being added, that figure should increase in 1996, Mr. Reed said. The wait, which averages three to six years, may well extend years longer. For the first time since the Government began the Section 8 program for subsidized housing, qualified low-income renters will not be guaranteed renewals of assistance in 1996.
State cuts in housing subsidies are probable; Federal cuts are all but certain, Mr. Reed said. New Jersey's big cities -- Newark, Jersey City, Trenton -- may well wind up with more residents balancing on the margin, or falling into homelessness and destitution. But smaller cities and towns, he said, will come to realize that they too have residents who depend on subsidized housing and other programs.
"The magnitude of proposed cuts are severe enough that it's difficult for people to imagine," he said. "City councilmen, mayors, state officials -- they'll all be in the position of having to pick up the pieces."
The State Legislature may offer advocates like Mr. Reed some good news in an otherwise unrelievedly gloomy outlook for 1996. A $290 million bond issue to develop inexpensive housing is under consideration for the November ballot. This would be an example of the state's taking over a task long handled by the Federal Government.
But people in nonprofit agencies are not hopeful that volunteer workers and donors can fill the need left by Federal cutbacks in other areas. Services for the homeless and poor are simply too labor-intensive to be done entirely by volunteers, said Ms. Christensen of Let's Celebrate.
"We spend all our time stitching the basics together," she went on. "We think, Gee, if only we didn't have to spend all our energy on mere survival. If only we could use our brilliance, our smarts, on putting together bigger and better solutions."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Let's Celebrate, a nonprofit coalition in Jersey City, says its services, like this soup kitchen, will have to fight to survive in 1996. (Dith Pran/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: ON POLITICS;
Congressional Deadlock As a Campaign Tool

BYLINE: By Iver Peterson; Iver Peterson is Trenton bureau chief of The New York Times.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
A little more than a year ago the Republicans were campaigning against Democratic gridlock on Congress, and we all know what happened: the Democrats got creamed.
Now we are beginning to hear the Democrats campaign against Republican deadlock, specifically, Gingrichian deadlock, in Congress. Will Republicans be hoist on their own petard? Representative Robert G. Torricelli, the likely Democratic nominee in the United States Senate race this year, is itching to light the fuse. 
 "These weeks of deadlock define the race for the U.S. Senate," Mr. Torricelli said in an interview. It will be the contention of the Democratic campaign that the Zimmer record is indistinguishable from Newt Gingrich and that nothing demonstrates this better than the Zimmer votes to keep the Government closed.
"Zimmer," of course, is Representative Richard A. Zimmer of Hunterdon County, the presumptive Republican nominee to go against Mr. Torricelli. His response is a variant of "not so fast."
"If we shut down the Government," Mr. Zimmer began, and then cheerfully corrected himself, "I mean, if Clinton shuts down the Government to no useful end, there will be long-term problems for us. But if this strategy to bring about the first balanced budget in generations succeeds, I think it will be worth the short-term cost."
In other words, if the Republicans can deliver the balanced budget, voters won't care in November that the passport office shut down over Christmas.
So who holds the best hand? Looked at from Mr. Zimmer's point of view, the idea of a little pain now for a lot of gain later is appealing, and the alternative appalling: when the big banks cut their interest rates two weeks ago, they did so on the expectation that the Zimmers in Congress would deliver on the balanced budget and therefore reduce the Government's need to borrow.
If the poll numbers are to be believed, the Republican stonewalling is unpopular, even frightening for many voters; yet if the same pollsters ask, "Do you think Congress and the President should reach a balanced budget?" they unhesitatingly say yes.
One reason for this popular unhappiness with a policy that is popular on paper is that many people are uncomfortable when they are told by Mr. Zimmer and his party to put their values to a test: You want a balanced budget? Then what are you prepared to cut?
The two sides of that coin are likely to be the two sides of the Torricelli-Zimmer contest this year, and New Jerseyans should consider themselves lucky to be the arbiters of such a classic social science debate.
With the memory of the shutdown fading, Mr. Torricelli will point out that Mr. Zimmer has voted consistently with his quixotic leader, Speaker Gingrich, to end entitlements to Medicaid and welfare, thereby cutting the growth in Federal funds to New Jersey. He will say that making Medicare patients pay at least $800 a year in higher premiums by the end of 2002 (when the budget is supposed to be balanced) is cruel, when many Medicare recipients subsist on Social Security stipends of less than $14,000 per year. And that just as the cuts in Federal subsidies will hurt the poorest and benefit the richest, so Mr. Gingrich's changes in environmental rules will chiefly benefit investors.
And he will point out that as the budget impasse dragged on, not even Senator Bob Dole of Kansas was willing to continue the standoff, while Mr. Gingrich, and Mr. Zimmer, stuck to their guns. "There is this ideological extremism that has gained disproportionate control of the Federal Government," Mr. Torricelli said. "It is so extreme, even Bob Dole won't go along with it."
Mr. Zimmer conceded that some members of the House Republican Caucus were uncomfortable with the prolonged shutdown, but not many. "Regardless of some differences in conference, there is close to unanimous support for hanging tough," he said. Translation: It's too late to turn back.
In November, New Jerseyans will be able to choose which version they like best.

HEADLINE: NEW JERSEY & CO.;
From Discounts to Diaspora: A Bazaar Starts to Fold Its Tent

BYLINE: By RICHARD D. SMITH 

DATELINE: NEW BRUNSWICK

 BODY:
A handwritten sign in Craft Plus says "Clearance Store Wide."
For the proprietor, Rebecca Mutahi, storewide is an 8-by-10-foot stall she rents at U.S. No. 1 Flea Market & Antiques. The clearance is necessary because the market -- an everything-under-the-sun bazaar that may be the state's largest indoor venue for independent discount merchants -- will soon be torn down to make room for a 16-screen movie theater. 
 Ms. Mutahi, 24, who came to America from Kenya in 1993, established her African art and jewelry business a year ago. She stands to lose a $12,000 investment, most of it borrowed on credit cards, she said. She will try to sell her remaining inventory and then seek work in data entry.
"It's like running from a lion into a hot fire," she said. "It's so frustrating."
Since its opening in October 1975 in the hulk that was once the Great Eastern discount department store, the U.S. No. 1 Flea Market has been a destination not only for antiques buyers but also for bargain hunters seeking new clothing and household goods, tapes and toys, gifts and groceries.
It was home to 250 to 400 vendors, depending on the season. Now it has fallen victim to competition from proliferating malls, the retail recession -- and a better offer.
Sony Theaters of New York has signed a long-term lease for the 35-acre site with its owner, the Sheldon Elizabeth Company of Roseland. Plans call for a 60,000-square-foot theater, two restaurants of between 200 and 300 seats each and a 70,000-square-foot retail space to open in the fall.
In October, vendors were told that the market would close on Dec. 31. But the 140-member merchants' association argued that notice was too short and won an extension until March 31. However, the diaspora of mom-and-pop businesses from the market has already begun.
Some are moving to a smaller rival, the Route 18 Market in East Brunswick. Some are looking for stand-alone stores or good deals on mall space.
Wayne Shiao, 40, owner of the Gold Mart, said he would use the extension to find a location combining low rent and high security for his jewelry business. Mr. Shiao, who came to the United States from Taiwan in 1980, had a store on Long Island for seven years and has been at the U.S. No. 1 Flea Market for three. Mr. Shiao was taking the move in stride, calling it "a small problem."
Others are expressing more anxiety. Jim Morrison, 58, of Jim's Auto Improvement Center, an accessories supplier, estimates he will have to spend $500 a month on inventory storage and at least $10,000 to move.
"I'm prepared to go a year without an income," said Mr. Morrison, who is looking at a space in Union but fears that his current local patrons will not drive that far to buy from him.
Sham Rao, 38, a native of Bombay, India, has already established a second location for his Bare Essentials lingerie store in Union. But the U.S. No. 1 site, he said, does about 30 percent more business.
For some, the prospect of leaving such well-trafficked aisles has been devastating. When word about the closing came just before the busy Christmas season, one long-established vendor suffered a nervous breakdown.
"He can't handle it," said his wife and business partner, who spoke on condition of anonymity. "We're being forced into early retirement."
Meanwhile, the owners of Phoenix, which has been selling clothing, crafts, incense and gifts at the market for 20 years, are using the flea market's closing as an opportunity.
The owners, Michael Peler, 46, and Kathy Dobozinski, 42, will relocate to a branch they opened in Beach Haven five years ago. But because it's only a seasonal Jersey-shore location they will keep in touch with customers year-round through a catalogue and an 800 number.
"One door closes and another opens up," Mr. Peler said. "It's just part of life."
John McGhee, 59, of the Donigan Collection is also maintaining his optimism. Mr. McGhee, who began selling collectible figurines of black Americans four years ago after a 27-year career at the Ford Motor Company plant in nearby Edison, plans to travel the craft show circuit this spring and then open a store in downtown New Brunswick.
"We've got a good clientele now," Mr. McGhee said. "We can make the jump to a storefront."
Mayor James Cahill of New Brunswick said the city's economic and community development offices have offered to help merchants relocate.
Responding to complaints that that the Sony multiplex will employee only 60 people, Mr. Cahill said that few flea market vendors live in New Brunswick and their profits largely go elsewhere. He also said Sony's estimated $10 million project would increase the taxable value of the property.
The vendors have been here on a month-to-month basis. So has Ray Travis, the market's manager, who in 1975 leased the empty 175,000-square-foot department store on Route 1 South overlooking the Raritan River and opened its doors to retail entrepreneurs.
"It's an expensive piece of property to operate, and the money ultimately comes from the floor," said Mr. Travis, who declined to give specific figures but said the market could never generate the rent that Sony can afford to pay.
Mr. Travis has offers to manage other markets. As for the merchants he rented to, he said: "I've watched people come to rent space and they didn't have nickel one or know what they were doing," he said. "And they got started and changed their world around.
"They're going to be all right," he said, "because these are some of the best and toughest merchants I've ever known."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Hundreds of vendors will be displaced by a new 16-screen movie theater. (Dith Pran/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: For Homeless, a Long, Cold Winter Ahead

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER 

DATELINE: YONKERS

 BODY:
LIKE other homeless people who sleep on benches in the train station here, 40-year-old Brenda Chester lives precariously in the winter, seeking warmth from the few rays of sunlight that make it through the dusty windows of the waiting room.
Naomi Williams, an educator for the Sharing Community, a church-sponsored organization that feeds and shelters the poor and homeless, said of Ms. Chester: "More and more I fear that some of them like her will die. There's a long, cold winter ahead." 
 This winter could be especially hard for Ms. Chester, who was recently denied all public benefits for six months because she failed to comply with some of the county's newly tightened regulations. An admitted former heroin and crack addict who now drinks heavily, she said she was penalized because she did not file required medical documents with the county's Department of Social Services.
"Now I'm always in danger, living this way," she said, angry at having to fend for herself. "Life's hard out here."
But life may get even more difficult for Ms. Chester and the 3,600 other homeless people in Westchester this winter. Gov. George E. Pataki's proposed budget for 1996-97 sharply limits welfare benefits and encourages work and independence. The Governor contends that his plan would, among other things, discourage poor people from moving to the state in search of generous benefits.
Critics, however, say Mr. Pataki's plan would only cause further despair among the state's needy and throw many onto the streets, further swelling the ranks of the homeless.
According to the County Department of Social Services, there are 743 single homeless people in Westchester and 871 homeless families with 1,792 homeless children. The figures are incomplete, however, because they do not indicate how many adults are in each household.
Officials say the causes of homelessness vary, ranging from eviction by family or friends because of overcrowding -- by far, the most common reason -- to eviction for other reasons, including nonpayment of rent, burned-out housing, discharge from hospitals and other institutions, domestic violence and drug and alcohol abuse.
Ms. Chester said she was estranged from her male companion and her two daughters when she became addicted to drugs, and she had no place to go but the streets.
In the case of Diane DiNunzio, it was the loss of her job as a practical nurse three years ago and a threatened eviction that took her and her family to the offices of the Department of Social Services. She and her husband, John, who is also unemployed, and their three children were temporarily housed in the Coachman Hotel in White Plains.
The family is planning to move shortly from a one-room apartment in transitional housing to larger quarters.
Mrs. DiNunzio said that her children -- one of them is on the wrestling and football teams and another is on the swimming team -- will continue attending public school in White Plains.
It costs the county about $110 a day to house a homeless family in a motel and $84.37 for a shelter. As of Nov. 30, 21 families and 10 singles or childless couples were in motels, and the rest were in emergency shelters or transitional housing, statistics showed.
Westchester budgeted $46.3 million in 1995 to feed, transport and house its homeless population, almost $4 million more than the year before.
The incidence of homelessness in Westchester is 1.4 percent of the population -- one of the highest rates in the country and even higher than New York City's 1.2 percent. Over a 10-year span, the number of homeless in the county grew to 3,614 last year, from 1,173 in 1985, according to officials.
"Overall, things are getting worse, not better, for a large part of our population," said the Rev. George Anthony Hoeltzel, an Episcopal priest and the executive director of the Sharing Community.
Father Hoeltzel said that his organization, which is financed in part by the county, was formed in 1983 to get people through that winter only, and that it now has a staff of 62 and operates year round, serving meals to the poor and offering shelter to homeless men.
"Here we are 13 years later with even more work before us," he said, observing that attendance at the Sharing Community's Thanksgiving and Christmas soup kitchen dinners hit record highs in 1995.
But Father Hoeltzel was not optimistic that his organization and others like it would be able to continue meeting the needs of the needy. He said the current political climate in Washington and Albany "conjures up visions of Dickens" and bodes ill for the future.
At the Department of Social Services, Marion J. LaFranco, assistant commissioner for housing, agreed that her department was struggling in an environment of tightened budgets to meet the growing needs of its homeless clients.
Father Hoeltzel and Mrs. LaFranco blamed Westchester's high cost of living and its lack of affordable housing for the increasing homeless population.
At the mid-Hudson offices of the Volunteers of America, Clifford D. Schneider, director of the nonprofit social service agency, attributed part of the increase to public institutions for the mentally ill "that send patients home with little more than bus fare."
"The next thing you know is that they're in the shelter system with a bagful of medicine, unable to fend for themselves," Mr. Schneider said. "And we're obligated to offer them more than just three hots and a cot."
The Volunteers of America, which is under contract with the county, runs a center for homeless single men at the County Airport, an emergency drop-in center in Valhalla, a residence for mentally ill and other special-needs homeless people in Yorktown and a shelter in Valhalla for homeless people infected with the human immunodeficiency virus, which causes AIDS.
Another nonprofit organization, Westhab, runs about two-thirds of the county's housing for the homeless. Robert Miller, president of the development and management organization, said he oversees 750 units, including a family center in Elmsford, a residence in Greenburgh for men enrolled in a workfare program, the Coachman Hotel for families in transition in White Plains and another family shelter in Mount Vernon.
Westhab also oversees 350 apartments for families in various places in the county and another 150 permanent apartments for families and single people.
Like other officials working with the homeless, Mr. Miller said he was concerned about the political climate shaping public policy for the needy.
"Our biggest worry is the growing feeling throughout the country that the poor and homeless are at fault for their circumstances," Mr. Miller said. "It's unfortunate, but we don't see government at any level willing to put in the resources to solve the problems."
Community workers like Ms. Williams at the Sharing Community, who were once homeless themselves, also criticized government at all levels for the unsympathetic approach to people like Ms. Chester.
In particular, though, Ms. Williams said Westchester's system for the homeless amounted to a "revolving door that takes people in and spits them back out on the street."
But Mrs. LaFranco defended her department's policies, saying clients are put off the rolls only after they repeatedly fail to cooperate. She said all clients are assessed when they first apply for help to determine the cause of homelessness and plan a program of remediation.
"At the beginning we ask questions to find out why they're homeless and if they are employable," she said. "Are they mentally ill, substance abusers or are they just burned out of their house?"
She said clients are turned away only after they repeatedly fail to comply with requirements like attending workfare programs or drug- and alcohol-abuse clinics. Even then, she said, they are given the chance to refute a decision at a public hearing.
"Our goal is to get them back to functioning," she said. "It would be more heartless to just let them languish in the shelter system."
But Laurie Chase, executive director of the Coalition for the Homeless in Westchester, a Yonkers-based advocacy group, said: "Some people simply can't complete the requirements. Are we going to let them freeze to death?"

HEADLINE: Westchester Q&A: Ray Seidelman;
How Nonvoters Affect Government

BYLINE: By DONNA GREENE 

 BODY:
FOR political junkies, 1995 was a fascinating year, with the Republicans gaining control of both houses of Congress and Newt Gingrich attempting to push through his "revolution." Likewise, 1996, a presidential election year, promises to be equally intriguing: which forces -- liberal or conservative -- will control the country? Does it matter?
One who watches closely is Prof. Ray Seidelman, a political science professor at Sarah Lawrence College in Yonkers since 1982, who specializes in American politics, voting and political participation. He sees the country divided not so much by conservative-vs.-liberal forces as by the fact that so many of the poor and working class disfranchise themselves by not voting. The result, he says, is an elite democracy. 
 Professor Seidelman is the co-author (with Bruce Miroff and Todd Swanstrom) of two college textbooks. The more recent, "Debating Democracy: A reader in American Politics" (Houghton Mifflin) is scheduled for publication this year. A resident of Ossining, he was an antiwar activist in the late 1960's as a college student and active in the 1970's in the Democratic Party.
Professor Seidelman taught a year in China for Johns Hopkins University and was a Fulbright Scholar in Korea. Here are excerpts from a recent conversation with him:
Q. You believe that people do not vote more out of dissatisfaction than because of apathy?
A. Yes. The conventional explanation is that people are apathetic. That implies that they don't care: they don't think they will make any difference or that they're not very knowledgeable. I combat that explanation by some of the research I have done.
Generally speaking, the case I try to make is that it's not people who have left the political system but that the political system has left them. The language that the political system speaks -- talking about the deficit and entrepreneurial language like "we have to revive business and give capital-gains tax cuts to business" -- doesn't turn on most people, especially those who don't vote.
Therefore, people perceive politics as defined by terms and languages and debates they really don't understand. And there's good reason they don't understand it. The political debate is geared toward the affluent and doesn't speak to the concerns of people who are not affluent.
Q. Do people feel that no matter what they do it will not make a difference?
A. Most of the polls of nonvoters -- and for that matter many of the polls of voters -- demonstrate that it's not so much apathy as exactly what you said -- people don't feel they can make a difference, and they don't feel their vote will necessarily matter. Politics seems to come from on high; it's something other people do.
That serves the interest of very powerful interests in American politics in the sense that it confines politics to people who have the resources to participate, especially those with money.
The political system becomes much more geared toward the affluent, those people who have those kinds of resources, such as E-mail, the ability to call members of Congress and the ability to send out a check or give out a credit card number over the phone to a political organization, whether it be the National Rifle Association or the American Association of Retired Persons.
These organizations become what I call mail-order politics. Instead of encouraging conversations among the people who are their members, they tend to be lobbying organizations concentrated in Washington. And when that happens politics becomes professionalized and dominated by experts.
Q. How do you feel about this?
A. I think it's a real threat to the best traditions of American democracy. It explains why a lot of things that are happening in our economy are just not discussed that much in the current debate in Washington -- such as the tremendous and growing wage inequality, tremendous insecurity most people feel today in their jobs, the absence of pension protection and health care insurance. All these things are mentioned in politics, but they are certainly not mentioned to the extent that they would be if nonvoters voted in massive numbers. That's why our political debate is dominated by things such as tax cuts for the wealthy. We have a Democratic president who to many people sounds like an Eisenhower Republican in the sense that Democrats used to be pro unions.
Q. Do you think things would change if large numbers of working-class people became more active?
A. I certainly do. If you have a party and only invite people who make over $150,000, the conversation is going to be very different from what you'd hear at a party to which you invite lots of poor people. To a certain extent if poor people and middle-class people organize and vote in greater numbers, the agenda of politics would change to reflect their concerns.
People care about these issues, but the parties today are not organized to talk about them. Look at the Democratic Party: about 10 years ago corporate contributions to the Democratic Party began to exceed the amount that came from labor.
So we have a two-party system, one of which is almost totally funded by the affluent, the Republicans; the other of which is, for the most part, also funded by the affluent, the Democrats.
The leadership of the Democratic Party has a problem on its hands. Its money pushes it to the right, but its constituencies remain unorganized. So the party can't come out and talk about opposing Nafta because it insults the business wing of the party. You can't fire Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, whom business loves, and appoint someone who is more concerned with raising wages.
I like to quote an article called "Bowling Alone" by Robert Putnam. In it he says there are more people bowling than ever, but there are fewer people in bowling leagues. He argues that bowling is not just entertainment, it was a way for people to associate with people who would otherwise be strangers.
We have very few means to do that in America today. We tend to look at other people through TV, instead of through grass-roots associations, whether they be political or social or recreational. These mixed people together: they conversed and shared power with each other. There is a big difference between those kinds of associations and, say, being a member of the AARP.
Q. Do you think the country is ripe for a third party?
A. The surveys tend to show that over half of the American public would welcome a third party. The problem is that if you look more closely there is a lot of division among people who want a third party, and that means we would need four or five parties to have a fully represented system. But there are tremendous obstacles to that, such as the election laws for getting on the ballot and the fact that, generally speaking, people who are disgusted with the parties don't participate.
Q. Why is President Clinton suddenly coming up in the polls?
A. Bill Clinton was elected with 43 percent of the vote. He received about one out of five votes of the voting-age population. The Republican Party in 1994 got approximately 51 percent of the 37 percent of those who voted.
So two out of three people almost didn't vote in 1994. We're talking about a narrow slice of the American electorate in both cases. I think to claim that Clinton had a mandate in 1992 or that the Republicans had one in 1994 is wrong in both cases. The central fact in American politics is that elections don't convey mandates anymore.
Once Clinton started talking about things like Republicans stripping Medicare and the Clean Water Act going down the toilet, people responded. But Clinton flip-flops between being a person who talks to ordinary people and a person who advocates moderate-to-conservative social policies.
