HEADLINE: A Plan for the Butternut

BYLINE: By ANNE C. FULLAM 

DATELINE: CROSS RIVER

 BODY:
THE United States Forest Service is looking for a few good butternut trees. A grafting program that it hopes will save the species from a deadly fungus needs more grafting shoots or twigs. Butternut is dying nationwide.
Locally, dead trees were found in the Ward Pound Ridge Reservation in Cross River. A state forester, Robert Herberger, found the specimens growing close to Honey Hollow Creek. One dead tree, estimated to have been 50 years old when it fell in 1987, was girdled with large cankers. A narrower growth encircled a live, 15-year-old specimen nearby. 
 "The shame is that this tree isn't even old enough yet to produce nuts," Mr. Herberger said, pointing to the live tree.
Discovered in Wisconsin in 1967, the disease has spread throughout the range of butternut, which extends from Minnesota to Mississippi to Maine. The nuts are prized by animals and cooks, but butternut trees provide valuable wood known as white walnut. Like its close cousin black walnut, which is not affected by the disease, butternut is used in fine furniture, paneling and woodcarving. Experts say they fear that butternut could disappear if an all-out effort to find disease-resistant trees is not made.
In New York, where butternut is second only to black walnut in economic value, foresters are surveying the entire state for healthy butternut trees. Sick trees exhibit oval-shaped cankers that ooze inky fluid.
"The general symptoms are dieback of twigs and branches or whole trees," said Michael Birmingham, a supervising forester in the state's Department of Environmental Conservation in Albany. "I don't know if a wound by an insect is necessary. It can be wind-borne, or rain splash can spread it or trees with crowns interlocked. The spores require suitable media to germinate. If a tree is wounded by a person hitting it with a lawn mower, it would establish an area for disease. There's no lack or shortage of wounds."
Named for the color of its wood rather than the taste of its nuts, butternut grows to 100 feet and lives about 75 years. A skinny tree by hardwood standards, the butternut's diameter rarely exceeds 4 feet. Butternut grows in moist, rich soil, preferring the banks of streams and the edges of meadows. Shade intolerant, butternut will not produce nuts if there is insufficient sunlight. Before the 1860's, it was used in tanning and known as oil nut.
Butternut stamens take the form of catkins, while pistillate flowers of six to eight spikes receive the wind-borne pollen. The nuts are oval-shaped and generally hard to crack.
Once the primary fungus, sirococcus clavigignenti-juglandacearum, invades a wound in the tree, a secondary infection, caused by melanconis juglandis, takes place. The secondary disease alone does not kill the trees. Fungicides, because they kill healthy fungi, are impractical to use in combatting disease except in nurseries or on plantations. Butternut grows mostly in the wild.
Since 1993, Mr. Birmingham has been surveying the state's butternut trees. Of 30 specimens he took in trips to 51 of the state's 60 counties, he found the disease in 26 samples. The 4 negative samples are being retested. "Most butternut in New York State are infected," he said.
Once healthy trees are found, cuttings from them are mailed to Minnesota. At the Forest Service's North Central Forest Experiment Station in St. Paul, the wood is grafted onto black walnut trees, which give their immunity to the butternut. The grafts are returned to the New York nursery in Saratoga Springs, where seedlings are grown for distribution in New York and Vermont, another state where butternut is in decline. Vermont's wood industry depends heavily on butternut trees.
In 1992, Minnesota imposed a moratorium on the harvesting of healthy butternut trees on state land. A year later, the Forest Service put restrictions on healthy butternut in national forests. Currently, butternut is listed under the Federal Endangered Species Act as having evidence of vulnerability. The results of several states' surveys will determine if butternut is declared a threatened species.
Butternut trees have been in trouble since 1923, when melanconis juglandis was first detected. Causing dieback, the fungus could take 20 years to kill a tree. Not so with the new disease.
"I don't think this fungus was around in 1923," said Michael E. Ostry, a research plant pathologist at the St. Paul station. "The botanists were very thorough. They never saw this fungus. It has probably been here since the 1950's, based on aging cankers. We don't know where it came from."
Mr. Ostry continued: "We believe it was introduced from outside the country. The only evidence that would lead us to believe that it is not native is that it fairly rapidly kills trees and fairly rapidly extended its range. There are very few places where we don't find it. There are very few healthy trees. We found a very low level of resistance."
So far, the disease has not affected any other species of tree. "Butternut is its only known natural host," Mr. Ostry said. "It has only been reported a few times on black walnut. It could have come from Asia."
At the molecular level, there is no variation in the fungus. "We don't find the two stages of asexual and sexual," Mr. Ostry said. "We only have the asexual stage. Usually a fungus is quite mutable, but this fungus has not had time to change or recombine. So, we're probably looking at something new."
Based on the success of the public-private partnership known as the American Chestnut Foundation, which saved American chestnut trees from extinction, also by a fungus, state and Federal foresters are asking citizens to report the location of healthy butternut trees for use in the grafting program. The program was started to save the American chestnut.
Identifying strains of healthy butternut trees may take some historical digging, said Daniel F. Millikan, a plant pathologist at the University of Missouri in Columbia, where he has studied butternut trees for more than 50 years. Dr. Milliken remembers nut contests sponsored in the 1930's by the Northern Nutgrowers Association in conjunction with the United States Department of Agriculture.
"They were looking for better quality and quantity from the wild," Mr. Milliken said. "People would send 15 or 20 nuts to Northern Nutgrowers and do the same with fruits. Nuts were selected for size and meat, and they developed cultivars. There was Cracked Susan from Michigan and Buckwheat from Iowa. The U.S.D.A. would recommend propagation. We don't know yet whether any of those cultivars are reistant."
Mostly, butternut has been classified according to the ease with which its meat can be extracted. A famous butternut cultivar in New York State was Chamberlin, found in New Madrid just before World War II by Fred Ashworth. But a strain named Craxezy and discovered around the same time in Union City, Mich., gave it some competition.
Butternut is one of only a handful of native American crops that are used for food or anything at all, said Bill Reid, a horticulturist at Kansas State University in Chetopa. He writes "Kernels of Wisdom," a column in the Kansas Nutgrowers Newsletter and has books from 1886 to the present on nut culture.
"Butternut has commercial value for furniture, specialty custom furniture makers and woodcarvers," said Mr. Reid, a former president of the Northern Nutgrowers Association. "But nut production has never been commercialized. If you study history, species have always disappeared for one reason or another. A species doesn't have genetic resiliency to overcome a pathogen or it could be anything. Why don't we have a lot of things that used to be around?"
 
A Guide to Selecting Trees
Guidelines from the United States Forest Service for selecting healthy butternut trees:
*Candidate trees must be within 100 feet of sick trees. The location indicates that the tree has had a reasonable chance at exposure to the pathogen.
*Trees must be 10 inches in diameter at a height of 10 1/2 inches and must be free of cankers, or if cankers are present, the tree must have overgrown them.
*The manager or property owner must be willing to allow collection of scion wood and seed from the tree for several years.
Retention of trees follows the 70-20-50 rule. Trees with more than 70 percent live crowns and less than 20 percent of their circumference affected by cankers should be retained as well as trees with at least 50 percent of their crowns and no cankers. Dead butternut may be cut.

HEADLINE: Carlos Torres, Plumber In a Sea Of Distrust

BYLINE: By N. R. KLEINFIELD 

 BODY:
BASICALLY everyone thinks Carlos Torres charges too much, but then they back off when he suggests that they do what he does. His company's rate is $87.50 an hour, and he gets aggravated listening to the mocking cracks about the doctors and lawyers, looking to sweeten their already sugary life styles, who abandon their practice to be like him, a plumber.
When he hears opposition to his rate, Mr. Torres points out some of the endless and often appalling items he has to dislodge from toilets: pens, shards of glass, clumps of cat litter, toothbrushes, hairspray tops, toenail clippers, bobby pins, a figure of the Joker from the Batman movie, the cover of Vanity Fair. He yanked out a beeper once, waterlogged into silence. "You know what a lot of people do," he said. "They flush dental floss down the toilet. That's the worst thing. It sticks to the side of the pipe and as paper comes down, it attracts the paper and causes a backup." 
 He expounds about the water bugs big as birds that make his skin crawl. "I've seen, like, thousands of water bugs," he said. "Every plumber has to work around water bugs. It's always a good idea to look around as you work so the bugs don't get you from behind and go in your pants. The thing to do is put the blowtorch on them. They don't bother you then."
He talks about the rats he intrudes upon in the basement sewer lines. When Mr. Torres tries to unclog a line, a rat will sometimes get hooked on his plumber's snake and, when Mr. Torres attempts to extract the snake, curl up into a ball and put up the fight of its life. People hear this, and they say, "Yeah, yeah." You want to be a plumber, you take a lot of grief.
Few people seem to care as much about cracked pipes and clogged drains as Carlos Torres does, and he wants to do all he can to put them in proper working order. Something like 20,000 plumbers fix the labyrinthine network of pipe that transports water through the streets and buildings of New York, and they are a tribe with their own rituals and heroic tales. Mr. Torres is a union man, which means that he earns union scale of $845 a week (benefits bring his personal compensation to about $31 an hour). He handles almost exclusively residential leaks. In the trade, he is known as a jobbing plumber. Conventional stoppages and cracked pipes are known as jobs, as opposed to more involved, longer-lasting renovations and new construction, which get done by alteration plumbers.
Mr. Torres works for Mac Felder Inc., a high-energy place sandwiched into a small town house on West 86th Street. It has been in business since 1936, when it was founded by Max Felder, whose son and grandson, Lawrence and Maxwell, now run it. In the early days, supplies were heaved onto a pushcart and the plumbers shoved them around town, sometimes huffing all the way to Wall Street from the Upper West Side (traffic was lighter then). The neighborhood around the office was Irish, and people thought Max's name was "Mac." He got called Mac so often that he eventually named the company Mac Felder. About 15 plumbers are employed in the shop now, servicing Manhattan and the Bronx, and they get about in vans.
Wiping sleep from their eyes, the plumbers straggled in around 7:30 in the morning, and some of them hung out in the slender garage among the vans parked bumper to bumper, swapping plumbing stories ("You hear about that high-rise, the water two inches deep, the cat swimming through it?"); others retreated to the dingy basement, where there was a shower and endless shelves containing a hodgepodge of spare parts: shut-off valves, faucet stems, tees, pipe, O-rings.
In the office upstairs, Johnny Keaveney, the dispatcher, carefully sorted the assignments, scrawled on yellow sheets, and affixed them to clipboards. Around the office, Mr. Keaveney has acquired a certain cachet for having made it onto "Candid Camera" in the 1960's. He was summoned to unclog a drain in a basement. He inserted his plumber's snake and pulled. It wouldn't budge. He assumed it was a well-muscled rat. In actuality, on the other side of the wall were two bodybuilders who had grabbed firm hold of the snake. "I was strong back then," Mr. Keaveney recalled. "I put my foot against the wall and I pulled both the snake and the entire drain trap out. Then they told me I was on 'Candid Camera.' I said, 'Oh yeah?' "
At 7:45, Mr. Keaveney barked into the intercom, "Show time." The plumbers trooped up the stairs, retrieved their clipboards with murmured grunts and headed out to battle water.
"Hey, Carlos, how you doing," one of the plumbers greeted Mr. Torres.
"Not bad, you?"
"Not bad, but I'm trying," came the reply.
"Well, you're alive," Mr. Torres said. "That counts."
Mr. Torres is 56, with thinning black hair, a neat mustache, clifflike cheeks and a strong jaw. He speaks slowly, his voice caressing the words. He has an earthy, easy-going nature that comes in handy when he gets awakened at 2 in the morning because somebody has water gushing into his apartment ("People call a plumber because they're too lazy to bend over and turn off the shut-off valve. It's crazy.") He wears an olive-colored work shirt and matching pants. As he tools around town in his white Ram van, he puffs on a cigar, a habit that reminds him that he is not excessively sensitive to odors, a highly appreciated trait in his chosen profession.
There is a steady industriousness about Mr. Torres. He is immersed in an often misunderstood existence, a world at once distasteful and oddly satisfying, where life moves in predictable rhythms but has its raffish moments.
 
 
 
DELIVERING THE BAD NEWS
 On West 83d Street, he parked and snatched his plumber's bag, a white canvas sack laden with a mash of tools: pliers, wrenches, screwdrivers, an electric snake, a pipe cutter, channel locks, a blowtorch, solder, gloves, a chisel, a light, a putty knife, a ruler, a vise and some pieces of pipe.
He led the way into the kitchen of the superintendent's apartment. Corroded pipe here, leaking.
"Oh, I've got to take that pipe out," he said straight off. "It's rusted through."
"Do you have to go upstairs, too?" the super asked.
"Yeah," he said, "I have to take the toilet out above here and cut through the floor."
"C'mon, Carlos, don't say that," she pleaded.
"I've got to."
Upstairs, he trooped into the bathroom and gave his rapt attention to the toilet. The landlady, a woman of stern bearing who was fond of never spending a nickel more than absolutely necessary, met him there.
"Can you put some gook on and maybe it'll last another 20 years?" she inquired.
The direct thrust of the question stopped him. "No," Mr. Torres said.
"Well, don't break the tile," she said. "It's a new floor."
The floor had to be broken. The landlady looked as if she had lost her pet.
To do the job, Mr. Torres said he would have to get a new lead vent.
The landlady: "I'm going to go down with you so you can call the office in my presence and have them send over what you need. I don't want you to waste an hour going back and forth."
Mr. Torres nodded and gave a disingenuous smile. He marched downstairs and placed the call with the landlady two-tenths of an inch from his face.
She was still talking: "One guy came here and took three days to change a lead vent. He spent most of his time staring out the window. He said he was thinking about how he was going to do the job."
And still talking: "One of my tenants had all these animals -- gerbils, whatnot. He flushed the stuff from the cage down the toilet and he clogged up two of my drains. I could kill him."
Perched on a ladder, Mr. Torres adroitly sawed the old pipe off. The whoosh of somebody flushing a toilet above. Mr. Torres inserted a new pipe.
The landlady sat and watched. She said: "They could just put the gook in there and it would last 20 years. But they want to do this. You know why? It takes longer. They get more money. It's all money. Money, money."
Hours later, Mr. Torres was on his way, trying to believe the landlady had disappeared from human history. "See, a real glamorous job, huh?" he said. "People treat you so well."
 
 
 
THE FLAWS IN HUMAN NATURE
 Mr. Torres has sound reason for feeling that there will always be strong demand for plumbers. In a brownstone on West 86th Street, he responded to a report of a clogged kitchen drain. He took a look. He had left his plunger in the van. That was all right.
He put the palm of his hand over the drain, worked it up and down twice.
He removed his hand.
The drain drained.
Mr. Torres shook his head. "If people would only think before calling a plumber," he shrugged. "Nobody wants to think."
He climbed back into his van and headed for a shower dilemma. "You know," he said, "if only people were a little careful. I go to these office buildings, where workers stir their coffee with these wooden stirrers. They're drinking, stirring, dumping stuff in the sink. Boom, the stirrers go down the sink. Forget it. I've got to get the sticks out."
Idling at a light, he said: "One thing, I never find any money. I never really found anything of value in stuffed toilets. I've never pulled out any drugs. They seem to go down. I've gotten calls for rings in drains. If they don't use the water I can get it out of the trap underneath. But if they use the water, which they usually do, it's goodbye. People get really bent out of shape. Can't you go find it? Hey, I can't fit down the drain and go through the whole sewer system. I'm a plumber. I'm not God."
 
 
 
HOW A PLUMBER CAN SLIP ONE BY

There are, of course, good plumbers and bad plumbers, and malevolent plumbers can be a real nuisance. There are a lot of ways a plumber can sweeten profit and compromise quality. He could install 1/2-inch pipe instead of 3/4-inch. That retards the water flow. You can't really take a shower and flush the toilet at the same time. There are different grades of copper piping. Who's going to know if he puts in K or L grade, which is less costly but not as durable as M.
In New York, plumbers are prohibited from using plastic pipe except in one- and two-family homes and laboratories that discharge acid waste. Plastic is cheaper and quick to install but noisier, flammable and less sturdy. It is outlawed partly because plumbers are against plastic, since almost anyone can install it. Nonetheless, Mr. Torres says he encounters plastic pipe all the time, particularly beneath sinks.
Another common thing Mr. Torres sees in New York City is the soapsuds-in-the-toilet phenomenon. Prewar apartment buildings were not built with washing machines in mind. That means they don't contain a "suds pressure zone" in the wall to relieve the flow of suds down the pipes. People, however, install washers anyway. What happens is the plumbing in the second-floor apartments in these buildings, where the main waste stack makes a 90-degree turn, backs up. Suds surge up into the kitchen sink or the toilet, then overflow. There are few things more unsettling than to wander into the bathroom and see soapsuds erupting out of the toilet.
 
 
 
EMBARKING ON A CAREER

While he dealt with a drain problem on East End Avenue, weariness on his face, Mr. Torres offered some facts about his life. He was born in 1939 in Puerto Rico, where his parents worked in a factory rolling tobacco leaves. In 1950, the family, which included seven other siblings, moved to New York. His father got a job as a salad man at the Hilton Hotel.
When he finished high school, Mr. Torres needed to help support the family. He found work cutting fabric in a garment factory in Union City, N.J. The job was mind-numbing. "One day," Mr. Torres said, "some of the guys said, 'Hey, why not try plumbing, you can make a few dollars.' "
Just like that, he embarked on a career releasing stoppages and tempering pipes in revolt. He has no pretensions about the life, and keeps it all in proportion. "Yeah, it's dirty and smelly," he said. "People say, 'Oh, you're a plumber, how can you stand such a job?' Well, I'm making things work again. You're accomplishing something. You make the water flow. You know anyone who wants to get along without plumbers?"
He lives with his wife, Haydee, in Parkchester in the Bronx. They have three children in college, and it irritates him sometimes that his children remain uncommitted to any particular career. "I say, 'When are you going to know?' " he said. "Isn't it time? I say, 'In my time,' and they interrupt and say, 'Yeah, but that was your time. Now it's our time.' 'Great,' I say, 'I'm paying for your time.' They say, 'Hey Dad, you're an old man. You don't know how it is.' Sometimes you want to grab them by the neck and choke them."
 
 
 
THE TRAUMAS OF THE JOB

Plumbers have their own way of interpreting what it is they do. There is no getting around the sensory grotesqueness of the work. When there are memorable experiences in plumbing, they tend to be of an unpleasant nature.
"I'm lucky that I'm not too sensitive to smells," Mr. Torres said, bent over an uncooperative radiator in a fifth-floor apartment sorely in need of heat. "Sometimes my wife tells me, 'Smell this sweater, is it a little moldy?' I don't smell anything. She says, 'Geez, working in plumbing must have lost you your sense of smell. Your nose is kaput.' I tell her, 'Good thing it is.' "
The worst experience is clearing out a badly stuffed-up waste line, one that has maybe 15 floors' worth of waste swirling around in it, begging to escape, and sometimes succeeding.
"Oh man, that's an experience," he said. "I tell you what happens a lot. Up on the roof of buildings there's an open waste pipe that lets the odor out. Sometimes kids on the roof drop sticks down the pipe. Or balls. The second time I had one I threw up. Now I know to walk around and around to clear my head. It's part of the job. But you never get used to it."
The business of plumbing takes him to a wide variety of settings. He has gone to an apartment where there were a dozen raggedly clothed people sleeping on the floor of the living room. He has gone to a multimillionaire's apartment, where an armed guard trailed him as he moved among the 12 bathrooms. One place where Mr. Torres never derives much delight is a funeral parlor. In their basements, funeral homes typically have drains encased in the floor to swallow waste as bodies are readied for burial. Now and then, Mr. Torres has to unclog one of those drains, doing his best not to focus on what went down them.
Mortuary workers love to tease plumbers. Mr. Torres will be wrestling with the drain and a worker will call to him, "Hey, Carlos, don't turn around now, we've got a leg lying here." Then another worker will shout, "Hey, Carlos, keep your head down, an eyeball just popped out."
"They think that's really funny," Mr. Torres said. "Meanwhile, my skin is crawling. It makes it kind of hard to concentrate."

 
 
THOSE CRAZY WATER LEAKS

He had a leak on Park Avenue and 36th Street. It was straightforward but would take some time. Some days are a delirium of leaks. Finding them can be tedious. They don't always show up where they are leaking from. He has something called a moisture meter that you stick in the wall and it tells you the amount of moisture, but he rarely uses it because it still doesn't identify the source of the leak. Often, you need some luck.
"I had a leak that I was going crazy over," he said. "The ceiling was wet. I go upstairs and I don't see anything. I open up the ceiling. Nothing. A couple of days later, I get called again. It's leaking. I opened up more of the wall. Nothing. Then a guy came to replace the wet Sheetrock. He saw it. A nail in the hot-water pipe. When the hot water went through it, the pipe expanded and sealed itself. Then when the water cooled off, a little of it leaked. It was annoying. That's the thing about water. It's annoying."
He finished up, packed his bag. The owner looked in on him. "Good, good, good," she said. "Is it going to work now?"
"Yeah, it'll work." Mr. Torres said.
"It better work," she said, her voice raised. "Or I'll come after you with a sledgehammer."
Mr. Torres pursed his lips and went out the door. "See, you meet people," he said. "They talk to you. You listen. You fix leaks. That's plumbing."
 
The Basics on Carlos Torres
 
Resides: The Bronx
 
Born: 1939 in Puerto Rico
 
Wages: $845 a week.
 
General Outlook: People are often their own worst enemies and should be more careful.
 
Highlights of Tool Bag:
Electric snake, blowtorch, channel locks, pieces of pipe
 
Quote from official of his union:
"You can live a month without food, but you could not live more than three days without pure water. Plumbing is not a glamourous business, but it can't go away. Without plumbing, there is no life as we know it."
 -- Peter Marzak, business manager, Plumbers Local 2.
 
 
 
The Truth About Hiring: You're On You're Own
 YOU just got your plumbing bill. It's $200 more than the estimate, and the darn pipe is leaking again. What can you do?
Basically, not a lot.
First, call the Buildings Department Licensing Division and file a complaint, (212) 312-8221. The folks there aren't going to care about the $200 -- that you'll have to deal with in small claims court -- but they can investigate. However, thanks to shrinking budgets, the number of inspectors is only about 20 now -- for the whole city. In the most serious cases of bad work, the license could be revoked or suspended. That is rare: there were no such cases last year.
And if you have hired someone other than a licensed master plumber, or a plumber supervised by one, the only punishment your tormentor can expect is a fine.
As far as rates go, plumbers who do residential jobs tend to charge by the hour. KBM/Brand Plumbing and Heating, at 49 Grand Street, charges $90 an hour to send two mechanics, a price that one partner, Walter Brand, figures to be fairly average. A simple toilet replacement might take a little under three hours, so Mr. Brand estimate $260 (plus sales tax). He likes to see the worksite before giving an estimate, because there are so many variables. And, he says, he never gives an estimate on a stopped-up drain. "Because there's no way to tell how long it'll take to clear it up," he says.
While there are 20,000 plumbers of various kinds in the city, as of June 1995, the city had only 1,462 licensed master plumbers, who are the only people legally allowed to contract for plumbing work and supervise non-licensed plumbers, including union workers like Carlos Torres.
It is not easy to get a license. There is a three-part exam, and applicants must have seven years of experience, or a bachelor's degree in engineering or engineering technology and three years of experience.
There are plenty of people out there plumbing illegally. Last year, Buildings fined 17 people anywhere from $100 to $3000 for advertising plumbing services without licenses. The Yellow Pages now checks that a plumber is licensed before agreeing to list the company.
The wise consumer must start smart.
* Word of mouth is the best guide.
* The smaller the operation, the likelier the master plumber is doing the work himself.
* Hiring locally means faster response and less travel time (which you pay for).
* Buildings' Licensing Division can tell you if your plumber is licensed, and whether any complaints have been filed against him.
* Estimates are not binding, so don't be shocked by overruns.
One final note of consumer comfort: It's a hirer's market. Thanks in part to slow construction and new competition from Con Ed and Brooklyn Union Gas on gas-pipe service, plumbers have a 45 percent unemployment rate. On top of that, their work is seasonal. So plumbers are likely to be eager to please. ANDREA KANNAPELL

HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS QUARTERLY REPORT;
The Longer the Bond the Better as Rates Fell Last Year

BYLINE: By EDWARD WYATT 

 BODY:
The Benham Target Maturity funds, which invest only in volatile securities known as zero-coupon Treasuries, pulled off an amazing feat in 1995: they had gains in 11 months of the year. Only in July, when long-term interest rates rose to 7 percent from 6.5 percent, did they post a loss.
The sharp decline in long-term rates last year also benefited more staid bond funds, as well as a few emerging-markets debt funds, which capitalized on a rebound in several markets for Latin American debt. 
 In the fourth quarter, high-income funds, often called junk bond funds, had a slowdown as default rates continued to rise. But after a strong move last year by investment-grade bonds, some experts think further bond rallies could favor the lower-grade issues and funds.
Among municipal funds, California specialists performed well one year after the Orange County debacle, and the sector regained favor after being battered in the first half of the year by concerns over Republican proposals to pass a flat tax. After recording a net outflow for six consecutive quarters through the third quarter of 1995, municipal funds have taken in money in 7 of the last 10 weeks, according to AMG Data Services of Arcata, Calif.
 EDWARD WYATT

HEADLINE: Films Face the Squirm Factor

BYLINE: By MICHEL MARRIOTT 

 BODY:
OH, how America loves the movies. But does it love them three hours' worth?
Film patrons are finding their devotion severely tested by a spate of exceedingly lengthy offerings. In just the last couple of months, for instance, audiences have had to sit still for "Casino," "Heat" and "Nixon." While these cinematic labors share short titles, they also pack long running times, hovering at three hours, twice the once-time-honored Hollywood standard of 90 minutes. 
 As the credits rolled on Martin Scorsese's "Casino," a 50-something theater patron hobbled to the exit. Disappearing down the escalator at the Ziegfeld Theater in midtown Manhattan, he could be heard repeating, "Too long . . . too long."
Long films, while sometimes wildly entertaining, are nonetheless complicating the lives of many of the very people who love them, often making for longer waits in line and inconvenient show times and generally heightening the risks that the movie might be a waste of time and money. For movie makers, that's no small concern in the wake of an off year like 1995, when box-office receipts were flat.
Some moviegoers say long movies complicate dating, leaving little time afterward for dinner. And consequences could be dire if a date thinks he or she has just been subjected to three hours of tedium, warned Robin Gorman Newman, the founder of the School of Flirting at Stand-Up New York, a comedy club on the Upper West Side.
"Maybe they should plan a little break together to get some popcorn and a soda," said Ms. Newman, 35, the author of "How to Meet a Mensch in New York" (City & Company, 1994). "That way they can get a moment to confer on whether to stay or leave the theater together." Of course, time was when an intermission came with the price of admission.
Couples with young children lament that they have particular problems with the longer movies, namely prohibitive baby-sitting costs.
Lonnie Soury, 43, the father of two children, ages 3 and 7, said he and his wife did not see a movie for a year because juggling time, money, children and baby sitters was too stressful for what should be a simple night out.
"In a conversation my wife and I had, 'Casino' came up," recalled Mr. Soury, a public-relations executive in Manhattan. "I said: 'How long is it? Three hours. Forget it! We can't do this.' "
Cathy Che, 28, who was mulling over movie options at a theater in Greenwich Village, said: "I certainly have to prepare myself differently for a long movie. I go to the bathroom first."
For staunchest movie fans, those for whom video just won't do, three-hour movies are presenting a different sort of problem: they can't get enough of them. Also concerned are theater managers who have to deal with the fact that long movies cannot be shown as many times a day as shorter ones, and therefore the seats cannot be filled as often.
For example, "Heat," which is 2 hours 41 minutes long, plays 4 times a day at the Murray Hill Cinemas, at 34th Street and Third Avenue. The computer-animated megahit "Toy Story," which is 2 hours 21 minutes long, is shown 6 times a day at the same theater complex, offering more moviegoers convenient starting times.
Roberto Liy, a manager at the 4,000-seat Sony Lincoln Square theaters at Broadway and 68th Street, said longer running times may cut down on the amount of popcorn and soft drinks moviegoers buy, again because there are fewer shows.
Stuart Applebaum, 46, an executive at Bantam Doubleday Dell in Manhattan and an ardent moviegoer, said, "I don't have a problem with movies being long, but I have a problem with the theaters' inability to schedule them the way I want." Mr. Applebaum goes to no less than 30 movies a year with friends.
For Mr. Applebaum, moviegoing is both escape and social ritual. Part of that ritual, he said, is getting enough popcorn before the film starts to last through the entire screening. He said he had learned the hard way that a three-hour movie requires at least a tub of popcorn.
He also has learned to insist on an aisle seat for his 6-foot-2-inch frame. "The longer the movie, the more the leg cramp-up issue becomes a factor," he explained.
"Two of the burning issues of the moment," he added, "are 'Are the movies too long?' and 'Will the Government go back to working as it should again?' "
So why are more movies getting longer?
Morris Dickstein, the director for the Center of the Humanities at the Graduate Center of the City University of New York, explained that a film's length can be as much of a statement as the film itself. "Film makers have always used length to show that they are making a major work of art," he said.
But today's longer-running films may be better understood, he said, as a response to changes in the audience. Television and its popular mini-series -- essentially 4-to-10-hour movies shown over days or weeks -- have helped to condition viewers to richly detailed and complex stories with lots of characters, often adapted from a book, Mr. Dickstein said. And movie audiences have come to expect the same intricate storytelling, he said.
Long movies usually do not come without staggering economic risks. Mel Gibson took the risk last summer and won at the box office with "Braveheart," a 2-hour-48-minute sweep of medieval Scottish history, with him as director, star and producer. Although the film cost $70 million, it has earned $175 million in worldwide release. "It was a creative decision, really," Mr. Gibson said of the length of the film. "Those sorts of decisions can't be based solely on economics. You have to make the film you want to see and hope others will want to see."

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: PARK SLOPE;
AIDS Ends Bookshop Dream

BYLINE: By SOMINI SENGUPTA 

 BODY:
After years in publishing, Clinton Morris realized his dream when he opened A Room of Our Own, a sprawling bookstore that borrowed its name from a Virginia Woolf book and specialized in lesbian and gay writing. In August, a summer after the store opened during Gay Pride Week in 1994, Mr. Morris died of AIDS-related complications at 35.
Now AIDS, in effect, has also claimed the life of the bookstore. 
 A Room of Our Own, whose lime-colored walls were host to book readings as well as community forums, closed Christmas Eve, saddening and surprising many neighborhood residents.
The store manager, Elizabeth Shipley, said financial problems at A Room of Our Own started within months of its opening, when Mr. Morris's condition worsened. Checks weren't signed. Publishers weren't paid on time. Ads promoting the store weren't placed in community publications.
"Because of Clinton's illness, he put it together rather hastily," Ms. Shipley said. "He wanted to live out his dream before he died. A lot of corners were cut."
And while Mr. Morris initially pumped his own money into the store, his own health needs soon began to deplete his funds. "AIDS," Ms. Shipley said, "basically ate up our financial base."
Evan Morris, 37, who took over the store after his brother's death, said that in a stronger economic climate, the bookstore might have been able to survive -- its sales had doubled since it first opened in an area with a large lesbian and gay population. But the store would have needed another twofold increase in sales to become profitable in costly Park Slope, Ms. Shipley said.
Katherine Acey, a Park Slope resident who is the executive director of the Astraea National Lesbian Action Foundation, surmised that the area's mixed-income lesbian community could not support a bookstore in the same way that the more affluent gay men's community of the West Village could, although she still expressed surprise that A Room of Our Own had closed.
"Why it didn't make it in the Slope, I can't figure out," she said.
Others said the neighborhood was saturated with three bookstores -- though none specialize in lesbian and gay material -- while others compared it to small niche-market shops that recently went out of business. Judith's Room, a West Village women's bookstore, closed in 1994, and University Place Books, a bookstore that specialized in black and African works, closed last month.
Despite those factors, Ms. Shipley said she hopes to open another gay and lesbian bookstore in the neighborhood. In the meantime,
to the writer Jacqueline Woodson, the closing of A Room of Our Own is chilling.
"As a writer who is a person of color and who is gay, I get really scared that a lesbian bookstore can't survive in its own neighborhood," said Ms. Woodson, 32, who lives in Park Slope and is the author of "Autobiography of a Family Photo" and several other books for children and adults. "Will publishers then say, 'No one is buying gay and lesbian books, no one is buying African-American books, no one is buying women's books?' " said Ms. Woodson, who is black. "For me as a writer, economically, that's a dangerous thing." SOMINI SENGUPTA

HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS QUARTERLY REPORT;
What a Year It Was For Domestic Funds

BYLINE: By EDWARD WYATT 

 BODY:
ARE any mutual fund investors unhappy?
Maybe a few who made big bets last year on foreign markets or gold. But 1995 was one of the best years of the last decade for United States stock and bond funds, leaving most everyone to count their profits. And those who invested aggressively were swimming in them. 
 Stock funds that invest in American companies rose 31.5 percent on average, while their bond counterparts gained 16 percent.
Across the board in the United States, the mutual funds that took the biggest risks generated the most profits. The year's top-performing equity fund, Alger Capital Appreciation, not only put 75 percent of its assets in volatile technology stocks, but also borrowed money so it could leverage its assets even more. Alger's reward: a gain of 78.6 percent, more than eight percentage points ahead of its nearest competitor.
Similarly, the top bond funds were those that went farthest out the risk-reward curve, where returns can plummet or soar when interest rates inch up or down. Three Benham Target Maturity funds, each investing in zero-coupon bonds that mature in 2020, 2015 or 2010, rode a two-point decline in long-term rates to give their investors one-year gains of 61 percent, 53 percent and 42 percent, respectively. The next best performance by any bond fund was a mere 35 percent increase.
The blistering returns generated by both stock and bond funds last year proved true to a trend of more than a decade: in general, a good year for stocks has been matched by a good, if less robust, year for bonds. Likewise, when stock returns have slipped, bond returns have fallen.
With much of Wall Street predicting that economic growth will remain sluggish and long-term interest rates will level off this year, few prognosticators expect a repeat of last year's rich returns. If the economy slows appreciably, or slips into a recession, stocks and bonds might no longer move in tandem either.
That makes diversification at home particularly important for individual investors. And even if bonds and stocks continue to shadow each other in the coming year, a slower economy would mean much smaller returns in both categories, making diversification abroad advisable as well.
For evidence of how quickly market sentiment can change, look no further than the first few days of 1996. Pacific Rim and Latin American stocks -- among last year's worst performers -- surged. In the first week of the year, the only asset group to outperform the emerging market funds was gold, another big loser in 1995. Meanwhile, technology stocks, which paced the best-performing funds of 1995, continued a decline that began in the fourth quarter of 1995.
Now, as mutual fund companies send out year-end statements, is an especially good time for fund shareholders to reassess just how their fund investments are allocated.
"Individuals have put a lot of money into the equity market this year after going through a period in 1994 where they only wanted to buy bond funds," said Leslie J. Nanberg, chief fixed-income officer at Massachusetts Financial Services, parent of the MFS family of mutual funds. "After the kind of year we had in 1995, investors should take a look to see if they are too far out on a limb in one asset category or another."
IF the trends of the fourth quarter continue through the first half of this year, mutual fund investors will benefit by increasing their bond exposure. For all of last year, taxable fixed-income funds, which invest in bonds issued by the Federal Government and domestic and international corporations, gained an average of 16 percent. And tax-free bond funds, which invest in municipal debt, returned an average of 15.9 percent.
But while the average stock fund rose 2.7 percent in the fourth quarter, taxable bond funds returned 3.7 percent and municipal bond funds rose 4.3 percent.
"I think it's particularly important to have some fixed-income exposure this year," said C. Frazier Evans, senior economist at Colonial mutual funds. Whereas coupon payments made little difference last year in the 34 percent total return generated by long-term Treasuries, a volatile bond market this year could make those interest payments more meaningful. Mr. Evans said he expects further declines in long-term interest rates will lead to gains in bond prices of about 3 percent, on top of coupon rates of about 7 percent, for a total bond return of about 10 percent.
Municipal bonds suffered for much of 1995 because of concerns about the possibility of a flat tax, which presumably would eliminate the bonds' tax-free advantage. But Al Kugel, investment strategist at Stein Roe & Farnham, a Chicago fund company, said he expects municipal bonds to do better this year than last, continuing the path started in the fourth quarter.
"The flat tax will not be taken up in Washington until after the election, and it will only be taken up seriously if the Republicans elect a President and keep control of Congress," Mr. Kugel predicted. "Right now, you'd have to say that Clinton's a favorite to be re-elected, and it's not clear that the Republicans will keep control of the House. By next November we will probably see even more changes."
After such a strong year, few seers expect stock funds to have as good a year in 1996. Last year's returns were, after all, the best since 1991 and the second best in 10 years.
"I think the stock market used up a lot of its potential for gain in the 1990's in 1995," said John C. Bogle, chairman of the Vanguard Group, the country's second-largest mutual fund company. Particularly, investors who flocked to equity funds in the fourth quarter might not see their investments grow much for several quarters, he said.
"But we are saying the same thing after an extraordinary year that we say after a bad year: stay the course," he said, and avoid trying to time the market.
Mr. Bogle's longtime advocacy of index investing was supported last year. Index funds that tracked the S.& P. 500 outperformed roughly 87 percent of actively managed general equity funds, according to Lipper Analytical Services of Summit, N.J. But last year's performance far exceeds what investors can expect even from index funds over the long term. "It was astonishing, and probably nonrecurrent," he said.
The laggard in 1995 among the major groups tracked by Morningstar was the international stock category, whose funds grew 9 percent on average. For investors in the riskiest of the foreign markets, 1995 was a disaster. The average fund invested in emerging markets fell 7 percent.
"I think in fact we will see a shift to overseas markets performing better," said John W. Ballen, chief equity officer at MFS. But he said much of the upward move in overseas markets "is more a late '96 into '97 event." In Japan and Europe, he said, companies are starting to improve their profitability. "But I think it still might be too early at this point."
While most of these experts predict that both stock and bond funds will produce gains in 1996, they allow room for the unexpected, including the possibility that the economy may take a turn for the worse.
"I think what would cause the bond and stock markets to decouple is if enough people were worried about a recession or we actually got one," said Mr. Kugel, of Stein Roe. Stock and bond markets have moved in sync for most of the last 13 years, he said, as interest rates have fallen and the economy has grown.
The exception was in late 1990, he said, when Iraq's invasion of Kuwait caused the price of oil to jump unexpectedly, and the economy slipped into recession. That year, the average stock fund fell nearly 6 percent, while bond funds gained nearly 5 percent.
Which provides further evidence of the ability of bonds to provide a cushion against uncertainty, said Mr. Evans of Colonial mutual funds -- a cushion that investors still basking in the glow of a year like 1995 might not realize they need.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 1; Column 3; Money and Business/Financial Desk

HEADLINE: Yes, He's Revived Sears. But Can He Reinvent It?

BYLINE: By JUDITH H. DOBRZYNSKI 

DATELINE: HOFFMANN ESTATES, Ill.

 BODY:
IT'S 9 A.M. on a November Friday. The auditorium at Sears, Roebuck & Company's headquarters here in suburban Chicago is filled with balloons. More than 900 employees jam the seats and spill over onto the floor.
A spotlight breaks the semidarkness, revealing a ringmaster. "Welcome to the Sears P.S.E. Circus," he says. "It's eye-popping. Death-defying. Larger than life. Well, not death-defying." 
 Next comes Jim La the clown, in orange hat, turquoise-and-pink jacket and plaid pants. He tells a few corny jokes. Then he breaks into a rap song, ending with "we work real hard; now it's time to play. Hey, hey, what do you say?"
What has this got to do with Sears?
The next verse does work in "come see the softer side of Sears," straight from the campaign advertising the company's expanded clothing departments. The following one mentions customer service. And it helps to know that Sears sponsors the Ringling Brothers Barnum & Bailey circus's national tour as part of its appeal to families. Even so, questions linger. Shouldn't these people be working?
Arthur C. Martinez, chief executive of Sears, wanted town hall meetings, pep rallies really. The P.S.E. (for pure selling environment) circuses -- which dovetailed with the sponsorship -- were the results. He wanted, as one aide put it, "to create common ground, to make sure people understand what he's doing."
What Mr. Martinez is trying to do at Sears is foment a cultural revolution, a re-education effort that would make Mao proud.
Mr. Martinez has already made monumental changes. When retailers released their holiday sales figures last Thursday, Sears was no longer a laggard. It was the star. In the worst season since the 1990 recession, other big stores posted minimal gains or losses, but Sears registered a 9.2 percent sales increase. In domestic stores open a year or more, the gain was 6.8 percent.
And that comes on top of an impressive earlier record. As soon as Mr. Martinez became head of the Sears retail operations in 1992 -- when Sears still owned insurance and financial services businesses -- he started spending $4 billion to remodel shabby stores. He upgraded the merchandise and added private-brand apparel and cosmetics at the faded American institution, which was once known affectionately as the Big Store. He revamped marketing.
Sears, again just a retailer, was back. Revenue climbed 5.9 percent in 1995 to about $35 billion, while net profit, $890 million in 1994, probably grew to $995 million, according to a conservative estimate by Goldman, Sachs. In 1995, the company's stock price jumped nearly 71 percent, closing at $39 on Dec. 29 -- a gain second only to Merck among the 30 blue-chip stocks in the Dow Jones industrial average. The Standard & Poor's index of 32 retailers including Sears, meanwhile, increased just 10.3 percent.
But that was the easy part. As the just-passed holiday season showed, the retail environment is brutal. America is over-stored, and brand-name retailers like Bradlees and Caldor are among the many who have belly-flopped into bankruptcy court.
Sears will survive. But unless it woos new, loyal customers, the Big Store is unlikely to thrive. Diminishing its profitability, for example, is an annual sales-per-square-foot figure that, at $365, lags behind that of Wal-Mart as well as its own goal of topping $400 by 1998. "What was good enough to get us where we are is not good enough to get us going forward," Mr. Martinez said recently, his deep blue eyes looking earnest and ambitious.
If employees can be convinced -- by circuses or whatever -- that change is a must, they may alter their behavior willingly and accept Mr. Martinez's attempts to decentralize and restructure Sears for growth.
That's the theory. And with the help of consultants like McKinsey & Company and A. T. Kearney, he is pushing programs to change the way people think about and go about their jobs.
THE effort goes far beyond pep rallies. It includes discussion groups, training sessions, new job descriptions, new operating structures and a new pay system -- all intended to place decision making closer to the customer and make it customer friendly. And it involves employees, soliciting their ideas, letting them experiment and improving their skills as they reach for better performance. It is a blend of Barnum and business school basics.
"We've tried to take it beyond the classroom and get it into an environment where people can get energized," Mr. Martinez explained. "That's better than a 25-minute videotape of the chairman." In a service business, the best workers are happy about doing their jobs.
And so, at 9:20 A.M., Patricia A. Recktenwald, vice president for store operations, takes over from Jim La and turns the circus into a serious, though still amusing, training exercise. In gold-and-silver sequined tails, Ms. Recktenwald repeats a Martinez goal -- stripping some reporting requirements and administrative tasks from store managers and clerks so they have more time to actually sell.
"Store managers were only spending 20 percent of their time on the sales floor," she said. "Now they are spending 80 to 90 percent of their time on the floor."
"Some of our managers didn't know how to work a register," she added, a measure of how removed they were from store operations. "They had moved up because they filled in reports well."
But if the jobs of store "associates" -- company argot for managers and rank-and-file employees alike -- are changing, so too are those of the support staff at headquarters, the associates at this circus. Some of them will lose their jobs.
Many more will be reassigned, thanks to the work of four task forces, one studying the big mall stores; another looking at the free-standing, off-the-mall hardware and home-related stores; a third reviewing the automotive stores, and the last studying the headquarters support staff.
"Their job is to help structure the company for growth and increase the accountability and responsibility further down the organization," Mr. Martinez said. "We want them to define what has to happen to create opportunities for growth in new areas and sustain opportunities for growth in mall stores." The ultimate goal, of course, is bigger profits.
When he tapped these management teams in October -- using managers' input like this was a total departure for Sears -- Mr. Martinez gave them a 90-day deadline.
The day before the P.S.E. circus is rainy, and the gray furniture in a gray conference room matches the mood of the 15 or so Sears employees sitting around a big table in a room a few steps away from their offices in the advertising department.
A discussion leader, their boss, is asking them to answer basic questions, Socrates-style, about the business: Why is Sears targeting women? How well is Sears meeting shoppers' needs?
"The merchandise and the stores are improving," he said, sharing the results of a customer survey. "But what drives our overall score down is service."
Customer satisfaction numbers for Sears and its rivals, tallied by a consultant, indeed deliver bad news. The Sears score in 1994 was 69 out of 100, lower than Kmart's (70), J. C. Penney's (71) and Wal-Mart's (78). The complaints would be funny if they were not real:
* "There were plenty of cash registers but there's never anyone at them."
* "We were looking for an oven. The salesperson knew nothing. We went elsewhere."
* "Twice I called and was told an item was in stock, but when I got there it wasn't."
Finally, the leader unveils a chart that breaks down the resolution of customer complaints and shows how those customers feel. "The implication is, even if we resolve a complaint, many customers won't come back."
Conversation in the room has jumped from topic to topic, but the customer is the common thread. Guiding the talk is a "learning map," a multicolored chart the size of two Monopoly boards that sits on the table. Every one of the company's 300,000 workers journeyed around copies of this particular learning map in 1995.
THIS is their second learning map. The first, completed by everyone between April and September, covered the general retail environment. It pointed out that today's consumers are time-strapped shoppers who have many stores to choose among for whatever they buy. To compete, Sears had to provide more service, convenience and value. After discussing these points, Mr. Martinez's plans to put more emphasis on specialized stores outside malls made more sense to employees.
This month, Sears employees will again start sitting down to go over a third learning map, this one explaining where the money comes from and goes to at Sears.
"We are trying to build a level of economic literacy so they can make the right decisions," explained Barbara Lehman, director of the special communications initiative.
In the old days, Sears employees could check their economic literacy at the door. They worked in a command-and-control environment, where everything was decided for them or laid out in a 29,000-page manual of rules and procedures.
Mr. Martinez tossed out the manual. In its place, he put a folder called "Freedoms and Obligations." Measuring about an eighth of an inch thick, it contains a one-page letter from him; a one-page list of "shared beliefs" (like "we recognize our obligation to shareholders: profitable growth and superior total shareholder return"); a 16-page booklet outlining leadership principles for managers ("reward people who add value to Sears"), and a 17-page code of business conduct for every employee ("we must always describe products and services accurately").
Suddenly, participatory management was in. Store managers and associates were allowed to think for themselves, to experiment. "Our focus is to push ownership down and have people take responsibility," Ms. Lehman said.
But it is dangerous to ask that of employees unless they share a common frame of reference. So the learning map exercises, the town hall meetings, Sears University and other training exercises were born.
Mr. Martinez came to Sears from the vice chairman's post at Saks Fifth Avenue. He was brought in by Edward A. Brennan, who ran the larger, diversified Sears for nine years before finally bowing to shareholder pressure and spinning off the nonretailing businesses, one by one, the last few years. Even its trophy headquarters building, the Sears Tower in Chicago's Loop, is gone. When Mr. Brennan finished the task last summer, he retired. In August, Mr. Martinez, 56, became chief executive of the slimmed-down company.
He had never staged pep rallies at Saks. "The difference is that this is an organization that needed to start feeling good about itself and its customers," he said.
Sears had long since lost its status as an American retailing icon in the face of new competition from the likes of Wal-Mart and category killers like Circuit City and Bed, Bath and Beyond. As sales stagnated, its stores suffered from inattention. Nobody likes working at an ailing company. And customers sensed it.
Sears is not yet flying high, though it is gaining altitude. "He is now taking market share away from stores above him and from many specialty stores as well as from stores below him, the discount stores," said Kurt Barnard, president of Barnard's Retail Marketing Report.
Sometime in 1994, Sears had gained enough sales momentum for Mr. Martinez to focus on corporate culture. "Sears' fundamental problem was arrogance from past success," Mr. Martinez said. "That blinded it to what was going on in the competitive arena and with customers."
His prescription: "We have to change how we think about ourselves and what we want to be known for," Mr. Martinez said. "That's how we came to the three C's."
"The three C's" is internal shorthand for the overarching theme at Sears. The actual slogan, introduced in 1994, is: "A compelling place to shop/work/invest."
Mr. Martinez believes that, until recently, when Mr. Brennan reversed course, Sears tried to march to Wall Street's beat, diversifying for growth and basing incentive pay on return on equity. But failing to please shoppers and workers alike ended in failure with investors, too.
Make no mistake, said Anthony J. Rucci, executive vice president for human resources and administration, "a compelling place to work does not mean a nice place to work. We want people to feel some degree of anxiety, the stress of achievement-oriented people."
Like other companies in the throes of cultural change, Mr. Martinez has made it clear that the new Sears is not for everybody. "Arthur said last March to senior management, leave or change," Mr. Rucci said. Of the top 100 managers, those heavily involved in designing the Sears of the future, about 40 are new employees.
Everyone will have to stretch to meet the company's new goals. Despite pronounced improvement made since 1992, Mr. Martinez wants financial results that will put Sears among the nation's top performers in the stock market. To him, that means a return on equity consistently above 25 percent. "We're on the verge of meeting that imminently," he said on Friday. The trick will be to keep it there.
To get there, he figures that operating margins in the Sears mall stores should be 5 percent by 1998, compared with 2.3 percent now. Inventory turnover, now 3.67 times a year, needs to be about 4.5. Overhead expenses, now 20.7 percent of revenues, should drop to 19 percent.
As managers and workers strive toward the targets, Mr. Martinez believes he has one big thing working in his favor. "These came out of the organization; they were not delivered as the goal," he said -- as they would have been in the past.
None of this is rocket science. In fact, much of what Mr. Martinez is trying to do at Sears is common sense. When one top manager sought board room approval for an initiative, a director shot back that the plan was "a blinding flash of the obvious." Indeed.
But that does not mean that this, or any, cultural transformation is easy. Success stories do not abound, and the skeptics are plentiful.
"I see no evidence that the efforts are working," said Philip Johnson, president of Leo J. Shapiro & Associates, a Chicago retailing consultant. Then again, he added, "I have not seen Mr. Martinez make a lot of mistakes either, especially in the financial area. There have been disappointments in his fashion upgrade, but his overall judgment has been good."
Even so, many management experts believe it takes 10 years to change a culture.
Mr. Martinez cannot afford to take 10 years; Sears would never be more than an also-ran if he did. "The retailing environment is always challenging, but the pace of change has stepped up," he said. "Ultimately, fewer, stronger competitors will emerge."
As Sears managers design their future, though, many are fumbling their new-found responsibilities. Consider the task forces. "For the first 30 days, they didn't know how to do it," said Mr. Rucci, who joined Sears from Baxter International two years ago. Then they started to suggest simple things, like cutting management layers, to bolster their competitive position.
Things started to change after each task force did a profit-and-loss statement for their business unit that took into account the cost of capital and allocated corporate overhead. "They were shocked," Mr. Rucci said. "Their intensity level went up significantly. They started to come up with unconventional ideas."
The fruits of their labor were complete during the first few days of January. One new division, Home Services, was created, based on the fact that Sears appliance installers and maintenance people already visit the homes of 17 million customers a year. Why not turn that into a growth business?
A new office of the president will run the mall stores, headed -- actually -- by three presidents with responsibility for the stores themselves; the apparel and home furnishing departments, and the appliances, tools, electronics and other "hard-line" departments.
The move is a half-solution. It consolidates management, but is really a face-saving device for three people who already had the presidential title. Ultimately, Sears executives predict, one will rise to the top.
The company's auto units, free-standing furniture and hardware stores and credit organization keep their current structures.
Most important, the restructuring cements the company's top 100 managers in their jobs. Duly designated, they have until mid-February to submit structures and personnel for their units. Mr. Martinez has told them to weed out poor performers and consider bringing in new blood.
And now the job shifts will begin. A couple hundred staffers will be laid off. Between 150 and 200 people in areas like human resources, finance and marketing will be reassigned to the operating units. About 400 to 500 will remain as headquarters staff.
Another 2,100 to 2,200, in areas like information systems, will provide "shared services" to the operating units, which will be their clients -- treated like customers. The people who used to call the tune are now relegated to support roles.
So the method in Ms. Recktenwald's circus madness now becomes clear. She had explained how headquarters' staff should "better support store associates." They could, for example, answer the phones quickly, since stores calling in usually had customers waiting with them for an answer. And they could pitch in and help if a store is particularly busy when they shop.
Eventually, even more people could be affected, because Sears managers may contract out for some services now done in-house.
STORE employees have hardly escaped change. Half the store managers are new in their jobs. Good thing. They are no longer expected to spend their time in their offices reading directions from above. Instead, they should be on the sales floor, checking inventory, solving problems, adjusting prices.
As for the clerks, according to Ms. Recktenwald, they are supposed to remember "just one thing": Never disappoint a customer. "There are no manuals for this," she said. "It's the associate's job to figure out how to satisfy the customer."
And despite some glitches, many are. Mr. Martinez "has made the employees understand that they have to make the customer feel happy and not look down on the customer," Mr. Barnard said. Better yet for Sears, Walter Loeb, a retail consultant, believes a combination of better merchandise and more responsive service is attracting younger, more diverse customers.
By design, some stores are changing faster than others. Sears buys centrally, sometimes producing crazy results. In winters past, management has sent topcoats to Miami and snowblowers to Puerto Rico.
A test program could change all that. Under a "local focus initiative" involving 76 stores around Hartford, Los Angeles, Cincinnati, Miami and Louisville, area managers are making their own decisions, tailoring merchandise to local needs and designing local ad supplements. The store in Lantana, Fla., for example, wanted Hanukkah tschotkes as well as Christmas decorations this year.
In the first stage, the last four months of 1995, these stores increased sales modestly more than comparable Sears outlets. But 1996 will really be the test year. Then, these managers will come up with some "best practices" to share within the whole organization.
Mr. Martinez figures that decentralizing the company will distinguish it from rivals.
By decentralizing, however, Sears is rowing against the retailing tide. To cut costs, more big retailers centralize buying, or are moving in that direction, than do not. It is as yet unclear if Mr. Martinez is right on this tactic. "I can't tell if it's good for Sears," said Mr. Johnson, the retailing consultant. "But based on his judgment so far, I can't argue against it."
And as its holiday sales tally showed, Sears is making progress over all with customers.
Another measure, customer satisfaction, climbed a bit in 1995 -- although it must rise more to reach Mr. Martinez's goal for the end of 1997. "We want to get to high 70's, though that's still behind Wal-Mart and Nordstrom," Mr. Martinez said.
SHORTLY after the headquarters circus ended, there was a meeting of another team of managers -- charged with overseeing the cultural transformation. They perused a survey revealing that employees like the town hall meetings, a result that elicited a bit of gallows humor. "We've terminated all of those who didn't like it," someone said, sotto voce.
Still, munching sandwiches and chips, these managers worried that too many employees viewed the pep rallies strictly as events, not as training that was a prelude to "taking responsibility for their own learning." They do not believe that town hall meetings should be necessary in 1996; by this year, employees should be adapting to the new Sears without them.
But, inevitably, there is skepticism among employees. Mr. Martinez wants shopping at Sears to be fun, for example, but in the learning map session several employees had trouble grasping the concept. "What's fun about buying an appliance?" one asked.
It's a good question, one of many. "There's skepticism, because we've had efforts like this in the past," acknowledged Ms. Lehman, the manager in charge of communicating change. "The program of the month. They didn't see it integrated into their daily work. The only answer to that is getting managers to support it."
Mr. Martinez himself agreed that the company's past was not helping. "For a long time, we gave lip service to the customer." he said. "But at the end of the day, it was, 'Did you make your numbers?' "
That is why several accountability and incentive systems are changing. Copying leading companies, like General Electric, managers will now get 360-degree performance evaluations, or judgments from underlings and peers as well as supervisors. The pay system is being changed, too. In 1996, every employee's compensation will include a measurement for customer service.
Beginning this year, bonuses for the top 200 executives and managers will no longer be geared solely to financial measures. Revenue growth, return on assets and operating margins will be the basis of just half the bonus. The rest will depend equally on the customer satisfaction rating and subjective employee ratings. The idea is to measure Sears as a good place for shoppers and workers as well as investors.
MR. MARTINEZ and his management team know they are pushing hard. "We're asking people to produce, to hit performance targets and to take part in the transformation process," Mr. Rucci said. "That's like saying, 'Fly an airplane and change the wings on the plane while you're at it.' "
But business is tough, and they are far from finished. This year, top managers will learn more about what management experts call value creation, which is a fancy way of saying that Sears must figure out how to provide value to customers, thus attracting more shoppers and getting more of the money they spend. Too, the operating units are expected to develop detailed strategies this year. Lower down the organization, managers will learn things like how to hire better salesclerks.
Mr. Martinez is not wearing rose-colored glasses about his task. He believes that he is less than halfway through his planned transformation of Sears. And when asked what headline he would put on this article, he had a knowing answer: "They Said It Couldn't Be Done."

SECTION: Section 4; Page 18; Column 4; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 266 words

HEADLINE: Healthy Environment Aids the Economy

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The next time someone tells me we can't afford to protect the environment, I'm going to open my wallet and unfold your front-page article ("Federal Shutdown Hits Hard in Area Around Yellowstone," Dec. 30) on how the national park shutdown has hurt business.
Too many of us are still locked in that mindset that says the way to make money off a piece of land is to mine it, drill it or log it. That's certainly the prevailing view in Congress, though that may have more to do with who bankrolls campaigns. 
 In fact, nowadays trees in many parts of America are worth more when they're vertical than when they're horizontal and on their way to the mill. In the 20 counties near Yellowstone National Park, for example, 96 percent of new jobs over a recent 20-year period were created by businesses not part of the extractive industries or agriculture. In Oregon, forest-product executives had predicted that a reduction in national forest logging would devastate the state's economy. Yet companies lured in part by Oregon's natural qualities have helped drop unemployment to its lowest rate in a generation. In short, nature sells.
As Congressional efforts to give away the public's lands and reduce protection of water, air and wildlife turned into a donnybrook late last year, Speaker New Gingrich said that in January he would come up with a new approach on the environment. Let's hope this new approach reflects the reality that a healthy economy and a healthy environment go hand in hand.
 
JON ROUSH
President, the Wilderness Society
Washington, Jan. 4, 1996

HEADLINE: Investors Help Push The Downsizing Trend

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In the wake of AT&T's record layoffs, Labor Secretary Robert Reich got it half right in calling for incentives to encourage corporate compassion for employees and communities ("How to Avoid These Layoffs?" Op-Ed, Jan. 4). And Bob Herbert's Dec. 29 column correctly identified the growing economic peril in the surge of pink slips driven by cost-cutting corporate machismo.
But the pressure on corporate chieftains to outdo each other in ruthlessly pruning employees, wages and benefits -- even, or especially, when enjoying record profits -- is driven only partly by worldwide competition. Equally significant is the mania by investors that each successive fiscal quarter be financially better than the one before. 
 Increasingly, these investors are all of us; millions of Americans who have quadrupled the resources of mutual funds and giant employee pension funds. In fact, employee pension funds have taken the lead in demanding better bottom-line performance by managers of corporations in which they invest. And we as investors and future retirees certainly reap the dividends from better financial performance. But are we also reaping a whirlwind of castoff employees, declining consumer confidence and hollow communities as corporations spin off, re-engineer, downsize, merge and disappear?
Along with Secretary Reich's prescription for greater responsibility through incorporation and tax laws, we as individual investors ought to demand that our money managers reward good corporate citizenship as well as good financial performance.
 
ERIK PETER AXELSON
Brooklyn, Jan. 4, 1996

HEADLINE: Exiles in the Promised Land

BYLINE: By Elizabeth Gilbert; Elizabeth Gilbert is a staff writer for Spin magazine.

 BODY:
I grew up in the 1970's. Here's a quick recap: oil was expensive, American citizens were hostages, Detroit was a ghost town. My first political memory was something about President Gerald Ford forgiving somebody called Richard Nixon. I was late for gymnastics class because my mother had to wait in a gas line.
I was raised in a society that believed I had just missed out on something pretty good. No fault of mine, but the 1950's had really been much better. When I refer to the 1950's, I mean the catchall term that came to define the period from the end of World War II to the escalation of the war in Vietnam. When my parents were young, America was unchallenged, cars looked great, a wife could raise her children safely, a husband could buy a home on a laborer's wage. 
 All of that was diminishing as I was growing up. It's sad luck to be born at the end of your society's greatest glories. I grew up knowing that I would never have what my parents had -- idealism, security, faith, prosperity. I was cheated. I missed it.
But my grandparents missed it, too. My maternal grandparents were married in 1933, in rural Minnesota. They were farmers, the children of immigrants. They went on a weekend-long honeymoon to Minneapolis, and when they got back home a drought hit from which they never recovered. There wasn't enough money, and it was terrifying when anyone got sick. My grandmother had seven children. My grandfather took a job on a construction crew, leaving the dairy farm in the hands of his wife and my adolescent mother. My husband's family were coal miners in western Maryland. That's all you need to know about them, in order to understand what stake they had in America's famous affluence.
These are not exceptional stories. This is how people lived for a long time before the abundant 1950's, which was a privileged moment and a brief one. The tremendous prosperity of this nation was a freak of history. It depended upon an alignment of favorable stars that cannot be repeated. We were the sole victors of a war that destroyed the economies of every other industrial nation. We were exploiting all natural resources as if those resources were endless. Racial and sexual confines insured that we all knew our place, a peculier comfort that we no longer accept.
It's fine to believe that the 1950's were an easier time for many. I have no reason to doubt that. But why should we inherit the expectations of that period? My grandparents and my husband's grandparents had no contract with America except the contract of all immigrants -- the right to hope that things will be better for your children. At 83, my grandmother still closes every letter by writing, "I can't complain." She means it.
On the other hand, I have a young Republican acquaintance who makes almost $100,000 a year on Wall Street and feels victimized because his life does not have the pleasant order that his father's life had during the Eisenhower Administration. He is convinced that something has been stripped from him.
This distorted nostalgia is creating a country of citizens who feel like refugees in their own land. Our regretful fury makes us capable of anything: reflexive xenophobia and cynicism, even the desire to dismantle a perfectly good system of government.
Such nostalgia ultimately makes us vulnerable to any politician who promises a return to the golden age, and that golden age looks better and better every year. Trust me, nobody remembers it more fondly than the people who missed it entirely. Believing we have been exiled from our entitlements, we will crucify any leader who doesn't bring us back home. Such a society can only embrace a demagogue. Be careful what you wish for this year.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH
