HEADLINE: TELEVISION VIEW;
Sure, We're All Just One Big Happy Family

BYLINE: By BENJAMIN DeMOTT; Benjamin DeMott is the author of "The Trouble With Friendship: Why Americans Can't Think Straight About Race," to be published this month by Atlantic Monthly Press.

 BODY:
FOR A MOMENT -- THE MOMENT OF THE verdict in the O. J. Simpson trial in October -- white America discovered race difference. Film and photographs of reactions to the words "not guilty" proved that blacks and whites don't see things the same. Troubled citizens spoke in shock -- on televised "town meetings" and call-in radio shows, and in letters to the editor -- about the gap between the races. "As blacks exulted at Simpson's acquittal," wrote Henry Louis Gates Jr. in The New Yorker, "horrified whites had a fleeting sense that . . . blacks really were strangers in their midst."
Why are blacks and whites so divided? Repeatedly posed, this question was nevertheless vacuous. What needed serious inquiry were other questions. Why are whites so dim about the division between the races? What forces, what processes, lulled white America into assuming that blacks and whites were ever on the same page? 
 One answer is clear. Over the last generation this country's politics and pop culture have relentlessly sold the notion that the races have achieved equality and are the same. For an assortment of reasons, a great many Americans have bought the scam. Our most powerful media images depict black-white sameness. They are feel-good images. They fail to connect with the texture of city life familiar to the 60 percent of black Americans who have not reached middle-class status: the life of the projects, or of the jobless, the homeless and the illiterate. And they do not begin to reflect the deep conflicts of opinion between American blacks and whites at every class level.
The media images I speak of, remote from urban fact, have been teaching mass audiences everywhere that race differences belong to the past, that inequalities of power and status and means have disappeared, that at work and play blacks are as likely as whites to be found at the top as at the bottom, and that the agency responsible for the creation of near-universal black-white sameness -- the only agency capable of producing progress -- is that of friendship between the races.
Naturally the images teach without sermonizing. No preacher interrupts the NBC feed on weekdays at 6:59 A.M. to intone with podium sonority that a minute hence the "Today" show will conduct a morally improving demonstration of interracial collaboration and equality in action to which all right-feeling, God-fearing viewers should devotedly attend. Bryant Gumbel and Katie Couric, firm friends, simply show up, cozily communicating mutual enjoyment (Katie on occasion answers Bryant's teasing with a gentle nudge to his side). There is no competitive wariness or boss-underling antsiness; recurring casual remarks suggest familiarity with each other's after-hours pleasures and irritations.
In place of a lecture about black-white equality and sameness, "Today" brings to life a version of the thing itself, presenting it every weekday morning as the national norm. And thereafter come blizzards of sameness and sympathy narratives -- talk shows, sitcoms, cop shows, commercials, late night, prime time, all the time. In the hit NBC series "Seinfeld," George struggles to show his black boss that he's capable of winning and keeping a black friend. On "Designing Women," now in syndication on Lifetime, Anthony and Julia, black and white business partners, reveal how sympathy and affection cause race differences to vanish in the Atlanta environs. On "Murphy Brown," Candice Bergen comes to like and admire a new station manager, a black man who initially seemed threatening; the two make common cause for "standards."
On cartoon shows, jokes and gimmicks regularly highlight black-white palship. (When Freddie Flintstone of "Flintstone Kids" takes a picture of friends with his Polarock camera, a bespectacled black buddy is featured prominently.)
Switch channels -- to reruns or what you will. On "Doogie Howser, M.D." the teen-age doctor hero is held hostage in a drugstore holdup but -- here's street life loud and bold -- he not only makes friends with the black teen-ager who's threatening him but also suggests the possibility of a hospital job. Persuaded by his new buddy, the hoodlum releases the hostages and turns himself in. On "L.A. Law" a young black lawyer whose mother opposes his love affair with a white woman explains, "Mom, the reason I love her is that inside she's just like you."
Jessica, a black lawyer on the CBS soap "As the World Turns," marries white, debonair Duncan. On the talk show "Later," Camille Paglia compares herself to Anita Hill. At all hours of the day and night a black woman and a white woman (Dionne Warwick and Linda Georgian) converse companionably on the Preview channel, talking up the Psychic Friends Network. Black and white buddy stars -- Billy Crystal, Robin Williams and Whoopi Goldberg -- are co-hosts for HBO's annual "Comic Relief" telethon. HBO's "Dream On" chronicles the black-white friendship of Martin Tupper (Brian Benben) and Eddie Charles (Dorien Wilson).
Commercial content matches program content. Tonight's good-buddy blacks and whites discuss, in pairs, the virtues of products ranging from Cadillacs to Tylenol. (The black half of each pair usually explains the superiority of the product.) Yesteryear's memorable pitchmen-sidekicks included Kareem Abdul-Jabbar and Larry Bird, who chummily chaffed each other while explaining the virtues of Lay's potato chips. The old cronies exited together, a makeup cap on Larry's head redoing them into interchangeable, dome-headed twins.
Round the clock, ceaselessly, the elements of this orthodoxy of sameness are grouped and regrouped, helping to root an unspoken but felt understanding throughout white America: race problems belong to the passing moment. Race problems do not involve group interests and conflicts developed over centuries. Race problems are being smoothed into nothingness, gradually, inexorably, by good will, affection, points of light.
RACE-DELETING THEMES IN the movies are uncommonly various. At times -- see "Pulp Fiction" -- interracial sameness emerges in contexts of violence and amorality. At times the good news is delivered through happy faces, loving gestures, memorable one-liners. Tom Hanks as Forrest Gump loses his beloved best buddy, a black soldier (Mykelti Williamson), in combat and thereafter devotes years to honoring a pledge made to the departed. In "Driving Miss Daisy," rich Jessica Tandy turns to Morgan Freeman, her poor black chauffeur, and declares touchingly, "You're my best friend, Hoke."
At times, scene and action hammer home the message of interracial sameness; mass audiences see individuals of different colors behaving identically, sometimes looking alike, almost invariably discovering, through one-on-one encounter, that they need or delight in, or love, each other.
Danny Glover sits on the toilet in "Lethal Weapon," trousers around ankles, unaware of a bomb ticking below him; Danny's white buddy, Mel Gibson, breezily at home in Danny's house, saves his life by sweeping him from the throne to the tub. Minor and major films show well-off white grown-ups unhesitatingly helping young blacks. In "Dangerous Minds," Michelle Pfeiffer selflessly teaches black youngsters, using Bob Dylan songs to hook them on poetry. "Philadelphia" plumbs the friendship of two lawyers -- white, AIDS-afflicted Tom Hanks and black, spiky Denzel Washington. (Joanne Woodward as Hanks's mother underlines the black-white sameness theme: "I didn't raise my children," she says angrily, "to ride in the back of the bus.")
A monograph on the history of race-sameness themes in movies would reach back to breakthrough works like "The Defiant Ones," "Brian's Song" "Guess Who's Coming to Dinner" and "Hurry Sundown." A hint of the quantity of relevant "product" can be gleaned from an almost random list of recent films -- television and junk action movies mingling with more pretentious work -- that treat friendship themes for part or the whole of their length. They range from "The Shawshank Redemption" to "Fried Green Tomatoes," from "Sister Act" to "Platoon," from "Die Hard With a Vengeance" to "Angels in the Outfield," from "Clockers' to "Clueless" to "Smoke" to "Money Train"
Nor is it the case that black-white sameness is a staple only of the more mindless entertainment and sales pitches. Admittedly the most vulgar dramatizations of the theme turn up on dirty-talk shows: Rolonda, Ricki and their peers encouraging utterly undifferentiated whites and blacks to wallow in aberrationist muck. And it's true, too, that the grubby opportunism of the theme is least well-disguised in the Wal-Mart fliers that jam rural and suburban mailboxes, pairing, on every page, black and white models who glow in each other's company.
But friendship and sameness themes actually respect no class or "intellectual" border, appearing often in the work of PBS essayists and longtime liberal heroes. Studs Terkel opens his book "Race" by recommending a program of "affirmative civility," meaning, efforts by whites to reach out with genial evening greetings when passing blacks on city sidewalks. Discussing his son's warm friendships with blacks, Roger Rosenblatt declares, "Our proper hearts tell the truth, which is that we are all in the same boat, rich and poor, black and white."
The most intricate exploration of friendship orthodoxy that I've seen occurs at the highest level of sitcom sophistication, "The Larry Sanders Show." The show regularly presents a black-white relationship -- between Larry (Garry Shandling) and Beverly (Penny Johnson), his black assistant -- that's grainy, unsentimental and relatively free of the maudlin squishiness endemic in pop interracial narratives. In one segment it even dared to confront precisely the question that most black-white friendship tales labor to bury: do race problems require structural solutions, or can they be worked out through one-on-one personal relations?
This affirmative-action segment of "The Larry Sanders Show" details the rupture and later repair of the relationship between Larry and Beverly. The cause of the rupture is a dispute about hiring. Beverly, convinced that the show's production staff and guest lists are "too white," campaigns to force Larry to hire her cousin, Clyde, as propman. She argues her case in structural terms: Clyde lacks experience, but for him as for other blacks, inexperience is a result of racist exclusion. How can he or any black get and keep a decent job if denied a chance to learn?
Narcissistic, whim-ridden, detached from everything but his own ego, the star is unmoved. He offhandedly mouths the usual slogans about hiring on a personal basis, in accordance with qualifications -- and tells Beverly to lace his shoes. Infuriated, taunted by Clyde as Larry's slave, Beverly quits, whereupon Larry capitulates not long after and hires Clyde. The reason, of course, isn't that he has seen the affirmative-action light but that he can't survive without the personal service Beverly has hitherto uncomplainingly and inventively rendered.
Now comes reversal. Back on the job, Beverly discovers that cousin Clyde, the affirmative-action propman, is a drag. He talks too much, has no feeling for the rhythms of other people's work, runs on about the techniques of transforming Barbie dolls into miniature dinosaurs when Beverly's in the midst of errands and telephoning.
What's happening, subtly but devastatingly, is that this black woman campaigning for affirmative action is being swiftly drawn to the side of the anti-affirmative-action party. She has fought her boss hard, meaning to push him out of self-absorption into a world of serious issues and conflicts. But before the end of the show, she gives up. She admits, that is, that Larry Sanders is right, that race relations, like everything else, are personal, matters of individual likes and dislikes.
Wit, knowingness and skepticism all figure in the episode. Viewers are allowed to hear arguments for structural remedies and against the claim that race problems are purely personal. But the weight of the show is, finally, straight Doogie Howser; we learn that those arguments are totally wrong. Beverly, tormented: "Is there any way we can get rid of Clyde?" Larry, grinning in satisfaction (live with it, hon; you got what you wanted): "No."
Black and white together -- against blacks. Roll promo.
Why has white America bought so enthusiastically into race-friendship, race-sameness orthodoxy? The problem is complex; spelling out possibly adequate answers has taken this writer an entire book, "The Trouble With Friendship."
THE COUNTRY IS WEDDED TO an egalitarian, individualistic, can-do, making-it mythology, the American Dream, that's meant to leave nobody out. The country is keen on historical romance, impatient with historical fact, weak on the realities that uniquely characterize the African-American past. Pop versions of history ("Roots," Ken Burns's "Civil War," movies like "Mississippi Burning") are therefore at liberty either to delete the experience of separateness altogether or to transform slavery and the civil rights movement into periods of happy black-white collaboration.
Neoconservatives are troublingly eager to exaggerate the size and rate of expansion of "the new black middle class," and liberals are astonishingly tolerant of politically calculated exploitation of friendship dogmas. President Clinton is among those who have found that trumpeting black-white amity as a "solution" is a convenient and economical way of dramatizing one's "concern"; it wins praise for sensitivity. No need to confront the hard truth that a caste society attempting erratically to dismantle its caste structures can't expect to get the job done without making commitments to developmental assistance on an order this country has never imagined.
Beyond these explanations of white receptiveness to sameness-and-sympathy dogma stands the complicating truth that friendship ideas do, after all, represent a step forward from yesterday's race-viciousness. Combined with an intelligent address to the problems of non-middle-class blacks, the friendship faith could move us toward a positive interracial future. Some sameness themes radiate real moral energy and carry an inspiring, even lyric charge. You can hear the promise ring out in black-white duets -- Aretha Franklin and George Michael, or Conway Twitty and Brook Benton sharing choruses of "A Rainy Night in Georgia" -- or in the Garth Brooks song about learning to ignore "the color of skin" and looking for "the beauty within."
But if there's some decency as well as vast nonsense in the ideology of sameness from which, for a week or two last fall, white America seemed almost to awaken, there's also fearful obliviousness. What whites need to do is stop being amazed at their own obliviousness and start being repelled by it -- and by the opinion engineers whose difference-abolishing pap still plays cover-up with cruel, hope-erasing race matters as they are.

CORRECTION-DATE: January 21, 1996, Sunday

 CORRECTION:
An article on Jan. 7 about television's and films' portrayal of racial relationships misidentified the performer who sang a duet of "A Rainy Night in Georgia" with Conway Twitty on "Rhythm, Country and Blues," a 1994 PBS special. He was Sam Moore, not Brook Benton. Mr. Benton, who recorded the song in 1970 and made it a hit, died in 1988. The article and a caption also misstated the role played by Julius Carry 3d on "Murphy Brown." As Mitchell Baldwin, he played a television network executive, not a station manager.

SECTION: Section 4A; Page 25; Column 1; Education Life Supplement 

LENGTH: 2116 words

HEADLINE: TEACHING TEACHERS;
Getting Minority Students Turned On to Teaching

BYLINE: By MICHELE N-K COLLISION; Michele N-K Collison is a freelance writer who lives in Washington.

 BODY:
Jessica Benitez Elliott almost didn't become a teacher. All her life she had heard the adage, "Those who can, do. Those who can't, teach." So Ms. Elliott pursued, albeit miserably, a career as a psychologist. Then in 1994, while completing her master's in psychology at Johns Hopkins University in Baltimore, she spotted a flier offering paid teaching internships for minority students.
 That's how Ms. Elliott's career took a detour and why, on a Friday afternoon, she was trasforming a second grade classroom at the private Park School of Baltimore into a bazaar of Hispanic culture. Hispanic art and storybooks were diplayed along with magazines featuring Hispanic productsandmodels. Students tasted mango nectar and galleta cookies (similar to shortbread), popular in Puerto Rico, where Ms. Elliott grew up.
 "These children will probably be future leaders," she said. "And they have to realize today's economy is a global economy, and it's important not to be ignorant about other people's culture."
 Ms. Elliott, 24, is one of 135 minority interns teaching in 110 independent and 25 public schools this year as part of the Multicultural Alliance, an organization that works to promote teaching as a career to minority students at the undergraduate and graduate levels.
 In 1990, minority children made up 31 percent of the nation's public school students; that number is projected to increase to 35.8 percent by the end of the century. Meanwhile, only 13 percent (including 7 percent African-American and 4 percent Hispanic) of the 2.5 million public school teachers are minorities, according to the Washington-based American Association of Colleges for Teacher Education. Minority students make up 22 percent of the nation's 4.8 million students in both parochial and independent schools, reports the United States Department of Education. About 8 percent of the 340,000 private school teachers are minorities (including 3 percentAfrican-American and 3 percent Hispanic).
 "There really is a national crisis," said Kevin Franklin, a director of the Urban Institute at San Franscisco State University and creator of the Multicultural Alliance. "There just aren't enough students of color becoming teachers at a time when we need them most."
 Although the Alliance's interns can get their teaching experience at public or independent schools, it is the independent schools that are likely to be the greatest future users of the program, said Kathleen Harris, the Alliance's mid-Atlantic director.
 "Independent schools have the money to hire the teachers, provide professional development," she said.
 Mr. Franklin began the Multicultural Alliance in 1990 after administrators at Bay Area independent shcools complained to him about unable to find minority teachers.
 His premise was simple: lure more minority students into teaching by providing internships at an attractive salary with plenty of professional support from experienced teachers and the Multicultural Alliance's partner schools and universities. He believes his interns become hooked once they step into the classroom and realize the influence they can have on the lives of their students. And he wants to ensure that this influence comes from the best teachers.
 Mary Dillworth, senior director for research at the American Association of Colleges for Teacher Education, echoed this sentiment, "The role model argument is not an effective argument" for bringing more teachers of color into schools. "While it is fine to talk about role models, we need qualified role models," she said.
 Although some industry observers believe that many minority communities once considered teaching a desirable profession, it haslost status over time.
"Students have had an increase in options," said Joseph Aguerrebere, a program officer at the Ford Foundation, who heads the agency's Minority Teacher Initiative. Also, he said, many states have changed the standards for teaching licenses and many other more lucrative careers have begun to compete for the same students.
 Ms. Elliott remembers her own days of scoffing at teaching.
 We thought those were the people who couldn't make it in the real world,"she said.
 So far, 95 percent of the Multicultural Alliace's 222 graduates have gone on to become teachers or administrators in public schools or universities: 30 percent in public schools, 70 percent in private schools. Mr. Franklin said only two students a year on average who begin a teaching internship do not complete the program. From the organization's base in California, the Alliance has quickly expanded into the Midwest, South and Northeast. And Mr. Franklin recently hired a director to coordinateinternships in New England.
 The Alliance interns must be at least college juniors in good academic standing. Alliance staff members and representatives at schools interview prospective interns. Once they are hired, the interns are paid a minimum of $16,500 by an Alliance partner school for full-time work, and they earn an academic scholarship of at least $1,000 each year. Interns who teach part-time are paid a minimum of $10,000. Many of the Alliance's partner institutions, like Brown University in Providence, R.I., and Chapman College in Orange, Calif., offer full or partial scholarships to allow interns to earn their master's degrees in education or teacher certifications.
Roselyn Reyes, also an Alliance intern, is teaching in a Los Angeles public school as part of the district's alternative certification program. As a full-time teacher at Carpenter Avenue Elementary School, she receives a full teacher's salary and benefits while attending classes provided by the district to earn her teacher's certificate free of charge.
"It's a great, great deal," Ms. Reyes said.
After a week of orientation in August, during which students cover such topics as lesson planning and classroom management, each student is paired with a teacher. That teacher serves as a mentor, while the intern helps out in his or her classroom throughout the year. At the beginning of the school year, most interns spend time learning different teaching styles by observing veteran teachers. Other interns, particularly those with foreign language skills, may begin teaching right away.
By the end of the year, the interns take on more teaching duties. The interns also attend professional development seminars on topics like evaluating lesson plans and conducting parent-teacher conferences.
So far, the private schools in which the Alliance has placed interns belong to the National Association of Independent Schools. Of the 415,000 students attending those schools, 16 percent are minorities.
The average starting salary for a teacher at a school belonging to the National Association of Independent Schools is $21,000.
"Independent schools are based on networks, which, for a long time, minorities weren't part of," said Karan Merry, head of the Chestnut Hill School, a private elementary school in Chestnut Hill, Mass. Ms. Merry is one of the few African-Americans to head a predominantly white independent school. "But as more people of color become teachers," she added, "they can become administrators, then heads of schools and members of the board. It's a beginning, but it has the potential to transform our schools."
David Jackson, headmaster of the Park School of Baltimore, said, "Children will fall back on stereotypes in the absence of real people." Park has 10 minority teachers and administrators -- including Ms. Elliott and another Alliance intern -- out of a total staff of 98. Of Park's 818 students, 95 are minorities.
The Alliance's efforts have brought mostly praise. Indeed, many educators credit Mr. Franklin, with his engaging manner and bulging Rolodex, with the program's success. He travels to preach nationwide about the importance of a diverse teaching force and has attracted support from corporations and foundations like Philip Morris; Oracle, a software corporation, and the W. K. Kellogg Foundation.
"The program is a good way to immerse students in a school," said Ted Sizer, chairman of the Coalition for Essential Schools, whohas two Alliance interns as teaching assistants at Brown University. "They're not stumbling around taking theoretical courses in a university. They are with real kids in a classroom. The courses make sense when the students are with real kids."
Randolph Carter, director of
the office of diversity and multicultural services at the National Association of Independent Schools, cautioned that "it isn't adequate for schools to rely only on the strategy of hiring entry-level people." Public and private schools, he said, need innovative programs to attract more seasoned minority teachers to their classrooms.
"We need teachers who are master teachers, who can transform the curriculum and the way we teach our children," he said.
"An intern can't go to a headmaster and say, 'these programs aren't working,' " he added. "But a seasoned teacher can go to that same headmaster and say, 'I've been teaching for 13 years and I think we should change this program or incorporate these programs in our curriculum.' "
Interns, however, say that the opportunity to combine theory and practical experience has made teaching more palatable.
"You can really find out what you want to do," said Kimberly Burt, 24, who teaches kindergarten and first grade at Sidwell Friends School, the private school that Chelsea Clinton attends in Washington.
Ms. Burt, who is studying for her master's degree in early childhood education at Howard University, said now she feels that her best career choices will be in private schools. seemed redundant."Here you can do what you're supposed to do -- teach."
Spenser Tolliver, 25, a Morehouse College graduate, turned down a prestigious White House fellowship to become an Alliance intern. Today Mr. Tolliver is teaching history as an intern at the Branson School, a private school in Ross, Calif. In doing so, he said, he feels he will be able "to educate, to break down barriers and debunk myths."
Yet as much as they value their teaching experiences, some interns wonder if they really should be teaching in independent schools, where there are relatively few minority children.
"I questioned whether I was going to have an impact on other students," said Alton Nelson, 28, an Alliance graduate who also teaches history at the Branson School. "I feel the kids of color at independent schools need our presence. I'm the first black male teacher the school ever had. I changed the complexion of the school."
Chris Chatmon is an intern who felt compelled to return to his own community.
After earning his master's degree in education from Brown University, Mr. Chatmon began teaching at Thurgood Marshall Academic High School, a new predominantly black and Hispanic public school in San Francisco.
"There's an incredible need for black male teachers," Mr. Chatmon said. "This community brought me up and gave me what I needed. It was time for me to give some of that back."
Their teaching experiences aren't perfect, particularly at independent schools, the interns said. Sometimes it is difficult being one of a few minority teachers. In addition, they tend to serve as unofficial counselors to all the minority students in their schools.And, many said, it can be wearing to play the "resident multicultural expert."
But for many, the benefits outweigh the negatives.
"It's not like it's the 'in vogue' thing to do this year," said Angela McFarland, who helps teach kindergarten at the private Lexington School in Kentucky. "I don't think it's just lip service when they say diversity is important. The staff sits down and talks to me. They talk about things they want to integrate into the curriculum."
Tanya Patton, a student at Harris Stowe State College in St. Louis, is teaching at the independent Community School there. She points out that she has been able to spend time discussing how to teach students with different learning styles.
At the Park School, if Ms. Elliott needed any evidence that her cultural lessons were paying off, she got it on a field trip this fall. The class was visiting the Baltimore Museum of Art to see a Matisse exhibit. Suddenly, one of Ms. Elliott's students came charging through the museum, followed by guards who couldn't understand why he was making such a ruckus.
"Ms. Elliott! Ms. Elliott!" he yelled. "I saw a painting by that P. guy," he said, referring to Picasso. "There are Hispanic people in this museum. I remember it from the art book I saw last week."
Ms. Elliott smiles at the memory and said, "I really think they're getting it."

SECTION: Section 4A; Page 51; Column 1; Education Life Supplement

HEADLINE: QUIZ

BYLINE: By LINDA AMSTER 

 BODY:
After a century, many of the events of 1896 still influence us, as do people who were born or died that year. How many of the following can you identify?
 
1. An Italian inventor who failed the entrance exam at the University of Bologna received a British patent for his wireless telegraph. Who was he?
 
2. Strike up the band in celebration of two famous marches that made their debut -- one written in Dixieland style, the other a patriotic work that includes a prominent piccolo part. Name these marches.
 
3.At the Democratic National Convention, a famous orator's fierty speech in favor of silver-backed currency won him the party's Presidential nomination. (He lost the general election to William McKinley.) Who was he and by what name is his famous speech known?
 
4. The 45th state was admitted to the Union -- after it renounced polygamy. What state is it?
 
5. The public got its first taste of two new treats that we still enjoy: One was Cracker Jacks, the other a chewy candy introduced by Leo Hirschfield, who used the nickname of his daughter, Clara to label the confection. What was Clara's nickname?
 
6. George Washington Carver (below) joined the faculty of the Tuskegee Institute in Alabama. Best known for boosting the South's economy with peanut cultivation, he left another agricultural legacy: a planting system still used by farmers today to retard soil depletion and control pests. What is the method called?
 
7. Fortune seekers swarmed to northwestern Canada, where three prospectors had discovered gold at the juncture of Bonanza Creek and a river that gave the "gold-rush" its name. What river is it?
 
8. After 1,500 years, the Olympic Games were reborn. What city was host to the first modern Olympics?
 
9. In Plessy v. Ferguson, the Supreme Court upheld a Louisiana law that required black passengers to travel separately from whites. The case established the famous "separate but equal" doctrine that dominated the civil rights arena for the following half-century. What was the 1954 Supreme Court case that finally overturned this doctrine?
 
10. Nathan Birnbaum, who was born on Jan. 20, later became famous as a wisecracking half of a comedy team. What is his stage name?

HEADLINE: TEACHING TEACHERS;
Teach for America: Learning the Hard Way

BYLINE: By RACHEL SHTEIR; Rachel Shteir is a freelance writer based in New York

 BODY:
Five years after Teach for America began sending recent college graduates to some of the poorest urban and rural schools, the organization finds itself still trying to handle its growing pains with grace.
 Teach for America, which sprang from the 1989 senior thesis that its founder, Wendy Kopp, wrote at Princeton University, has placed 3,000 teachers and gained both praise and strong criticism for its methods. Every year, after training 500 recruits -- many of them graduates of Ivy League colleges -- for five weeks, the program assigns them to two-year teaching posts in areas as varied as New York City, the Mississippi Delta and South Central Los Angeles.
 
Patterned after the Peace Corps, Teach for America has been hard hit by what its director of development, Richard Barth, calls a "belt-tightening crisis." In 1995 the recruiting staff was slashed from seven to two. (Overall, the organization employs about 80 people.) To maintain one of the program's essential components -- the on-site mentors who help new recruits get adjusted to teaching -- Teach for America has begun to seek out partnerships with local universities and community colleges, as well as to rely more heavily on alumni to contribute time and expertise.
 "We're stepping back from trying to take on all to the responsibility ourselves," explained Ms. Kopp, 28, as she sat in her organization's headquarters in New York City's financial district.
 In addition, Teach for America is struggling to rebut its critics.
 In May, responding to several recent studies by educational groups criticizing its teacher training program. Teach for America released a report it had commissioned. According to the report, the majority of superintendents are happy with the teachers' work. "In some areas we come out looking good," Ms. Kopp said.
 Sharon Mitchell, the placement coordinator in the Unified School District of Oakland, Calif., said: "They're climate changers. They think out of the box."
 Teach for America is part of a larger trend that has emerged since the early 1980's, when states began to offer alternative licensing or certification programs for teachers. Such programs allow liberal arts graduates and others without education degrees to work as teachers in areas where there are teacher shortages. Most often these schools are found in poor districts. According to data collected by the National Center for Education Information in Washington, 40 states now offer such programs, up from 33 in 1990.
 "If the school district provides adequate mentoring and support," said Pat Dingsdale, the education committee chairwoman for the National Parent-Teacher Association, in Chicago, "any alternate certification program can work."
 Yet many of Teach for America's critics argue that such support is not forthcoming. In 1991 Melissa McDonald graduated from Tufts University with a degree in American history. She then spent a turbulent nine weeks in a New Orleans school she described as "a trash can" before reluctantly leaving Teach for America. She is now a manager at the Nature Company in Boston.
 "I had 10-year-olds who had failed second grade three times," said Ms. McDonald. She blames Teach for America for her quick departure because it placed her in the school and failed to give her support.
 "The corps members who finished their two-year commitments had strong mentors -- and their schools wanted them there," she said.
 In New York City, firs-year Teach for America teachers make about $28,000, about $4,000 less than first-year teachers with master's degrees. During their two-year commitment, program participants have the option of working toward their permanent licenses.
 Supporters of Teach for America say that over the last five years the program has filled a gap in recruiting hard-to-find bilingual, special education and math and science teachers. According to the organization's statistics, the number of its teachers who finish the two-year commitment has risen from 70 percent in 1990 to 85 percent in 1993. The statistics also indicate that the organization does better than the education profession overall in recruiting minorities, who now make up 46 percent of all corps members. This figure includes 24 percent African-Americans, 8 percent Hispanics and 8 percent Asians. According to figures from the National Library of Education, 86.5 percent of all teachers nationwide are white and 7 percent are African-American, 4 percent Hispanic and 1 percent Asian.
 According to Teach for America statistics on the first group of program teachers, who finished in 1992, some 55 percent are still teaching, although 72 percent remain in education. By contrast, only 7 percent of teachers with master's degrees nationwide have dropped out of teaching after three years.
Teach for America, however, says that in the areas where its teachers are employed, the overall turnover rate tends to be much higher, up to 50 percent. And Ms. Kopp says as much as training teachers, the program seeks to create leaders.
"I'd like people to someday talk about T.F.A. the way they talk about the Rhodes scholarship," she said.
In the summer of 1993, President Clinton approved Teach for America as part of Americorps, his national service initiative. The program now receives about 21 percent of its $5.2 million budget from Americorps, which also pays off participants' undergraduate loans and offers small grants for future education. The majority of Teach for America's money, however, still comes from corporations and individuals -- among them are the Lilly Endowment Corporation and Philip Morris.
Yet because of Teach for America's budget cutting, some of its most ambitious initiatives are being dropped, like the costly and time-consuming efforts to get states to accredit its five-week summer training program as an alternative route to teacher certification.
And two education divisions of Teach for America have left to become nonprofit companies. The two divisions are Teach, which focuses on recruiting people in other professions to become teachers, and The Learning Project, which helped design the Houston Summer Institute where Teach for America teachers are trained.
In addition, many educators in traditional graduate teacher- training programs remain skeptical about Teach for America's long-term impact.
"What Teach for America is doing would be more productive if they recruited for the long term instead of as a pit stop," said Linda Darling Hammond, a professor of education at Teachers College at Columbia University in New York. By putting teachers into the neediest schools, she said, the program is cheating a generation of "high risk" children.
Professor Darling Hammond also accused the program of taking jobs away from teachers who are more qualified.
"Districts can only legally hire us if they have a shortage," Wendy Kopp responded.
But last year in Seattle, which has no teacher shortage, the Board of Education voted to hire 17 Teach for America teachers, even though Washington state certifies 2,500 teachers every year. Of these, half remain unemployed after receiving certification. "The vote was controversial," said Ted Andrews, the state's director of professional education and certification.
Most teacher educators critical of Teach for America say they do not oppose alternative certification as such, but what they characterize as the program'sslapdash approach to training.
"The summer institute is a series of one-hour workshops with no curriculum," said Robert Roth, a professor of education at the State University of California at Long Beach, who evaluated Teach for America's summer training institute in Houston for several states in 1993. "The students could choose anything they wanted in any order," he said. "In five weeks you cannot train teachers to step into the classroom. We have difficulty doing that in four years."
Teach for America, however, said the training institute's recruits teach at a summer enrichment program for students in Houston's public elementary schools. In the afternoons and evenings, according to program outlines, the trainees attend curriculum workshops. Veteran teachers and experienced corps members are asked to evaluate the performance of the new recruits on a daily basis.
"It was like educational boot camp," said Catherine Schoeffler, who got a sociology degree at the University of Southwestern Louisiana before teaching at a tiny elementary school in Ruleville, Miss.
Pam Briskman, a Teach for America recruit from Stanford University in Palo Alto, Calif., said, "I really don't think that anything can prepare you for the first day of class."
Ms. Briskman, who has taught at Bret Harte Middle School in Oakland, Calif., for three years, said she feels that the Teach for America approach is at least as effective as the traditional teacher-training education programs from which her colleagues graduated.
In New York, at P.S. 28 on West 155th Street in Harlem, Gina Laporta, an English major who graduated from Boston College in 1994, said her training was adequate, but her first year of teaching was still an enormous struggle.
"All of a sudden I was going to be responsible for 20 children who wanted to be educated."
For several months she was in shock, she said, overwhelmed by a classroom where many of the students had emotional problems for which she had no training.
She was assigned two mentors -- one from Teach for America and the other a veteran teacher at the school. But even now, Ms. Laporta does not know if she will stay a third year. "I change my mind every day," she said.
David Gunderson had a different experience.
After graduating from Yale University in 1989 with a major in political science, he wanted to teach before medical school.
But because he didn't want to spend a year getting a degree in education, he found that Teach for America presented an ideal opportunity. Mr. Gundersonspent four years teaching life science at Compton High in South Central Los Angeles.
"It's the greatest education you'll ever have," he said.
Now Mr. Gunderson intends to go back to medical school and to earn a master's degree in public health.
"In 10 years, I'd like to be living in a rural area where I can practice medicine half the time and teach the other half," he said.
For Seth Kugel, who finished his two-year stint in the South Bronx in New York last year, academic critics of Teach for America miss the point.
Mr. Kugel, who is now a first-year student at the Kennedy School of Government at Harvard University, said: "If you're a T.F.A. teacher, you don't have to worry about staying, about pension, about red tape, about getting the ideal job in the ideal school -- you don't have to worry about getting out of the South Bronx. You don't have to learn the system. If you're in T.F.A., you can just teach."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Wendy Kopp's Teach for America has put 3,000 recent college graduates into poor schools. (Andrew Lichtenstein for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: BLACKBOARD;
Stanford Gets Street Smart

BYLINE: By DEBORAH STEAD 

 BODY:
The subject was urban planning, and the professors -- for a day, anyway -- were six inner-city middle school students who recently taught a class at Stanford University.
 The three boys and three girls from San Francisco's Noth Mission neighborhood had plenty to teach the Stanford students enrolled in Prof. Milbrey McLaughlin's fall semester course on Urban Youth and Their Institutions. Last summer, the yougsters conducted a neighborhood assesment -- collecting data and making a detailed map -- and successfully lobbied the city for a new park. They did the work through a program run by St. John's Educational Thresholds, a community youth center. 
 "They did an absolutely fabulous job of mapping the neighborhood," said Professor McLaughlin, who asked the mapping team to teach a segment on neighborbood assessment in Novemberafter hearing about their work. "They just blew mystudents away."
 That didn't surprise Kyle Fiore, the youth center's director, who said the goal is "to have people realize that kids are not a problem to be solved but people who are incredibly wise about what they need."
 The young urban planners are already booked for a February lecture to be delivered to city youth workers. And Professor McLaughlin, an expert on city youth and the author of the book "Urban Sanctuaries," said that "if I teach the course again, I'll absolutely use them." D.S.

HEADLINE: TEACHING TEACHERS;
Is Experience The Best Teacher?

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME

 BODY:
Three years ago, when Cynthia Onore created a master's program at the New School for Social Research in Greenwich Village to train teachers for experimental schools, she repeatedly heard the same warning.
 "They'd say, 'Your students will never get jobs; they're the lunatic-fringe wacko people no one wants except at the most experimental schools,"' said Ms. Onore, the New School's director of teacher education. "But in fact we've had an incredible placement record, and the reason is that you call any principal anywhere and say, 'Are you trying to restructure your school?' and they all say, 'Yeah.' 
 "Everyone wants to change their schools and develop new ones, but teacher education is still training teachers for the old ones."
 Few education programs are like Ms. Onore's, which was built from scratch and has 41 students. But the calls for sweeping innovation in schools are being matched by similar rumblings in teacher training. At schools of education, which have often been criticized for providing irrelevant, textbook learning that fails to prepare teachers for the real world, alomost everything about how teachers are taught is being questioned or rethought.
 Whether the clamor is producing real change is open to question. But it has provoked wide-ranging debate on a number of issues, from how many years are enough to train teachers to whether education schools should be sidestepped altogether in favor of alternative training paths like Teach for America.
 Among the issues being debated are these:
 --Diveristy. There are widespread concerns about how to prepare an overwhelmingly white teaching corps for an increasingly minority student population, and how to recruit more members of minorities to the profession.
 --Curriculum. Educators are debating how college students' time should be divided among taking the subjects they plan to teach, learning about teaching, and being a student teacher. They also debate whether it makes sense to add a fifth year to the curriculum devoted almost solely to teaching.
 --Collaboration. There is broad support for creating partnerhsips between education schools and public schools to build so-called professional development schools, which would function the way teaching hospitals do for doctors. Only a few such schools are operating.
 --Technology. Many agree that teachers need to be better prepared to adapt to new technologies, particularly computers, but barriers -- in costs and expertise -- remain.
 What links all the issues is a problem with no easy solution: how to bridge the chasm between elementary and secondary schools that distrust university schools of education and universities that generally look down upon their own education schools as insufficiently rigorous trade schools.
 "The first and saddest thing to know about teacher education," said Michael Timpane, vice president of the Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching in Princeton, N.J., "is that it has to always face in two directions, toward the profession it is trying to assist and produce teachers for, and toward the rest of the university in which it resides. And the particular problem of teacher education is that historically it has been held in low regard by both of them."
 Teacher training is no abstract issue at a time when the student population and thus the need for teachers is on the verge of a dramatic increase. Enrollment in elementary and secondary schools is projected to rise to 56 million in 2004, from 47 million in 1991, producing more than a million new teaching jobs, according to a recent study by the American Council on Education.
 The first challenge, many say, is to address the growing mismatch between the background of teachers and the sutdents they will be teaching.
 Studies show that the typical teacher is a white, 40-year-old married mother to two children. The students in teacher-training programs are also white, female and middle-class. One recent study found that 76 percent are female and 91 percent are white, with most coming from suburban or rural backgrounds. Nearly half speak only English.
 On the other hand, about a third of the nation's school-age children belong to minority groups, and in most of the nation's urban centers the public schools are either largely or overwhelmingly minority. The minority percentage is expected to increase steadily over time.
 "I am convinced that there are large numbers of teachers who drop out of teaching after three years, not because they are incapable of teaching these children, but beause they never had the training or support in order to do it," said Jacqueline Jordan Irvine, and education professor at Emory University in Atlanta.
 In fact, a recent pool of 1,000 public school teachers by the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company found that less than half of the inner-city and other urban teachers said they were very satisfied with their careers.
 Using a grant from the United States Department of Education, Ms. Irvine has put together a program now being implemented among teachers in the Atlanta area in which they spend time not just in schools, but in homes, churches, community centers and playgrounds of inner-city neighborhoods. The goal is to educate teachers in diverse ways about the children they teach, the experiences they have and the way they learn. Such a program, Ms. Irvine said, would be an integral part of teacher education.
 But just increasing the ethnic diversity of the teaching pool, Ms. Irvine said, is not necessarily the solution. Middle-class black or Hispanic teachers can be as ill-prepared for inncer-city classrooms as middle-class whites, she said, and many of them will be entering diverse classrooms, too.
 But experts still see a critical need for increasing the pool of minority teachers. It is estimated that 85 percent of teachers are white women. Yet recruiting more minority teachers is a problem that has been compounded as other, more lucrative opportunities have opened to those who might have become teachers in the past. Although teachers' salaries rose an average of 2.7 percent during 1994-95, it was a rate just below that of inflation, which was 2.8 percent. The average teaching salary is $36,744, according to the American Federation of Teachers.
 The concern over minority hiring has led to the creation of some programs specifically designed to recruit minority teachers. Among them is the Multicultural Alliance, based in San Francisco.
 Still, even in states with the most minority teachers the gap between their numbers and those of minority students is enormous. In California, 21 percent of public school teachers belong to minority groups, compared with 53 percent of public school students. In Texas the figures are 19 percent and 48 percent, respectively; in New York, 10 percent and 34 percent.
 "This is a real time bomb," said Mr. Timpane at Carnegie. "Part of the issue is diversity training, but I think a more important issue is making the teaching force diverse, and that's a much, much tougher job."
 The concern is not just about African-Americans, who are most often cited. People of Asian or Pacific island descent make up just 1 percent of all teachers and about 1 percent of education students at a time when they are the largest ethnic group on some prestigious campuses like the University of California at Berkeley, and despite a 22 percent increase in their college enrollment rates between 1989 and 1991.
 Surveys show that low pay, lack of recruitment and a perception of teaching as insufficiently intellectual are among the reasons for their small numbers.
 Another issue regarding teacher training that is increasingly being raised is how to strike the balance between classroom learning in schools of education and actual experience in real schools.
 The issue is not new, but the changes in schools -- the multiple cultures, more pressing social needs and often more difficult students -- have made it particularly pressing.
 Traditionally, education majors have done their student teaching, usually for a semester, only at the end of their undergraduate training. The rest of their time has usually been split fairly evenly between education courses and courses in academic subject matter.
 But current education school students and recent graduates almost unanimously say that their most valuable experience was their time in the schools.
 And increasingly, education schools are moving to expand that part of their program.
 "You learn by doing," said Nicole Hart, a 25-year-old, second-year teacher at a racially diverse suburban Atlanta school district. She graduated from Emory's 15-month master's program and then went through Ms. Irvine's program. What benefited her most, she said, "was being in schools and communities and being in classes with students who were also teachers. There's nothing like trying and seeing what works or taking courses with students who've been working, who can listen to a lecture and say what really works and what means nothing when you get to the classroom."
 Ms. Onore's one-year program at the New School, for example, including the reading, is tied back to intensive experience in school classrooms at some of New York's small, experimental, public schools. The graduate training is done in a collaborative format based around small groups, called cohorts, that both study and work in schools together, so that teaching and learning are tied to group interaction.
 Ms. Onore's students spend most of their time from September to June in public schools and then finish with a summer of classroom study at the New School.
 "I didn't want to be in a college classroom; I wanted to be teaching in a school." said Margaret Holtz, one of Mrs. Onore's current students. Ms. Holtz, 44, had been a substitute teacher before entering the program in September. She added, "In this program you're in the schools right away."
 Among the greatest criticisms of education schools is that teacher training is not intellectually serious enough.
 For such critics, the greatest need is to make sure that teachers are adequately familiar with primary sources so they can be true experts in the areas they are supposed to be teaching. Some educators also emphasize tying the education courses with the more broadly academic ones, so that instead of taking separate courses in math and in pedagogy, a student might take a math course that incorporates a teaching component.
 "You can't learn what you don't understand by studying textbooks," said Edwin Delattre, who is the dean of the School of Education at Boston University. "If all you've ever done is read a textbook that refers to Ralph Ellison instead of reading Ellison, you are completely unprepared. Of the 1,300 schools of education in the country, very few can justify their existence intellectually."
 Because of such conflicting currents, there is a growing belief among educators that teacher training should be expanded from the typical four-year undergraduate program to five years. The first four would concentrate on course material and pedagogy; the last one would be steeped in intense student teaching and work in schools.
 The most conspicuous support for that structure has come from the Holmes Group, a consortium of 89 education schools nationwide studying ways to improve teacher training.
 The group is also one of the primary supporters of professional development schools.
 The idea of creating these learning alliances between universities and public schools has tremendous appeal. For schools, it could mean closer contacts with universities and up-to-date research on teaching. For universities, it could mean an opportunity to make their programs more concrete and vital. And for education students, it would be a crutial link between the classrooms in which they study and the ones in which they will teach. Some success stories thus far include collaborations between the Newark public schools and the Montclair State University and between the Camden, N.J., public schools and Rowan College in Glassboro, N.J.
 The University of Virginia in Charlottesville started with a professional development elementary school in 1989 and is adding ones for middle and high schools.
 "I believe in them." said Margo Figgs, a University of Virginia education professor. "I think they're definitely a good answer to what has been a widening chasm between people in the university training programs and people in schools."
 But the different cultures and reward structures of colleges on the one hand and elementary and secondary schools on the other have slowed progress. Universities still reward publishing over teaching, for example, which makes faculty members less inclined to favor approaches that emphasize experience. Elementary and secondary schools often see university programs as ivory-tower enclaves removed from the real world. Universities, explicitly or not, often give out signals that they see themselves as more lofty places than mere public schools.
 To deal with another pressing issue -- increasing the scientific and technological literacy of prospective teachers -- the City University of New York received a $5 million, five-year National Science Foundation grant. It will help prepare students to become better elementary and high school science and mathematics teachers and broaden the pool of students who elect a math or science teaching career.
 "In teacher training programs, there has been too much emphasis on teaching about teaching math and science and not enough math and science itself," said Richard Freeland, vice chancellor for academic affairs at the City University of New York. "We want to recenter teacher education programs for math and science on the actual scientific substance."
 And there is widespread agreement that teacher training remains well behind the curve when it comes to new technologies.
 An exception is the University of Texas at Austin, where the college of education sponsors a technology center with 500 computer work stations and has enough staff to make sure students are trained properly in using them. More common, however, are programs with far more modest resources and a single required course in computer literacy.
 "Unfortunately, most teachers leaving colleges of education are not as well prepared as they could be," said Paul Resta, a professor of instructional technology at the Unviersity of Texas. "In fact, the colleges of education often have less access to technology than the public schools do."
 With all the pressures for new approaches, many of the answers may have to come from outside schools of education. Advocates of so-called alternative certification say that the way to attract more members of minority groups or more technologically literate people may be through programs meant for recent college graduates or professionals from other fields. They would be sent to schools with very little orientation but with the expectation that they would take education courses while they teach.
 The best-known example may be Teach for America, the program modeled after the Peace Corps, which coincidentally has its own teaching program. At least 40 states have adopted some form of abbreviated study leading to a teaching certificate.
 These programs vary enormously in the degree of supervision and preparation teachers get, but increasingly they include training in pedagogy or close supervision by master teachers in conjunction with classroom teaching.
 "The idea is not to just throw peole into the fire; that's really the exception not the rule," said Morgan Appel, who recently prepared a study of alternative certification for the Tomas Rivera Center, of Claremont, Calif., which specializes in policy issues affecting Hispanic people. "The training might be accelerated, but often there's training in pedagogy at night, a lot done in conjuntion with both school districts and universities. It's not really a baptism by fire in most cases."
 Still, many experts doubt that alternative certification, which now produces about 45,000 of the 300,000 new teachers trained each year, will ever produce more than a sizeable fraction of the nation's teachers.
 "This is the largest single profession in the country," said Mr. Timpane of the Carnegie Foundation. "To say those people don't need the kind of specialized professional education we give every other important, socially valued activity in our society, I think would be disastrous. I'm not saying alternative certification can't be valuable as a piece of the puzzle. But to imagine it training the 300,000 teachers who enter classrooms each year is not going to happen, and I think, ought not to happen."

HEADLINE: New Toll Road Promises Lower Pollution

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re your Jan. 2 front-page news article "A Toll Road in California Offers a High-Tech Answer to Traffic": The environment ultimately stands to gain from California's new toll road. 
 This is so despite the fact that, as you noted, new roads typically invite new development and more traffic, which cause air pollution and loss of habitat. The new toll road in Orange County ushers in an environmentally friendly twist: peak period pricing.
Because tolls on the new road will be much higher during rush hours than at other times, and because vehicles with three or more passengers pay no toll, planners expect cars on the new road to carry an average of 1.5 people, far more than the regional average of 1.1 per car.
More people per car means fewer cars and less pollution.
The new road has opened the door for a pro-environment transportation policy.
 
MICHAEL CAMERON
Oakland, Calif., Jan. 4, 1996
 
The writer is an economist for the Environmental Defense Fund.

HEADLINE: BATTLE OVER THE BUDGET: THE OVERVIEW;
A Chilly G.O.P. Response To Clinton's Budget Plan

BYLINE: By JERRY GRAY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 7

 BODY:
After President Clinton yielded to Republican demands and submitted a plan late Saturday to balance the Federal budget in seven years, the Republican response today was as chilly as the weather.
The Government, meanwhile, was allowed to resume full operations after the longest shutdown in its history. 
 President Clinton's budget was certified as balanced by the Congressional Budget Office.
That was a condition Congressional leaders had set for allowing the full Federal Government to resume operations for about three weeks, and on Saturday the President signed legislation authorizing an end to the longest Government shutdown in history.
But for the nation's capital, which bore the brunt of the 21-day shutdown of parts of the Government, the huge snowstorm disrupted Federal employees' return to work on Monday. Federal offices here will be closed.
The snowstorm began on Saturday night, as President Clinton was meeting at the White House with the leaders of the Republican majority in Congress -- Speaker Newt Gingrich and Senator Bob Dole, -- to try to reach an agreement on a plan to balance the Federal budget by 2002.
Mr. Clinton opened that meeting by telling the Republicans that at their urging he had prepared his own seven-year plan.
Today, Republicans said that plan did not cut, or do, nearly enough.
"It shows us that Bill Clinton is the big-spending liberal Democrat we always thought he was," Representative John A. Boehner of Ohio, the chairman of the House Republican Conference, said on the CBS News program "Face the Nation." "It doesn't save the solvency of Medicare, it doesn't make the changes in it that will give Medicare recipients the choices they want. It continues welfare as we know it -- there's no real welfare reform."
Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin said today that the Federal Government would face another fiscal problem about a month from now because of the Republicans' refusal to pass legislation to raise the debt ceiling.
"We originally thought that the early part of February would be a problem," Mr. Rubin said on the NBC News program "Meet the Press." "But because of the unexpected increase in revenues to the Federal Government we are now O.K. until the middle of February. In the middle of February we will have a requirement again for additional resources."
Mr. Rubin sidestepped problems earlier in the budget crisis by postponing interest payments to some Federal pension funds and tapping into others for loans to keep the Government's credit line open.
His strategies angered Congressional Republicans, some of whom have asked that he be impeached.
Mr. Rubin said today that the Administration had yet to find another stopgap method to get around next month's anticipated problems.
"What the Congress should do is to not shut down the Government and pass a clean debt ceiling increase," the Treasury Secretary said.
On Saturday, the President signed a separate bill that provided money for certain Federal agencies and programs, chosen by the Republicans, to stay open through September, the end of the Federal budget year.
He also signed legislation that will allow all 285,000 furloughed Federal employees to return to work and restore money for all Government operations through Jan. 26. For most departments whose appropriations bills have not been approved, financing would only be 75 percent.
Unless the Democrats and Republicans can strike a budget deal in the next two weeks the Government would face the prospect of another partial shutdown on Jan. 27.
The Administration's budget plan is a modification of one put forth weeks ago by Senator Tom Daschle, the minority leader, and other Democrats, which was rejected by the Republican-controlled Senate.
According to the analysis by the Congressional Budget Office, the President's plan would save $602 billion over seven years, as compared with the $664 billion savings in the Republican budget plan that Congress approved in November and Mr. Clinton vetoed.
The major differences are on Medicare ($102 billion in savings in the Administration plan, $201 billion with the Republicans), Medicaid (the Administration proposing $52 billion in savings, the Republicans $117 billion), and tax cuts (Mr. Clinton set the target at $87 billion, but said he was willing to give up to $147 billion if the economy performs as well as he expects it will. Republicans want a $241 billion tax cut over the seven years.)
"This plan will show that you can balance the budget in seven years and protect Medicare, Medicaid, education and the environment, and provide tax relief to working families," Mr. Clinton said Saturday night during a news conference in the Oval Office. "This is a time of great national promise. We need to find unity and common ground."
The Associated Press reported Mr. Gingrich gave the the President a sharp response to the budget plan at the White House meeting.
One of the Republicans who was there quoted Mr. Gingrich as saying: "If this is where you are, we're so far apart we better start thinking about how we can call this off."
A White House spokeswoman said that the Saturday night session ended bout 11 P.M. with both sides "exchanging ideas" about each other's budget.
Because of the snowstorm, Democrats and Republicans canceled a meeting at the White House today to discuss the budget.
The weather also forced Democrats to drop plans to gather in the Oval Office with the President this afternoon to decide their next move in the budget negotiations.
Both the storm and the Republicans' attacks on the White House budget plan were unrelenting today.
"We're very concerned about whether or not there's two snow jobs going on in Washington," said Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi, the majority whip, who joined Mr. Boehner on "Face the Nation."
"Now, we feel like Charlie Brown, and Lucy has got the football, and every time you think you're going to get a real budget it's jerked away from you," Mr. Lott said. "It is a positive step, I think, and we should give the President that acknowledgment," he continued. "But there are still big differences."
For the last two months, the budget debate has been dominated by the Republicans' insistence that President Clinton submit a plan that balances the budget by 2002 with figures certified by the nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office. They made that a condition under which they would agree to a full reopening of the Government. The Administration submitted four previous budget plans that were analyzed by the Office of Management and Budget, a branch of the White House directly under the President's control.
"Unfortunately after the four tries he made before -- this is his fifth one -- it's still very much an effort to protect the status quo," Mr. Lott said.

HEADLINE: Clinton's Foreign Policy: Tough Election-Year Test

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 7

 BODY:
Even in the relatively rarefied world of foreign policy, this is a presidential election year.
Secretary of State Warren Christopher, no naif at 70, says wearily, "I don't do politics," and he is sincere. But he has people to do politics for him, including the formidable Thomas Donilon, his chief of staff, who once had important roles in the presidential campaigns of Jimmy Carter and Walter Mondale. 
 "The most useful thing I could possibly do for him," Mr. Christopher said of President Clinton in an interview Friday evening, "is to keep a steady course." A comprehensive peace in the Middle East would not go down amiss, Mr. Christopher acknowledged, but it should not become an obsession to the neglect of other issues. "I have to be effective in advising the President on an issue that hasn't even arisen yet."
But other senior Clinton Administration officials in the White House and the State Department are blunter when speaking on the condition that they not be identified. They see three areas that could deeply embarrass President Clinton, who is now reveling in the strange, new and finely tailored mantle of a foreign-policy President.
Bosnia, Haiti and the Russian presidential elections in June have the potential to rip the stitches out of the President's new clothes, these officials agree.
In Bosnia, American troops are at risk and the domestic support for their role there is thin. In Haiti, American intervention has hardly produced the foundations for a democracy in a country that may yet unravel further. And in Russia, the possibility of electing a new President who is opposed to economic reform and cooperation with the West clouds one of the few early accomplishments of the Clinton foreign policy.
"The exercise of presidential leadership abroad works wonders so long as the policy succeeds," said one official who has seen other policies fail. "Look at George Bush. His popularity ratings were enormous when the Iraqi Army was on the run, but they dropped pretty quickly when Bush let Saddam Hussein get away."
The new and much-heralded display of American leadership is similarly fragile. After a period of drift, when the United States fled Somalia and turned away from the morass of Bosnia, Adminstration officials are proud that President Clinton could be convinced "to make some decisions and to exercise some needed leadership," one official said, "to the great benefit of both his Presidency and America's position abroad."
"No one talks very much any more of a 'no superpower world,' " another official said.
Mr. Clinton's new decisiveness on Bosnia and Haiti "gives the President a lot of leverage and has a big spillover effect -- everyone from Congress to Hafez Assad has to take him and the United States more seriously," the official said, referring to the Syrian President.
But the same officials admit that leadership is most benefitial when accompanied by success, and Mr. Christopher himself warned: "There are no -- or very few -- final victories in foreign policy."
These officials recognize that particularly in Bosnia -- where 20,000 American troops will be at risk in the middle of a morally muddy civil war in which peace may be just an interlude -- "the domestic consensus is as thin as ice," as one official put it.
Television images of dead American soldiers, as happened in Somalia, could easily erode that consensus in a country that wants to feel like a superpower but rarely any longer wants to pay the price, the officials say.
That is the main reason that Mr. Clinton, with the happy agreement of the Pentagon, pushed for a clear and limited American role in Bosnia that happens to end roughly the same time as the presidential election in November.
Still, Clinton officials say that the President is aware of the need for a steadfast commitment in Bosnia, especially should American soldiers die. "Bosnia isn't Somalia," one official said, implying that Mr. Clinton had learned some lessons there. "We got into Somalia so casually that the President didn't realize how committed we had become."
Michael D. McCurry, the President's spokesman, said Mr. Clinton sees his main political vulnerabilities simply: "It's force projection and putting U.S. personnel in harm's way with all the regional instability in the world."
"What he worries about most is his duties as Commander in Chief as opposed to his political duties," Mr. McCurry said. If Mr. Clinton fails at that task, "he feels he will, and should, pay a price," Mr. McCurry added. "He knows that's the political reality."
At the same time, he acknowledged that there is a political benefit to being involved "in those places we make a difference in peace." Bosnia was one such place, he said, and so were the Middle East, Northern Ireland and South Africa, the more politically beneficial spots for a Democratic President.
"One of the lessons of my three years," Mr. Christopher said, "is how essential presidential leadership is -- to be called on in essential moments in Dayton, to make calls -- and we'll be calling on him in the Middle East at critical moments. You can't do without presidential leadership."
While European diplomats here generally acknowledged the usefulness of American involvement in a messy world, especially in Bosnia, they also expressed significant worries about the depth of Mr. Clinton's commitment to stay the course.
Among America's NATO allies, who are said to be relieved at the display of American leadership and commitment, there is little support for the American idea of equipping and training the Bosnian army to better defend itself after the peacekeepers leave.
"The British, French and Germans think it's stupid and dangerous," one official said, though the Turks, Muslims like many of the Bosnians, seem happy enough to help.
Other areas matter but not as much, at least not politically. While Administration officials describe themselves as torn about how best to deal with China -- which has been both belligerent and overly sensitive in their view -- they do not regard China policy as a major political issue for many Americans.
Beijing's brutality on human rights and the apparent American inability to soften it create pressure in Congress and on opinion pages to deny China most-favored-nation trade status, officials acknowledged. "But we tried that road once," said one official who said he believed that Mr. Clinton stood to lose by restricting American trade with China. The Chinese leadership, nervous about its legitimacy and stability as the reign of Deng Xiaoping closes, could not afford to be seen as softening its domestic policies.
While denying that he does politics, Mr. Christopher was happy to attack, like his President, the freshmen Republicans in Congress.
"It concerns me that they want the benefits of leadership without undertaking the responsibilities of leadership," he said. "There's a disconnect between people who talk the talk of leadership, but who are not prepared to give us the tools, the resources to lead. I hope that over time, as they work through some of these issues, they'll understand that equation."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

21-Day Budget Impasse Takes a Heavy Toll
Though Congress and the White House have agreed to reopen the Federal Government temporarily, uncertainty over the budget impasse remains. And the 21-day shutdown has already taken its toll on workers, home buyers, Government contractors and businesses, from media conglomerates to tourist cabins. The Clinton Administration estimates that the shutdown slowed the economy by a quarter of a percentage point in the fourth quarter of last year. [Page 12.]
 
In the midst of the debate in Washington over balancing the budget and getting rid of the deficit, it is hard to find an economist who is alarmed about the deficit as a problem. [13.]
 
Of Sources And Their Reasons
The dismissal by Money Magazine of Dan Dorfman, its celebrated columnist, last week again raised the most vexing problem facing financial journalists: they talk to people who have a stake in what is printed about companies. The people who think about markets and know what is going on are almost always participants. And they rarely speak against their own interests. Media. [41.]
 
Software Piracy on the Rise
For the American software industry, a counterfeiter who calls himself Captain Blood, is a symbol of the sharp increase they fear in software piracy. New low-cost techniques are making it easier than ever to make and distribute unauthorized copies of valuable programs. Even as they keep worrying about the multimillion-dollar offshore counterfeiting factories that have bedeviled American software makers recently, industry executives are now bracing for a surge of on-shore counterfeiters abetted by inexpensive CD-ROM copying devices. [39.]
 
New Microsoft Goal: Improve the PC
By now, the millions of people who have purchased Windows 95 have found that Microsoft's new operating system may be an improvement, but that personal computers can still be maddeningly difficult machines to use. Not to worry. Microsoft is already working to remedy the PC's shortcomings with a program whose goal is "to turn the PC into an easy-to-use appliance." [34.]
 
Rare Cases for Court to Hear
Normally, the Supreme Court deigns to ponder copyright and patent issues about as frequently as the Jets win the Super Bowl. So when the High Court schedules arguments on two different intellectual property cases in the same day, it's either an extraordinary coincidence or a sign of the times. Teresa Riordan: Patents. [38.]
 
The copyright infringement dispute between Lotus Development and Borland International is the first case in which the Supreme Court will rule on the applicability of copyright law to computer software. [38.]
 
Merger in Office Supplies
Corporate Express and U.S. Delivery Systems, two companies in the office-supply business, announced a merger valued at $410 million. Corporate Express is a office products provider, with customers drawn from the Fortune 500 community. U.S. Delivery is a network of local same-day delivery services, also serving large corporate customers. [40.]
 
All the Good News, Once a Month
For readers who seek only upbeat news, enter The World Times, a fledgling monthly newspaper in which all news is good news, an experiment in rose-colored journalism that covers the world as if Pollyanna were its editor in chief. [41.]
 
Keeping It (Very) Simple
Brain power is the subject of a tongue-in-cheek trade campaign for Viacom's Nickelodeon cable television network. The device used in the campaign, which carries the theme "The intelligent choice for kids," is to present "Brain Twisters" that are anything but. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [44.]

A magazine for lesbians has changed its name from Deneuve because of a lawsuit by the French actress, Catherine Deneuve. The magazine's new name is Curve. [41.]
